To my big brother, Bill.

Introduction

简介

MICHAEL RADFORD’S 2004 FILM VERSION OF WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE’SThe Merchant of Veniceopens as follows: A boatload of mean-looking monks floats along a Venetian canal, holding crucifixes and chanting vile imprecations, as monks in movies are wont to do. They pass a sophisticated group of Venetians wearing funny masks with phallic noses and cavorting with half-naked floozies. The floating monks now approach a bridge crowded with red-faced religious fanatics. Egged on by the monks, the fanatics beat the red-capped Jewish “usurers” in their midst and casually chuck them into the eco-unfriendly canal below.

米歇尔·拉德福德 2004 年拍摄的威廉·莎士比亚的《威尼斯商人》的电影是这样开场的：一船面目可憎的僧侣沿着威尼斯运河漂流，他们手持十字架，嘴里念着卑鄙的咒语，就像电影中僧侣经常做的那样。僧侣们经过一群精致的威尼斯人，他们戴着带有阳具鼻子的滑稽面具，与半裸的女浮尸交欢。漂浮的僧侣们现在接近一座桥，桥上挤满了红脸的宗教狂热者。在僧侣们的怂恿下，这些狂热分子殴打了他们中间的红帽犹太 ：“高利贷者”，并随手将他们扔进了下面那并不环保的运河里。

Just another day in Christian Venice.

只不过是威尼斯基督教徒的另一天。

Be assured, this is not Venice as Shakespeare imagined it. The Bard liked his Venetian merchants and at least respected the usurer Shylock. Rather, this is Venice as Radford sees it, and his view is not at all exceptional. How these sophisticates, fanatics, and usurers would turn Christendom into the world’s freest, richest, and most enduring commercial civilization is a question Radford and most of his peers could not begin to frame, let alone answer.

请放心，这不是莎士比亚想象中的威尼斯。他喜欢他的威尼斯商人，至少尊重高利贷者夏洛克。相反，这是拉德福德眼中的威尼斯，他的观点一点也不例外。这些老谋深算者、狂热者和高利贷者如何将基督教国家变成世界上最自由、最富有、最持久的商业文明，这是拉德福德和他的大多数同行都无法开始构建的问题，更不用说回答了。

It is much remarked in the literature of credit that only Jews and Christians — of all ancient people — held usury to be sinful. Yet they also collaborated almost exclusively in the creation of the West’s extraordinary economy. Is it possible that monks and other Judeo-Christian moralists were useful, maybe even essential, to the creation of this economy? If so, then is it possible that their dismissal from the marketplace has condemned us to our current economic purgatory?

在关于信用的文献中，人们常说在所有古代人中只有犹太人和基督教徒认为高利贷是有罪的。然而，他们也几乎完全参与了西方非凡经济的创造。是否有这种可能？—— 僧侣和其他犹太教/基督教道德家对这种经济的创造实有帮助，甚至是必不可少的？如果是这样的话，那么，他们被从市场上解雇，是否有可能使我们陷入目前的经济炼狱？

These questions, one suspects, are also beyond Radford’s grasp, beyond the grasp of most economists for that matter, but they deserve to be addressed. By tracing the history of credit and debt, orusury—— as lending at interest was widely called until at least AD 1800 — we can begin to answer them.

人们怀疑，这些问题不仅超出了拉德福德的掌握范围，也超出了大多数经济学家的掌握范围，但它们值得被解决。通过追踪信贷和债务的历史，或高利贷的历史 ——高利贷至少在公元 1800 年以前，人们普遍称其为利息借贷 —— 我们可以开始回答这些问题。

For the record, the wordusurycomes rather directly from the Latinusura, which means the charging of interest on loans, any interest. As we shall see, the larger history of credit and debt is in its essence a history of man’s struggle to make sense of God’s law. Given the limits of human nature, man never quite succeeds. And yet the creative tension between pious restraint on the one hand and economic ambition on the other has made us as prosperous as we are. The struggle continues.

从在案的记录来看，usury这个词直接来自拉丁语usura，意思是 “对贷款收取利息，任何利息”。正如我们将看到的，信贷和债务的大历史在本质上是一部人类为理解上帝的法律而斗争的历史。鉴于人性的局限性，人类从未完全成功。然而，一方面是虔诚的克制，另一方面是经济上的野心，两者之间创造性的紧张关系使我们达到了现在的繁荣程度。斗争仍在继续。

oneThe Seventh Circle 第七层

BOSTON IS THE HOME OF ONE MELONIE GRIFFITHS-EVANS. WERE SHE TO DIE unrepentant, which seems likely, she might well find herself in the fourth circle of Dante’s Inferno among the prodigals. A word used less today than it ought,prodigalsimply means “given to excessive or imprudent spending.” The prodigals have long been with us. “For, as has been said,” Aristotle writes in theNicomachean Ethics, “he is liberal who spends according to his substance and on the right objects; and he who exceeds is prodigal.” 1Prodigals matter here because historically they have kept lenders in business. They still do.

一位叫作梅洛妮·格里菲特·埃文斯的女士住在波士顿。如果她死不悔改（似乎很有可能），她可能会发现自己混迹在在但丁的《地狱》中的第四层败家子之中。今天，败家子（prodigal）这个词人们用得并不多，可它实际上 原本仅仅意味着 “过度或不谨慎的消费”。长期以来，我们之中一直有一些败家子。亚里士多德在《尼科马可伦理学》中写道 ：“因为，正如人们所说的那样，花钱大手大脚的人是自由的。 根据自己的财力和正确的目标进行消费的人是自由的；而过度消费的人则是浪荡的。”。1败家子在这里很重要，因为从历史上看，没有它们放贷者就没有业务。现在仍然如此。

The ethics surrounding credit and debit — ordebt, for our purposes — find expression in the oldest written records, those of the Greeks and the Hebrews. But the real history predates that, as the Mesopotamians kept records of borrowing and lending on stone tablets. And yet even when the terms of a loan were literally “written in stone,” people sought to evade them, most typically prodigals like the aforementioned Ms. Griffiths-Evans.

关于信贷和借贷 —— 或为了我们的目的将其称为债务—— 的道德规范，我们在最古老的书面记录中找到了希腊人和希伯来人的记录。但它真正的历史其实远远早于此时，因为美索不达米亚人在石板上就已经保留了借贷的记录。然而，即使贷款条款真的 “写在石头上”，人们还是试图逃避它们，最典型的是像前面提到的格里菲斯·埃文斯女士那样的败家子。

Fortunately for Griffiths-Evans, she has the sympathetic David Koeppel ofMSN Moneyto chronicle her tale, not the judgmental Dante Alighieri. As Koeppel tells it, in 2004 Griffiths-Evans contracted to buy a $470,000 home in Boston’s Dorchester section with no down payment. She claims to have been looking for an apartment, but those that suited her fancy cost about $5,000 to $6,000 a month. At that time, the amount was more than she could afford. Landlords, after all, demand rent. Lenders can be more flexible. Ambitious beyond her means, Griffiths-Evans heeded their siren song.

对格里菲斯·埃文斯来说，幸运的是她有MSN Money的大卫·科普尔同情她。是科普尔记录了她的故事，幸亏不是那爱评头论足的但丁·阿利吉耶里。据 Koeppel 介绍，2004 年，格里菲斯·埃文斯签约购买了波士顿 Dorchester 区的一套 47 万美元的房子，并且还是在没有首付的情况下。她声称一直在寻找公寓，但那些符合她心意的公寓每月大约需要 5000 至 6000 美元。在当时，这个数额超过了她的承受能力。房东毕竟要收租金。可贷款人可以更灵活。格里菲斯·埃文斯的野心超出了她的能力范围，她听从了他们的塞壬之歌。

The first question the obliging Koeppel asks her in a recorded interview is, “Was your loan a predatory loan?” Griffiths-Evans answers without hesitation, “It definitely was.” 2To swing the deal, she took out a fairly standard 8.5 percent loan on 80 percent of the purchase price. Lacking the traditional 20 percent down payment, she took out a second loan at a whopping 12.5 percent. Her combined monthly payment ran roughly $3,500 a month to begin, increasing as the loan adjusted.

在录音采访中，富有责任感的科普尔问她的第一个问题是 ：“你的贷款是掠夺性贷款吗？” 格里菲斯·埃文斯毫不犹豫地回答 ：“绝对是。” 2为了摆平这笔交易，她以相当标准的 8.5% 的贷款购买了 80% 的购买价格。由于缺乏传统的 20% 的首付，她又以高达 12.5% 的比例进行了第二次贷款。她的综合月付款开始时大约为每月 3500 美元，随着贷款的调整而增加。

Historically, lenders would not have allowed that size of a payment for anyone making less than about $200,000 a year, presumably more than Griffiths-Evans earned as a part-time teacher. But lenders in the first years of this new century were encouraged to accommodate people like Griffiths-Evans. She got the money. Still, she claims her lender told her that she could soon refinance into a lower-cost, fixed-rate mortgage. “That is where it became predatory,” she reassures herself and Koeppel.3

从历史上看，贷款人不会允许年收入低于 20 万美元的人支付这种规模的贷款，这个金额估计高于格里菲斯·埃文斯作为兼职教师的收入。但是，在这个新世纪的头几年，贷款人被鼓励接纳像格里菲斯·埃文斯这样的人。她得到了这笔钱。不过，她声称她的贷款人告诉她，她很快就可以再融资，获得更低的成本、固定利率的抵押贷款。“这就是它变得掠夺性的地方”，她向自己和科普尔斩钉截铁地说道。3

There is nothing unique about Griffiths-Evans. A million Americans just like her have unwittingly conspired to wreck the world’s economy. Writing twenty-three centuries ago, Aristotle sniffed out their ambitions:

格里菲斯·埃文斯没有什么特别之处。有一百万个像她一样的美国人在不知不觉中合谋破坏了世界的经济。亚里士多德在 23 个世纪前的著作中就已经嗅到了他们的野心：

They become apt to take because they wish to spend and cannot do this easily; for their possessions soon run short. Thus they are forced to provide means from some other source. At the same time, because they care nothing for honor, they take recklessly and from any source.

他们更喜欢轻易伸出自己的手，因为他们想花钱，但又做不到；因为他们的财产很快就不够用了。因此，他们被迫从其他来源获取资金。同时，因为他们不在乎荣誉，所以他们不顾一切地从任何渠道索取。

What changed over time, as shall be seen, was the nation’s willingness to oblige its prodigals. To fix her innocence, Koeppel asks Griffiths-Evans no questions about her elusive husband, her income, her seeming inability to save money, her job prospects, the alleged cost of rental housing, or any potential plans she might have had to surf the rising tide of real estate prices and flip the house for a profit, plans possibly swallowed in the subprime morass.

随着时间的推移渐渐转变的，我们将看到，是国家对其败家子的认可意愿。为了给她的洗白，科普儿没有问格里菲斯·埃文斯任何关于她难以捉摸的丈夫、她的收入、她似乎没有能力存钱、她的工作前景、所谓的租房成本，之类的问题；也没有问任何她可能有的计划，比如，在房地产价格上涨的浪潮中赚取差价或者倒卖房子以获取利润 —— 实际上可能被次贷泥潭吞噬的计划。

Like most in the media, Koeppel thinks less harshly of prodigals than those who enable them. In this comprehensive article, the reader hears not a word from Griffiths-Evans’s lenders or any other lenders. They remain as faceless and generic as the Jewish moneychangers in Radford’s Venice. Koeppel gives the final word to one of the predatory lender’s presumed prey: “If you’re given fraudulent loans,” says still another bamboozled woman, “someone needs to go to jail. Someone needs to be held accountable.” 4

和大多数媒体人一样，科普尔对败家子的看法没有对那些使他们成为败家子的人那么严厉。在这篇全面的文章中，读者没有听到格里菲斯·埃文斯的贷款人或任何其他贷款人的一个字。他们仍然像拉德福德笔下威尼斯的犹太货币兑换商一样，面目全非，毫无特色。科普尔给掠夺性贷款人的一个假定的猎物说了最后一句话 ：“如果你得到了欺诈性贷款，有人要进监狱了”。另一个被愚弄的妇女说，“有人要被追究责任。” 4

Unlike Dante, Koeppel does not seem to think of prodigals as sinners, preferring instead to think of them as they think of themselves — as victims. Indeed, it could be argued that the real divide in America today is not between left and right, but between those who would sympathize with Griffiths-Evans and those who would not. The latter we will call traditionalists; the former, social puritans, shorthand for those secular moralists who confuse their local banker with the devil and Wall Street with hell.

与但丁不同，科佩尔似乎不认为败家子是罪人，而是更愿意像他们一样认为 —— 自己是受害者。事实上，可以说今天美国真正的分歧不是在左派和右派之间，而是在那些会同情格里菲斯·埃文斯的人和那些不会同情的人之间。后者我们称之为传统主义者；前者则是社会清教徒，是那些将当地银行家与魔鬼、华尔街与地狱混为一谈的世俗道德家的简称。

Koeppel has no sympathy at all for lenders and no apparent interest in their motivation. And yet as offended as he seems to be by predatory lending and lenders, Koeppel, I suspect, would scoff at the whole concept of usury and usurers. To the modernist ear, the very words sound hopelessly papist and mired in medieval superstition.

科普尔对贷款人一点都不同情，对他们的动机也没有明显的兴趣。然而，尽管他似乎被掠夺性贷款和贷款人所冒犯，但我猜想，科普尔会对整个高利贷和高利贷的概念嗤之以鼻。对现代人来说，这些词听起来是无可救药的教皇主义，并陷入了中世纪的迷信。

When social puritans survey the moral landscape, they see aggregates of predators exploiting aggregates of victims, the goodness and badness of each fixed by little more than fashion. Koeppel, for instance, titled his article “Single women slammed by housing mess.” A traditionalist might just title the article “Single women help cause housing mess” and, if feeling churlish, talk of Griffiths-Evans as a “predatory borrower.”

当社会清教徒调查道德景观时，他们看到的是掠夺者的集合体在剥削受害者的集合体，每个人的善恶就好像只是由当时的风潮决定。例如，科普尔将他的文章命名为《单身女性被住房问题困扰》。一个传统主义者可能只是把文章的标题定为《单身妇女助力造成住房混乱》，如果觉得无礼，可以把格里菲斯·埃文斯说成是 “掠夺性借款人”

。

Traditionalists like Dante and Shakespeare have a distinct artistic advantage: they believe in sin. When they survey that same moral landscape, they see a thousand different souls struggling with a thousand different demons. Nor do traditionalists attempt to exculpate sinners by downgrading their demons to disease, depression, addiction, or “circumstances beyond Melonie’s control.” Sin makes for much better drama. It might also make for a much better economy.

像但丁和莎士比亚这样的传统主义者有一个明显的艺术优势：他们相信有罪恶。当他们审视同样的道德景观时，他们看到一千个不同的灵魂在与一千个不同的魔鬼挣扎。传统主义者也不会试图通过将罪人的恶魔降格为疾病、抑郁症、成瘾或 “梅洛尼·格里菲斯·埃文斯无法控制的情况” 来为罪人开脱。罪恶使戏剧效果更好。它也可能使经济状况好得多。

Dante, in particular, was a connoisseur of sin. He could divine its subtle gradations as finely as an Eskimo could snow. Indeed, the first part of hisDivinaCommedia, “Inferno,” reads like a veritable taxonomy of sin.

尤其是但丁，他是一个罪恶的鉴赏家。他可以像爱斯基摩人对待雪一样精细地判断其微妙的层次。事实上，他的《神曲》中的第一部分，《地狱》，读起来就像一部名副其实的罪恶分类学。

Written in the first person, in vernacular Italian, almost exactly seven centuries ago, theDivine Comedyrecounts Dante’s guided tour through the three zones of the dead ——Infernoor hell,Purgatorio, andParadiso. He begins his journey on Holy Thursday of Easter Week in the year 1300 and ends the following Wednesday.

几乎在七个世纪前，《神曲》以第一人称用意大利语写成，《神曲》的叙述指引着读着穿过死亡的三个区域 —— 地狱、炼狱和天堂。他在 1300 年复活节周的圣周四开始了他的旅程，并在接下来的周三结束。

His tour guide through hell and purgatory is not a saint or even a fellow Christian, but the Roman poet Virgil. From Dante’s perspective, sin transcended the priestly imagination. It was a universal, as was salvation, which “shows the road to everyone, whatever our journey.” 5

他在地狱和炼狱中的导游不是圣人，甚至不是基督徒同伴，而是罗马诗人维吉尔。从但丁的角度来看，罪恶超越了牧师的想象力。它和救赎一样是一种普遍现象，它 “为每个人指明了道路，无论我们的旅程如何”。5

The opening of “Inferno” finds Dante in the full throes of a midlife crisis and on the verge of moral breakdown, perhaps even suicide. It is at this low moment that Virgil rescues the troubled Florentine, and the two begin their journey through hell. The condemned sinners occupy nine descending circles: the self-indulgent the first five, the violent the next two, and the treacherous the bottom eighth and ninth.

《地狱》的一开篇，但丁完全处于中年危机的边缘，处于道德崩溃的边缘，甚至可能自杀。正是在这一低谷时刻，维吉尔拯救了这位陷入困境的佛罗伦萨人，两人开始了他们的地狱之旅。被判刑的罪人占据了九个下降的圆圈：自我放纵的是前五个，暴力的是后两个，而奸诈的是最底层的第八和第九个。

The first circle is reserved for those otherwise good souls who did not know or accept Christ, including Virgil himself. In this halfway agreeable Limbo-like state, Virgil and others live out an eternity deprived of a joy they cannot even fathom.

第一层是为那些不认识或不接受基督的善良灵魂保留的，包括维吉尔本人。在这个半途而废的类似于 Limbo 的状态中，维吉尔和其他人度过了一个他们压根就琢磨不透的被剥夺了快乐的永恒。

Eternity starts getting rough in the second circle. Here, just as they were torn by their own passions in life, the lustful are torn about forever in eternal storms. In the third circle gluttons are made to wallow in a nasty slush of freezing rain and black snow.

永恒在第二层开始变得艰难。在这里，就像他们在生活中被自己的激情撕裂一样，好色之徒在永恒的风暴中被撕裂至永远。在第三层中，贪婪者被逼着在冰冷的雨水和黑色的雪水中沉沦。

The fourth circle holds the miserly and the prodigal, now condemned to ram huge massive weights into each other for eternity. In the fifth circle the wrathful slug it out on the surface of the swamplike River Styx, while the grim and sullen get waterboarded, or something much like it, below. Things literally heat up in the sixth circle, where various and sundry heretics find themselves trapped in a flaming tomb from which they cannot escape.

第四层是吝啬鬼和败家子，他们现在注定要把巨大的重物砸向对方，直到永远。在第五层，愤怒的人在像沼泽一样的冥河表面上打斗，而阴沉的人在下面被水刑，或诸如此类。在第六层，各种不同的异教徒发现自己被困在一个燃烧着的坟墓里，无法脱身，温度也越来越高。

Until this point in Dante’s narrative, the modern reader would find little to disturb his or her finely tuned sensitivities. Dante gives the heathens a break in the first circle. He comes down relatively lightly on adulterers in the second, and since the greedy, the gluttonous, and the grim are always other people or their children, the reader would not particularly sweat their fates either.

到此为止，在但丁的叙述中，现代读者尚未发现有什么能扰乱自己已然精细调整过敏感度。但丁在第一层给了异教徒一个机会。他在第二层中对通奸者的处理相对较轻，而且由于贪婪者、贪吃者和冷酷者总是其他人或他们的孩子，读者也不会特别为他们的命运捏一把汗。

It is with the seventh circle, and only in its innermost ring, that Dante begins to challenge modern presumptions. The outermost ring is the unhappy home of the murderous and tyrannical. They stew in a river of boiling blood while centaurs shoot arrows at those who would dare escape. Few today would object to this consignment. Some would like to see Congress so consigned.

正是在第七层，而且只有在最里面的一圈，但丁才开始挑战现代的假设。最外圈是杀人犯和暴君无法开心的地方。他们在沸腾的血河中煎熬，半人马向那些敢于逃跑的人射箭。今天很少有人会反对这种待遇。有些人希望看到国会被如此对待。

In the middle ring dwell the suicides, now reduced to “stumps of wood,” 6painfully sensitive to any touch, eternally plucked at by Harpies. The punishment might seem harsh to the modernist, but he would not be surprised that people once thought thusly or that many still do.

在中环居住的自杀者，现在已经沦为 “木头桩子” 6， 碰到什么都疼痛无比，一个一个被女妖哈皮儿捉走。对现代人来说，这种惩罚可能显得很严厉，但他不会对人们曾经这样想或许多人仍然这样想感到惊讶。

Condemned to the inner and most frightening ring of the seventh circle are those whose offenses run counter to “nature and her gifts” 7: the blasphemers who defy God; the sodomites who defy their own nature; and, yes, the usurers who defy the right order of things. All are condemned to a half-life in a desert of flaming sand with fire raining upon them from the sky — Bakersfield as imagined by a San Franciscan.

被罚到第七层的最里面也是可怕的地方的人，他们的罪行与 “大自然和她的礼物” 背道而驰。7亵渎者藐视上帝；鸡奸者藐视自己的本性；还有，对，高利贷者藐视事物的正确秩序。所有的人都被判处在火焰沙漠中度过半生，火从天而降 —— 就是一个圣弗朗西斯科人所想象的贝克斯菲尔德。

The sodomy he gets, but Dante has a hard time understanding why usury is sinful. “Please,” he asks Virgil, “could we retrace our path back to that place where you said usury offends celestial Goodness, and solve that knot.” 8Usury here means no more than the lending of money at interest, even at a moderate rate. Anyone today who has ever deposited money in a bank, which in turn lends that money at interest, has committed this sin as Dante understood it.

鸡奸他懂，但丁却很难理解为什么高利贷是有罪的。“拜托”，他问维吉尔，“我们能不能追溯到你说高利贷触犯天理的那个地方，解决这个难题？” 8高利贷在这里的意思不过是指以利息借出钱财，甚至是以适当的利率。今天，任何一个在银行存过钱的人，而银行又以利息借出这些钱，都犯了但丁所理解的这种罪。

To make his case, not an obvious one even then, Virgil cites several esteemed sources, both secular and Christian, to the effect that “man should thrive and gain his bread” 9either by nature or art, that is, either through working the land or working with one’s hands. The usurer, however, “takes a different way,” 10and in so doing defies God’s plan for man. That much said, and it is frankly not much to go on, Virgil ploughs ahead with his student in tow.

为了说明他的观点，即使在当时也不是一个明显的观点，维吉尔引用了几个受人尊敬的来源，包括世俗的和基督教的，大意是 “人应该茁壮成长并获得他的面包”。9无论是通过自然还是艺术，也就是说，无论是通过耕种土地还是用手劳动。然而，高利贷者 “采取了不同的方式” 10而这样做违背了上帝对人的计划。说了这么多，坦率地说没有什么可继续说的，维吉尔带着他的学生继续前进。

Only two circles remain in the pair’s descent, and they host the consciously fraudulent and treacherous. The eighth circle is subdivided into ten truly vile pits. Here suffer the pimps, the flatterers, the false prophets, the corrupt politicians, the hypocrites, the thieves, the alchemists, the counterfeiters, the perjurers, and the “fraudulent advisors” 11—— but more on Bernie Madoff later.

随后这俩人只剩下两个层继续往下走，那里承载着有意识的欺诈和奸诈的人。第八个层被细分为十个真正卑鄙的坑。在这里，皮条客、谄媚者、假先知、腐败的政客、伪君子、小偷、炼金术士、造假者、作伪证者和 “欺诈顾问” 都在受苦。11

The icy hell of the ninth circle belongs to traitors, the most notorious of whom — Brutus, Cassius, and Judas Iscariot — hang from the bloody mouth of the greatest traitor of them all, Satan. As is fairly evident, the conscious act of betrayal — of one’s friends, one’s country, one’s nature, one’s God — troubles Dante more than the everyday vices that bedevil all of mankind.

第九层的冰冷地狱属于叛徒，其中最臭名昭著的是布鲁图斯、卡西乌斯和加略人犹大，他们都被吊死在最大的叛徒撒旦的血腥嘴里。显而易见，背叛朋友、背叛国家、背叛本性、背叛上帝的有意识行为，比那些困扰全人类的日常恶习更让但丁烦恼。

Wiser for having seen the horrific fate of traitors and the other evildoers, Dante follows Virgil down and out through an opening where he sees, on this glorious predawn Easter day, a sky brightly studded with stars, “some of the beautiful things that heaven bears.” 12

由于看到了叛徒和其他恶人的可怕命运，但丁跟随维吉尔下山，并通过一个开口出去，在这个光荣的复活节前的日子里，他看到天空中明亮地镶嵌着星星，“一些只属于天堂的美好事物”。12

Dante did not write theDivine Comedyjust to sell books. He wrote it to instruct his fellow man in the remarkably structured Christian cosmos and man’s place within it. To be sure, all cultures have their gods, their cosmogonies, their system of rewards and punishments, but none have anything like medieval Christianity’s intellectual order.

但丁写《神曲》并不仅仅是为了卖书而写的。他写这本书是为了指导他的同胞了解基督教宇宙的惊人结构以及人类在其中的地位。可以肯定的是，所有的文化都有它们的神、它们的宇宙观、它们的奖惩制度，但没有一种文化有像中世纪基督教那样的智慧秩序。

Even in 1300, that sense of order, a reflection of God’s divine plan, shaped Dante’s perception of the economy. After showing Dante the squalid materialists condemned to hell’s fourth circle, Virgil instructs his pupil in the ways of Fortuna, the angelic regulator who oversees the economic sphere. God has assigned her the “invisible” role of distributing “goods of worldly splendor” 13—— not at all unlike the famed “invisible hand” that ruled Adam Smith’s eighteenth-century economy. Try as he might, man proves incapable of fully grasping how the invisible hand works, how Fortuna “foresees, judges, and rules her appointed realm." Adds Virgil, “She is cursed too often by those who ought to sing her praises.” 14Dante has come to understand that those doing the cursing have likely violated God’s good order.

即使在 1300 年，这种秩序感，对上帝的神圣计划的反映，塑造了但丁对经济的看法。在向但丁展示了那些被打入地狱第四层的肮脏的唯物主义者之后，维吉尔向他的学生传授了福尔图娜的方法，她是监督经济领域的天使监管者。上帝赋予她 “无形” 的角色，即分配 “世俗华美的货物” 13—— 就好像是那只著名的统治着亚当·斯密十八世纪经济的 “看不见的手”。尽管人类努力尝试，但事实证明他们干脆无法完全掌握这只看不见的手是如何工作的，也弄不明白福尔图纳是如何 “预见、判断和统治她指定的领域的”。维吉尔补充说，“她经常被那些应该赞美她的人诅咒。” 14但丁已经明白，那些做诅咒的人很可能已经违反了上帝的良好秩序。

Much to her misfortune, Melonie Griffiths-Evans had no Virgil in her life, no guide through Boston’s unmapped moral terrain. And that has proved costly for all.

不幸的是，梅洛妮·格里菲斯·埃文斯的生活中没有维吉尔，在波士顿未规划的道德地形中也没有向导 —— s 事实证明，这对所有人来说都是代价高昂的。

“Society cannot exist unless a controlling power upon will and appetite be placed somewhere,” said the Anglo-Irish political philosopher Edmund Burke more than two centuries ago, “and the less of it there is within, the more there is without.” 15The denouement of the Griffiths-Evans case shows just how intrusive and expensive that controlling power can be when imposed from without.

“除非在某个地方放置一个控制意志和食欲的力量，社会就不可能存在。” 英爱政治哲学家埃德蒙·伯克在两个多世纪前说，“内部的力量越少，外部的力量就越多。” 15格里菲斯·埃文斯案的结局表明，当从外部强加控制权时，这种控制权会有多大的侵扰性和代价。

If Griffiths-Evans lacked a guide, she did not lack for advocates in the streets or in the media. City Life/Vida Urbana, a Boston community activist group, organized noisy street protests to forestall two separate eviction attempts. “We’re going to take back our cities! We’re going to take back our neighborhoods! We’re going to do what’s right for families, not what’s right for bankers!” Griffiths-Evans told the fifty or so protestors at a 2008 rally, four years after she bought the house.16For all of its rhetorical bluster, her call to political action would have left Fortuna’s head spinning. It made no economic sense whatsoever. As amplified and ratified, her rallying cry has pushed Western civilization to the edge of an economic abyss.

如果说格里菲斯·埃文斯的确缺乏一个向导，但她并不缺乏在街头或媒体上的倡导者。波士顿社区活动团体 City Life/Vida Urbana 组织了嘈杂的街头抗议活动，阻止了两次单独的驱逐企图。“我们要夺回我们的城市! 我们要夺回我们的社区！我们要做对家庭有利的事情，而不是对银行家有利的事情！” 格里菲斯·埃文斯在 2008 年的一次集会上对 50 多名抗议者说 —— 那是在她买下这所房子四年后。16就其所有的修辞虚张声势而言，她对政治行动的呼吁会让福图纳头晕目眩。它没有任何经济意义。由于被放大和批准，她的号召力将西方文明推向了经济深渊的边缘。

In his benchmark bookThe Spirit of Democratic Capitalism, Michael Novak insists that to be successful, “the moral cultural system of democratic capitalism must resist hedonism and decadence with all its power, and not merely accommodate itself to fashion.” 17The moral cultural is one pillar out of three that Novak sees as sustaining the capitalist enterprise. A functioning democracy provides the other two: the freedom to take risks without undue interference, and a reliable system of laws to protect the rights of the risk takers.

在他的标杆书籍《民主资本主义的精神》中，迈克尔·诺瓦克坚持认为，要想成功，“民主资本主义的道德文化体系必须全力抵制享乐主义和颓废，而不仅仅是适应时尚。” 17道德文化是诺瓦克认为维持资本主义企业的三个支柱中的一个。一个正常运作的民主制度提供了另外两个支柱：在没有不当干预的情况下承担风险的自由，以及一个可靠的法律体系来保护风险承担者的权利。

The media covering the Griffiths-Evans saga knew little about the moral cultural history that brought them to this moment. The protestors knew less. Playing to their cameras, they embarrassed the lender into allowing Griffiths-Evans to stay in her home for three more months, presumably free of charge, while she tried to find a buyer. When she failed to find one, the lender gave her still more time to find an apartment. Through it all, this poster child for the subprime meltdown remained confident that she would not be evicted. As she confided to theBoston Globe, likely without consulting her source, “The Lord is on my side.” 18

报道格里菲斯·埃文斯传奇的媒体对把他们带到这一刻的道德文化历史知之甚少。抗议者们知道得更少。在他们的镜头下，他们让贷款人感到尴尬，得允许格里菲斯·埃文斯在她的家里再住三个月，大概是免费的，同时她还要试图找到一个买家。当她没能找到买家时，贷款人又给了她更多的时间来寻找公寓。在这一切中，这位次贷危机的典型代表仍然相信她不会被驱逐。正如她向《波士顿环球报》(Boston Globe)透露的那样 —— 可能没有确认这个消息来源 —— “上帝在我这边。” 18

twoUnto a Stranger 遇到陌生人

HIGH ON THE LIST OF HISTORICAL IRONIES IS THIS: JEWS WERE THE first people to prohibit usury and, in the pre-Christian era, the only people of consequence to do so. Hittites, Phoenicians, Egyptians, and Babylonians accepted usury as a matter of course. Future developments aside, the Jewish prohibition should not be surprising. Jews were the first people to divine a monotheistic God, one who cared deeply enough about his people to share with them a how-to guide to life.

在历史上最讽刺的列表中排在相当靠前的是这个：犹太人是第一批禁止高利贷的人，而且在前基督教时代，他们是唯一这样做的重要人物。赫梯人、腓尼基人、埃及人和巴比伦人认为高利贷是理所当然的。抛开未来的发展，犹太人的禁令不应该令人惊讶。犹太人是第一个信仰一神教的人，他们非常关心自己的人民，与他们分享生活的指南。

As chronicled in the first five books of the Old Testament, God gave this law to the Israelites through Moses. The law begins with the Ten Commandments and includes many narrower rules of observance. These Jews call the Torah, or, as translated, “the Law.” An atheist might challenge the source of the law, but he would be hard pressed to deny that it transformed human history.

正如《旧约》前五卷中所记载的那样，上帝通过摩西将这一法律交给了以色列人。这部法律以十诫开始，并包括许多下载的遵守规则。这些犹太人称之为《托拉》，或译为 “律法”。一个无神论者可能会质疑法律的来源，但他很难否认法律改变了人类历史。

By contrast, the Code of Hammurabi, developed during the eighteenth century BC, has all the inspiration and ethical punch of a set of government regulations. In this spirit, the Code treated usury as a matter of ordinary Babylonian commercial life. The relevant articles of the code, in fact, were niggling enough to have been written by an IRS lifer: “If a merchant lent grain or money at interest and when he lent [it] at interest he paid out the money by the small weight and the grain by the small measure, but when he got [it] back he got the money by the [large] weight (and) the grain by the large measure, [that merchant shall forfeit] whatever he lent.” 1Word to our political betters: enduring civilizations are not built on regulations.

相比之下，在公元前十八世纪制定的《汉谟拉比法典》具有一套政府法规的所有灵感和道德冲动。本着这种精神，该法典将高利贷视为巴比伦普通商业生活的一个问题。事实上，该法典的相关条款足以让国税局的工作人员感到不安 ：“如果一个商人借出谷物或金钱并收取利息，当他按利息借出时，他按小重量支付金钱，按小计量支付谷物，但当他拿回时，他按大重量获得金钱（并）按大计量获得谷物，应没收该商人借出的任何东西。” 1应该给我们的政治上层人士的一句话是这样的：持久的文明并非建立在法规之上。

In Mosaic law, violations had existential consequences: they offended God. Although not all of the law was transformative — “He that is wounded in the stones, or hath his privy member cut off, shall not enter into the congregation of the LORD” (Deuteronomy 23:1) comes to mind — much of it was. Like no other code before and few since, Mosaic law respected the individual and treated those under its sway more or less equally.

在摩西律法中，违规行为有存在的后果：它们冒犯了上帝。虽然不是所有的法律都是变革性的，但我想到的是「在石头上受伤的，或割掉私处的，不得进入耶和华的会堂」（申命记 23:1），它的大部分是变革性的。与之前和之后的其他法典不同，摩西律法尊重个人，并或多或少平等地对待受其支配的人。

On the usury question, however, it should be noted that when Mosaic law was codified, Jews were a largely pastoral people, living less-settled lives than their contemporaries in Mesopotamia. They did not have complex systems of trade and the understandings those systems inspire. Thus when the law turned to the question of usury, it did so in the context of neighbors dealing with neighbors, not traders dealing with customers. That much said, the codifiers consistently and unequivocally scorned usury — at least among God’s people, and there, alas, was the rub.

然而，关于高利贷问题，应该注意的是，当摩西律法被编纂时，犹太人基本上是一个牧民，比他们同时代的美索不达米亚人生活得更不安定。他们没有复杂的贸易体系和这些体系所激发的理解。因此，当法律转向高利贷问题时，它是在邻居与邻居打交道的背景下进行的，而不是商人与客户打交道。说了这么多，编纂者始终明确地蔑视高利贷，至少在上帝的子民中是如此，唉，这就是问题所在。

The first prohibitions appear in Exodus, in the second book of Moses, which likely dates back to the thirteenth century BC: “If thou lend money to any of my people that is poor by thee, thou shalt not be to him as an usurer, neither shalt thou lay upon him usury” (22:25). The Hebrew word for usury in this instance,neshek, literally means “something bitten of.”

第一个禁令出现在《出埃及记》中，在摩西的第二部书中，可能可以追溯到公元前十三世纪 ：“你若借钱给我百姓中任何贫穷的人，不可向他放高利贷，也不可向他放高利贷” （22：25）。在这个例子中，高利贷的希伯来语neshek，字面意思是 “被咬的东西”。

Calvin Elliott, who wrote the twentieth century’s most spirited defense of the usury prohibition (albeit in 1902), traces the origin of theneshekto the biting of a serpent. To make his case, he cites the research of a contemporary with the intriguing name Dr. George Bush. Bush argues that a serpent’s bite “is often so small as to be scarcely perceptible at first, yet the venom soon spreads and diffuses itself till it reaches the vitals, so the increase of usury, which at first is not perceived, at length grows so much as to devour a man’s substance.” 2This whole notion of biting and slicing and infecting will resonate throughout the history of this subject up until the present. Elliott’s take on the subject has had such sufficient staying power that his book was reprinted in 2007.

卡尔文·埃利奥特（Calvin Elliott）曾为二十世纪最激烈的高利贷禁令辩护（尽管是在 1902 年），他将neshek的起源追溯到蛇咬人的咬伤。为了证明自己的观点，他引用了一位名叫乔治·布什博士的当代人的研究 —— 这个名字很有意思（与后来的某位美国总统同名）。布什认为，蛇的咬伤 “往往很小，一开始几乎察觉不到，但毒液很快就会蔓延扩散，直到到达要害。所以高利贷的增加，一开始是察觉不到的，最后增长到吞噬一个人的物质。” 2这整个咬人、切片和感染的概念将在这个主题的历史上产生共鸣，直到现在。埃利奥特对这一主题的看法具有足够的持久力，以至于他的书在 2007 年被重新印刷。

David, the second king of the united kingdom of Israel, reigned in the neighborhood of 1000 BC. A gifted musician as well as a warrior, he is believed to have authored many of the Psalms. In Psalm 15, he shares his take on the usurer’s trade with his countrymen. “Lord,” David asks, “who shall abide in thy tabernacle? who shall dwell in thy holy hill?” (v. 1). On the short list of those who just might hope to ascend that hill is “He that putteth not out his money to usury, nor taketh reward against the innocent” (v. 5). Recited in congregation, the Psalms had the effect of bringing community pressure to bear on the shaky resolve of the individual. Given that the composer was also the king, the sing-alongs must have been lively.

大卫是以色列统一王国的第二位国王，在位时间约为公元前 1000 年。他是一位有天赋的音乐家和战士，据说他撰写了许多诗篇。在《诗篇》第 15 篇中，他与他的同胞分享了他对高利贷交易的看法。“主啊”，大卫问道，“谁能住在你的帐幕里，谁能住在你的圣山上？” (第 1 节). 有希望登上圣山的人，是一个简短的名单，最后两句是 “他不放债取利，不受贿赂以害无辜。” （第 5 节）。诗篇在会众中诵读，具有将社会压力带给个人的动摇决心的作用。鉴于作曲家也是国王，歌声一定很响亮。

David’s successor, King Solomon, understood that in his time and place the question of usury was one issue that could not be split down the middle. In Proverbs 28:8, he links usury directly with other financial scams. “He that by usury and unjust gain increaseth his substance,” declares Solomon, “he shall gather it for him that will pity the poor.” One implication, as in most of the Old Testament citations on the subject, is that usury hurts the poor. There are, to be sure, no references to commercial loans, let alone collateralized debt obligations or credit default swaps, in the Old Testament. A second implication here, one that shows Solomon at his wisest, is that usury will inevitably betray the usurer.

大卫的继任者所罗门王明白，在他的时代和地方，高利贷的问题是一个不能被分割的问题。在《箴言》（28：8）中，他将高利贷与其他金融骗局直接联系起来。所罗门说 ：“人以厚利加增财物，是给那怜悯穷人者积蓄的。” 正如大多数旧约中关于这个问题的引文一样，其中一个含义是高利贷伤害了穷人。可以肯定的是，《旧约》中没有提到商业贷款，更不用说抵押债务义务或信用违约掉期。这里的第二个含义是，高利贷将不可避免地背叛高利贷者，这也显示了所罗门最明智的一面。【这句引文没看懂为啥是与骗局直接联系起来……】

Going forward, the prophets were not too keen on usury either. In the days after Solomon’s passing, corrupted perhaps by the wealth and power their kingdom had amassed, the people began to lose their moral vigor. Partly as a result, the unified Jewish nation split in two — Israel to the north and Judah to the south. The prophet Isaiah warned that if the Jews did not heed the laws handed down by Moses, if they continued, among other sins, to “beat my people to pieces, and grind the faces of the poor” (Isaiah 3:15), they would soon enough find themselves carried captive to an alien land.

随后的日子里，先知们对高利贷也不太感冒。在所罗门去世后的日子里，也许是被他们王国所积累的财富和权力所腐蚀，人们开始失去道德活力。部分原因是，统一的犹太民族一分为二；北方的以色列和南方的犹大。先知以赛亚警告说，如果犹太人不听从摩西传下来的法律，如果他们继续参与罪行的话，包括 “你们为何压制我的百姓，搓磨贫穷人的脸呢” （以赛亚书 3:15），他们很快就会发现自己被掳到异乡。

In the immediate decades before the catastrophe that Isaiah prophesied, the gloomy Jeremiah took up the warning. Writing circa 600 BC and weighing in on the moral corruption then infecting Jerusalem, Jeremiah revealed the depth of hostility toward the usurer without even intending to. “Woe is me,” he writes in a trademark burst of self-pity, “my mother, that thou hast borne me a man of strife and a man of contention to the whole earth! I have neither lent on usury, nor men have lent to me on usury; yet every one of them doth curse me” (Jeremiah 15:10). Were a prophet today to conjure up a universally despised sinner as a point of comparison, he would likely say “child molester” or “AIG exec” and would be hard pressed to get beyond that. Back in the day, “usurer” did the trick. The stigma was that severe.

在以赛亚预言的灾难发生前的几十年里，阴郁的耶利米接受了这个警告。大约在公元前 600 年，耶利米写下了关于当时使耶路撒冷的道德败坏的文章，他甚至无意中揭示了对高利贷者的敌意之深。“我有祸了”，他以一种标志性的自怜写道，“我的母亲哪，我有祸了！因你生我作为遍地相争相竞的人。我素来没有借贷与人，人也没有借贷与我，人人却都咒骂我。” （耶利米书 15:10）。如果今天的先知想出一个被普遍鄙视的罪人作为比较点，他可能会说 “恋童癖” 或 “美国国际集团执行官”，而且很难超越这个范围。在过去，“高利贷者” 就能解决问题。耻辱是如此严重。

As Jeremiah feared, the kingdom of Judah did indeed fall to Nebuchudnezzar. The temple was destroyed. And the people were carried off in captivity to a land that had been practicing usury for more than a millennium. Here the Lord instructed Ezekiel, a learned priest among the Jewish captives, in the ways they had gone awry in this corrupt and credit-happy land:

正如耶利米所担心的，犹大王国确实落入尼布甲尼撒之手。圣殿被毁。人民被掳到一个实行高利贷已超过一千年的地方。在这里，耶和华指示以西结，一个犹太俘虏中的有学问的祭司，他们在这块腐败和喜欢信贷的土地上出了什么问题：

And one hath committed abomination with his neighbour’s wife; and another hath lewdly defiled his daughter in law; and another in thee hath humbled his sister, his father’s daughter. In thee have they taken gifts to shed blood; thou hast taken usury and increase, and thou hast greedily gained of thy neighbours by extortion, and hast forgotten me. (Ezekial 22:11–12)

这人与邻舍的妻行可憎的事；那人贪淫玷污儿妇；还有玷辱同父之姐妹的。 12 在你中间有为流人血受贿赂的；有向借钱的弟兄取利，向借粮的弟兄多要的。且因贪得无厌，欺压邻舍夺取财物，竟忘了我。(以西结书 22:11–12)

In exile, deprived of power and inspired by priests like Ezekiel, the Jews began to define themselves by their adherence to the Torah. Removed from their own temporal kingdom, no force except the force within could compel them to honor it. That force, to be sure, would need constant propping.

在流亡中，被剥夺了权力之后，在以西结等祭司的激励下，犹太人开始以对《圣经》的遵守来定义自己。从他们自己的世俗王国中消失后，除了内心的力量外，没有任何力量可以迫使他们尊重它。可以肯定的是，这种力量需要不断的支持。

After the overthrow of Babylonia by the Persians fifty years into the captivity, the Persian ruler Cyrus the Great allowed the Jews to return to their homeland. Many thousands accepted the offer and made their way back. Some eighty years later, they were joined by a second group of returning exiles. Neither group prospered. When a third wave failed to pull the enclave together, a prosperous Jew named Nehemiah gave up a comfortable position in the Persian court and headed back to Jerusalem. As appointed governor, he hoped to stabilize Judea, now a struggling Persian province.

在巴比伦被波斯人推翻 50 年后，波斯统治者居鲁士大帝允许犹太人返回他们的家园。许多人接受了这一提议，并踏上了归途。大约 80 年后，第二批返回的流亡者加入了他们。这两批人都没有兴旺起来。当第三波流亡者也未能将飞地团结起来时，一个名叫尼希米的富有的犹太人放弃了在波斯宫廷的舒适职位，回到了耶路撒冷。作为被任命的总督，他希望能稳定犹太地区，现在是一个挣扎的波斯省份。

Upon arriving, Nehemiah saw for himself that all was not well in the promised land. Everywhere he went, he heard griping about the indifferent rich who were oppressing their poorer Jewish brethren. The combination of drought and taxes had pressed the people into bondage once again, this time to Jews who profited from their land and labor. “And I was very angry when I heard their cry and these words,” Nehemiah recounts. “Then I consulted with myself, and I rebuked the nobles, and the rulers, and said unto them, Ye exact usury, every one of his brother” (Nehemiah 5:6–7).

抵达之后，尼希米亲眼看到应许之地的一切都不太妙。他所到之处，都听到了对冷漠的富人的抱怨，他们正在压迫更贫穷的犹太教兄弟们。干旱和税收的结合使人民再次陷入奴役，这次是针对那些从他们的土地和劳动中获利的犹太人。“我听见他们呼号说这些话，便甚发怒。” 尼希米叙述道。“我心里筹划，就斥责贵胄和官长说：‘你们各人向弟兄取利！’” （尼希米 5:6–7）。

Nehemiah organized protests against the nobles and rulers and brought the pressure of the people to bear upon them. “Restore, I pray you,” Nehemiah insists, “to them, even this day, their lands, their vineyards, their oliveyards, and their houses, also the hundredth part of the money, and of the corn, the wine, and the oil, that ye exact of them” (v. 11).

尼希米组织了对贵族和统治者的抗议，并将人民的压力带给他们。尼希米坚持说 ：“如今我劝你们将他们的田地、葡萄园、橄榄园、房屋，并向他们所取的银钱、粮食、新酒，和油，百分之一的利息都归还他们。” （第 11 节）

“We will restore them, and will require nothing of them; so will we do as thou sayest,” said the moneylenders (v. 12), cowed by the thought of thousands of ACORN-like protestors and perhaps even a little contrite about ignoring the law of their forefathers.

“我们必归还，不再向他们索要，必照你的话行。” 放债人说（第 12 节），他们一想到成千上万像坚果一样的抗议者就瑟瑟发抖，也许甚至会对自己曾经无视祖先的法律而感到有点后悔。

During the nearly thousand years that separated Nehemiah from Moses, the hatred of usury remained white-hot, and the law remained largely unchanged. The authors who recorded this history could not be clearer or more consistent in their denunciation of usury, here meaning no more than the charging of simple interest on a loan. The question that remains, then, is, whence Shylock? How is it that the people with the world’s most thoroughly chronicled rejection of a particular act could, in a historic eyeblink, become the poster children for that same act?

在尼希米与摩西相隔的近千年时间里，人们对高利贷的憎恨依然白热化，法律也基本没有改变。记录这段历史的作者对高利贷的谴责再清楚不过，也再一致不过，这里指的是对贷款收取简单利息。那么，剩下的问题是，夏洛克从何而来？为什么世界上对某一特定行为拒绝得最彻底的人，会在一个历史性的眨眼之间，成为同一行为的海报儿童？

Here, much depends on one other citation from Deuteronomy (23:19–20 to be exact), arguably the most critical citation in all of Jewish history. The maxim begins unremarkably enough: “Thou shalt not lend upon usury to thy brother; usury of money, usury of victuals, usury of any thing that is lent upon usury.”

在这里，很大程度上取决于《申命记》中的另一条引文（确切地说，是 23:19–20），可以说是整个犹太历史中最关键的引文。这句格言的开头并不引人注目 ：“你借给你兄弟的银钱、食物，或是任何可以生利的东西，都不可取利。”

The intent of the law seems fairly straightforward. In a closed society where one historically lent money as a form of charity, charging for that money debased the very act. This understanding holds true today as well. If a friend or relative needs help, the one who lends the money looks like a totalschmuckif he asks for a littleneshekto make it worth his while.

法律的意图似乎相当直截了当。在一个封闭的社会里，人们在历史上把借钱作为一种慈善的形式，对这种钱的收费贬低了这种行为本身。这种理解在今天也是如此。如果一个朋友或亲戚需要帮助，借钱给他的人若是竟然要一点neshek来使其物有所值的话，那么他看起来就像一个彻头彻尾的笨蛋。

It is the second half of these verses that has caused the Jewish people so much grief: “Unto a stranger thou mayest lend upon usury; but unto thy brother thou shalt not lend upon usury.” Over the centuries there has been endless debate as to who, exactly, a stranger was. Champions of the usury prohibition, like the aforementioned Mr. Elliott, have argued for its narrowest interpretation. They would contend that only the avaricious among the Jews classed all Gentiles in the stranger category. This interpretation, Elliott insists, “set every Gentile Christian’s hand against the Jews for fifteen hundred years.” 3From Elliott’s perspective,strangerrefers only to active enemies like Canaanites and others “accursed of God.”

正是这些经文的后半部分给犹太人带来了巨大的痛苦。“借给外族人，你倒可以取利；只是借给你的兄弟，你就不可取利。” 几个世纪以来，关于陌生人到底是谁，一直有无尽的争论。高利贷禁令的拥护者，如前面提到的埃利奥特先生，主张对其进行最严格的解释。他们认为，只有犹太人中的贪婪者才会将所有外邦人归入陌生人类别。艾略特坚持认为，这种解释 “使每一个外邦人基督徒的手与犹太人对立了一千五百年”。3从艾略特的角度来看，陌生人只指主动的敌人，如迦南人和其他 “被上帝诅咒的人”。

Elliott, however, overlooks the dispersal of the Jews, the famed Diaspora. As threatened in Deuteronomy 28:25, a Lord whose laws were ignored could and would allow his people to be “removed into all the kingdoms of the earth.” Whether deserved or not, such was the fate of the Jews. Beginning with the Babylonian captivity and ending with the ruthlessly suppressed Bar Kokhba revolt against Rome in AD 132, the Jews were removed, if not to all the kingdoms of the earth, at least to all of those that had been Hellenized, and from the Greek perspective, those were all the kingdoms that mattered.4

然而，埃利奥特忽视了犹太人的分散，即著名的散居地。正如《申命记》28:25 所威胁的那样，一个自身所订的法律被忽视的主可以而且会让他的子民 “必在天下万国中抛来抛去”。无论是否应得，这就是犹太人的命运。从巴比伦被掳开始，到公元 132 年被无情镇压的反罗马的巴可巴起义结束，犹太人被驱逐，如果不是被驱逐到地球上的所有国家，至少是被驱逐到所有已经希腊化的国家，而从希腊人的角度来看，那些（驱逐犹太人的）国家都是重要的。4

In those few centuries on either side of the birth of Christ, Greek culture and language dominated the Mediterranean littoral. At the time, given their dominance, the Greeks believed in the oneness of humanity. Not unlike today’s champions of inclusiveness, they saw theirs as a multiracial, multinational cultural empire that embraced any people that accepted their hegemony.

在基督诞生后的那几个世纪里，希腊文化和语言主导了地中海沿岸。当时，鉴于他们的主导地位，希腊人相信人类的一体性。与今天的包容性倡导者不一样，他们认为自己是一个多种族、多民族的文化帝国，拥抱任何接受其霸权的人。

The children of Abraham, however, saw themselves as a race apart. Their belief in monotheism, their dietary and hygienic standards, their insistence on the barbarous practice of circumcision all reinforced their difference in a world of presumed harmony. Everywhere Jews looked they saw people who were strangers, who were not their brothers. Their laws forbade dining with these people, let alone marrying them. This self-imposed alienation was reinforced by a growing hostility from indigenous peoples put off by the Jews’ seeming aloofness. The phraseanti-Semitismhad yet to be coined, but the sentiment was alive and well centuries before the birth of Christ.

然而，亚伯拉罕的子孙把自己看作是一个与众不同的种族。他们对一神教的信仰，他们的饮食和卫生标准，他们对野蛮的割礼习俗的坚持，都加强了他们在这个假定的和谐世界中的差异。犹太人在任何地方看到的都是陌生人，都不是他们的兄弟。他们的法律禁止与这些人吃饭，更不用说与他们结婚了。这种自我封闭的疏离感，因原住民对犹太人看似冷漠的态度而产生的日益强烈的敌意而得到加强。反犹太主义这个短语当时还没有出现，但这种情绪在基督诞生前几个世纪就已经存在了。

Most of these strangers, however, could have cared less about the Jews’ willingness to lend money at interest. They had been doing the same for millennia. Ironically, the growing Jewish trade in usury would only trouble those Gentiles who inherited Jewish law, namely, the Christians. “Nothing more clearly marked the line between Christian and Hebrew during fifteen centuries than this one thing,” argues Elliott, “that the Hebrews exacted usury or interest of the Gentiles while the Christians were unanimous in its denunciation, and forbade its practice.” 5

然而，这些陌生人中的大多数人可能并不关心犹太人是否愿意借钱收息。几千年来，他们一直在做同样的事情。具有讽刺意味的是，犹太人越来越多的高利贷交易只会给那些继承了犹太法律的外邦人，即基督徒，带来麻烦。埃利奥特认为 ：“在 15 个世纪中，没有什么比这一点更清楚地标明了基督教和希伯来人之间的界限。希伯来人向外邦人索取高利贷或利息，而基督徒则一致谴责并禁止其做法。” 5

threeHoping for Nothing Again 施恩不图报

THERE CAN BE LITTLE ARGRGUMENT, EVEN AMONG NONBELIEVERS, ABOUT the identity of history’s most influential figure. As Christians see it, the prophet Isaiah predicted his coming six centuries before his birth: “Therefore the Lord himself shall give you a sign,” Isaiah proclaimed. “Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel” (Isaiah 7:14).

对于历史上最有影响力的人物的身份，即使是在非信徒之间，也不会有什么争论。在基督徒看来，先知以赛亚在他出生前六个世纪就预言了他的到来。以赛亚宣称 “因此，主自己要给你们一个兆头，必有童女怀孕生子，给他起名叫以马内利（就是‘神与我们同在’的意思）。” （以赛亚书 7:14）。

Despite his extraordinary influence on just about every moral issue under the sun, Jesus Christ was nearly mum on the subject of usury. The two times he does weigh in, he does so indirectly and enigmatically, no more so than in the controversial parable of the talents and the pounds, which both Luke and Matthew recount at length.

尽管耶稣基督对阳光下的每一个道德问题都有非凡的影响，但他对高利贷的问题几乎保持沉默。在他的两次发言中，他都是间接地、神秘地表达了自己的观点，其中最重要的莫过于路加和马太都详细叙述的有争议的才干和斤两的寓言了。

As Luke tells the story, a certain nobleman gives each of his ten servants one pound and tells them to busy themselves trading while he ventures into a far country to take over a kingdom. The nobleman, however, proves no more popular in his new kingdom than Cromwell in Ireland. The citizens hate him and let him know it in no uncertain terms. He soon heads home and upon returning convenes his servants and asks how they have done with the money.

正如路加所讲的故事，某个贵族给他的十个仆人每人一锭银子，让他们忙着做买卖，而他则冒险到一个遥远的国家去接管一个王国。然而，事实证明，这位贵族在他的新王国里并不受欢迎，甚至都不如在爱尔兰的克伦威尔。市民们憎恨他，并明确告诉他这一点。他很快就回家了，回来后召集他的仆人，问他们如何处理这些钱。

The first servant boasts, “Lord, thy pound hath gained ten pounds” (Luke 19:16). Pleased with the profit, the nobleman gives him authority over ten cities. The second servant has gained five pounds through trading and gets five cities. But the third servant hid the money while his boss was gone and returns just the one pound he was given. More provocatively, he tells the boss that he feared him for his hard-hearted profiteering.

第一个仆人夸口说 ：“主啊，你的一锭银子已经赚了十锭” （路加福音 19:16）。贵族对这一收益感到高兴，就把管理十个城市的权力交给他。第二个仆人通过交易获得了五锭，得到了五个城市。但第三个仆人在老板不在时把钱藏了起来，现在只能归还给老板一锭。更具挑衅性的是，他告诉老板，他害怕老板心狠手辣的暴利行为。

The boss challenges his answer. If the servant were really afraid of him, why did he not put “my money into the bank, that at my coming I might have required mine own with usury?” (v. 23). In Matthew, the nobleman phrases his complaint almost identically: “Thou oughtest therefore to have put my money to the exchangers, and then at my coming I should have received mine own with usury” (25:27). In both accounts, the nobleman then takes the remaining pound away from his underperforming servant and gives it to the fellow with ten pounds.

老板质疑他的回答。如果这个仆人真的害怕他，那他 “为什么不把我的银子交给银行，等我来的时候，连本带利都可以要回来呢？” (路加福音 v. 23). 在马太福音中，这个贵族对他的抱怨的措辞几乎是相同的。“就当把我的银子放给兑换银钱的人，到我来的时候，可以连本带利收回。” （马太福音 25：27）。在这两个故事中，贵族从他表现不佳的仆人那里拿走了剩余的一锭，并把它给了那个有十锭的人。

Matthew and Luke both use the Greek wordtokos, meaning “offspring,” forusury.Tokoscomes with the lively understanding that money breeds money, that savvy investments should multiply, if not like rabbits, at least like derivatives. Of historical note,tokosis the word that evangelists used when they were translating the usury references in the Psalms and Ezekiel into Greek.1

马太福音和路加福音都使用希腊语tokos表示高利贷。Tokos的意思是 “后代”。伴随着一种生动的理解，即钱会滋生钱，精明的投资应该繁殖，如果不是像兔子，至少是像衍生品。从历史上看，tokos是布道者使用的词。是传道人在将《诗篇》和《以西结书》中有关高利贷的内容翻译成希腊文时使用的词。1

It should be noted, too, that Matthew uses the Greek wordtrapezetesto describe exchangers, or as it often translated,moneylenders. Matthew, Mark, and John use a different word,kollybistes, to describe the money changers whom Jesus famously threw out of the temple. These were not practitioners of usury but of simony, the selling of sacred things. What upset Jesus was that they had commoditized their sacrificial offerings and turned the temple into a spiritual swap-and-shop.

还应该注意的是，马太使用希腊语trapezetes来描述交换者，或如通常所翻译的放债人。 《马太福音》、《马可福音》和《约翰福音》使用了一个不同的词：kollybistes。来描述那些被耶稣众所周知地赶出盛典的货币兑换商。这些人不是放高利贷，而是出售圣物。让耶稣感到不安的是，他们把祭品商品化，把圣殿变成了一个精神上的交换常场所。

Although not as notorious as the temple’s money changers, the nobleman in question makes an unlikely protagonist. Jesus, however, tells this tale not to endorse his behavior but rather to chide the unprofitable servant for failing to benefit from the opportunity and dissembling about the reason why. Jesus, it seems, uses the parable to make the case that mortals should take advantage of God’s gifts while they can. Those who put those gifts to good use will be rewarded. Those who don’t, and then make lame excuses for their poor performance, will find themselves among the goats at the last judgment, not the sheep.

虽然不像圣殿里的兑换银钱的人那样臭名昭著，但这个贵族是个不可能的主角。然而，耶稣讲这个故事并不是为了赞同他的行为，而是为了责备这个无利可图的仆人没有从机会中获益，并对其原因遮遮掩掩。耶稣似乎用这个寓言来说明，凡人应该在他们可以利用的时候利用上帝的礼物。那些善于利用这些礼物的人将得到回报。那些不这样做的人，然后为他们的糟糕表现寻找蹩脚的借口，在最后的审判中，他们将发现自己属于山羊，而不是绵羊。

Defenders of the usury prohibition have obvious trouble with this parable. Martin Luther, for instance, would cite any number of quotations from Luke and Matthew to attack usury, but he chooses not to talk about this parable at all. Calvin Elliott cites it only to dismiss it. To use the parable as a defense of usury, he says, is a “flagrant perversion of the truth.” 2In fact, however, most Christian defenders of usury, John Calvin among them, were as reluctant to refer to this parable as were usury’s foes. To make the case that Jesus actually favoredtokoswould imply that the admonitions againsttokosby David and Ezekiel no longer held sway, an argument that, if waged in the wrong circles, could get the usury defender into hot water or even boiling oil.

高利贷禁令的辩护者对这个寓言显然有意见。例如，马丁·路德会引用路加和马太的任何一段话来攻击高利贷，但他选择根本不谈这个寓言。加尔文·艾略特引用它只是为了否定它。他说，用这个寓言为高利贷辩护，是 “对真理的公然歪曲”。2然而，事实上，大多数基督教高利贷的捍卫者，包括约翰·加尔文，都像高利贷的敌人一样不愿意提及这个寓言。如果要证明耶稣实际上赞成tokos的话将意味着大卫和以西结的反对tokos的告诫 —— 这个论点如果在错误的圈子里发动，可能会将高利贷的辩护人扔进放满开水甚至沸油的锅中。

Although not exactly endorsing usury, Jesus does not seem terribly upset by the practice. Lending at interest was apparently common enough in his time, despite Mosaic legal prohibitions, that his listeners understood its workings.

虽然没有完全认可高利贷，但耶稣似乎并没有对这种做法感到非常不满。在他的时代，尽管有摩西法律的禁止，但收取利息的借贷显然是很普遍的，他的听众了解其运作方式。

Just about every Christian foe of usury has put great stake in one other citation from Luke — chapter 6, verses 30 to 35. It begins, “Give to every man that asketh of thee; and of him that taketh away thy goods ask them not again.” Says Luther of this passage, “Here no exception is made of enemies or opponents; nay, they are included, as the Lord Himself makes clear in the same passage.” 3Luther quotes the following lines from Jesus to that effect:

几乎每一个反对高利贷的基督徒都对路加福音第六章第 30 至 35 节的另一段引文非常感兴趣。它的开头是 ：“凡求你的，就给他。有人夺你的东西去，不用再要回来。” 路德在谈到这段经文时说 ：“这里没有把敌人或对手作为例外；不，他们也包括在内，正如主自己在同一段经文中明确指出的那样。” 3路德为此引用了耶稣的以下几句话：

And if ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive, what thank have ye? for sinners also lend to sinners, to receive as much again. But love ye your enemies, and do good, and lend, hoping for nothing again; and your reward shall be great, and ye shall be the children of the Highest: for he is kind unto the unthankful and to the evil. (Luke 6:34–35)

你们若借给人，指望从他收回，有什么可酬谢的呢？就是罪人也借给罪人，要如数收回。你们倒要爱仇敌，也要善待他们，并要借给人不指望偿还，你们的赏赐就必大了，你们也必作至高者的儿子，因为他恩待那忘恩的和作恶的。(路加福音 6:34–35)

In practical terms, it is hard to summon a single biblical passage upon which so much has hinged. As interpreted by Luther and virtually every church father through the sixteenth century, this passage, specifically the line “hoping for nothing again,” not only laid down the Christian law on usury but also explicitly put Jews outside that law. From this perspective, there were no strangers. Everyone was worthy of a loan without expectation of return.

在实际生活中，这一段《圣经》经文最难言传身教，可它又是如此的关键。正如路德和十六世纪的几乎所有教会教父所解释的那样，这段话，特别是 “（借给人）不指望偿还” 这句话，不仅规定了基督教关于高利贷的法律，而且明确地将犹太人置于该法律之外。从这个角度来看，不存在陌生人。每个人都值得借钱，而不指望回报。

To buttress their argument, usury foes have cited any number of other New Testament passages that show Jesus as a prudent and practical man, one who rejected material excess and unjust profit of the sort that usurers gathered.

为了支持他们的论点，高利贷的反对者引用了《新约》中的任何其他段落，这些段落显示耶稣是一个谨慎和实际的人，他拒绝物质上的过度和高利贷者获取的那种不公正的利润。

As many of these passages also show, Jesus had no gripe with the making of profit per se. He grew up, after all, in a small business that he inherited from his earthly father and ran himself. He does have a problem, however, with an undue fixation on the making of money and the hoarding of wealth. What is remarkable about Jesus’ teaching on matters economic is that he could run for office on his record in any country in the Western world and not be embarrassed by it. Indeed, it would put him in good stead almost everywhere.

正如许多这些经文所显示的那样，耶稣对赚取利润本身并无怨言。毕竟，他是在一个小企业中长大的，这个企业是他从尘世间的父亲那里继承下来的，并且自主经营。然而，他确实对过度专注于赚钱和囤积财富有意见。耶稣在经济问题上的非凡的教导，使得他可以在西方世界的任何一个国家以他的记录竞选公职，而不会因此而感到尴尬。事实上，这几乎会使他在任何地方都处于有利地位。

Christian socialists labor to make Jesus one of themselves. In fact, protosocialists like Robert Owen, Charles Fourier, and the Duc de Saint-Simon grounded their theories in the Gospels. Many contemporary socialists, Christian and otherwise, still do. In addition to citing Christ’s frequent pleas for charity and compassion, some theorists make a macro case for socialism based on one particular passage from Matthew (25:31–46): “And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats” (v. 32).

基督教社会主义者努力使耶稣成为自己的一员。事实上，像罗伯特·欧文（Robert Owen）、查尔斯·傅立叶（Charles Fourier）和圣西蒙公爵（Duc de Saint-Simon）这样的原社会主义者将他们的理论建立在福音书上。许多当代社会主义者，不管是基督教还是其他，仍然这样做。除了引用基督对慈善和怜悯的频繁呼吁外，一些理论家还根据马太福音中的一段话（25:31–46）为社会主义提供了一个宏观案例。“万民都要聚集在他面前。他要把他们分别出来，好像牧羊要分别绵羊山羊一般。” （第 32 节）。

The key word quoted above isnations. The argument goes that Jesus will reward those nation states that have assumed as a matter of policy a redistributive role toward “the least of these my brethren” (v. 40). The problem with this reading is that nowhere else in the New Testament — or the Old Testament for that matter — do Jesus, his apostles, the prophets, Moses, or God the Father suggest that the children of God should yield their good-deed doing to a coercive state. This is a task assigned in every instance in the Bible to the individual, the family, or the church.

上面引用的关键词是nations。这种说法认为，耶稣将奖励那些在政策上对 “我这弟兄中最小的人” （第 40 节）承担再分配角色的民族国家。这种解读的问题在于，在《新约》或《旧约》中，耶稣、他的使徒、先知、摩西或父神都没有暗示神的儿女应该将他们的善行屈服于一个有强制力的国家。这是《圣经》中分配给个人、家庭或教会的每一项任务。

There is one other major problem with the Jesus-as-socialist argument: in both the New Testament and the Old, one gave alms not so much to redistribute the wealth as to manage one’s own eternal wealth. The English wordcreditorderives from the Latincredere—— “to believe.” In a very real sense, to extend credit to the poor was to testify to one’s belief in God. As Jesus famously said to the rich young man in Matthew 19:21, “If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come and follow me.” The payoff was to be expected not on earth but in heaven. Usury debased the currency of exchange.

耶稣作为社会主义者的论点还有一个主要问题：在《新约》和《旧约》中，人们施舍的目的不是为了重新分配财富，而是为了管理自己的永恒财富。英语中的creditor一词源自拉丁语credere—— “相信”。在一个非常真实的意义上，向穷人提供信贷是为了证明自己对上帝的信仰。正如耶稣在《马太福音》19:21 中对那个富有的年轻人所说的那样，“你若愿意作完全人，可去变卖你所有的，分给穷人，就必有财宝在天上；你还要来跟从我。” 报酬不是在地上而是在天上。高利贷贬低了货币交易。

Writing in the fourth century after Christ, Augustine of Hippo, the most justly celebrated of early church philosophers, clarifies the Scriptures’ meaning. No fan of usury, he nevertheless uses the usurer as model:

在基督之后的第四个世纪，希波的奥古斯丁，这位最著名的早期教会哲学家，澄清了圣经的意义。他不喜欢高利贷，但他还是以高利贷者为榜样：

Study the money lender’s methods. He wants to give modestly and get back with profit; you do the same. Give a little and receive on a grand scale. Look how your interest is mounting up! Give temporal wealth and claim eternal interest, give the earth and gain heaven.4

研究放债人的方法。他想适度地给予，并以利润回报；你也要这样做。给予少许，获得巨大的回报。看看你的利息是如何增加的! 给予暂时的财富，要求永恒的利益，给予地球，获得天堂。4

Augustine asks rhetorically to whom should the money be given. The answer is the same person who “forbade you to be a usurer,” the Lord himself. He now “comes forward [in the form of the poor person] to ask you for a loan.” Augustine insists that Scriptures are clear on this point: “Anyone who gives alms to the poor is lending to the Lord.” 5This is at the very heart of the Judeo-Christian objection to usury. It also explains why Jews and Christians were asked to lend and not worry about being repaid. The ROI (return on investment) would come in heaven.

奥古斯丁反问道，这些钱应该交给谁。答案就是那个 “禁止你做高利贷者” 的人，即主自己。他现在 “（以穷人的形式）站出来，向你借钱”。奥古斯丁坚持认为，《圣经》在这一点上是明确的 ：“任何向穷人施舍的人都是向主借钱”。5这正是犹太教和基督教反对高利贷的核心所在。这也解释了为什么犹太人和基督徒被要求放贷而不担心被偿还。投资回报率（ROI）会在天堂出现。

In our ignorance of the Scriptures, and in our ability to influence public polity, observes Old Testament authority Gary Anderson, “We have developed a larger interest in redistributing income legislatively than in providing a rationale for sacrificial giving on the part of the laity.” 6

在我们对圣经的无知中，在我们影响公共政体的能力中，旧约权威加里·安德森观察到，“我们在立法上重新分配收入的兴趣比在为教友的牺牲性奉献提供理由的兴趣更大。” 6

And yet the socialist attempt to co-opt Christ’s message is not entirely cynical. There is something about what Jesus says and does that intrigues even the most godless communists. There are two nonexclusive reasons why this might be so. One is that Jesus is, in fact, transcendentally wise. The second and less subjective reason is that the Christian ethos has so deeply penetrated Western civilization for so long that no one, not even those at the local Ministry of Atheism or the Church of Satan, are immune to its power.

然而，社会主义者试图篡改基督的信息并不完全是玩世不恭的。耶稣的言行有些地方甚至让最不敬神的共产主义者也感到好奇。有两个非排他性的原因可以说明这一点。其一是，耶稣事实上是超然的智慧。第二个不那么主观的原因是，基督教精神长期以来深深地渗透到西方文明中，以至于没有人，甚至是当地无神论部或撒旦教会的人，都无法幸免于其力量的影响。

In the first few hundred years after Christ’s birth, usury did not preoccupy many minds. The Romans, whose laws held sway over the Mediterranean world, had had a mixed history on the subject. According to the historian Tacitus, Rome had no usury laws at all for the first three centuries of its existence.7

在基督诞生后的最初几百年里，高利贷并没有引起很多人的关注。罗马人的法律支配着地中海世界，他们在这个问题上的历史不尽相同。根据历史学家塔西佗的说法，罗马在其存在的前三个世纪中根本就没有高利贷法律。7

Codification came only in 450 BC with the Law of Twelve Tables. This may have been the first attempt by any culture to set a legal interest rate, in this case in the 8 to 10 percent range, depending on how the law is read. Lawmakers have obviously not lost this urge. As I write, the president of the United States is jawboning America’s credit card companies into capping their interest rates and threatening legislation if they don’t.

公元前 450 年，《十二表法》才开始编纂。这可能是任何文化中第一次尝试制定法定利率，在这种情况下，利率在 8% 到 10% 之间，这取决于如何解读法律。立法者们显然没有失去这种冲动。就在我写这篇文章的时候，美国总统正在向美国的信用卡公司施加压力，要求他们设定利率上限，并威胁说如果他们不这样做的话，就要立法。

More so than the Greeks and other contemporaries, the Romans had a lingering cultural distaste for the practice of usury, legal or otherwise. Tacitus, who was born fifty years after Christ, called it “the old curse of the city.” 8In the half millennium between the Twelve Tables and Tacitus’s birth, Roman law swung back and forth on its legality at least a half dozen times. And even when the law permitted usury, which was most of the time, the philosophical class held its collective nose.

比起希腊人和其他同时代的人，罗马人对高利贷的做法有着挥之不去的文化厌恶，无论是合法的还是其他的。塔西佗（Tacitus）出生于基督之后 50 年，他将高利贷称为 “城市的古老诅咒”。8在《十二表》和塔西佗出生之间的半千年里，罗马法律至少在其合法性上来回摇摆了六次。即使是在法律允许高利贷的情况下，也就是在大多数时候，哲学界也是集体忍气吞声。

。

The Roman statesman Cato, writing in the second century before Christ, imagined usurers in a class with murderers. Argued Cato, as Cicero remembered, “Would you take interest?” “Would you kill a man?” 9Fifteen hundred years later, his countryman Dante Alighieri would also equate usury with homicide and consign the practitioners of both to the Inferno’s seventh circle, the usurers deeper in. Dante’s guide to theInferno, the Roman poet Virgil, spoke of usurers in real life as “drones, a slothful race.” 10Cicero was no friend of the usurer either. InDe Officiis, he cautions his son to avoid both money lending and tax collecting, “In the first place, those callings are held in disesteem that come into collision with the ill will of men.” 11

罗马政治家加图在公元前二世纪写道，他把高利贷者和杀人犯想象在一起。加图争辩说，正如西塞罗所记得的那样，“你会拿利息吗？” “你会杀了一个人吗？” 91500 年后，他的同胞但丁·阿利吉耶里也将高利贷与杀人相提并论，并将两者的从业者打入《地狱》的第七层，高利贷者则更深。但丁的《地狱》指南Inferno里，罗马诗人维吉尔（Virgil）将现实生活中的高利贷者说成是 “无赖，一个懒惰的种族”。10西塞罗也不是高利贷者的朋友。在De Officiis中。 他告诫他的儿子要避免放贷和收税，“首先，那些早晚撞倒人之恶意的职业是不会被尊重的”。11

In the first few hundred years after Christ’s birth, no Roman citizen inveighed more heartily against usury than Plutarch, the Greek-born biographer and moralist. In his essay “Against Borrowing Money,” he denounces moneylenders as “barbarous and wicked,” a scourge to be avoided at all costs. His description of the borrower’s fate still resonates, especially among those trying to pay their lenders off on sports bets gone bad: “At the very delivery of their money they immediately ask it back, taking it up at the same moment they lay it down, and letting out to interest that which they have received for the use of what they had lent.” 12

在基督诞生后的最初几百年里，没有哪个罗马公民比希腊出生的传记作家和道德家普鲁塔克更衷心地反对高利贷。在他的文章《反对借钱》中，他谴责放债人是 “野蛮和邪恶的”，是要不惜一切代价避免的祸害。他对借款人命运的描述仍然引起人们的共鸣，特别是在那些试图通过体育博彩来偿还贷款人的人中 ：“他们刚借出钱就立即要求归还，在他们放下钱的同时就把它拿起来，并把因他们借出东西而得到的利息再放出去。” 12

What particularly piqued Plutarch, though, was what has always piqued intellectuals: being mocked by those lesser mortals whose actual practice undermines their best theories. “They laugh at the philosophers,” laments Plutarch, “who hold that nothing can be made out of nothing.” 13The moneylender may have started with nothing, but he was obviously making enough out of it to irritate his intellectual betters.

让普鲁塔克特别气堵的是一直让知识分子生气的事情：被那些用实际操作破坏其最佳理论的小人物嘲笑。“他们嘲笑哲学家”，普鲁塔克哀叹道，“他们认为没有什么可以从无中生有”。13放债人可能是白手起家，但他们显然以无中生有的方式赚到了足够多的钱去激怒比他们聪明的人。

。

Christians, in these first few centuries after Christ, had enough to worry about — the lions in the Coliseum for instance — without worrying about usury. The first church manual of instruction, called the Didache, does not mention usury at all, at least not directly. It does, however, consider the conditions of a loan’s repayment and makes a salient distinction between the poor who cannot pay and the rich who can: “Woe to him that receiveth; for if a man receiveth having need, he is guiltless; but he that hath no need shall give satisfaction . . . until he hath given back the last farthing.” 14This instruction suggests that some impulse other than charity motivated the loan to the wealthy man, but it stops well short of condoning loans as investments.

基督徒，在基督之后的最初几个世纪里，有足够的事儿要担心 —— 例如斗兽场的狮子 —— 而不必担心高利贷。教会的第一本指导手册，即《圣训》，根本没有提到高利贷，至少没有直接提到。然而，它确实考虑了贷款的偿还条件，并对无力偿还的穷人和有能力偿还的富人作了突出的区分。“接受的人有祸了；因为如果一个人接受时有需要，他是无罪的；但没有需要的人应给予满足 —— 直到他归还了最后的钱财。” 14这条指示表明，除了慈善之外，还有一些冲动促使他向富人提供贷款，但它远远没有宽恕将贷款作为投资。

It was not until AD 313 that the emperor Constantine called off the lions, at least officially. Twelve years later, more than 250 bishops convened in the town of Nicea in what is now Turkey for the first churchwide convocation. There were some weighty issues on the table, most notably the relationship between Jesus and God the Father. Participants hammered out consensus on lesser issues as well, ranging from self-castration (prohibited) to standing in church (approved) to usury (discouraged). These rulings have come to be known collectively as the Nicene Creed.15

直到公元 313 年，君士坦丁皇帝才叫停了狮子会，至少是正式的。12 年后，250 多名主教在尼西亚镇（即现在的土耳其）召开了第一次全教会会议。会议上有一些重要的问题，最引人注目的是耶稣和父神之间的关系。与会者还就一些较小的问题达成了共识，从自我阉割（禁止）到教会中的地位（批准），再到高利贷（不鼓励）。这些裁决被统称为《尼西亚信条》。15

The canon on usury restricted itself to the role of certain clergy, “motivated by greed and a desire for gain,” 16in the lending of money. The specificity of the ruling — it documents a routine monthly rate of return of 1 percent — suggests that more than a few clerics had turned loan shark. The council determined that in the future any cleric who tried to earn a little discretionary income as a usurer was “to be deposed and removed from his order.” Of note, the council based its prohibition not on anything Jesus had said or done, but on David’s description of the good man in Psalm 15: “He that putteth not out his money to usury, nor taketh reward against the innocent” (v. 5).

关于高利贷的教规只限于某些神职人员的作用，“出于贪婪和对利益的渴望” 。 16在借贷方面。该裁决的特殊性 —— 它记录了 1% 的常规月回报率 —— 表明不止几个神职人员变成了放高利贷者。理事会决定，今后任何试图作为高利贷者赚取一点可支配收入的教士都 “将被罢免并从他的教团中除名”。值得注意的是，理事会的禁令不是基于耶稣所说或所做的任何事情，而是基于大卫在《诗篇》第 15 篇中对好人的描述 ：“他不拿出钱来放高利贷，也不对无辜的人收取报酬” （第 5 节）。

Twenty years later, the Council of Carthage extended the usury sanction, calling the practice reprehensible. That same council reinforced the outright prohibition on the clergy doing the same. A century after Carthage, the Council of Arles II upped the ante on usurious clergy to excommunication.

20 年后，迦太基会议扩大了对高利贷的制裁，称这种做法应受到谴责。该会议还加强了对神职人员做同样事情的彻底禁止。迦太基会议之后的一个世纪，阿尔勒二世会议将对高利贷神职人员的处罚提高到了开除教籍。

One of the first of the church fathers to pay serious attention to usury was St. Ambrose, a fourth-century bishop of Milan and one of four significant early church doctors. His election to the bishopric shows just how inchoate the Catholic Church was in these first few centuries. A student of the law and a consular prefect, Ambrose attended a meeting after the death of the reigning bishop at which the quasi-heretical Arians were contending with the Catholic hierarchy over the succession. So persuasive was his call to order at this turbulent meeting that the participants elected the reluctant Ambrose bishop by acclaim. In that he had never been baptized, let alone ordained a priest, the election took him rather by surprise.

最早认真关注高利贷问题的教父之一是圣安布罗斯，他是四世纪米兰的主教，也是四个重要的早期教会医生之一。他被选为主教表明，在最初的几个世纪里，天主教会是多么的不成熟。安布罗斯是一名法律系学生，也是一名执政官，他参加了在位主教去世后的一次会议，会上准异端阿里教派与天主教高层争夺继承权。在这次动荡的会议上，他对秩序的呼吁是如此有说服力，以至于与会者以鼓掌方式选举不情愿的安布罗斯为主教。由于他从未接受过洗礼，更不用说被任命为牧师了，这次选举让他颇感意外。

Once elected, however, Ambrose made the best of his new position. He gave away his land and money to the poor, got himself baptized and ordained, and chose to not marry, the last still an option for Catholic clergy. A serious intellectual, he addressed himself to the hot theological issues of the day, including usury, which he defined as “whatever exceeds the amount loaned.”

然而，一旦当选，安布罗斯就把他的新职位发挥到极致。他把自己的土地和钱财捐给了穷人，让自己接受洗礼和任命，并选择不结婚，最后一项仍是天主教神职人员的选择。作为一个严肃的知识分子，他致力于解决当时热门的神学问题，包括高利贷，他把高利贷定义为 “超过贷款金额的任何东西”

。

Although he condemned usury in general, Ambrose was the first known Christian intellectual to address the seeming double standard on display in Deuteronomy. In hisDe Tobia, written in AD 377, he confirmed that it was, in fact, appropriate to extract usury from strangers, presuming they were the enemy in a just war. “Ubi jus belli, ibi etiam jus usuras,” he wrote somewhat famously — “Therefore, where there is the right of war, there also is the right of usury.”

虽然他普遍谴责高利贷，但安布罗斯是第一个解决《申命记》中所展示的看似双重标准的已知基督教知识分子。在他写于公元 377 年的De Tobia中他确认，事实上，“向陌生人索取高利贷是适当的，假定他们是正义战争中的敌人” （Ubi jus belli, ibi etiam jus usuras）。他写道 ：“因此，在有战争权的地方，也有放高利贷的权利。”

Ambrose’s interpretation of Deuteronomy may well have shaped his controversial role in the attacks on non-Christians in the second half of the fourth century. Flexing their muscles as the empire’s increasingly dominant religious group, Christians began the work of tearing down pagan temples and, soon enough, turned their ire on the Jews as well.

安布罗斯对《申命记》的解释很可能决定了他在四世纪下半叶对非基督徒的攻击中扮演的有争议的角色。作为帝国日益占主导地位的宗教团体，基督教徒开始了拆毁异教庙宇的工作，并很快将他们的愤怒转向了犹太人。

Although the Jews as a group were relatively wealthy, and conspicuously so, there is little hard evidence that the Christians attacked them at this stage because of their role as moneylenders. There was enough lingering resentment about the Jews’ presumed role in the empire’s earlier Christian persecutions to stoke Christian rage — that and the Jews’ continued denial of the divinity of Christ.17

尽管犹太人作为一个群体是比较富有的，而且很显眼，但几乎没有确凿的证据表明基督徒在这个阶段攻击他们是因为他们作为放债人的角色。对于犹太人在帝国早期的基督教迫害中被认为扮演的角色，有足够的怨恨挥之不去，激起了基督徒的愤怒 —— 以及犹太人对基督神性的持续否定。17

And yet the usury question could not have been too far below the surface. As early as the first century AD, Jewish philosophers like Philo were warning about the potential blowback from a practice that could fairly be interpreted as hostile, an interpretation at which Ambrose had himself arrived. Whatever his motive, when the emperor Theodosius I ordered a mideastern bishop to rebuild a synagogue his congregants had burned down, Ambrose intervened on behalf of the bishop, ultimately convincing the emperor that religious fervor trumps civil law.18In response to the much-asked question “What would Jesus have done?” a safe answer would have been, “Something different.”

然而，高利贷问题不可能处于表面之下太远。早在公元一世纪，像斐洛这样的犹太哲学家就警告说，这种做法有可能被解释为敌意，安布罗斯自己也是这样解释的，不管他的动机是什么，当皇帝狄奥多西一世命令一个中东主教重建他的教徒烧毁的犹太教堂时，安布罗斯代表主教进行了干预，最终说服了皇帝，宗教热情胜过民法。18在回答 “耶稣会怎么做？” 这个被广泛问及的问题时，一个安全的答案是 ：“不同的做法。”

。

four Master of Those Who Know 智者们的大师

TODAY, PERHAPS THE ONLY POSITIVE THING THAT SCHOOLCHILDREN ARE encouraged to believe about the otherwise genocidal Christopher Columbus is his insistence that the earth was round. This distinguished him from the flat-earth crowd who, the students learn, ruled Christendom in the benighted Middle Ages. At a putative higher level of education, students are told that the semibarbaric Christians had driven the enlightened Muslims out of their Andalusian paradise and sunk Iberia and the rest of Europe into another half millennium of darkness before the first rays of the Enlightenment began to pierce through the papist clouds.

今天，也许学校鼓励学生相信的关于克里斯托弗·哥伦布的唯一积极的事情是他坚持认为地球是圆的。这使他有别于平地人，学生们知道，持有平地认知的人在愚昧的中世纪统治着基督教世界。在一个所谓的更高的教育水平上，学生们被告知，在启蒙运动的第一缕阳光开始穿透教皇的云层之前，半野蛮的基督徒已经把开明的穆斯林赶出了他们的安达卢西亚天堂，并使伊比利亚和欧洲其他地区陷入了另一个五百年的黑暗。

This is scarcely an overstatement. Consider the following passage from mainstream historian Daniel Boorstin, then the librarian of the United States Congress, in his 1983 best seller,The Discoverers:

这几乎是一种夸张的说法。请看主流历史学家丹尼尔·博斯廷（Daniel Boorstin）在其 1983 年的畅销书《发现者》（The Discoverers）中的以下一段话:

A Europe-wide phenomenon of scholarly amnesia . . . afflicted the continent from AD 300 to at least 1300. During those centuries Christian faith and dogma suppressed the useful image of the world that had been so slowly, so painfully, and so scrupulously drawn by ancient geographers.1

从公元 300 年到至少 1300 年，一种全欧洲的学术失忆现象…… 困扰着整个欧洲大陆。在那几个世纪里，基督教信仰和教条压制了古代地理学家缓慢地、痛苦地、严谨地绘制的有用的世界图像。1

Boorstin was merely advancing an orthodoxy that has been alive and well for the last four centuries and that has truly flourished in this, our glorious multicultural moment. The early philosophers of the modern era set the tone with a vengeance. Shakespeare’s contemporary, the scientist Francis Bacon, placed the preceding European centuries among the “deserts and wastes in times as in countries.” The Baconian brand of thinking has lead directly to the kind of creepy caricatures of the Middle Ages seen in the opening of Michael Radford’sMerchant of Venice, discussed earlier. It also distorts our whole understanding of the eventual lifting of the usury ban, which is not nearly as simple as the enlightened escape from medieval shackles it is made out to be.

博斯廷只是在推进一种正统观念，这种观念在过去的四个世纪里一直生机勃勃，并且在我们这个光荣的多元文化时刻真正得到了发展。现代的早期哲学家们以一种报复性的方式确定了基调。与莎士比亚同时代的科学家弗朗西斯·培根（Francis Bacon）将之前的欧洲几个世纪表述为 “在时间上和国家上都是沙漠和荒芜”。培根式的思维方式直接导致了迈克尔·拉德福德的《威尼斯商人》开篇中的那种令人毛骨悚然的中世纪漫画。前面讨论过。它还扭曲了我们对最终解除高利贷禁令的整个理解，这并不像人们所说的那样简单，是对中世纪桎梏的开明的摆脱。

As commonly used, the nounMiddle Agesor the adjectivemedievaldescribes the period from the fall of Rome to the birth of the modern, roughly AD 500 to AD 1500 or 1600. No period is as misunderstood. Yes, it did get off to a rough start. This sometimes happens when successive waves of savage tribes overrun a declining civilization. The first few centuries after Rome’s demise saw a decline in scholarship, a general breakdown in the civic order, and a scramble to survive the tribal realignments that had unsettled Europe. The one stabilizing, centralizing force in these first few centuries was the church, but church fathers, the occasional edict notwithstanding, had more pressing matters than to establish and enforce usury laws.

按照通常的用法，名词 “中世纪” 或形容词 “中世纪的” 描述了从罗马的衰落到现代的诞生，大概是公元 500 年到公元 1500 年或 1600 年这段时间。没有哪个时期是被如此这般误解的。的确，它有一个艰难的开始。当一波又一波的野蛮部落占领了一个衰落的文明时，这种情况有时会发生。在罗马灭亡后的头几个世纪，学术水平下降，公民秩序普遍崩溃，人们争先恐后地在使欧洲不安的部落重组中生存。在这最初的几个世纪中，唯一稳定、集中的力量是教会，但教会的教父们，尽管偶尔有一些法令，但他们有比制定和执行高利贷法律更紧迫的事情。

More critical for the history of usury law, although indirectly so, was the fact that Islamic tribes had swept out of the Arabian Peninsula and were establishing hegemony over a broad sweep of the known world from Persia to Iberia. As the culture of Islam matured, its scholars discovered and sought to preserve the works of the great Greek philosophers housed in libraries in Egypt, Syria, Mesopotamia, and elsewhere. They translated these works into Arabic, commented upon them freely, and sometimes expanded on their findings. Said the revered ninth-century Muslim philosopher Al-Kindi of his respect for the Greek heritage, “It would have been impossible for us, despite all our zeal, during the whole of our lifetime, to assemble these principles of truth which form the basis of the final inferences of our research.” 2

对于高利贷法律的历史来说，更关键的是，虽然是间接的，但伊斯兰部落已经走出阿拉伯半岛，并在从波斯到伊比利亚的广大已知世界上建立了霸权。随着伊斯兰文化的成熟，它的学者们发现并试图保存存放在埃及、叙利亚、美索不达米亚和其他地方的图书馆中的伟大希腊哲学家的作品。他们将这些作品翻译成阿拉伯语，对其进行自由评论，有时还对他们的发现进行扩展。尊敬的九世纪穆斯林哲学家阿尔·金迪在谈到他对希腊遗产的尊重时说 ：“尽管我们有很大的热情，但在我们的一生中，不可能把这些构成我们研究的最终推论基础的真理原则集合起来。” 2

Arabs had also ventured into India. There, while still in their culturally curious stage, they had come across the essential building block of modern commerce, the Indian numbering system, including the magical “zero.” This system would have at least as much liberating power on the development of a credit-based culture as any shift in law or faith.

阿拉伯人也曾冒险进入印度。在那里，当他们还处于文化上的好奇阶段时，他们发现了现代商业的基本组成部分，即印度的数字系统，包括神奇的 “零”。这个系统对基于信用的文化的发展所产生的解放力量至少不亚于法律或信仰的任何转变。

Yet for all the glories of the Islamic breakout, the culture had some inherent restraints that would become obvious soon enough. Until modern times, for instance, only its mathematicians used Arabic numerals. Muslim scientists used a Babylonian system, and merchants used still another system based on the Arabic alphabet. As was true for Greek science and philosophy as well as for Indian numbers, the Arabs did the preserving and transmitting; the Europeans would do the exploiting and transforming.

然而，尽管伊斯兰爆发了的那么多荣耀，但这种文化有一些固有的限制，很快就会变得很明显。例如，直到近代，只有其数学家使用阿拉伯数字。穆斯林科学家使用的是巴比伦系统，而商人使用的则是基于阿拉伯字母的另一种系统。正如希腊科学和哲学以及印度数字一样，阿拉伯人负责保存和传播；欧洲人负责利用和改造。

For any number of reasons, global warming high among them, trade and commerce had once again come alive in Europe. One trader’s son, Leonardo Fibonacci of Pisa, would make so stunning a contribution to this commerce it is hard to believe he remains unsung. As a young man, Fibonacci traveled to North Africa to help his father work his trading post. There he first became acquainted with the Hindu-Arabic numbering system. Sensing its superiority over the clumsy Roman numerals the West was still using, Fibonacci began a serious study under some of the leading Arab mathematicians throughout the Mediterranean world.

由于各种原因，其中以全球变暖为首，贸易和商业在欧洲再次活跃起来。一个商人的儿子，比萨的莱昂纳多·斐波纳契，将对这种商业做出惊人的贡献，很难相信他仍然默默无闻。年轻时，斐波那契前往北非，帮助他父亲在贸易站工作。在那里，他第一次认识了印度·阿拉伯数字系统。感受到它比西方仍在使用的笨拙的罗马数字的优越性，斐波纳契开始在整个地中海世界的一些领先的阿拉伯数学家手下认真学习。

In his 1202 treatiseLiber Abaci, Fibonacci introduced what he accurately called themodus Indorum(method of the Indians) to Europe. Given his father’s background, Fibonacci took pains to show the system’s potential not just for higher math but for everyday business calculations. Indeed, the cool new numbers made calculating interest and the compounding thereof much easier. Merchants and scholars both embraced the new math. It helped expedite the commercial revolution already underway and launch the scientific revolution that was to come. It also, alas, helped to enable fraud. Turning a 0 into a 6 or a 1 into a 4 was as tempting in Florence as it is on Wall Street. In 1229, concerned about fraud, Florence prohibited bankers from using the “infidel” symbols, but commerce, as always, found a way around regressive regulation.3

在他 1202 年的论文Liber Abaci中，斐波纳契准确地称其为modus Indorum（印度人的方法）的方法，并将其引入欧洲介绍给大家。考虑到他父亲的背景，斐波纳契不遗余力地展示了这个系统的潜力，不仅适用于高等数学，也适用于日常商业计算。事实上，这些很酷的新数字使计算利息和复利变得更加容易。商人和学者都接受了这种新的数学方法。它帮助加快了已经进行的商业革命，并启动了即将到来的科学革命。不幸的是，它也有助于实现欺诈。在佛罗伦萨，把 0 变成 6，把 1 变成 4，就像在华尔街一样诱人。1229 年，出于对欺诈行为的担忧，佛罗伦萨禁止银行家使用 “异教徒” 符号，但商业总是能找到绕过倒退法规的方法。3

A historic turning point on the scientific front, rarely given its due, had taken place a few years earlier in Toledo. The Christian knights of theReconquistaperiod had lately — and rather civilly — repossessed the city from its Islamic placeholders. There, in the city’s cathedral, a polyglot crew of Muslim, Jewish, and Christian scholars labored away in surprising harmony, translating into Latin the works of the great Greek philosophers that had earlier been translated into Arabic.

在此之前几年，在托莱多发生了科学战线上的一个历史性转折点，这个转折点很少被重视。十字军东征时期的基督教骑士们刚从 —— 而且相当文明地 —— 从伊斯兰教徒手中夺回了这座城市。在那里，在城市的大教堂里，由穆斯林、犹太教和基督教学者组成的多语种团队在令人惊讶的和谐中努力工作，将早先被翻译成阿拉伯语的伟大希腊哲学家的作品翻译成拉丁语。

Richard Rubenstein, author of the impressiveAristotle’s Childrenand not likely a Catholic apologist, calls the eventual outcome of this gathering “an acute source of embarrassment” for many modernists.4As it happened, Jews and Muslims would turn their backs on this treasure trove of admittedly pagan scholarship, and “farsighted popes and bishops therefore took the fateful step that Islamic leaders had rejected.” 5Not without a few speed bumps en route, the Catholic Church rode away with the goods. Historian Edward Grant calls the medieval Christian renaissance that ensued “the best kept secret of Western civilization.” 6

理查德·鲁宾斯坦，令人印象深刻的《亚里士多德的孩子》一书的作者，也不可能是天主教辩护士。而且不可能是天主教的辩护人，他称这样的聚集的最终结果对许多现代主义者来说是 “一个严重的尴尬来源”。4果不其然，犹太人和穆斯林背弃了这个公认的异教学术宝库，而 “有远见的教皇和主教们因此采取了伊斯兰领导人所拒绝的决定命运的步骤”。5在这一过程中，天主教会并非没有遇到一些障碍，但它还是带着他们战利品全身而退。历史学家爱德华·格兰特将随之而来的中世纪基督教文艺复兴称为 “西方文明中保存得最好的秘密”。6

One of the rediscovered scholars so loomed above all the others that his acolytes in the next few centuries would refer to him simply as “the Philosopher.” Dante had come across the Philosopher in the first circle of the Inferno, the one reserved for those good souls who had never gotten to know Jesus. “I raised my eyes a little,” writes Dante, “and there was he who is acknowledged Master of those who know, sitting in a philosophic family who look to him and do him honor.” 7Among a cast that included Plato, Socrates, Democritus, Zeno, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, Thales, Heraclitus, Diogenes, and other pagan wise men, it was Aristotle who held center stage. The reader does well to recall that Dante was a devout Christian writing in the first decade of the 1300s. He and his readers proved immune to the “Europe-wide phenomenon of scholarly amnesia.”

其中一位被重新发现的学者是如此的高高在上，以至于在接下来的几个世纪里，他的追随者会把他简单地称为 “哲学家”。但丁在《地狱》的第一个层里遇到了这位哲学家，这个圈子是为那些从未认识过耶稣的善良灵魂保留的。但丁写道 ：“当我把眼皮抬得稍高时，我看到智者们的大师，坐在一群哲学家的中间。大家注视他；大家尊崇他” （取自朱维基的译文）7在包括柏拉图、苏格拉底、德谟克利特、芝诺、恩培多克勒、阿那克萨戈拉、泰勒斯、赫拉克利特、第欧根尼和其他异教智者在内的演员中，亚里士多德占据了中心位置。读者不妨回顾一下，但丁是一个虔诚的基督徒，他在 13 世纪的第一个十年里写作。事实证明，他和他的读者对 “欧洲范围内的学术失忆现象” 是全无知晓。

Some three thousand pages of Aristotle’s wisdom had been retrieved through the Islamic connection, not just philosophy as we understand it, but also his insights into biology, physics, logic, political science, and, yes, even usury. Give Jesus Christ his due as history’s most influential figure, but the case could be made for Aristotle as number two. On the subject of usury, however, Aristotle may have had even more influence than Jesus.

通过伊斯兰教的联系，亚里士多德的智慧被检索出来了，不仅仅是我们所理解的哲学，还有他对生物学、物理学、逻辑学、政治学以及，是的，甚至高利贷的见解。作为历史上最有影响力的人物，给耶稣基督以应有的地位，但亚里士多德作为第二名也是有道理的。然而，在高利贷的问题上，亚里士多德的影响可能比耶稣还要大。

Writing in the fourth century before Christ, Aristotle’s empirical research has held up reasonably well over the centuries. In his treatiseOn the Heavens, for instance, Aristotle affirmed the correct shape of the earth more than eighteen hundred years before Columbus. “In eclipses the outline is always curved,” he writes. “And since it is the interposition of the earth that makes the eclipse, the form of this line will be caused by the form of the earth’s surface, which is therefore spherical.” 8This bit of wisdom, by the way, was not lost with the fall of Rome. Even in the early Middle Ages, the dominant textbooks supported the spherical nature of the earth. In thePurgatariosection of hisDivine Comedy, Dante casually alludes to the curvature of the earth with his discussion of time zones and his recognition of the Southern Hemisphere’s distinct perspective on the sun and stars. The canard that these early Christians thought the earth flat did not emerge until the post-Darwinian nineteenth century and was employed then, as now, as a way of slandering Christian scholars.

写于公元前四世纪，亚里士多德的经验研究在几个世纪以来一直保持得相当好。在他的论文《论天》（On the Heavens）中，亚里士多德的经验研究在几个世纪以来保持得相当好。例如，亚里士多德在哥伦布之前一千八百多年就肯定了地球的正确形状。他写道 ：“在日蚀中，轮廓总是弯曲的”，他说。“由于是地球的介入使得日食发生，这条线条的形式将由地球表面的形式引起，因此它是球形的。” 8顺便说一下，这一点智慧并没有随着罗马的衰落而消失。即使在中世纪早期，主流的教科书也支持地球的球形性质。在他的《神曲》中，但丁随口就提到了地球的球形性质。但丁在讨论时区和承认南半球对太阳和星星的独特视角时，随口暗示了地球的曲率。这些早期基督徒认为地球是平的这一说法直到达尔文主义之后的十九世纪才出现，而且当时和现在一样，被用作诽谤基督教学者的一种方式。

To be sure, there were many points on which the views of Aristotle diverged from those of the monotheists gathered at Toledo. Where Christian scholars found common ground with Aristotle was in their shared belief in an ethical, perfectly ordered universe. What attracted them to Aristotle in particular was his ability to use reason to discern that order.9These scholars wondered whether they could marry Aristotelian reason to faith to help them locate a Christian God as the source of that order. What is more, unlike their Jewish and Islamic brethren, the Christian scholars worked within a monolithic church structure. If they could convince their superiors of Aristotle’s value, that whole monolith just might embrace his work. In any case, they could not be easily marginalized.
