可以肯定的是，亚里士多德的观点与聚集在托莱多的一神论者的观点有很多不同之处。基督教学者与亚里士多德的共同点在于他们对一个有道德的、完全有序的宇宙的共同信念。特别是亚里士多德吸引他们的地方是他用理性来辨别这种秩序的能力。9这些学者想知道他们是否能将亚里士多德的理性与信仰结合起来，以帮助他们将基督教的上帝定位为该秩序的来源。更重要的是，与他们的犹太教和伊斯兰教兄弟不同，基督教学者在一个单一的教会结构中工作。如果他们能说服他们的上级相信亚里士多德的价值，那么整个铁板就可能接受他的作品。在任何情况下，他们都不会轻易被边缘化。

One other new tool for educating ordinary citizens in the simple elegance of God’s order was the clock. In the thirteenth century, mechanical clocks began to show up in Europe, most prominently on churches. Church fathers used them not only to get parishioners to church on time, but also to reinforce the rationality of God’s universe. Although not obvious at the time, clocks would lead to the commoditization of time, and the understanding, most succinctly phrased by Ben Franklin, that “time is money.” 10

另外一个教育普通公民了解上帝秩序的简单优雅的新工具是时钟。十三世纪，机械钟开始在欧洲出现，最突出的是在教堂上。教父们使用它们不仅是为了让教友们准时去教堂，也是为了加强上帝宇宙的合理性。虽然在当时并不明显，但时钟将导致时间的商品化，以及本·富兰克林最简洁的说法，即 “时间就是金钱” 的理解。10

Clocks, of course, also added precision to the commercial revolution in progress, and commerce helped spread the word about Aristotle. Increased commerce, however, also renewed concerns about the practice of usury. At the second Lateran Council in 1139, Pope Innocent II did not exactly mince words in describing usury as “detestable and disgraceful rapacity condemned by human and divine law alike.” 11At the Council of Tours in 1163, Pope Alexander III expanded the definition of usury to include any sale on credit in which the accumulative price was higher than the cash price. In 1179, Alexander III argued that usurers should not only be excommunicated but also be denied a Christian burial. In 1187, Pope Urban III reaffirmed the position taken by his predecessors, this time basing his objection to usury on Christ’s counsel in Luke 6:35, “lend, hoping for nothing again.”

当然，钟表也为正在进行的商业革命增加了精确性，商业也有助于传播亚里士多德的信息。然而，商业的增加也重新引起了人们对高利贷行为的关注。在 1139 年的第二次拉特兰会议上，教皇英诺森二世毫不吝啬地将高利贷描述为 “被人类和神圣的法律所谴责的可恶和可耻的掠夺行为”。11在 1163 年的图尔会议上，教皇亚历山大三世扩大了高利贷的定义，包括任何累计价格高于现金价格的赊销。1179 年，亚历山大三世认为，高利贷者不仅应该被逐出教会，还应该被剥夺基督徒的葬礼。1187 年，教皇乌尔班三世重申了他的前任所采取的立场，这次他反对高利贷的依据是基督在路加福音 6:35 中的忠告 ：“借给人不指望偿还”。

All the while these popes were weighing in on the usury question, Aristotle’s wisdom was spreading about as quickly as it could in a world where even an “instant message” could take weeks to deliver. By the beginning of the thirteenth century, his books were being read and taught at the nascent European universities, particularly at that hotbed of radicalism, the University of Paris. Today’s students could not begin to imagine the intellectual fervor of their medieval counterparts. If debate ranged within certain accepted Christian boundaries, those boundaries were at least as expansive and no more “correct” than those of the typical American university. The early modernist attempt to deny the intellectual progress of this period astounds. Indeed, Rubenstein compares it to “the rewriting of history that we associate with Stalinism in the Soviet Union — the ‘airbrushing’ out of figures and events embarrassing to the current regime.” 12

在这些教皇对高利贷问题进行权衡的同时，亚里士多德的智慧在一个连 “即时信息” 都需要几周才能送达的世界里，正以最快的速度传播。到十三世纪初，他的书在新兴的欧洲大学，特别是在激进主义的温床巴黎大学被阅读和教授。今天的学生无法想象他们的中世纪同龄人的知识热情。如果说辩论是在某些公认的基督教界限内进行的，那么这些界限至少和典型的美国大学的界限一样宽泛，而且不比它们更 “正确”。早期现代主义者试图否认这一时期的知识进步，令人震惊。事实上，鲁宾斯坦把它比作 “我们与苏联的斯大林主义有关的历史改写 —— 即，‘刷掉’令现政权尴尬的人物和事件。” 12

Then, as always in the Western world, push meant push back. Throughout Christendom, there was mounting pressure on church officials to ban the arguably heretical works of the inarguably pagan Aristotle, much as those works were already being censored in the Muslim world.

然后，像西方世界一样，推动意味着反击。在整个基督教世界，教会官员面临着越来越大的压力，要求禁止无可争议的异教徒亚里士多德的可能的异端作品，正如这些作品在穆斯林世界已经被审查一样。

The issue moved front and center at the Fourth Lateran Council convened by Pope Innocent III in 1215 and died there. The founder of the order that bore his name, Domingo de Guzman (known to history as St. Dominic), argued successfully that the reasoning of Aristotle was essential in the fight against heresy. And so began the century of Aristotle’s greatest ascendance, made possible in no small part due to the genius of Aristotle’s most devoted follower, the Dominican scholar Thomas Aquinas.

这个问题在教皇英诺森三世于 1215 年召开的第四届拉特兰会议上走到了前台和中心，并在那里死去。以他的名字命名的教团的创始人多明戈·德·古斯曼（历史上称为圣多米尼克）成功地论证了亚里士多德的推理在打击异端方面是必不可少的。就这样，亚里士多德最辉煌的世纪开始了，这在很大程度上要归功于亚里士多德最忠实的追随者 —— 多米尼加学者托马斯·阿奎那斯的天才之作。

In the way of background, Thomas had grown up in the hill country between Naples and Rome, the son of an ambitious nobleman. His father had sent Thomas to be educated by the monks with the expectation that his bright son would quickly ascend the church hierarchy and help accommodate family ambitions. At the University of Naples, however, Thomas encountered the fresh Aristotelian breeze blowing in from the Arab world and liked the feel of it. What Aquinas pulled from Aristotle was that reason ought to be embraced, not feared. He came to believe, as Aristotle did, that a rational man could make sense of the world through his experience. By reflecting upon that experience, man could discern the causes that shape existence. To find these first causes, Aristotle argued, and Aquinas agreed, should be the whole object of man’s knowledge.13

在背景方面，托马斯在那不勒斯和罗马之间的山地长大，是一个雄心勃勃的贵族的儿子。他的父亲把托马斯送到僧侣那里接受教育，期望他聪明的儿子能迅速登上教会的等级，帮助满足家族的野心。然而，在那不勒斯大学，托马斯遇到了从阿拉伯世界吹来的亚里士多德的新风，并喜欢这种感觉。阿奎那斯从亚里士多德那里得到的启示是，理性应该被拥抱，而不是被恐惧。他开始相信，正如亚里士多德所做的那样，一个理性的人可以通过他的经验来理解这个世界。通过对这种经验的反思，人可以辨别出塑造存在的原因。亚里士多德认为，找到这些最初的原因，阿奎那斯也同意，应该是人类知识的全部目标。13

The Dominicans’ enthusiasm for intellectual exchange inspired Thomas to join this ascetic, unworldly order. This move so displeased his worldly father that he had Thomas’s brothers kidnap the precocious lad and hold him under something like house arrest for two years while the family tried to break his will. When the father finally relented, Thomas fled directly to the Dominicans in Paris.

多米尼加人对知识交流的热情激发了托马斯加入这个禁欲主义、不谙世事的组织。这一举动让他的世俗父亲非常不满，他让托马斯的兄弟们绑架了这个早熟的孩子，并将他软禁了两年，同时家人试图打破他的意志。当父亲终于松口时，托马斯直接逃到了巴黎的多米尼加人那里。

The stolid Thomas so kept his own counsel at the university that his fellow students took to calling him the Dumb Ox, but those who watched Thomas up close knew otherwise. His mentor, the Dominican scientist and philosopher Albertus Magnus, chastised Thomas’s classmates, saying, “You call him a Dumb Ox; I tell you this Dumb Ox shall bellow so loud that his bellowings will fill the world.” 14If anything, Thomas exceeded Albert’s expectations.

呆板的托马斯在大学里一直保持着自己的想法，以至于他的同学们都称他为 “笨牛”，但那些近距离观察托马斯的人却不知道。他的导师，多米尼加科学家和哲学家阿尔伯特·马格努斯（Albertus Magnus）责备托马斯的同学说 ：“你们叫他笨牛；我告诉你们，这头笨牛将大声吼叫，他的吼声将充满整个世界”。14如果有什么的话，托马斯超过了阿尔伯特的预期。

In Thomas’s time, despite the papal edicts of the previous century, lending at interest remained, at the street level at least, a lively subject of debate. The best evidence for its still unsettled nature can be found in the usury chapter in Thomas’s masterwork, the unfinishedSumma Theologica. At the outset he poses the question of “whether it is a sin to take usury for money lent” 15and then lays out a series of popular objections to that premise. Relentlessly fair, Thomas makes a good case for the opposition. Alluding to Deuteronomy, he wonders how it could be sinful to lend money to one’s brother but not to a stranger, or how could it be wrong to follow a civil law if that law allows usury, or how one erred by accepting something that is freely given, or whether the Lord’s counsel in Luke 6:35 — “lend, hoping for nothing again” —— was “binding” or merely just good advice.

在托马斯的时代，尽管有上个世纪的教皇诏书，但至少在大街上，借贷利息仍然是一个活跃的辩论主题。在托马斯的代表作，即未完成的《神学概要》中的高利贷章节中，可以找到这种悬而未决的最好证据。在一开始，他就提出了一个问题 ：“为借出的钱收取高利贷是否是一种罪？” 15然后对这个前提提出了一系列流行的反对意见。托马斯不遗余力地保持公正，为反对意见提供了很好的理由。在提到《申命记》时，他想知道把钱借给自己的兄弟而不借给陌生人怎么会是有罪的，或者如果民法允许高利贷，那么遵循民法怎么会是错误的，或者接受自由给予的东西怎么会是错误的，或者主在《路加福音》（6:35）中的建议 —— “借给人不指望偿还” —— 是否有 “约束力” 或者仅仅是好建议。

The problem, as orthodox Catholic scholars like Thomas Woods and John Noonan concede, is that Thomas’s response to his own objections is not particularly convincing. Here, his fondness for Aristotle seems to betray him. Rather critically for the history of Western commerce, Aristotle deeply disliked the whole practice of usury. But unlike the Jewish and Christian scholars before him who had objected to usury over social justice concerns, Aristotle objected largely on the issue of taste. In theNichomachean Ethics, he compares usurers to “those who ply sordid trades, pimps and all such people” and scolds them all for the “sordid love of gain.” 16This sentiment, to be sure, has lost no currency.

问题是，正如托马斯·伍兹和约翰·努南等正统的天主教学者所承认的，托马斯对他自己的反对意见的回应并不特别令人信服。在这里，他对亚里士多德的喜爱似乎出卖了他。对于西方商业史来说，亚里士多德深深地不喜欢整个高利贷的做法，这一点相当关键。但与他之前的犹太和基督教学者不同的是，亚里士多德反对高利贷是出于社会正义的考虑，他反对的主要是品味问题。在《尼古马科伦理学》（Nichomachean Ethics）中，他将 “高利贷者” 比作 “那些从事肮脏交易的人、皮条客和所有这些人”，并斥责他们都是 “对利益的肮脏的爱”。16可以肯定的是，这种情绪并没有消失。

For Aristotle, the charging of interest was not only unseemly but also unnatural. So he argues in hisPolitics: “Very much disliked also is the practice of charging interest; and the dislike is fully justified, for the gain arises out of the currency itself, not as a product of that for which the currency was provided.” 17He elaborates that the Greek word for usury,tokos, means “offspring,” as we have previously noted. As each animal produces its like, so “interest is currency born of currency.” This he finds “most contrary to nature.” 18In Dante’sInferno, it should be recalled, Virgil contends that it is usury’s unnatural character that provokes God to place usurers in hell’s seventh circle. He cites only two sources to make this argument: Genesis and Aristotle’sPhysics.

对于亚里士多德来说，收取利息不仅是不体面的，也是不自然的。所以他在他的《政治学》（Politics）中论述道: “非常不喜欢收取利息的做法；这种不喜欢是完全有道理的，因为收益出自货币本身，而不是作为所提供货币的产出。” 17他阐述了高利贷的希腊语单词tokos的意思是 “后代”，正如我们之前所指出的那样。正如每一种动物都会生出自己的同类，所以 “利息是货币所生的货币”。这一点，恰恰是亚里士多德觉得最违逆大自然的地方。18在但丁的《地狱》中，我们应该记得，维吉尔认为，正是高利贷的非自然特性才激起了上帝将高利贷者置于地狱的第七层。他只引用了两个来源来进行这一论证。《创世纪》和亚里士多德的《物理学》。

“Study yourPhysicswell,” Virgil tells Dante, “and you’ll be shown in not too many pages that your art’s good is to follow Nature insofar as it can.” 19In other words, work with your hands or work the land; don’t let money work for you. Aristotle’s works carried so much weight that smart Christians like Dante echoed his thoughts even when they did not fully understand them. Seventh circle or not, no sin in theInfernohas less moral resonance than usury. By subtracting issues of justice and morality and even fairness from the usury equation, Aristotle rested his thesis solely on the flouting of nature, and it did not add up.

“好好学习你的《物理学》吧”，维吉尔告诉但丁，“你会挺多篇幅中看到，你（创作）的艺术之善来自于尽可能地遵循自然。” 19换句话说，用你的双手工作或耕种土地；不要让钱为你工作。亚里士多德的作品具有如此大的分量，以至于像但丁这样聪明的基督徒都赞同他的思想，即使他们并不完全理解这些思想。不管是不是第七层，《地狱》中的任何罪恶都没有高利贷的道德共鸣大。通过从高利贷的方程式中减去正义和道德甚至公平的问题，亚里士多德将他的论点完全建立在从自然产生的蔑视上，但，这并不符合事实。

In the twentieth century, the poet Ezra Pound tried to clarify Aristotle’s objection in his poem “With Usura,” but his cockeyed economics only distorted the picture. Not unlike Aristotle, Pound considers usury a “sin against nature,” but he somehow comes to the conclusion that “with usura is no clear demarcation / and no man can find site for his dwelling.” 20

在二十世纪，诗人埃兹拉·庞德试图在他的诗作《与乌苏拉》中阐明亚里士多德的反对意见，但他那狂妄直达的经济学（知识）只是扭曲了画面。与亚里士多德没什么不同，庞德认为高利贷是一种 “违反自然的罪恶”，但他不知不觉地得出了这样的结论 ：“高利贷没有明确的分界线/没有（背负着高利贷的）人能够找到他的住所。” 20

Pound almost perfectly misunderstood the consequences of credit unleashed. As shall be seen, too many people would find their way into too many dwellings.

庞德几乎完美地误解了信贷释放的后果。正如我们将看到的那样，太多的人将会找到他们的方式，进入太多的住宅。

Aquinas wrote hisSumma Theologicajust one generation before Dante wrote hisDivine Comedyand proved at least as dependent on the economic wisdom of Aristotle as Dante had been:

阿奎那斯（Aquinas）写他的《神学概要》（Summa Theologica）仅仅比但丁写他的《神曲》早一代，并证明至少像但丁那样依赖亚里士多德的经济智慧：

Now money, according to the Philosopher, was invented chiefly for the purpose of exchange: and consequently the proper and principal use of money is its consumption or alienation whereby it is sunk in exchange. Hence it is by its very nature unlawful to take payment for the use of money lent, which payment is known as usury: and just as a man is bound to restore other ill-gotten goods, so is he bound to restore the money which he has taken in usury.21

现在，根据哲学家的说法，货币的发明主要是为了交换：因此，货币的适当和主要用途是其消费或转让，从而在交换中沉没。因此，就其本质而言，为使用借出的钱而收取报酬是非法的，这种报酬被称为 “高利贷” ：正如一个人有义务归还其他不义之财一样，他也有义务归还他在高利贷中获得的钱。21

Aquinas makes the labored argument that commodities such as wine and wheat are, like money itself, sold to be consumed. “Accordingly,” he writes, “if a man wanted to sell wine separately from the use of the wine, he would be selling the same thing twice, or he would be selling what does not exist.” This, Aquinas reasons unconvincingly, would be “a sin of injustice.” A house, on the other hand, is not consumed in the use. “For this reason,” says Aquinas, “a man may lawfully make a charge for the use of his house.” 22

阿奎那斯提出了一个费力的论点，即葡萄酒和小麦等商品就像货币本身一样，是为了消费而出售的。“因此”，他写道，“如果一个人想把酒和酒的使用分开来卖，他就会把同一件东西卖掉两次，或者他是在卖不存在的东西”。阿奎那斯基于并不令人信服的理由总结说 “这属于不公正的罪”。“也是基于这个理由”，阿奎那斯说，“一个人倒是可以向别人收取房租。” 22

In his thoughtful bookThe Church and the Market, Catholic historian Thomas Woods can make no more sense out of Aquinas than the reader likely has to this point. As an exasperated Woods asks, when in all of human history has someone attempted to sell wine or wheat a second time separately from its use?23Merchants have lent money at interest, however, since the invention of money.

在他深思熟虑的书《教会与市场》中，天主教历史学家托马斯·伍兹对阿奎那斯的理解并不比读者到此为止的理解多。正如气急败坏的伍兹所问的，“在所有的人类历史中，什么时候有人试图把酒或小麦与它的使用分开来第二次出售？” 23然而，自从货币发明以来，商人们就一直以出借来收取利息。

John Noonan, an authority on scholasticism, applies a classic Catholic maxim to the usury ban:Cessante ratione, cessat ipsa lex, “When the reason for the law ceases, the law itself ceases.” 24By the thirteenth century, the reason for the ban had ceased making sense. An invigorated commerce and a newfound ability to calculate interest had made the prohibition on commercial credit obsolete.

约翰·努南（John Noonan）是学术界的权威，他将天主教的经典格言应用于高利贷禁令 ：“当法律的理由停止，法律本身也停止了。” （Cessante ratione, cessat ipsa lex）24到十三世纪，禁令的理由已经不再有意义。蓬勃发展的商业和新发现的计算利息的能力使禁止商业信贷的规定变得过时了。

Here is where Aristotle channeled the flow of history, especially as it relates to Jews. The Philosopher carried such intellectual weight among Christian scholars that if he had championed banking, the ban on usury would almost surely have faded away. Aquinas and his pals could have then put their intellects to work differentiating between predatory loans and reasonable business transactions and in the process built an integrated Christian business philosophy into which Jews could have been easily assimilated. Unfortunately, none of this happened.

这里是亚里士多德引导历史潮流的地方，尤其是在与犹太人有关的方面。这位哲学家在基督教学者中具有如此高的智力分量，如果他支持银行业务，对高利贷的禁令几乎肯定会消失。阿奎那斯和他的伙伴们可以把他们的智慧用于区分掠夺性贷款和合理的商业交易，并在这个过程中建立一个完整的基督教商业哲学，犹太人可以很容易地被同化进去。不幸的是，这一切都没有发生。

In the era of Aristotle’s ascendance, although not yet reaching the point of stereotype, the image of the Jew as usurer was firming up. This is evident in certain rulings of the Fourth Lateran Council. Convened by Pope Innocent III in 1215, this council may have given Aristotle a second life, but it dealt a near deathblow to the Jewish banking community.25

在亚里士多德上台的时代，虽然还没有达到定型的程度，但犹太人作为高利贷者的形象已经稳固下来。这在第四届拉特兰会议的某些裁决中很明显。由教皇英诺森三世在 1215 年召开的这次会议可能给了亚里士多德第二次生命，但它对犹太银行界造成了几乎致命的打击。25

By this time, church leaders had figured out that the usury ban had the practical consequence of enriching Jews. “The more Christians are restrained from the practice of usury,” reads the council’sConstitution 67, “the more they are oppressed in this matter by the treachery of the Jews, so that in a short time they exhaust the resources of the Christians.” As this language suggests, the ban was also driving a wedge between the two groups. Of note, this council ordered Christians not to boycott usurers per se, or even Jewish usurers, but those who practiced “grave and immoderate usury.” Another reference in the same text objects to “oppressive and excessive interest.” Although unspoken, there seemed to a growing sentiment that charging modest interest might not be all that sinful.

此时，教会领袖已经意识到，高利贷禁令的实际后果是让犹太人致富。议会的《宪法第 67 条》中写道 ：“基督徒越是被限制放高利贷，他们在这个问题上就越是被犹太人的背叛所压迫，以至于他们在短时间内耗尽了基督徒的资源。” 正如这一措辞所表明的，该禁令也在这两个群体之间打下了一个楔子。值得注意的是，这个议会命令基督徒不要抵制高利贷者本身，甚至不要抵制犹太高利贷者，而是抵制那些实行 “严重和不适当的高利贷” 的人。同一文本中的另一个提法是 “反对压迫性和过度的利息”。虽然没有说出来，但似乎有一种日益增长的情绪，即收取适度的利息可能并不完全是罪过。

In Greece, it was another occupation altogether that irked the Jews’ Christian neighbors. Benjamin of Tudela attests to this in his wonderfully wide-eyedBook of Travels, which recounts his journeys around the northern rim of the Mediterranean in the late twelfth century. Although Benjamin thought his fellow Jews “rich, kind, and charitable,” he acknowledges that the Greeks thought them otherwise “because of the tanners who pour out their dirty water outside their houses and thus defile the Jewish quarter.” 26How Aristotle felt about tanning is lost to history, but his hatred of usury predated the Greek hatred of Jews.

在希腊，让犹太人的基督教邻居感到恼火的完全是另一种职业。图德拉城的本杰明在他令人打开眼界的《旅行书》（Book of Travels）中证明了这一点。该书叙述了他在十二世纪末在地中海北缘的旅程。尽管本杰明认为他的犹太同胞 “富有、善良、慈善”，但他承认希腊人并不这么认为，“因为那些皮匠把他们的脏水倒在屋外，用这种方法玷污犹太区。” 26亚里士多德对制革的感受（因为气味而讨厌）已湮没在历史中，但他对高利贷的憎恨早于希腊对犹太人的仇恨。

In one other critical area, Christian scholars followed Aristotle’s lead with unfortunate consequences, at least on the public relations front. Aristotle, as it happened, believed in an earth-centered cosmos. Not all Christian scholars yielded to Aristotle’s wisdom, of course. By 1514, Nicolaus Copernicus was speculating about a heliocentric universe and was being encouraged in his research by key players in the Catholic hierarchy. More than a half century after Copernicus’s death, and armed with a powerful new telescope, Galileo Galilei began to flesh out Copernicus’s theory.

在另一个关键领域，基督教学者追随亚里士多德的步伐，造成了不幸的后果，至少是在公共关系方面。亚里士多德，正如它所发生的，相信以地球为中心的宇宙。当然，并非所有的基督教学者都屈服于亚里士多德的智慧。到 1514 年，尼古拉斯·哥白尼（Nicolaus Copernicus）正在推演一个以太阳为中心的宇宙，并且在他的研究中得到了天主教等级制度中关键人物的鼓励。在哥白尼去世半个多世纪后，伽利略·伽利莱带着强大的新望远镜，开始充实哥白尼的理论。

For the greater part of his career, Galileo enjoyed the Vatican’s support and did most of his work at church-sponsored observatories and universities.27In 1616, after one of Galileo’s rivals called in a complaint to the Inquisition, Cardinal Robert Bellarmine met with Galileo and reviewed with him the church’s position. As Bellarmine explained, Scripture seemed to argue for an earth-centered universe. In that the Catholic Church was under attack for being too lax on Scripture in this post-Reformation era, Bellarmine asked to see hard proof before the church rethought its interpretation. Galileo could continue his research, but Bellarmine asked that he not promote new findings without the church’s approval.

在他职业生涯的大部分时间里，伽利略得到了梵蒂冈的支持，他的大部分工作都是在教会赞助的天文台和大学进行的。 271616 年，在伽利略的一个对手向宗教裁判所提出申诉后，红衣主教罗伯特·贝拉明会见了伽利略，与他一起回顾了教会的立场。正如贝拉明所解释的，圣经似乎主张以地球为中心的宇宙。在这个后宗教改革时代，天主教会因对圣经过于宽松而受到攻击，贝拉明要求在教会重新考虑其解释之前看到确凿的证据。伽利略可以继续他的研究，但贝拉明要求他在未经教会批准的情况下不要宣传新的发现。

A practicing Catholic, Galileo agreed and honored his word for several years. In 1632, chafing at the restraints and with a friendly new pope at the helm, Galileo published hisDialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems. Although he could count the moons around Jupiter, Galileo could not read the handwriting on the Vatican wall. It was bad enough that he had gone back on his word, worse that some of his proofs were far from certain — he argued, for instance, that the sun’s movements caused the tides — and worse still that he named the pope character in hisDialogueSimplicio, a name as demeaning as it sounds. As Salmon Rushdie might agree, Galileo’s getting off with house arrest seventy years into his church-subsidized life is a testament to the evolved state of mercy in sixteenth-century Christendom.

作为一个虔诚的天主教徒，伽利略同意并在几年内履行了他的诺言。1632 年，在一个友好的新教皇的领导下，伽利略发表了他的《关于两个主要世界体系的对话》（Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems）。虽然他能数出木星周围的卫星，但伽利略却看不懂梵蒂冈墙上的字迹。他出尔反尔已经够糟的了，更糟糕的是他的一些证明远远不能确定 —— 例如，他认为太阳的运动引起了潮汐 —— 更糟糕的是他在他的《对话》中将教皇称为朴素的人（Simplicio），这个称呼听起来太过凡人。正如萨尔蒙·拉什迪可能同意的那样，伽利略在其受教会资助的生活中被软禁了 70 年，这证明了十六世纪基督教世界的仁慈的进化状态。

If historians and dramatists have forgotten, Galileo well understood that the real resistance to his theorizing came from a fundamentalist reading not of Scripture but of Aristotle. He observed:

如果历史学家和戏剧家们忘记了，伽利略很明白，他的理论研究的真正阻力来自于原教旨主义的对亚里士多德的解读，而不是对圣经的解读。他说：

If Aristotle should see the new discoveries in the sky, he would change his opinions and correct his books and embrace the most sensible doctrines, casting away from himself those people so weak-minded as to be induced to go on maintaining abjectly everything he had ever said.28

如果亚里士多德看到天空中的新发现，他就会改变自己的观点，修正自己的书，接受最明智的学说，把自己从那些心智薄弱的人中解脱出来，而不是诱使他们继续卑微地维持他曾经说过的一切。 28

From the seventeenth century on, church and science, like church and commerce, would more and more go their separate ways, and the world would not necessarily benefit from the divergence. “Business is a morally serious enterprise,” Catholic social philosopher Michael Novak reminds us. “By its own internal logic and inherent moral drive, business requires moral conduct; and, not always, but with high probability, violations of this logic lead to personal and business disgrace.” 29An inverted yield curve in logic, as history has shown, tracks all too neatly with long-term prospects for disgrace.

从十七世纪开始，教会和科学，就像教会和商业一样，会越来越多地分道扬镳，而世界并不一定会从这种分歧中受益。“商业是一个道德上严肃的事业”，天主教社会哲学家迈克尔·诺瓦克提醒我们说。“根据其自身的内部逻辑和内在的道德驱动力，商业需要道德行为；而且，并非总是如此，但很有可能，违反这一逻辑会导致个人和商业的耻辱。” 29正如历史所表明，逻辑中倒置的收益曲线与耻辱的长期前景完全吻合。

fivePrepared for the Crown 做好为皇冠牺牲的准备

ON OR ABOUT THE YEAR 1119, SOME TWENTY YEARS AFTER THE WARRIORS OF ans ventured out from that fortified city “in joy and with a cheerful heart” on an Eastertime pilgrimage to the River Jordan.1They never got there. In the mountainous region between the city and the river, a merciless swarm of Saracens descended on the pilgrims, unarmed and weak from fasting, and slaughtered them. Three hundred were killed. Sixty were captured. And all of Christendom was outraged.

大约在 1119 年，也就是安斯的勇士们 “带着喜悦和欢快的心情” 从那座坚固的城市出发，在复活节期间前往约旦河朝拜。 1他们没有到达那里。在城市和河流之间的山区，一群无情的撒拉逊人袭击了朝圣者，他们没有武器，因禁食而虚弱，惨遭屠杀。三百人被杀。60 人被俘。整个基督教世界都被激怒了。

。

In 1120, in the town of Nablus, forty miles north of Jerusalem, church and secular leaders from throughout the region gathered to plan a response to this and other assaults. The most memorable result of that assembly was the formal recognition of a unique monastic order, the brainchild of two French knights, both veterans of the First Crusade. King Baldwin II of Jerusalem sanctioned the new order and ceded it use of headquarters space on the Temple Mount, so called because the ruins of the ancient Temple of Solomon were believed to lie buried beneath. From the location, the order took its name, Poor Knights of Christ and the Temple of Solomon, or as it has come to be known to history, the Knights Templar.

1120 年，在耶路撒冷以北 40 英里的纳布卢斯镇，来自整个地区的教会和世俗领导人聚集在一起，计划应对这一袭击和其他袭击。这次会议最令人难忘的结果是正式承认了一个独特的修道会，这是两位法国骑士的创意，他们都是第一次十字军东征的老兵。耶路撒冷国王鲍德温二世批准了这个新的修道会，并将圣殿山的总部空间让给了它，之所以被称为圣殿山，是因为古代所罗门圣殿的遗址被认为埋在下面。从这个地点，该组织取名为 “基督和所罗门圣殿的可怜骑士”，或如历史上所知，圣殿骑士。

Over the course of the next two centuries, the Templars would create the first great international banking enterprise. In the seven centuries following their demise, they would serve as grist for all manner of conspiracy mills — anti-Catholic, Masonic, anti-Masonic, anticapitalist. Indeed, had there not been a real Knights Templar, the publishing world would have had to create one. Today, scores of recently published books on the Templars — from the serious to the ludicrous to the blasphemous — can be had at the local bookstore. In addition to books, a browser on Amazon can easily find Templar armor shields, swords, pewter resin skull displays, high-gloss ceramic doorknobs, even “a Knights Templar Logo Baby Ultrasoft Onesie.”

在接下来的两个世纪里，圣殿骑士团将创建第一个伟大的国际银行企业。在他们灭亡后的七个世纪里，他们将成为各种阴谋论的素材 —— 反天主教、共济会、反共济会和反资本主义。事实上，如果没有真正的圣殿骑士团，出版界就不得不创造一个。今天，在当地书店可以买到几十本最近出版的关于圣殿骑士的书 —— 从严肃的到可笑的到亵渎的。除了书籍之外，在亚马逊上浏览可以很容易地找到圣殿骑士的盔甲盾牌、剑、锡制树脂骷髅头陈列品、高光陶瓷门把手，甚至 “圣殿骑士标志婴儿超软连体衣”。

The fascination with the Templars derives largely from their oxymoronic role as an order of warrior monks fighting on behalf of a pacifist religion. The Templars, acknowledges Malcolm Barber, the leading historian on this subject, were admittedly an “unnatural hybrid.” 2Unnatural or not, this was a serious order, and these were serious people. Under the early guidance of Saint Bernard of Clairvaux, the knights lived by a code strict even by medieval monk standards: “Since despising the light of the present life, being contemptuous of the torment which is your bodies, you have promised to hold cheap worldly matters for the love of God.” 3So reads in part the “Rule” that guided them through their life of silent meals, coarse clothing, daily prayers, and perpetual celibacy. In this regard, the Templars were in sync with a spirit of reform then sweeping Catholic Europe, particularly among the priestly classes. Tempted as they inevitably were by the eternal vices, clerics periodically realigned themselves with their Christian mission — or at least they tried to.

对圣殿骑士团的迷恋主要来自于他们作为一个代表和平主义宗教而战斗的战士僧侣的矛盾角色。马尔科姆·巴伯（Malcolm Barber）承认，圣殿骑士团是一个 “不自然的混合体”。2无论是否不自然，这都是一个严肃的团体，而这些人是严肃的。在克莱尔沃的圣伯纳德的早期指导下，“骑士们按照甚至是中世纪僧侣标准的严格准则生活。” 3 “规则” 部分它指导他们过着沉默的饮食、粗糙的衣服、每日祈祷和永久独身的生活。在这方面，圣殿骑士与当时席卷欧洲天主教的改革精神是一致的，特别是在牧师阶层。尽管他们不可避免地受到永恒的恶习的诱惑，但教士们定期将自己与他们的基督教使命结合起来 —— 或者至少他们试图这样做。

The Templars faced temptations beyond those of ordinary monks. They were, after all, knights, a position that historically came with a goodly share of perks. Each Templar, for instance, was allowed three horses and a squire. A horse conferred genuine power, and power spawned pride. That pride manifested itself in knightly fashions like long hair and pointed lace-up shoes. These and other earthly seductions Saint Bernard railed against on a regular basis. And yet there was no denying the Templars’ distinctive mission, and this Bernard did not attempt to soft sell: “After the consumption of the divine mystery,” the Rule continues, “no one should be afraid to fight, but be prepared for the crown.” 4

圣殿骑士面临着超出普通僧侣的诱惑。他们毕竟是骑士，这种地位在历史上是有相当份额的福利的。例如，每个圣殿骑士可以拥有三匹马和一名侍从。一匹马赋予了真正的权力，而权力催生了自豪感。这种自豪感体现在骑士的时尚上，如长发和尖头花边鞋。这些和其他世俗的诱惑，圣伯纳经常予以抨击。然而，不可否认的是圣殿骑士团的独特使命，而伯纳德并没有试图进行软性推销 ：“在消费了神圣的奥秘之后”，规则继续说道，“任何人都不应该害怕战斗，而应该做好为皇冠牺牲的准备。” 4

Despite the church’s approval of the order, more than a few church leaders were uneasy about the multitasking Templars. As early as 1159, John of Salisbury was openly questioning the wisdom of it all. “Communities which had originally rejoiced in poverty,” he writes, “are now favored with privileges which, ceasing to be necessary and snubbing charity, are deemed to be instruments of avarice rather than of religion.” 5John conceded the biblical precedent for men who “wage legitimate war,” David most notably, but he saw in the group’s knightly vocation a slippery slope to greed and pride, two of the most deadly sins of that time and place.

尽管教会批准了该组织，但不止几个教会领袖对身兼数职的圣殿骑士感到不安。早在 1159 年，索尔兹伯里的约翰就公开质疑这一切是否明智。他写道 ：“原本以贫穷为乐的社区”，“现在被赋予了特权，而这些特权不再是必要的，并且冷落了慈善，被认为是贪婪而非宗教的工具。” 5约翰承认《圣经》中关于 “发动合法战争” 的人的先例，其中以大卫最为突出，但他在这个团体的骑士使命中看到了通往贪婪和骄傲的滑坡，这是那个时代和地方最致命的两种罪。

John had a hard time finding an audience. By mid-twelfth century, the Templars had already proved their worth, not so much on the battlefield as off it. In 1147, they had accompanied the Crusaders under French king Louis VII to the Holy Land. As often happens on these kinds of military adventures, the king had run out of money halfway to his destination. At Antioch, lacking options as well as cash, he turned to the Templars for help. They raised the needed funds out of their own resources and likely supplemented those resources by borrowing.6Although the massive loan to the king nearly bankrupted them, the Templars had saved the Crusade, and the king acknowledged as much. So was launched a new mission for the pious knights, one that would prove more valuable than the military one that inspired their creation.

约翰很难找到观众。到十二世纪中叶，圣殿骑士团已经证明了他们的价值，与其说是在战场上，不如说是在战场外。1147 年，他们陪同法国国王路易七世领导的十字军前往圣地。正如这类军事冒险中经常发生的那样，国王在到达目的地的半路上就没钱了。在安提阿，由于缺乏选择和现金，他向圣殿骑士团寻求帮助。6尽管给国王的巨额贷款几乎使他们破产，但圣殿骑士团拯救了十字军，国王也承认了这一点。于是，虔诚的骑士们开始了新的使命，这个使命将证明比激发他们创建的军事使命更有价值。

The emergence of the Templars’ banking empire flowed naturally from their role as fighting monks. Once experience had shown them that pitched battles against a merciless enemy take an unholy toll on a religious order, they turned more and more to logistical support. Traditionally, monastic houses had provided safe storage for all manner of goods and documents. (Locals felt that if they could not trust the monks, whom could they trust?) The Templars inherited the good reputation of the monks who preceded them and built on it.

圣殿骑士团的银行帝国的出现，自然是源于他们作为战斗僧侣的角色。一旦经验告诉他们，与无情的敌人进行的战斗会对一个宗教团体造成巨大的损失，他们就越来越多地转向后勤支持。传统上，修道院的房子为各种货物和文件提供了安全的存储。(当地人认为，如果他们不能信任僧侣，他们还能信任谁呢？）圣殿骑士团继承了他们之前的僧侣的良好声誉，并在此基础上发展。

The Templars emerged as Europe’s principal banking order for several obvious reasons. For starters, they had the equivalent of branch offices stretching from one end of the Mediterranean to the other. They also had major complexes in Paris and London, cities in which decisions about war and peace were often made. Even more usefully, the Templars interacted with kings and popes, and they did so precisely when those leaders needed money, namely, on the way to the battlefield. And finally, the Templars did not need to hire security to protect their money transfers. In the rougher neighborhoods in which they operated, their reputation preceded them, and that helped.

圣殿骑士团成为欧洲的主要银行团体，有几个明显的原因。首先，他们拥有相当于从地中海的一端延伸到另一端的分支机构。他们还在巴黎和伦敦拥有大型综合机构，而这些城市往往是决定战争与和平的地方。更有用的是，圣殿骑士团可以与国王和教皇互动，而且他们正是在这些领导人需要钱的时候与之互动 —— 即，将要开战的时候。最后，圣殿骑士团不需要雇用保安来保护他们的资金转移。在他们经营的粗糙街区，他们的名声在他们之前，这很有帮助。

A detailed analysis of the Templars’ performance under thirteenth-century French king Philip IV shows just how wide ranging were the services they provided. They raised taxes for the king, paid bills, minted money, collected tariffs, chased down deadbeats, provisioned the army, supported diplomatic missions, and advanced loans to the kings’ friends and relatives — even Grandma, literally.7Although a not-for-profit organization whose employees lived on little, the Templars still had to generate enough revenue to cover their extensive overhead, horses and squires included.

对十三世纪法国国王菲利普四世手下的圣殿骑士团表现的详细分析表明，他们提供的服务范围是多么广泛。他们为国王征税，支付账单，铸造货币，征收关税，追捕死囚，为军队提供补给，支持外交使团，并向国王的朋友和亲属提供贷款 —— 甚至是奶奶，真的。 7虽然是一个非营利性组织，其雇员的生活费很少，但圣殿骑士团仍然必须创造足够的收入来支付其大量开销，包括马匹和侍从。

The Templars were well placed, of course, to finesse exchange rates over distance, a practice that was becoming widespread in Christian banking circles. In addition, there exists hard evidence that the Templars, on occasion at least, charged interest. When, for instance, Edward I of England reimbursed the Templars a substantial sum he had borrowed for a recently completed crusade, he included an additional 18 percent for “administration, expenses, and interest.” 8This was in 1274. Less than forty years later, the Templars would be history.

当然，圣殿骑士处于有利地位，可以巧妙地利用远距离的汇率，这种做法在基督教银行界正变得很普遍。此外，有确凿的证据表明，圣殿骑士团至少在某些时候是收取利息的。例如，当英格兰的爱德华一世向圣殿骑士团偿还他为最近完成的一次十字军东征所借的大笔款项时，他包括了额外的 18% 的 “管理、费用和利息”。 8这是 1274 年。不到 40 年后，圣殿骑士团将成为历史。

Despite the interest charges, the demise of the Templars had almost nothing to do with usury. Their asceticism in the service of kings and popes seems to have eliminated the social justice concerns that drove the usury debate in medieval Europe. The Templars were not exploiting anyone, nor were they living conspicuously high on the hog. Plus, they were too well connected and too well armed to accuse without superior arms to make the accusation stick. Philip IV of France had arms enough and debt even more.

尽管有利息费用，圣殿骑士团的消亡实际上与高利贷没什么太大关系。他们为国王和教皇服务的禁欲主义似乎已经消除了推动中世纪欧洲高利贷辩论的社会正义问题。圣殿骑士没有剥削任何人，他们也没有明显地高枕无忧地生活。此外，他们的关系太好，武器太精良，如果没有足够强大的军事力量，就无法使对他们的指控成立。法国的菲利普四世虽然有足够的军队，但，他的债务更多。

In 1306, after years of debasement, Philip had ordered the return of his treasury to the hard-money standards of 1266.9To pull this off, he would need an infusion of specie, specifically gold and silver for recoining. Like Willie Sutton, who robbed banks because that’s where the money was, Philip went after the bankers — the Jews in 1306 and the Templars in 1307. He had already driven the Italians and those pesky Lombards out of the country.

1306 年，经过多年的贬值，菲利普下令将国库恢复到 1266 年的硬通货标准。9为了实现这一目标，他需要注入纸币，特别是用于重铸的金银。就像威利·萨顿一样，他抢劫银行，因为那是钱的地方，菲利普去找银行家 —— 1306 年的犹太人和 1307 年的圣殿骑士。他已经把意大利人和那些讨厌的伦巴第人赶出了这个国家。

Given the Templars’ reputation for financial probity, Philip accused them not of usury but of heresy and sexual depravity, charges roughly comparable in severity at the time.10Even then, Paris life could rob a people of their fighting edge, the Templars included; when the king’s men swooped down on their HQ, they chose not to resist. The French government, acting under the cloak of Inquisition, proceeded to “get medieval” on them. Confessions were quickly forthcoming.

鉴于圣殿骑士团在财务方面的声誉，菲利普指控他们不是高利贷，而是异端和性堕落，这些指控在当时的严重程度上（与高利贷）大致相当。 10即使如此，巴黎的生活也会使一个民族失去战斗力，包括圣殿骑士；当国王的手下向他们的总部扑来时，他们选择不抵抗。法国政府披着宗教裁判所的外衣，开始对他们进行 “中世纪式” 审判。他们很快就招供了。

All too indicative was the confession tortured out of John of Tour, the fifty-nine-year-old treasurer of the temple at Paris. According to the notary who recorded it, John recounted the details of his initiation into the Knights Templar, a tale of depravity that could have rung true only to those who lusted for Templar property or who read Dan Brown novels.

巴黎圣殿的五十九岁司库图尔（John of Tour）被拷问出来的供词也很有参考价值。根据记录的公证人的说法，约翰讲述了他加入圣殿骑士团的细节，这个堕落的故事只有对那些觊觎圣殿骑士团财产或阅读丹·布朗小说的人才会感到真实。

“On the order of the receptor, [John] denied Jesus Christ once only, and spat upon the cross once.” John also confessed to kissing the receptor three times in three places, none of them good, and acknowledging that although prohibited from knowing women, “if any natural heat should move him, he could unite himself with his brothers.” 11At the time of his arrest, John, a longtime trusted advisor of the king, was on official royal business. He, like the other Templars, would have had to live extraordinarily well-concealed double lives if one were to believe their confessions.

“根据受戒者的命令，图尔只否认了耶稣基督一次，并在十字架上吐了一次口水”。图尔还承认在三个地方亲吻了受戒者三次，没有一次是好的；并承认虽然被禁止认识女人，但，“如果有任何自然的热量打动他，他可以与他的兄弟们结合。” 11在被捕时，图尔是国王长期信任的顾问，正在处理皇家官方事务。如果你相信这个坦白供词的话，那么，他和其他圣殿骑士一样，只能是一直在过着极其隐蔽的双重生活。

Under pressure from Philip — known as Philip the Fair, presumably for his good looks and not for his sense of justice — Pope Clement V ordered the arrest of all the Templars throughout Europe for further investigation. Clement’s insistence on due process further irritated Philip, who was hoping to confiscate the Templars’ property as quickly as he had the Jews’ the year before. Worse, from Philip’s perspective, the Templars had begun to recant their confessions. To keep the Inquisitional ball rolling, Philip threatened to invade the Papal States and proceeded to execute some of the Templars while he waited for a papal commission to decide whether or not they deserved it. Not until 1312 did the decision come in.

在菲利普（Philip）的压力下 —— 他被称为 “公平的菲利普” （Philip the Fair），可能是因为他的美貌而非正义感 —— 教皇克莱门特五世下令逮捕整个欧洲的所有圣殿骑士，以便进一步调查。克莱门特对正当程序的坚持进一步激怒了菲利普，他希望能像前一年没收犹太人的财产一样迅速没收圣殿骑士的财产。更糟糕的是，从菲利普的角度来看，圣殿骑士团已经开始反悔他们的供词。为了保持审讯越滚越大，菲利普威胁说要入侵教皇国，并着手处决一些圣殿骑士，同时等待教皇委员会决定他们是否应该被处决。直到 1312 年才有了决定。

The commission refused to condemn the Templars as Philip had demanded, but the scandal had reached such proportions that the commission thought it better to disband the order. Then the commission applied the salt: the Knights Hospitaller, a less bellicose knightly order, would receive the Templars’ holdings, not Philip the Fair.12One can imagine the howling from the palace when Philip saw the verdict.

委员会拒绝按照菲利普的要求谴责圣殿骑士团，但丑闻已经达到了这样的程度，委员会认为最好是解散该团。然后，委员会又撒了一把盐：由不那么好战的好望角骑士团来接收圣殿骑士团的财产，而不是由公平的菲利普来接收。12可以想象当菲利普看到这个判决时，皇宫里一片哀嚎。

Dante was in the process of writing hisPurgatorio, the second part of hisDivine Comedy, during Philip’s assault on the Templars. In purgatory, the narrator encounters Hugh Capet, the originator of the Capetian line. “From me were born the Louises and Philips,” laments Hugh. He sees himself not as proud patriarch but rather as “the root of that malignant plant, which overshadows all the Christian world.” 13In describing the current representative of that line, otherwise unnamed, Hugh says:

在菲利普对圣殿骑士的进行疯狂攻击的时候，但丁正在写他的《炼狱》，他的《神曲》的第二部分。在炼狱中，叙述者遇到了卡佩一支的始祖休·卡佩。休哀叹道 ：“路易丝和菲利普都是从我这里诞生的”。他认为自己不是骄傲的族长，而是 “笼罩整个基督教世界的恶性植物的根”。13在描述该系氏族的现任代表时，休说：

I see the modern Pilate so relentless,
This does not sate him, but without decretal
He to the temple bears his sordid sails!14

我看到现代的彼拉多如此无情，
这并不能让他满足，但没有法令……
他向圣殿扬起他肮脏的风帆! 14

A decretal is a papal decree. The temple is that of the Knights Templar in Paris. Pilate is Philip. Dante goes beyond scolding Philip. He compares the sacrifice of the Templars to that of Christ. The comparison has resonated through the ages, especially in reference to the order’s last Grand Master, Jacques de Molay, who was burned at the stake in Paris in 1314.

法令是教皇的命令。圣殿是指巴黎的圣殿骑士团。彼拉多就是菲利普。但丁超越了对菲利普的责骂。他将圣殿骑士团的牺牲与基督的牺牲相提并论。这种比较在历史上引起了共鸣，特别是在提到该组织的最后一位大团长雅克·德·莫莱时，他于 1314 年在巴黎被烧死在火刑柱上。

In a popular book calledThe Second Messiah: Templars, the Turin Shroud,and the Great Secret of Freemasonry, Masonic historians Christopher Knight and Robert Lomas insist that the image on the famed shroud of Turin is not Jesus, but Jacques himself.15As the story goes, the establishment executed de Molay to keep him from revealing the untold story of Christ’s real intentions for the world. Today, de Molay’s legacy lives on in DeMolay International, a Masonicsponsored youth organization founded in Kansas City in 1919. The Masons, in fact, have done much to keep the mystique of the Templars alive, if not exactly their history. It will not surprise the reader to learn that Catholics are not too keen on the Masons.

在一本名为《第二个救世主: 圣殿骑士，都灵裹尸布，以及共济会的伟大秘密》的书中，共济会历史学家克里斯托弗·奈特和罗伯特·洛马斯坚持认为，著名的都灵裹尸布上的图像不是耶稣，而是雅克本人。 15正如故事所言，当局处决了德·莫莱，以阻止他揭示基督对世界的真实意图这一不为人知的故事。今天，德莫莱的遗产在德莫莱国际中继续存在，这是一个共济会赞助的青年组织，于 1919 年在堪萨斯城成立。事实上，共济会为保持圣殿骑士团的神秘感做了很多工作，即使不完全是他们的历史。读者了解到天主教徒对共济会并不热衷，也不会感到惊讶。

Then, of course, there is the question of Masonic influence on the seal of the United States — especially that weird pyramid with an eye on the top and the call toNovus Ordo Seculorum, or “new world order,” on the bottom. Even though the seal adorns the United States dollar, the subject of much discussion to come, this author will choose to leave this particular can of worms unopened.

当然，还有共济会对美国国玺的影响问题 —— 特别是那个奇怪的金字塔，上面有一只眼睛，下面是对《新世界秩序》（Novus Ordo Seculorum）的呼吁。尽管这枚印章是美元的装饰，也是未来许多讨论的主题，但笔者将选择不打开这个特殊的虫子罐。

One subject that does merit exposure is the systemic British anti-Catholicism that tainted the reputation not only of the Templars but also of the Crusades themselves. Instead of working itself out after the civil wars of the seventeenth century, this sentiment continued to fester into the nineteenth century and found its literary outlet in the novels of Sir Walter Scott. Scott was educated in the Church of Scotland, a fire-and-brimstone enterprise that had not quite yet embraced the ecumenical spirit. Indeed, its ministers had a habit of referring to the Roman Catholic Church as the “whore of Babylon” and the pope as the “antichrist.”

一个值得曝光的主题是英国系统性的反天主教主义，它不仅玷污了圣殿骑士的声誉，也玷污了十字军东征本身。这种情绪在十七世纪的内战后并没有得到解决，而是继续发酵到十九世纪，并在沃尔特·斯科特爵士的小说中找到了文学的出口。斯科特是在苏格兰教会接受教育的，那里还没有完全接受普世精神的火与硫磺。事实上，它的牧师们习惯于将罗马天主教会称为 “巴比伦的妓女”，将教皇称为 “反基督者”。

In the most popular of Scott’s novels,Ivanhoe, published in 1819, a Templar named Brian de Bois-Guilbert plays the heavy. “They say he is valiant as the bravest of his order,” says one of Scott’s humble Saxons, “but stained with their usual vices — pride, arrogance, cruelty, and voluptuousness.” 16Among the Templar’s impressive range of character flaws, bigotry stands out. “It would seem the Templars love the Jews’ inheritance better than they do their company,” says one character speaking for the author.17

在斯科特最受欢迎的小说《艾文荷》（Ivanhoe，1819 年出版）中，一个名叫布莱恩·德·布瓦·吉尔伯特的圣殿骑士扮演着重任。“他们说他是教团中最勇敢的人”，斯科特的一个卑微的撒克逊人说，“但沾染了他们通常的恶习 —— 骄傲、傲慢、残忍和贪婪。"16在圣殿骑士的一系列惊人的性格缺陷中，偏执很突出。“看来圣殿骑士团对犹太人的遗产比他们对自己同伴爱得更深”，一个任务替作者如此说道。17/p>。

Humiliated in a tournament, the Templar subsequently plots to rob a kindly Jewish moneylender, succeeds in kidnapping the man’s beautiful daughter Rebecca, and flees to the nearest temple outpost from which he hopes to exit the country, hostage in tow. The Grand Master of the Templars shows up unexpectedly and is shocked by Brian’s behavior. He concludes that only a witch could have caused a Templar to violate so many vows in so many outsized ways. Being a devout Catholic, the Grand Master promptly tries the Jewess Rebecca for witchcraft and sentences her to burn at the stake. Just another day at the office for the Knights Templar.

在一次比赛中被羞辱，圣殿骑士随后策划抢劫一个善良的犹太放债人，成功地绑架了这个人的漂亮女儿丽贝卡，并逃到最近的圣殿前哨，他希望从那里带着人质离开这个国家。圣殿骑士团的大团长意外地出现了，并对布莱恩的行为感到震惊。他得出结论，只有女巫才能使一个圣殿骑士以如此多的方式违反这么多的誓言。作为一个虔诚的天主教徒，大法师立即以巫术罪审判犹太女郎丽贝卡，并判处她在火刑柱上烧死 —— 对圣殿骑士来说，这稀松平常。

To his credit, Scott draws a sympathetic portrait of his Jewish characters, even the moneylender Isaac. Not wanting to estrange his less progressive audience, he concedes that Jews had adopted “a national character in which there was much, to say the least, mean and unamiable.” But this, he attributes to centuries of hounding. “There was no race existing on the earth, in the air, or the waters, who were the object of such an unintermitting, general and relentless persecution as the Jews of this period.” 18

值得称道的是，斯科特为他的犹太人物，甚至是放债人艾萨克刻画了一幅充满同情的肖像。他不想疏远他那些并不太进步的观众，他承认犹太人采用了 “一种民族性格，其中有很多东西，至少可以说是卑鄙和不可爱的”。但是，他把这一点归结为 “几个世纪以来的围追堵截”。“在地球上，在空中，在水中，没有任何一个种族像这一时期的犹太人那样，成为不间断的、普遍的、无情的迫害的对象。” 18

Like so many other enlightened souls to follow, however, Scott compensated for his largesse toward one group with his comically crude stereotyping of another. In his 1825 novelTalisman, Scott expands his protected classes to include the romantically heroic Crusade-buster, Saladin, at the expense, of course, of the venal and treacherous Crusaders themselves.

然而，就像后来许多其他开明的灵魂一样，斯科特用他对另一个群体滑稽粗暴的成见来补偿他对一个群体的慷慨。在他 1825 年的小说《护身符》（Talisman）中，斯科特扩大了他的受保护阶层，包括浪漫的英雄十字军战士萨拉丁，当然，牺牲的是卑鄙和奸诈的十字军战士本身。

Scott’s novels were enormously influential. They propagated the first seeds of a caricature that would blossom in the late twentieth century. That the Crusades were no more than a blundering, plundering proto-imperialism is today a truism believed by just about everyone except for serious students of history. “Historians have long known that the image of the Crusader seeking his fortune is exactly backwards,” says Thomas Madden, a leading historian of the period.19As Madden observes, the Crusades were pilgrimages, acts of penance. Crusaders gave up just about everything, often their lives, to right undeniable wrongs. Typically, the Crusaders returned as soon as they could and usually with nothing more than the cross on their tunic. Indeed, if giving alms to the poor was thought to be an investment in one’s heavenly reward, fighting a crusade was a leveraged buyout of the same.

斯科特的小说具有巨大的影响力。它们传播了一种漫画的最初种子，这种漫画将在二十世纪末开花结果。十字军东征不过是一个错误的、掠夺性的原帝国主义，这在今天几乎是每个人都相信的不争事实，除了严肃的历史学生。“历史学家早就知道，十字军寻求财富的形象恰恰是倒过来的”，该时期的著名历史学家托马斯·马登说。19正如马登所说，十字军东征是朝圣，是忏悔的行为。十字军战士放弃了几乎所有的东西，往往是他们的生命，以纠正不可否认的错误。通常情况下，十字军战士一有机会就会返回，而且通常只带着他们外衣上的十字架。事实上，如果向穷人施舍被认为是对自己的天国奖赏的投资，那么参加十字军东征就是对天国奖赏的杠杆式收购。

sixAboveboard 光明正大

BEFORE JEWS HAD ASSUMED THE REPUTATION AS THE WORLD’S GREAT usurers, that honor — or dishonor, depending on one’s perspective — belonged to the Italians. Italians brought Arabic numerals to the Western world, introduced the revolutionary concept of double-entry bookkeeping, and gave us the very wordbankfrom the old Italianbanco, meaning “bench or board.” In Florence, the epicenter of banking in fourteenth-century Europe, a money changer would set up his board each morning in a designated Florentine street, lay a green cloth over it, place the official ledger on top of that, and start doing deals. The Exchangers Guild, to which he had no choice but to belong, dictated that every transaction had to be recorded. Although the origin of the phraseaboveboardis uncertain, an Italian banking provenance would make perfect sense.

在犹太人承担了世界上最大的高利贷者的名声之前，这一荣誉 —— 或不光彩，取决于个人的观点 —— 属于意大利人。意大利人把阿拉伯数字带到了西方世界，引入了复式记账的革命性概念，并给我们提供了 “银行” 这个词，它来自古老的意大利语 banco，意思是 “板凳或董事会”。在十四世纪欧洲银行业的中心 —— 佛罗伦萨，货币兑换商每天早上会在指定的佛罗伦萨街道上摆好他的板凳，在上面铺上一块绿布，把官方账本放在上面，然后开始交易。他别无选择，只能属于兑换商协会，该协会规定每笔交易都必须被记录。虽然这句话的来源aboveboard不确定，但意大利银行业的出处是完全合理的。

Even seven centuries ago, there was something wonderfully improvisational about Italian culture. Despite being denied the banker’s most essential instrument — the ability to lend money at interest — Italians had managed to create the world’s most progressive banking system. In the fifteenth century, the Medici family would raise the art of improvisation to a new level of sophistication and always aboveboard — more or less.

即使在七个世纪前，意大利文化中也有一些奇妙的即兴表演。尽管被剥夺了银行家最基本的工具 —— 借钱生息的能力，意大利人还是设法创造了世界上最先进的银行系统。在 15 世纪，美第奇家族将把即兴创作的艺术提高到一个新的水平，而且总是光明正大的 —— 或多或少。

No one has better understood the Italian ability to improvise — or described it more amusingly — than the fourteenth-century Florentine author, poet, and banker’s son, Giovanni Boccaccio. That he kept his sense of humor in the face of the Black Death that ravaged Europe in mid-century, killing at least a quarter of its citizens, is a testament to the culture’s historic resilience.

没有人比十四世纪佛罗伦萨的作家、诗人和银行家的儿子乔瓦尼·薄伽丘更了解意大利人的即兴创作能力 —— 或更有趣地描述它。即便是在面对本世纪中叶肆虐欧洲、至少杀死了四分之一公民的黑死病的时候，他都保持了自己的幽默感，这证明了该文化的历史悠久的复原力。

Boccaccio started writing his masterwork,The Decameron, in 1350, at the peak of the plague. The very first of his tales so nicely captures the creative tension of Italian culture that it makes the Medici century that follows almost comprehendible.

薄伽丘于 1350 年开始写他的代表作《十日谈》，当时正值瘟疫的高峰期。他的第一个故事很好地抓住了意大利文化的创造性张力，使随后的美第奇世纪几乎可以被理解。

As the story opens, a clan of godless Burgundians is cheating a wealthy and well-connected merchant out of his rightful investments. So the merchant contracts with an even more faithless and violent rapscallion by the name of Ser Ciappelletto to shake down the Burgundians. The diminutive Ciappelletto glories in having committed every sin known to Dante. He was a “profuse blasphemer of God and His saints,” a glutton, a drunk, and “as fond of women as a dog is of the stick.” When all was said and done, Ciappelletto was “perhaps, the worst man that ever was born.” 1

故事开始时，一个不信神的勃艮第人氏族正在欺骗一个富有的、有关系的商人，使其失去应有的投资。因此，该商人与一个更无信仰、更暴力的强奸犯签订了合同，他的名字是基亚佩莱托爵士，以撼动这些勃艮第人。身材矮小的基亚佩莱托以犯过但丁所知的所有罪行为荣。他是一个 “亵渎上帝和他的圣徒的人”，贪吃，酗酒，而且 “像狗一样喜欢女人”。当所有的这些描述他的话都说完后，基亚佩莱托 “也许是有史以来最糟糕的人”。1/p>

On the way to the shakedown, Ciappelletto stops near Florence at the home of two brothers, both usurers, and there he falls gravely ill. The brothers are in a quandary. If they turn this sick man out of their house, their lack of mercy will outrage the villagers, who will be all the more outraged when they discover just whom the brothers have been harboring.

在前去勒索的路上，基亚佩莱托在佛罗伦萨附近的两兄弟家里停留，他们都是高利贷者，在那里他病得很重。兄弟俩陷入了两难境地。如果他们把这个病人赶出家门，他们的不仁慈会激怒村民，当他们发现这对兄弟窝藏了谁时，村民们会更加愤怒。

On the other hand, if the brothers let Ciappelletto die at their house, this aggressively wicked man will surely refuse confession and provoke the church into denying him burial. When his unburied body is found and identified, the usurious brothers fear the worst:

另一方面，如果兄弟们让基亚佩莱托死在他们家，这个咄咄逼人的恶人肯定会拒绝忏悔，被惹怒的教会肯定会拒绝安葬他。当他未被埋葬的尸体被发现并被确认时，放高利贷的兄弟们担心出现最坏的情况：

In which case the folk of these parts, who reprobate our trade as iniquitous and revile it all day long, and would fain rob us, will seize their opportunity, and raise a tumult, and make a raid upon our houses, crying: “Away with these Lombard dogs, whom the Church excludes from her pale.” 2

在这种情况下，这些地方的人们会抓住机会，掀起一阵骚动，对我们的房子进行突袭，他们指责我们的贸易是不公正的，整天谩骂，恨不得抢劫我们。"2

Evil to the end, Ciappelletto proposes to solve the brothers’ problem by an act of profanely reckless cunning. He will confess to “the worthiest and most holy friar” in the neighborhood a series of teeny counterfeit sins. “I have committed so many offences against God in the course of my life,” he tells the brothers, “that one more in the hour of my death will make no difference whatever to the account.” When the friar is found, Ciappelletto unblushingly confesses a life so saintly that that friar spreads the word of his holiness far and wide. Once dead and buried, the scoundrel becomes an object of local veneration.

邪恶至极的基亚佩莱托提议通过一种亵渎性的鲁莽狡猾行为来解决兄弟俩的问题。他将向附近的 “最值得和最神圣的修士” 承认一系列微小的假罪。他告诉兄弟们，“在我的一生中，我已经对上帝犯下了许多罪行”，他说，“在我死亡的时刻，再犯一次也不会有任何影响。” 当那个修士被找到时，基亚佩莱托毫不羞愧地承认他的生活是如此的圣洁，以至于那个修士将他的圣洁之事传得很远很广。下葬之后，这个无赖就成了当地人崇拜的对象。

。

Boccaccio gives the modern reader a humbling look back at fourteenth-century Italian culture. The people disdain usurers regardless of ethnicity — Lombards especially — and not without some cause. Although informed by a Christian ethos, they are not oppressed by it. They take their faith seriously, sometimes too seriously perhaps, but not preposterously so. This is the kind of open, ambitious, unruly world in which the Medici would prosper. It is not that much different from our own.

薄伽丘让现代读者谦卑地回顾了十四世纪的意大利文化。人们对高利贷者不屑一顾，不分种族 —— 尤其是伦巴第人 —— 而且并非没有原因。虽然受到基督教精神的影响，但他们并没有受到它的压迫。他们认真对待自己的信仰，有时也许过于认真，但并不矫情。这是一个开放的、雄心勃勃的、不受约束的世界，美第奇家族在其中会很兴旺。它与我们自己的世界并无太大的不同。

The Medici served as something of a Beta test for the merchant banking families that would follow: moneylending 1.0. Whether Protestant, Catholic, or Jew, the dynastic arcs of these outsized families — Morgan, Medici, Rothschild — track closely with one another. The Medici story might profitably begin with the bank’s founding father, Giovanni di Bicci, born in 1260 into a respectable Florentine family of moderate wealth.3Thanks to the dowry from an ambitious marriage, Giovanni was able to finesse a partnership in a cousin’s bank in Rome, then the hub of international finance.

美第奇家族为后来的商业银行家族提供了某种测试：放贷 1.0。无论是新教、天主教还是犹太教，这些庞大的家族 —— 摩根、美第奇、罗斯柴尔德 —— 的王朝轨迹彼此紧密相连。美第奇的故事可以从银行的创始人乔瓦尼·迪·比奇开始，他于 1260 年出生在佛罗伦萨一个令人尊敬的中等财富家庭。3得益于一次雄心勃勃的婚姻带来的嫁妆，乔瓦尼能够在当时国际金融中心罗马的一个表哥的银行里巧妙地建立起一个伙伴关系。

Rome had assumed this role for one reason: the Catholic Church was headquartered here. In another one of history’s great ironies, it was the flow of tithes to Rome that inspired the infrastructure for a continentwide financial network. It was the church’s presence that made Italians the world’s bankers. It was the church’s regulations that made them such creative bankers. And it was the fear of God that kept their activities aboveboard, more or less.

罗马承担这个角色有一个原因：天主教会的总部设在这里。在历史上另一个巨大的讽刺中，正是流向罗马的什一税，激发了整个大陆的金融网络的基础设施。正是教会的存在，使意大利人成为世界上的银行家。正是教会的规定使他们成为如此有创造力的银行家。而正是对上帝的敬畏，使他们的活动或多或少地保持了公正。

From 1385 to 1397, Giovanni worked at his cousin’s bank in Rome. There he learned what it would take to set up a major international bank of his own. This would include sufficient capital, branches in all the major trade centers staffed by Italians he could trust, and, finally, a discreet understanding of how money could be made in banking without charging interest. In 1397, Cosimo and two partners headed back to Florence and opened their doors for business.

从 1385 年到 1397 年，乔万尼在他表哥在罗马的银行工作。在那里，他了解到建立一家属于自己的大型国际银行需要什么。这将包括足够的资本、在所有主要贸易中心的分支机构，由他可以信任的意大利人担任工作人员，以及最后，对如何在不收取利息的情况下在银行业赚钱的谨慎理解。1397 年，科西莫和两个伙伴回到佛罗伦萨，开门营业。

Although it had other profit centers — the Medici were merchants as well as bankers — the Medici bank made most of its money by mastering the art of exchange. Let us say, for instance, that a merchant in Florence wanted to borrow a thousand florins to send a silk shipment to London. Once the silk was delivered and paid for, the merchant’s agent would repay the London Medici branch officer back for the loan — without interest, of course — based on the going rate of exchange.

尽管它还有其他的利润中心 —— 美第奇家族既是商人也是银行家 —— 美第奇银行通过掌握交易艺术赚取了大部分的钱。比如说，佛罗伦萨的一个商人想借一千弗罗林，把一批丝绸运到伦敦。一旦丝绸交付并付款，商人的代理人就会根据汇率向伦敦美第奇分行的官员偿还贷款 —— 当然没有利息。

This transaction would seem pointless for the Medici given that exchange rates between currencies can float up or down. Fortunately, however, some banking records still exist, and they verify what everyone suspected: exchanges among agents in London, Bruges, and Venice from that period show a profit for the bankers in sixty-six out of sixty-seven cases. The gains ranged from 7.7 to 28.8 percent. The method of assuring profit was inordinately complicated — manuals were written to help bankers and merchants understand — but everyone got it. “Basically,” writes Tim Parks inMedici Money, “the trick is that the currency quoted as a unit is always worth more in the country of issue.” 4

鉴于货币之间的汇率可以上下浮动，这项交易对美第奇家族来说似乎毫无意义。然而，幸运的是，一些银行记录仍然存在，它们验证了每个人的怀疑：那个时期伦敦、布鲁日和威尼斯的代理人之间的交易显示，在 67 个案例中，银行家有 66 个获得了利润。收益从 7.7% 到 28.8% 不等。确保利润的方法极其复杂 —— 为了帮助银行家和商人理解而编写了手册 —— 但每个人都得到了它。“基本上”，蒂姆·帕克斯在《美第奇赚钱法》（Medici Money）中写道，“诀窍是，作为单位的货币报价在发行国总是更有价值。”

The Medici gained their edge by staffing their branches with relatives, in-laws, and otherpaisanoswho could be trusted with the “trick.” Ironically again, the usury prohibition helped drive international trade and made banking an international business. Church fathers insisted on distance to legitimize exchanges. Bankers went awry when they tried to pull off exchange deals with only a nominal swapping of currencies. This kind of transaction church fathers called acambio secco, or dry exchange.5The church forbade it, and Florence outlawed it in 1429.

美第奇通过为其分支机构配备亲属、姻亲和其他农民工兄弟（paisanos）可以信任的 “招数” 来获得优势。具有讽刺意味的是，禁止高利贷有助于推动国际贸易，使银行业成为国际业务。教父们坚持用距离来使交流合法化。当银行家们试图仅以名义上的货币互换来完成交换交易时，他们就出了问题。5教会禁止这种交易，而佛罗伦萨在 1429 年将其定为非法。

For all of the obstacles, however, the Medici had formalized what the Templars and others had pioneered, namely, the banking industry. What international banking did, the third Lord Rothschild would say with his inherited precision, was “facilitate the movement of money from point A, where it is, to point B, where it is needed.” 6In the process of moving this money, the Medici and others like them laid the foundation for the further economic development of the Western world.

然而，对于所有的障碍，美第奇家族已经将圣殿骑士和其他人所开创的东西正式化，即银行业。第三任罗斯柴尔德勋爵以其继承的精确性说，国际银行业所做的是 “促进货币从 A 点（它所在的地方）向 B 点（它需要的地方）流动。” 6在移动这些货币的过程中，美第奇和其他像他们一样的人为西方世界的进一步经济发展奠定了基础。

By 1429, Giovanni had retired, and his son Cosimo had taken over the bank, now organized into a vast holding company. Each branch director had a stake in the company and an obligation to honor the holding company’s guidelines, chief among them, “Thou shalt not gamble.” 7This meant no loans of more than three hundred florins to cardinals and no loans to Germans under any terms. The Medici effectively redlined Germany not out of blind prejudice but from the hard experience of getting stiffed with the full approval of German courts. If the loans to cardinals were made without charging interest — the expected payback was in averted gazes — the commercial loans were fueled by roughly the same kind of subterfuges that makeshariabanking possible today.

1429 年，乔瓦尼已经退休，他的儿子科西莫接管了银行，现在组织成一个庞大的控股公司。每个分行的董事都有公司的股份，并有义务遵守控股公司的准则，其中最主要的是 ：“你不能赌博。” 7这意味着不得向红衣主教提供超过 300 弗罗林的贷款，不得以任何条件向德国人贷款。美第奇家族有效地给德国划定了红线，这不是出于盲目的偏见，而是来自于在德国法院的充分批准下被拖欠的艰难经历。如果说给红衣主教的贷款是不收利息的 —— 预期的回报是通过让主教睁一只眼闭一只眼来实现的 —— 那么商业贷款则是通过与今天遵从伊斯兰教规（sharia）的银行业务相同的潜规则来实现的。

The pawnbrokers’ trade in Florence testifies to the city’s flexible standards for both crime and sin. Then as now, society held pawnbrokers in much less esteem than bankers. In that they openly charged interest, pawnbrokers bore the added fifteenth-century stigma of being “manifest usurers.” As such, they could not belong to the Exchangers Guild. They could, however, be fined. And conveniently for everyone, they were fined en masse — two thousand florins — for the “detestable sin” of usury each year.8By paying their individual share of that fine, pawnbrokers could be assured of another year without punishment or outside competition. Today, we call this a license. It was not until 1437 that the church banned Christians from the trade altogether. Although this ban proved to be an economic boon for Jewish pawnbrokers, they would pay a high dividend in anti-Semitic resentment.

佛罗伦萨的典当业证明了这个城市对犯罪和罪恶的灵活标准。当时和现在一样，社会对典当商的尊重程度远远低于银行家。由于公开收取利息，典当商在 15 世纪还背上了 “明显的高利贷” 的污名。因此，他们不能属于兑换商协会。不过，他们可以被罚款。对每个人来说都很方便，他们被集体罚款 —— 两千弗罗林 —— 因为每年的高利贷是 “可憎的罪行”。8通过支付他们各自的罚款份额，典当商可以保证再过一年没有惩罚或外部竞争。今天，我们把这称为许可证。直到 1437 年，教会才完全禁止基督教徒从事这一行业。尽管这项禁令被证明是犹太典当商的经济福音，但他们将在反犹太主义的怨恨中付出高昂的代价。

To navigate a safe path between the Scylla of church and the Charybidis of state, Cosimo got deeper into politics than the old man. Like the big-city bosses of the twentieth century, he preferred to work behind the scenes, pushing deals and pulling strings. In fact, east of Chicago, there may have been no more politically turbulent time and place than the Italian peninsula in the fifteenth century. It should surprise no one that Niccolò Machiavelli, the author of that classic in political cynicism,The Prince, was born in 1469, the same year that Cosimo’s grandson, Lorenzo, assumed power, and in the same city, Florence.

为了在教会的希拉和国家的卡律比迪斯之间找到一条安全的道路，科西莫比老爷子更深入政治。像二十世纪的大城市老板一样，他更喜欢在幕后工作，推动交易和拉拢关系。事实上，在芝加哥以东，可能没有比十五世纪的意大利半岛更动荡的政治时间和地点了。没有人应该感到惊讶的是，马基雅弗利，这个政治犬儒主义经典《君主论》（Prince）的作者，出生于 1469 年，同年科西莫的孙子洛伦佐掌权，并且在同一个城市，佛罗伦萨。

In fifteenth-century Christendom, few, if any, sovereign rulers could match Cosimo’s political clout and ecclesiastical connections. “He it is who decides peace and war and controls the laws,” said Pope Pius II of Cosimo in 1458. “He is king in everything but name.” 9Despite Cosimo’s power, the church did not change its usury laws to accommodate him. As Tim Parks assures us in a compliment so left-handed that it could get that hand lopped off in a less-tolerant religion — one comes immediately to mind — “The church was not entirely rotten.” 10Thank you, Tim.

在十五世纪的基督教世界中，很少有主权统治者能与科西莫的政治影响力和教会关系相媲美。教皇皮尤斯二世在 1458 年对科西莫说 ：“他是决定和平与战争并控制法律的人。” 9尽管科西莫的权力，教会并没有改变其高利贷法律以适应他。正如蒂姆·帕克斯在一次极左的赞美中向我们保证的那样，“在一个不太宽容的宗教中，他的（左）手可能会被砍掉” —— 我马上想到了一个宗教 —— “教会并不完全腐朽。” 10 谢谢你，蒂姆。

Throughout the Middle Ages, in fact, orthodox reformers battled the bureaucrats for the church’s soul. Antonio Pierozzi, a Dominican friar better known as Saint Antoninus, was writing theSumma, his major work on moral theology, in Florence during Cosimo’s tenure. And although he worked with the Medici on the renovation of San Marco, he gave them no leeway on the moral questions of the day.

事实上，在整个中世纪，正统的改革者为了教会的灵魂与官僚们展开了斗争。安东尼奥·皮耶罗齐，一位多米尼加修士，被称为圣安东尼，在科西莫任期内，正在佛罗伦萨撰写《知识大全》（Summa），他关于道德神学的主要著作。虽然他与美第奇家族合作修缮圣马可教堂，但在当时的道德问题上，他没有给他们留任何余地。

“Usury,” Antoninus writes, “ever breaks and consumes the bones of the poor, night or day, on feasts and workdays, sleeping or waking its work never ceases.” 11He had no use for usury’s subterfuges either. The pawnbroker trade he particularly disdained. Given his social justice perspective, he likened it to prostitution, a comparison that surely would have offended the ladies of the Florentine night.

“高利贷”，安东尼写道，“不管是晚上还是白天，不管是节日还是工作日，不管是睡觉还是醒来，它的工作都不会停止。” 11高利贷的伪装也骗不了他。他尤其不屑于典当业。鉴于他的社会正义观，他把高利贷比作卖淫，这种比较肯定会冒犯佛罗伦萨夜总会的女士们。

For all of Antoninus’s distaste for lending at interest, his writing on economics revealed an evolving sophistication. He understood profit and loss and the need to make the former. Like most Catholic theologians, he had no objection to thesocietas, a partnership in which one partner invests and runs the risk of losing that money if the project goes awry. He recognized the legality of what was calledlucrum cessans, the loss of an assured profit in a safe enterprise as a result of money lent to another, riskier one.

尽管安东尼对借贷利息很反感，但他关于经济学的著作却显示出一种不断发展的复杂性。他理解利润和损失，以及赚取前者的必要性。像大多数天主教神学家一样，他不反对合伙（societas），即一个合伙人投资并在项目出现问题时承担损失风险的伙伴关系。他承认所谓的 “阴暗面” （lucrum cessans）的合法性，即，由于把钱借给另一个风险更大的事业而导致一个原本安全的事业失去保证利润。

Antoninus approved of thecensusas well. This was a popular form of annuity contract in which an investor provided the up-front cash, often to a city, and was paid back over a period of years by the revenue, often tax revenue, generated from the investment. As Ekelund et al. concede in their unflattering economic history of the medieval church, “Practically from its conception, the Christian Church defended private property and trading activity.” 12Although deformed by the flat-out ban on usury, the quality of the moral dialectic on the economy in the fifteenth century has not been rivaled since.13

安东尼也赞同 “人口协议” （census）。这是一种流行的年金合同形式，投资者提供前期现金，通常是给一个城市，并在几年内通过投资产生的收入，通常是税收来偿还。正如艾克伦德（Ekelund）等人在他们的中世纪教会的不光彩的经济史中承认的那样，“实际上从一开始，基督教会就为私有财产和贸易活动辩护。” 12尽管由于平白无故地禁止高利贷而变形，但十五世纪关于经济的道德辩证法的质量自此之后再也无法匹敌。 13

The Medici, meanwhile, concentrated on getting by. After a brief period of exile, the result of a political gambit gone south, Cosimo returned to Florence more powerful than ever. Among his first acts was to lift the ban on so-called dry exchanges. He cracked down on his enemies, exiled some of them, and got himself elected head of government when it suited his purposes. His grandson Lorenzo would confirm some years later, “In Florence things can go badly for the rich if they don’t run the state.” 14

与此同时，美第奇家族则专注于过日子。在经历了短暂的流亡 —— 之前一次政治赌博失败的结果 —— 之后，科西莫回到了佛罗伦萨，比以往任何时候都更加强大。他的第一个行动是取消了对所谓的干货交易（dry exchanges）的禁令。他打击了他的敌人，流放了其中一些人，并在符合他的目的时让自己当选政府首脑。他的孙子洛伦佐几年后证实 ：“在佛罗伦萨，如果富人不管理国家，事情就会变得很糟糕。” 14

As happens in dynastic banking families, the heirs lose the passion for making money but not for spending it. Cosimo’s well-fed son Piero, the “Fredo Corleone” of the clan, had no gift for the business. He got to mismanage it for only eight years before gout liberated him from this mortal coil. Piero’s son Lorenzo had more talent than his father but even less interest in banking.

正如在王朝银行家族中发生的那样，继承人失去了赚钱的激情，但却没有花钱。科西莫衣食无忧的儿子皮耶罗，家族中的 “弗雷多·柯里昂” （电影《教父》中那个没出息的二儿子），对生意没有天赋。他只管理了 8 年，就被痛风折磨得离开了人世。皮耶罗的儿子洛伦佐比他父亲更有天赋，但对银行业的兴趣更少。

Blame it on Plato. Shortly before Cosimo’s death and under his patronage, he had a friar named Marsilio Ficino translate the entire works of Plato into Latin. Ficino Christianized Plato through his translation, but he did so in a way that elevated art and life in general. Nature, in this interpretation, centers around the human soul, which naturally strives heavenward. To reach the pure light of God, that soul has to transcend the impure and earthly, and for Plato there was little more impure or earthly than the making of money, especially through usury.15

这要归咎于柏拉图。在科西莫去世前不久，在他的赞助下，他让一位名叫马西利奥·菲奇诺的修士将柏拉图的全部作品翻译成拉丁文。菲奇诺通过他的翻译使柏拉图基督教化，但他是以一种提升艺术和一般生活的方式进行的。在这种解释中，自然界以人类灵魂为中心，自然而然地向着天堂努力。为了达到上帝的纯洁之光，这个灵魂必须超越不纯洁和世俗的东西，而对柏拉图来说，“没有什么比赚钱，特别是通过高利贷赚钱更不纯洁或世俗的了。” 15

Ideally, government played a role in encouraging the heavenly aspirations of its citizens. The “safe and happy” state, Plato writes inLaws, accorded the place of highest honor to the soul. To the lowest place the state assigned “money and property.” Plato mentions that “interest was not to be taken on loans,” but he does so almost as an aside, as though the impurity of such a transaction were generally understood.

事实上，政府在鼓励其公民的天堂愿望方面发挥了作用。柏拉图在《法律》（Laws）中写道，“安全和快乐” 的国家给予灵魂最高的荣誉地位。国家将 “金钱和财产” 置于最低位置。柏拉图提到，“贷款不得收取利息”，但他这样做几乎是作为一个旁观者，仿佛这种交易的不纯洁性被普遍理解一样。

The celebration of Plato that Cosimo launched — including extravagant birthday parties every November 7 — all but licensed Lorenzo to ignore the family business, which he promptly did. Now, as Lorenzo saw it, whatever he did short of making money glorified God. So he spent most of his energies on patronizing art, plotting intrigue, and writing poetry, much of it pornographic. One typical poem begins with the unsubtle line, “Cucumbers we’ve got, and big ones,” 16and goes quickly and predictably downhill from there. Lorenzo also dabbled in bad loans and embezzlement. He managed to escape one assassination attempt that his brother Guliano did not and died in bed in that momentous year of 1492, consoled by none other than his erstwhile scourge, the Dominican firebrand, Savonarola.

科西莫发起的柏拉图庆祝活动 —— 包括每年 11 月 7 日的奢侈生日派对 —— 几乎是在诱使洛伦佐忽视家族企业，他也很快就这样做了。现在，在洛伦佐看来，无论他做什么，只要不赚钱就能荣耀上帝。因此，他把大部分精力用于赞助艺术、策划阴谋和写诗，其中大部分是色情诗。一首典型的诗以不含糊的一句话开始 ：“我们有黄瓜，而且是大黄瓜，” 16并从那里迅速且可预见地走向下三路。洛伦佐还涉足不良贷款和挪用公款。他设法逃脱了一次刺杀企图，他的兄弟古里亚诺死于此次刺杀。到了 1492 年那个重要的年份他死在了床上，安慰他的不是别人，正是他曾经的祸害，多米尼加的火炬手萨沃纳罗拉。

Savonarola deserves a sidebar. While the young Lorenzo was writing porn about tumescent cucumbers, the young Savonarola was writing poems titled “On the Decline of the Church.” If proof be needed that not all Catholic clerics were rotten, Savonarola served it up in spades. A contemporary of Lorenzo, Savonarola joined the Dominican order as a young man, heaven-bent on reforming the church from within. Never shy about speaking his mind, he wrote his poem on church decline during his first year of monastic life.17

萨沃纳罗拉应该有一个侧边栏。当年轻的洛伦佐在写关于膨胀的黄瓜的色情文章时，年轻的萨沃纳罗拉正在写题为 “论教会的衰落” 的诗篇。如果需要证明并非所有的天主教教士都是腐朽的，萨沃纳罗拉提供了大量的证据。作为洛伦佐的同代人，萨沃纳罗拉年轻时加入了多明我会，一心想从内部改革教会。他从不羞于说出自己的想法，在修道的第一年就写下了关于教会衰落的诗篇。17

In 1489, three years before Lorenzo’s death, Savonarola descended on Florence determined to purge city and church of their conspicuous consumption. He did so, the Catholic Encyclopedia says in something of an understatement, “without regard to consequences.” 18At San Marco, a church funded by the Medici, he preached against not only the lenders of money but also the spenders of money, the prodigals. The Medici were both. A hard-core ascetic and self-mortifier, Savonarola was among the first to understand the synergy between usury and prodigality.

1489 年，在洛伦佐去世的三年前，萨沃纳罗拉来到佛罗伦萨，决心清除城市和教会的显性消费。18在由美第奇家族资助的圣马可教堂，他不仅宣扬反对放债人，也反对花钱的人，即败家子。美第奇家族两者都是。萨沃纳罗拉是一个顽固的禁欲主义者和自我牺牲者，他是最早理解高利贷和挥霍之间的协同作用的人之一。

After Lorenzo’s death, Savonarola stepped up his assault on then–Pope Alexander VI and the Medici. Inspired by Savonarola’s impassioned homilies, the Florentines rose up and drove Lorenzo’s tyrannical son and heir, Pietro, out of town in 1494, the effective end of the Medici banking era. Backed by French king Charles VIII, Savonarola and his allies established a lively democratic theocracy in Florence.

洛伦佐死后，萨沃纳罗拉加紧了对当时的教皇亚历山大六世和美第奇家族的攻击。在萨沃纳罗拉慷慨激昂的布道词的鼓舞下，佛罗伦萨人奋起反抗，于 1494 年将洛伦佐的暴虐儿子和继承人皮特罗赶出了城，美第奇银行时代实际上已经结束。在法国国王查理八世的支持下，萨沃纳罗拉和他的盟友在佛罗伦萨建立了一个生动的民主神权。

The highlight of Savonarola’s ascendancy was the 1497 “Bonfire of the Vanities” —— a series of public burnings of what secular moralists would one day call “nonproductive items of consumption” : fine clothing, cosmetics, playing cards, dice, mirrors, and more. The impassioned Florentines went after the lenders as well as the spenders. They stormed the Medici palace and burned very near all of the bank’s records.

萨沃纳罗拉上台的亮点是 1497 年的 “虚荣的篝火” —— 一系列公开焚烧世俗道德家有一天会称之为 “非生产性消费” 的物品：精美的衣服、化妆品、扑克牌、骰子、镜子等等。慷慨激昂的佛罗伦萨人在追捕放贷者的同时也在追捕消费者。他们冲进美第奇宫殿，烧毁了几乎所有的银行记录。

A Savonarola partisan, the painter Sandro Botticelli is reported to have fueled one of the bonfires with a few of his own less inspired doodlings. Had he felt a wee bit more repentant he might have tossed in his now-classicAdorationof the Magi. As Florentine art fans surely knew, the three wise men in the painting were all Medici — Cosimo and his two sons, Piero and Giovanni. Botticelli might more accurately have labeled the paintingAdoration of the Medici. The Medici were, not surprisingly, among Botticelli’s more generous patrons.

画家桑德罗·波提切利（Sandro Botticelli）是萨沃纳罗拉的支持者，据说他用自己的一些灵感不足的涂鸦为其中的一堆篝火加油。如果他感到有一点忏悔，他可能会把他现在的经典之作《魔法师的崇拜》（Adoration of the Magi）扔进去。佛罗伦萨的艺术爱好者肯定知道，画中的三位智者都是美第奇家族的人 —— 科西莫和他的两个儿子皮耶罗和乔瓦尼。波提切利可能更准确地将这幅画称为 “美第奇的崇拜”。毫不奇怪，美第奇家族是波提切利更慷慨的赞助人之一。

Historians have a hard time with Savonarola. The excesses of the official church may trouble them, but the reformers frighten them, especially fundamentalists like Savonarola. At the risk of generalization, they would likely have cheered the humanist counterreformers who hanged Savonarola in 1498, just four years after he had driven the Medici out of town. Forty years later, the Florentine elite summoned Cosimo the younger back to Florence where he would eventually become the grand Duke of Tuscany, a Medici bailiwick for the next two hundred years.

历史学家对萨沃纳罗拉很是不满。官方教会的过度行为可能会给他们带来麻烦，但改革者却让他们感到害怕，尤其是像萨沃纳罗拉这样的原教旨主义者。就在他把美第奇家族赶出城的四年后，冒着以偏概全的风险，他们很可能会对 1498 年绞死萨沃纳罗拉的人文主义反改革者表示欢呼。四十年后，佛罗伦萨的精英们召唤小科西莫回到佛罗伦萨，在那里他最终成为托斯卡纳的大公爵，在接下来的两百年里一直是美第奇的辖区。

The Medici would exact their most enduring revenge on Savonarola and his ilk in the person of Lorenzo’s second son, Giovanni. Born in 1475, the future Pope Leo X was invested as a cardinal at sixteen while Lorenzo was still around to stage-manage his ecclesiastical career. Unlike the Jane Fondas and Tori Spellings of the world, who swear their last name had nothing to do with their success, Leo harbored no such illusions. He would ascend to the papacy in 1513 on skids well-enough greased that he did not trouble himself to become a priest until after he became pope.

美第奇家族将通过洛伦佐的次子乔瓦尼对萨沃纳罗拉及其同伙进行最持久的报复。未来的教皇利奥十世出生于 1475 年，16 岁就被任命为红衣主教，而洛伦佐还在身边为他的教会事业做着铺垫。与世界上那些发誓自己的姓氏与成功无关的简·芳达和托里·斯佩林不同，利奥并不抱有这种幻想。他将在 1513 年登上教皇的宝座，他在成为教皇之后，才开始麻烦自己成为一名牧师。

Today’s media critics envision popes as extravagant and self-indulgent, always scheming and intriguing, more interested in the power and perks of the office than in the saving of souls. They ignore the extraordinary two-thousand-year continuity of the papacy and the sterling examples of papal piety in their own lifetimes — Benedict XVI, John Paul II, John XXIII. They prefer instead to confuse the occasional bad apple with the entire crop. It is as if, when they imagine the American presidency, they ignore Lincoln and Washington and fix on Warren G. Harding.

今天的媒体批评者把教皇设想为奢侈和自我放纵，总是心怀鬼胎，这耐人寻味，他们对权力和职务的好处比对灵魂的拯救更感兴趣。人们忽视了教皇职位两千年的非凡延续性，以及他们自己一生中教皇虔诚的杰出典范 —— 本笃十六世、约翰·保罗二世、约翰·二十三世。人们宁愿把偶尔的坏苹果和整个庄稼混淆起来。就好像他们在想象美国总统的时候，忽略了林肯和华盛顿，而把注意力放在沃伦·G·哈定身上（美国历史上最帅却又能力最差的总统）。

As it happens, Pope Leo Xwasthe Warren G. Harding of Catholic popes — a little bit worse actually, much worse come to think of it. In truth, he makes a much too appropriate poster child for those inclined toward anti-Catholicism. Raphael, who flourished under Leo’s patronage, actually provided that poster. To this day, his painting of Leo hangs in the Pitti Gallery in Florence, and Leo does, in fact, look like confirmed Catholic-bashers might have hoped he would: corpulent, effeminate, bandy-legged, shifty-eyed. Were it not for the fact that Leo helped launch the modern era of democratic capitalism — and that by accident — he would have little to recommend him.

恰好，教皇利奥十世是天主教教皇中的沃伦·G·哈丁 —— 实际上有点糟糕，仔细想想的话就更为糟糕。事实上，对于那些倾向于反天主教的人来说，他是一个非常合适的海报儿童。在利奥的赞助下蓬勃发展的拉斐尔实际上提供了这种海报。时至今日，他的利奥画作仍悬挂在佛罗伦萨的皮蒂画廊，而利奥事实上确实像那些被证实的天主教抨击者所希望的那样：肥胖、娘娘腔、腿脚不利索、眼神闪烁。如果不是因为利奥帮助开创了民主资本主义的现代时代 —— 而且是偶然的 —— 没人会乐意提及他。

For the record, Catholics do not impute infallibility to the character of their popes. In Leo’s case, that would require faith beyond all understanding. As Dante made clear, Catholics, like all Christians, fully recognize the weaknesses of a fallen human nature, even among popes. Indeed, the first pope, Peter, the rock upon whom the church was built, proved more gelatinous than rocklike on the eve of Jesus’ death, and yet Jesus did not hold that permanently against him.

为了记录在案，天主教徒不会将无误性归于他们教皇的性格。在利奥的情况下，这将需要超越一切理解的信仰。正如但丁所表明的那样，天主教徒和所有基督徒一样，充分认识到堕落的人性的弱点，甚至在教皇中也是如此。事实上，第一任教皇彼得是教会赖以建立的岩石，在耶稣去世前夕，他被证明是凝胶状的，而不是岩石状的，但耶稣并没有因此而永久地反对他。

In Catholic doctrine, infallibility is reserved only for solemn declarations on faith or morals as inspired by divine revelation. Church rulings on usury have never quite risen to that level. Indeed, Leo would rewrite the rule book on this issue as an administrative aside, much the way Jimmy Carter did the 401(k), each ushering in an era of investment and prosperity without quite meaning to.

在天主教教义中，无误性只保留给由神圣启示启发的关于信仰或道德的庄严声明。教会对高利贷的裁决从未上升到这个高度。事实上，利奥将在这个问题上改写规则，作为行政上的一个旁观者，就像吉米·卡特对 401(k) 所做的那样，每个人都迎来了一个投资和繁荣的时代，但并没有什么意义。

The case upon which Leo ruled involved an institution called theMonte di Pietà(Piety Mountain), this one located at Perugia in modern-day Italy. The case had been kicking around for a half century without resolution. TheMonte di Pietàwas run by the Franciscan order to help the poor through times of peril. Hard-pressed locals would come to theMonte di Pietàand leave the sixteenth-century equivalent of an engagement ring or a chain saw in exchange for a loan. The term of the loan would typically last the course of a year and then, ideally, the borrower would repay the loan and regain the collateral.19

利奥裁决的案件涉及一个名为虔诚山（Monte di Pietà）的机构，该机构位于现代意大利的佩鲁贾。这起案件已被搁置了半个世纪而没有解决。虔诚山是由方济各会管理的，旨在帮助穷人度过危险期。困难的当地人会来到虔诚山，留下相当于十六世纪的订婚戒指或链锯来换取贷款。贷款期限通常会持续一年，然后，在理想情况下，借款人会偿还贷款并重新获得抵押品。19

The Bishop of London had launched the first such institution in 1361. Backed by generous donors who provided the start-up capital, these institutions found particularly friendly soil in Italy the following century. In his memoirs, Franciscan Marco di Matteo Strozzi has left a record of his order’s intentions, namely, to deny Jewish moneylenders their seemingly usurious rates by replacing them with this chain of Christian-themed pawnshops.20

伦敦的主教在 1361 年启动了第一个这样的机构。在提供启动资金的慷慨捐助者的支持下，这些机构在下一世纪在意大利找到了特别友好的土壤。在他的回忆录中，方济各会的马尔科·迪·马特奥·斯特罗兹(Marco di Matteo Strozzi)留下了关于其教团意图的记录，即用这种以基督教为主题的连锁当铺取代犹太放债人的看似高利贷的利率。20

What the Franciscans may have overlooked is that the managers of Jewish pawnshops, not having taken vows of chastity or poverty, had wives and kids to support, some of whom were likely very demanding. What the Franciscans did not overlook is that they, too, would have to charge borrowers a certain interest rate to cover the occasional default and their own humble overhead.

方济各会可能忽略的是，犹太当铺的经理没有发过贞洁或贫穷的誓言，他们有妻子和孩子需要抚养，其中一些人可能要求很高。方济各会没有忽视的是，他们也必须向借款人收取一定的利息，以弥补偶尔的违约和他们自己的卑微开销。

To understand the spirit of the Franciscan endeavor, one need look no further than recent Nobel Peace Prize winner Muhammad Yunus, a Bangladeshi banker with an American education. Some thirty years ago, as a well-fed economics professor in a starving country, Yunus felt the moral urge to experiment with what he calls “micro-lending.” 21

要理解方济各会努力的精神，不需要再看最近的诺贝尔和平奖得主穆罕默德·尤努斯，一位受过美国教育的孟加拉国银行家。大约三十年前，作为一个饥饿的国家中衣食无忧的经济学教授，尤努斯感到有一种道德上的冲动，要尝试他所谓的 “小额贷款”。21

The first loan — for just twenty-seven dollars — came out of his pocket. Although traditional bankers thought he was daft, Yunus kept making loans to collateral-less poor people. He was convinced that folks who had the gumption to start cottage industries would have the honor to repay their loans, and this they did. Indeed, more than 98 percent of his 2.5 million loans have been repaid. In the process, Yunus and his Grameen Bank have transformed thousands of poor people into a productive class of entrepreneurs. Some one hundred different countries have since adapted the Grameen micro-credit program, including our own.

第一笔贷款 —— 仅 27 美元 —— 来自他的口袋。尽管传统的银行家们认为他很愚蠢，但尤努斯还是继续向没有抵押物的穷人提供贷款。他相信，那些有勇气开创家庭手工业的人将有勇气偿还贷款，而他们也确实做到了。事实上，在他的 250 万笔贷款中，98% 以上都得到了偿还。在这个过程中，尤努斯和他的格拉米银行已经将成千上万的穷人转变为有生产力的企业家阶层。此后，约有 100 个不同的国家采用了格拉米银行的小额信贷计划，包括我们自己。

Like the Franciscans, Yunus understood that he would have to charge a modest interest if he were to run a business. By the twenty-first century, even the socialists on the Nobel committee had come to understand this. They awarded Yunus and the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh top honors in 2006, the first forprofit enterprise ever to be so distinguished, a refreshing turn of events.

像方济各会一样，尤努斯明白，如果他要经营企业，就必须收取适度的利息。到了 21 世纪，甚至连诺贝尔委员会中的社会主义者也已经明白了这一点。2006 年，他们授予尤努斯和孟加拉国的格拉米银行最高荣誉，这是有史以来第一个获得如此殊荣的营利性企业，这是一个令人耳目一新的转变。

In the sixteenth century, however, the issue of interest remained unsettled. The rival Dominican order was vexed because the Franciscans seemed to be cheating on church law. The Jewish moneylenders were equally vexed because the Franciscans were undercutting their market. Charges were brought, and in 1513, they came before the Lateran Council over which Leo was presiding.22

然而，在十六世纪，利益问题仍然没有得到解决。敌对的多米尼加教团很烦恼，因为方济各会似乎在欺骗教会法律。犹太放债人也同样感到烦恼，因为方济各会正在压低他们的市场。他们提出了指控，并在 1513 年提交给利奥主持的拉特兰会议。22

An original of Leo’s “broadside bull” still exists. CalledBulla concilii in decima sessione super materia Montis Pietatis, it is for sale online for a mere 1750 British pounds with, one hopes, easy financing terms available. In a nutshell, Leo ruled that theMonte di Pietàwas a valuable institution and that its policies only made sense. Never one to do things halfway, he then threatened with excommunication anyone who said otherwise. Covering Leo’s back during his papacy was cousin Giulio, the son of Giuliano de Medici, the unlucky brother killed during the assassination attempt on Lorenzo. Two years after Leo’s death in 1521, Giulio was named Pope Clement VII.

利奥的 “宽边公牛” 的原件仍然存在。它被称为《第十次会议上的公报，关于虔诚山的材料》，它在网上出售，价格仅为 1750 英镑，人们希望它有简单的融资条款。简而言之，利奥裁定虔诚山是一个有价值的机构，其政策才有意义。他从来不是一个做事半途而废的人，然后他威胁要将任何持反对意见的人逐出教会。在利奥担任教皇期间，他的表弟朱利奥为他撑腰，他是朱利亚诺·德·美第奇的儿子，这个不幸的兄弟在刺杀洛伦佐的行动中丧生。1521 年利奥死后两年，朱利奥被任命为教皇克莱门特七世。

Before dying, Leo excommunicated an obstreperous German priest. That same decade, an aspiring French theologian left the Catholic Church. Had he been paying more attention, Pope Clement VII might have been troubled by the respective falling away of Martin Luther and John Calvin, but that anxiety he would leave to future popes.

在临终前，利奥将一位顽固的德国神父逐出教会。在同一年，一位有抱负的法国神学家离开了天主教会。如果教皇克莱门特七世有更多的关注，他可能会对马丁·路德和约翰·加尔文各自的堕落感到不安，但这种焦虑他将留给未来的教皇。

sevenThe Rules of Equity 公平法则

IN THE EUROPE OF THE 1450S, WHILE THE PIOUS POPE NICHOLAS V held (relatively) gentle sway over the united colors of Christendom, a German craftsman was hard at work on a project that would, without his intending, forever disunite them. Unworried by the intentions of Johannes Gutenberg, and generally encouraging of his progress, the Vatican in 1454 helped him finance his new endeavor by contracting with him to print thousands of indulgences, formal papal decrees that one’s sins had been forgiven. A year later Gutenberg produced his famous Bible, and the world has not been the same since.

在十四世纪五十年代的欧洲，当贪婪的教皇尼古拉五世（相对）温和地控制着基督教世界的统一色彩时，一位德国工匠正在努力完成一个项目，这个项目将在他无意中永远使他们分离。梵蒂冈对约翰内斯·古腾堡的意图并不担心，而且普遍鼓励他的进展，在 1454 年，梵蒂冈帮助他为新的努力提供资金，与他签订了印刷数千份宽恕令的合同，宽恕令是表示一个人的罪行得到宽恕的正式教皇命令。一年后，古腾堡制作了他著名的《圣经》，此后，世界就变得不一样了。

Print had at least as much impact on the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries as the Internet did on the late twentieth and twenty-first. Each democratized the flow of information, but any gain in knowledge was offset by a loss in humility, a formula for trouble in either era. Despite their enhanced access to data, the humanists of the Gutenberg era chose to forget the accomplishments of the millennium that had just preceded them. In their retelling, a purifying gale had blown through the Europe of that epoch, sweeping away with it the dust and cobwebs of a cranky old papacy.

印刷品对十五和十六世纪的影响至少与互联网对二十和二十一世纪的影响一样大。两者都实现了信息流的民主化，但任何知识的获得都被谦逊的丧失所抵消，这在任何一个时代都是一个麻烦的公式。尽管他们获得了更多的数据，古腾堡时代的人文主义者还是选择了忘记在他们之前的那个千年的成就。在他们的叙述中，一股净化的大风吹过了那个时代的欧洲，将一个古怪的老教皇的灰尘和蜘蛛网一扫而空。

On the economic front, this story line received its imprimatur with the 1905 publication of Max Weber’sThe Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism. Weber argued, in essence, that the Protestant Reformation inspired the capitalist revolution. Once a Christian had lost the safety net of authoritative Catholicism, he was thrown onto his own resources. Insecure and anxious about salvation, especially if he hewed to a Calvinist faith, he turned his energy to work and looked to his ensuing success as a sign of his place among the elect.1
