在经济方面，随着 1905 年马克斯·韦伯的《新教伦理与资本主义精神》的出版，这一故事线得到了认可。韦伯认为，从本质上讲，新教改革激发了资本主义革命。一旦基督徒失去了权威的天主教的安全网，他就会被抛向自己的资源。不安全感和对救赎的焦虑，特别是如果他坚持加尔文主义的信仰，他把精力转向工作，并期待他随后的成功作为他在选民中的地位的标志。1

For Weber, this psychic energy survived the erosion of faith and piety and became part of the culture, no greater exemplar of which was one of America’s own founding fathers. “We shall nevertheless provisionally use the expression ‘spirit of capitalism’ for that attitude which,in the pursuit of a calling, strives systematically for profit for its own sake in the manner exemplified by Benjamin Franklin,” 2writes Weber. He traces this rationalization, at least in part, to the fact that Luther — and other self-styled reformers who followed — paid more attention to the Old Testament than the Catholic hierarchy had, and so were more influenced by Jewish thought.

对韦伯来说，这种精神能量在信仰和虔诚的侵蚀中幸存下来，并成为文化的一部分，其中最典型的例子就是美国自己的开国元勋之一。“尽管如此，我们还是要暂时使用‘资本主义精神’这一表述，来表示那种在追求一种召唤的过程中，以本杰明·富兰克林所示范的方式，系统地为自身利益而奋斗的态度”，2韦伯写到。他认为这种合理化至少有一部分原因是，路德 —— 以及后来其他自诩为改革者的人 —— 比天主教高层更关注《旧约》，因此更受犹太思想的影响。

For all his insight, Weber generalized much too freely in linking Martin Luther and John Calvin as partners in economic progress. The progress needed no jump start. When Luther and Calvin surfaced, both within a hundred years of the introduction of the Gutenberg Bible, they inherited a commercial revolution that had been progressing — with few major reversals — for the last five hundred years. Their contemporaries in the Catholic Church were quietly yielding on the flat-out usury ban. In the early sixteenth century, Franciscan Juan de Medina emerged as the first scholastic writer to insist that risk should rightly be rewarded with interest.3Others would follow.

尽管韦伯的洞察力很强，但他在把马丁·路德和约翰·加尔文作为经济进步的伙伴联系起来时，过于随意地概括了。这种进步不需要启动。当路德和加尔文出现时，他们都是在古腾堡圣经问世后的一百年内出现的，他们继承了过去五百年来一直在进行的商业革命 —— 很少出现重大的逆转。与他们同时代的天主教会在禁止高利贷方面悄悄地做出了让步。十六世纪初，方济各会的胡安·德·梅迪纳成为第一位坚持认为风险应该得到利息回报的学者。3其他人也会跟进。

As a case study in progress, one need look no further than the rollout of Gutenberg’s Bible. Only in this fully Catholic world (and nowhere else) would Gutenberg have been able to find the freedom, the capital, and the institutional stability to industrialize the art of movable type. Gutenberg had investors, a practice the church allowed as long as all investors shared the risk. He also received a loan, presumably interest free, which remains one of the few advantages of having in-laws.

作为一个进步的案例研究，我们不需要再看古腾堡圣经的推广。只有在这个完全的天主教世界里（而不是其他地方），古腾堡才能找到自由、资本和机构的稳定性，使活字印刷术工业化。古腾堡有投资者，这是教会允许的做法，只要所有投资者共同承担风险。他还得到了一笔贷款，估计是免息的，这仍然是有姻亲的少数优势之一。

Complicating the whole notion of reform was that these two theological rebels, Calvin and Luther, had largely divergent views on the direction of things economic. Calvin was bridging to the seventeenth century, Luther to the fifteenth. Nowhere was their divergence more evident than on the related subjects of usury and the Jews. Given the Reformation’s elevation of the individual preacher over the institution, Calvin would have more impact on the subject of usury than any pope who preceded him, and Luther would have more impact on the fate of the Jews.

使整个改革概念复杂化的是，这两位神学反叛者，加尔文和路德，对事物的经济方向有很大的分歧。加尔文是在十七世纪，路德是在十五世纪。他们的分歧最明显的莫过于在高利贷和犹太人的相关问题上。鉴于宗教改革将传教士个人置于机构之上，加尔文对高利贷问题的影响将超过他之前的任何教皇，而路德对犹太人的命运影响更大。

In the way of background, the thirteen-year-old Martin Luther headed off to a Latin school in Magdeburg, Germany, in 1497, the same year that Savonarola was scorching the vanities in Florence. At twenty-one, Luther dropped out of law school and became a monk, an intensely introspective one at that. Two years later, he was ordained a priest and turned to teaching to help break out of his own self-imposed gloom.4In 1517, Luther posted his famed ninety-five theses on the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg, objecting, among other things, to the sale of indulgences by the Vatican. A century earlier this would likely have remained a local dustup, but the printing press changed all that. Within months, Luther’s defiance was the talk of Christendom.

在背景方面，13 岁的马丁·路德于 1497 年前往德国马格德堡的一所拉丁语学校，同年萨沃纳罗拉正在佛罗伦萨 “把虚荣架在篝火炙烤”。21 岁时，路德从法学院退学，成为一名修士，而且是一名强烈反省的修士。41517 年，路德在维登堡城堡教堂的门上张贴了他著名的九十五条论文，除其他事项外，反对梵蒂冈出售赎罪券。在一个世纪前，这很可能只是一场地方性的骚乱，但印刷术改变了这一切。在几个月内，路德的抗争成为基督教世界的话题。

For the next three years, the Vatican walked the increasingly obstreperous Luther through a series of unfriendly administrative hearings. Although the potential punishment could be a bit more severe — burning at the stake, for instance — these hearings were, if anything, more forgiving than those college students face today should they run afoul of campus thought police. In 1520, Lorenzo’s son, Pope Leo X, issued a formal decree threatening Luther with excommunication if he persisted. Luther persisted in spades, publicly burning the papal bull and irrevocably crossing the Rubicon that he had dug for himself. A year later, Luther was declared a heretic. He escaped with his freedom and, possibly, his life only through the intervention of certain sympathetic German nobles.

在接下来的三年里，梵蒂冈通过一系列不友好的行政听证会来引导日益顽固的路德。尽管潜在的惩罚可能会更严重一些 —— 例如，被烧死在火刑柱上 —— 但这些听证会，如果有的话，比今天大学生在触犯校园思想警察时面临的听证会更宽容。1520 年，洛伦佐的儿子，教皇利奥十世，发布了一项正式法令，威胁路德，如果他坚持下去，就会被逐出教会。路德坚持不懈，公开焚烧教皇的诏书，无可挽回地越过了他为自己挖的卢比肯河。一年后，路德被宣布为异端。在某些同情他的德国贵族的干预下，他才带着自由，甚至可能是生命逃了出来。

For the next twenty-five years, Luther would speak and write on any number of subjects, but few with more vigor than when speaking on usury, a subject he addressed in detail in 1524, just three years after his final break with the Catholic Church. Given that the ranks of the shy and diffident produce few heretics, it should not surprise that Luther spoke forcefully, even when merely defining a subject. “He who lends expecting to get back something more or something better than he has loaned,” writes Luther, “is clearly a damned usurer.” 5His source was Christ himself. Here he cites the critical passage in Luke, “Lend, hoping for nothing again.”

在接下来的 25 年里，路德会就任何数量的主题进行演讲和写作，但很少有人比他在谈论高利贷时更有力度，这是他在 1524 年详细讨论的一个主题，就在他与天主教会最后决裂的三年后。鉴于害羞和漫不经心的人很少产生异端，路德说话很有力，即使只是在定义一个主题时也不令人惊讶。路德写道 ：“借钱的人期望得到比他所借出的更多或更好的东西，显然是一个该死的高利贷者。” 5他的来源是基督本人。在这里，他引用了路加福音中的关键段落 ：“借给人不要指望偿还。”

Luther then focuses his ire — and his irony — on those arguments used to justify this “tender business.” 6He had a particular distaste for semantic evasions. Just as today one man’s interest-only, adjustable-rate mortgage is another man’s predatory loan, so the neologisminteressewas, for Luther, just another way of saying “damned usury.”

路德随后将他的愤怒 —— 和他的讽刺 —— 集中在那些用来为这种 “温柔的生意” 辩护的论据上。6他对语义的规避特别反感。就像今天一个人的只付利息、可调整利率的抵押贷款是另一个人的掠夺性贷款一样，所以新词 “利息” （interesse）对路德来说，只是 “该死的高利贷” 的另一种说法。

Interessederives from the Latin, meaning “that which is in between.” Introduced by the Christian scholar Hispanus in the early thirteenth century (but far from universally accepted),interessewas originally used to describe the compensation awarded a lender for a loan not returned on time. It covered his theoretical loss of the use of that money from the date that the loan should have been repaid until the date it was repaid. In more opportunistic circles,interesseall but replaced the wordusuryto describe the opportunity cost of money lent during the entire cost of a commercial loan. In English, it would hold that meaning and evolve intointerest.

interesse源自拉丁语，意思是 “介于两者之间”。由基督教学者历史学家希斯帕努斯（Hispanus）在 13 世纪初提出（但远未被普遍接受），interesse最初用于描述贷款人因未按时归还贷款而获得的补偿。它涵盖了他在理论上的损失，即从贷款本应偿还之日到偿还之日的资金使用情况。在更多的机会主义圈子里，interesse几乎取代了usury这个词，来描述商业贷款的整个成本期间借出资金的机会成本。在英语中，它将保持这个意思，并演变成interest。

Luther would have none of this. To him “this noble, precious, tender, little word” was simply usury by another name. “Here they say, now, that the purchase of the income is proper because, with these [100] gulden, I might perhaps have made more in a year, and the interest is just and sufficient,” he observes. But, as Luther fairly argues, nowhere in the real world is there any guarantee that money would make money during a given time. “If I have a hundred gulden, and am to do business with it,” says Luther, “I may run a hundred kinds of risk of making no profits at all, nay, of losing four times as much besides.” 7

路德不会接受这些。对他来说，“这个高贵的、珍贵的、温柔的、小小的词只是换了个名字的高利贷”。“现在他们在这里说，购买收入是适当的，因为用这一百个古尔登，我也许可以在一年内赚得更多，而且利息是公正和足够的”，他观察到。但是，正如路德公正地论证的那样，在现实世界中，没有任何地方可以保证金钱在特定的时间内会赚钱。路德说 ：“如果我有一百个古尔登，并且要用它来做生意，我可能要冒一百种风险，完全没有利润，不，还要损失四倍。” 7

Luther was more understanding of income invested in land, but here, too, he offered caveats. He objected to the lumping together of properties, as was common, and insisted on “specifying and defining the particular piece of ground from which the income is derived.” In this way, the income would fluctuate with the value of the ground, “as is right.” He also objected to the taking of “too much return” on the land. He defined “too much” as the 7 to 10 percent return that was then something of a norm. “The poor common people are secretly imposed upon and severely oppressed,” he objected. In other words, there should be no bundling of mortgages, no subprime loans, and no predatory lending, even on land. “The rulers ought to look into this,” 8says Luther, nearly five hundred years before his time.

路德对投资于土地的收入更加理解，但在这里，他也提出了注意事项。他反对将财产混为一谈，这很常见，并坚持 “具体说明和定义收入所来自的特定土地”。这样一来，收入就会随着土地的价值而波动，“这是正确的”。他还反对在土地上获取 “过多的回报”。他把 “太多” 定义为 7% 到 10% 的回报，这在当时是一种标准。他反对说 ：“贫穷的老百姓被暗中强加，受到严重的压迫。换句话说，不应该有捆绑抵押贷款，不应该有次级贷款，不应该有掠夺性贷款，甚至在土地上。统治者应该研究这个问题”，8路德说，这比他的时代早了将近五百年。

Perhaps given his German background, Luther was not averse to using the state to enforce the comprehensive Christian business ethics that he lays out for his followers (and not just on the question of usury). Like almost all Christian philosophers, Luther accepted private property and enterprise. “It is not to be denied,” he writes, “that buying and selling are necessary.” 9He believed, however, that a combination of internal and external restraints should shape the kind of trade that states and individuals transacted.

也许考虑到他的德国背景，路德并不排斥使用国家来执行他为其追随者制定的全面的基督教商业伦理（而不仅仅是在高利贷问题上）。像几乎所有的基督教哲学家一样，路德接受私有财产和企业。他写道 ：“不可否认，买卖是必要的。” 9然而，他认为，内部和外部约束的结合应该形成国家和个人交易的那种贸易。

“Cattle, wool, grain, butter, milk and other goods,” Luther writes, “these are gifts of God.” He may have been the first person of consequence, however, to inveigh against “foreign trade,” especially trade from points east like “Calcutta, India, and such places.” The problem with this trade was not only that it “drain[ed] away the wealth of land and people,” but that it also corrupted them, specifically those “costly silks, gold-work and spices, which minister only to luxury and serve no useful purpose.” 10

“牛、羊毛、谷物、黄油、牛奶和其他商品”，路德写道，“这些都是上帝的礼物。” 然而，他可能是第一个对 “外国贸易”，特别是对来自 “印度加尔各答和此类地方” 的东方贸易进行抨击的有影响的人。这种贸易的问题不仅在于它 “耗尽了土地和人民的财富”，而且还腐蚀了它们，特别是那些 “昂贵的丝绸、金饰和香料，它们只为奢侈品服务，没有任何有用的用途”。10

Luther’s frustration with high prices moved him to favor government intervention. Much to his chagrin, the merchants of his acquaintance seemed to have only “one common rule,” namely, to sell at whatever price the market would bear. If, on the upside, this practice was returning a good profit, on the downside it was “opening every door and window to hell.” 11In an ideal Christian world, as Luther saw it, the common rule would not have been, “I may sell my wares as dear as I can or will,” but rather, “I may sell my wares as dear as I ought, or as is right and proper.” Unfortunately, sixteenth-century Germany was not an ideal Christian world. Such a world has not yet existed.

路德对高价格的失望使他赞成政府干预。令他懊恼的是，他所认识的商人似乎只有 “一条共同的规则”，即以市场能承受的任何价格出售。如果从好的方面看，这种做法能带来丰厚的利润，从坏的方面看，它是 “打开了通往地狱的每一扇门和窗”。11在路德看来，在一个理想的基督教世界里，通常的规则不会是 ：“我可以把我的货物卖得越贵越好，或者说是越贵越好”。不幸的是，十六世纪的德国并不是一个理想的基督教世界。这样的世界还没有出现过。

Given the shortcomings of human nature, Luther recommended instead a practice that has been tried by any number of temporal rulers since (although it’s always failed). The authorities, writes Luther, “should appoint over this matter wise and honest men who would appraise the cost of all sorts of wares and fix accordingly the outside price at which the merchant would get his due and have an honest living.” Luther was savvy enough to know that Germans were too “busy with drinking and dancing” 12to tolerate much regulation. The best he could hope for was that competition would force merchants to sell their wares in a common market at a customary price.

鉴于人性的缺陷，路德推荐了一种做法，这种做法后来被任何数量的临时统治者所尝试（尽管它总是失败）。路德写道，“当局应该任命聪明和诚实的人负责此事，他们将评估各种商品的成本，并相应地确定外部价格，使商人能够得到他应得的报酬，并有一个诚实的生活”。路德很聪明，知道德国人太 “忙于喝酒和跳舞” 12，无法容忍很多监管。他所希望的最好结果是，竞争会迫使商人在一个共同的市场上以习惯的价格出售他们的商品。

Luther wrote in detail about a wide range of commercial transactions — annuities, a just price, and usury among them. In this he was not unique. In pre-Enlightenment Christendom, Protestant and Catholic philosophers saw no reason to separate faith and finance. Many tried to craft an integrated Christian business ethic. But as international commerce became more uniform, and faith became less so, such efforts came to seem less and less relevant. If they chose to, and many did, leaders in the realm of commerce could ignore the whole history of Judeo-Christian business philosophy. As shall be seen, this has not necessarily been to the benefit of the world’s economy.

路德详细写了一系列的商业交易 —— 年金、公正的价格和高利贷等。在这一点上，他并非独一无二。在启蒙运动前的基督教国家，新教和天主教哲学家们认为没有理由将信仰和金融分开。许多人试图制定一个综合的基督教商业伦理。但随着国际商业变得更加统一，而信仰变得不那么统一，这种努力似乎越来越不相关。如果他们选择这样做，而且很多人确实这样做了，商业领域的领导人可以忽略整个犹太教·基督教商业哲学的历史。正如我们将看到的那样，这不一定对世界经济有利。

French theologian John Calvin broke from the Catholic Church in the same turbulent decade that Luther did, but from his writing, especially on the subject of usury, one would think that he happened on the scene a century or so later. Environment mattered here. While Luther wrestled with his demons in the closed quarters of a German monastery, Calvin stuck with law school — and that under the influence of reform-minded French humanists.

法国神学家约翰·加尔文与路德在同一动荡的十年中脱离了天主教会，但从他的著作，尤其是关于高利贷的主题，人们会认为他是在一个世纪左右才出现的。环境在这里很重要。当路德在德国修道院的封闭区域与他的恶魔搏斗时，加尔文坚持在法学院学习 —— 而且是在具有改革意识的法国人文主义者的影响下。

In the France of the 1530s, reform was a pretty brutal business, and Calvin and friends found themselves on the run, first to Geneva and then to Strasbourg and then to Geneva again and then to Strasbourg again and then finally to Geneva. In 1536, still only twenty-six years old, Calvin published his theological masterwork,Institutes of the Christian Religion, and his reputation was established. Calvin would live and write for nearly thirty more tumultuous years and leave perhaps his greatest influence on Western culture through the portal of New England.

在 1530 年代的法国，改革是一件相当残酷的事情，加尔文和朋友们发现自己正在逃亡，先是到日内瓦，然后到斯特拉斯堡，再到日内瓦，然后再到斯特拉斯堡，最后到日内瓦。1536 年，加尔文仍然只有 26 岁，他出版了他的神学巨著《基督教教义》，他的名声就此确立。加尔文还将生活和写作近 30 年的动荡岁月，并通过新英格兰的门户留下他对西方文化的最大影响。

Although Weber and others have given Calvin, if anything, too much credit for the development of the capitalist spirit, Calvin deserves his due on the subject of usury. In this regard, he was something of a revolutionary. In his celebrated letter to his colleague Sachinus in 1545, he broke with the nearly three-millennia-old Judeo-Christian usury ban and adapted the spirit of the Gospels to the imperatives of sixteenth-century commerce.

尽管韦伯和其他人在资本主义精神的发展方面给了加尔文太多的荣誉，但在高利贷问题上，加尔文应该得到他应有的回报。在这方面，他是一个革命者。在他 1545 年写给他的同事萨奇纳斯（Sachinus）的著名信件中，他打破了近三千年的犹太教·基督教高利贷禁令，并使福音书的精神适应十六世纪商业的需要。

In reading Calvin and Luther, one cannot help but be impressed by their super-sized certitude. Catholic church fathers like Aquinas and Antoninus moved forward but always probingly, with continual backward glances at the wise men who preceded them, Christian and classical. For Calvin and Luther, it was pedal to the metal, with no looking back until they got to Jesus. They may have respected their predecessors, but they trusted their own instincts and inspiration more.

在阅读加尔文和路德时，人们不能不被他们的超大肯定性所打动。像阿奎那斯和安东尼这样的天主教会教父一直在前进，但总是在探究，不断地向他们之前的智者、基督教和古典教派的人看去。对加尔文和路德来说，他们是踩着金属踏板前进的，不回头看，直到他们找到耶稣。他们可能尊重他们的前辈，但他们更相信自己的直觉和灵感。

“I am certain that by no testimony of Scripture is usury wholly condemned,” writes Calvin. “For the sense of that saying of Christ, ‘Lend hoping for nothing again’ (Luke 6:35), has up to this time been perverted.” 13Perverted! One reason Calvin succeeded while so many other breakaway divines failed is the clarity of his thought and language. He may have spoken boldly, but he did not bluster. Nor was he at all intimidated by the cautious thinking on this subject of the church fathers, let alone Luther. Says Calvin of Jesus, “His words ought to be interpreted that while he would command loans to the poor without expectation of repayment or the receipt of interest, he did not mean at the same time to forbid loans to the rich with interest.” 14Touché!

“我确信，圣经中没有任何证词是完全谴责高利贷的”，加尔文写道。“因为基督那句话的意思是：‘借给人不指望偿还’（路加福音 6:35），到现在为止一直被扭曲误解了。” 13加尔文成功的原因之一是他的思想和语言的清晰性，而其他许多断章取义的神学家则在这方面一败涂地。他可能说得很大胆，但他并没有虚张声势。他也完全没有被教父们在这个问题上的谨慎思考所吓倒，更不用说路德了。加尔文在谈到耶稣时说 ：“他的话应该被解释为，虽然他命令向穷人提供贷款，但不指望偿还或收取利息，他并不意味着同时禁止向富人提供带利息的贷款。” 14感动！

Calvin strikes the contemporary reader as the first theologian to assess the usury question in the context of a highly evolved sixteenth-century commerce. “If all usury is condemned,” he writes, “tighter fetters are imposed on the conscience than the Lord himself would wish.” 15He worried that an absolutist interpretation could lead to the abandonment not only of the usury ban but also of the spirit behind it. In this regard, he echoes traditional church canon,Cessante ratione, cessat ipsa lex: “When the reason for the law ceases, the law itself ceases.”

加尔文给当代读者的印象是第一个在高度发展的十六世纪商业背景下评估高利贷问题的神学家。“如果所有的高利贷都被谴责”，他写道，“强加在良心上的枷锁比主自己希望的还要紧。” 15他担心绝对主义的解释不仅会导致放弃高利贷禁令，还会导致放弃其背后的精神。在这方面，他呼应了传统的教会教规，“当法律的理由停止，法律本身也停止了。” （Cessante ratione, cessat ipsa lex）

The intrepid Calvin took on Aristotle as well: “It is said, ‘Money does not beget money.’ What does the sea beget?” Calvin walks the reader through the process by which money does, in fact, beget money; that is, through “the product that results from its use or employment.” Why, he wonders, is it morally acceptable to squeeze a poor tenant farmer for a cut of his harvest, but not acceptable to ask a wealthy merchant for return on a commercial loan that has been put to use in some productive industry? “I therefore conclude that usury must be judged, not by a particular passage of Scripture,” says Calvin in summary, “but simply by the rules of equity.” 16

无畏的加尔文也拿亚里士多德开刀。“有人说，‘钱不生钱’。那海生什么？” 加尔文向读者介绍了金钱事实上产生金钱的过程；也就是说，通过 “使用或雇用它所产生的产品”。他想知道，为什么压榨一个贫穷的佃农以获得他的收获，在道德上是可以接受的，而向一个富有的商人索取商业贷款的回报，并将其用于某些生产性行业，则是不可以的？加尔文在总结中说 ：“因此，我的结论是，高利贷必须只根据公平法则判断，而不是根据特定的经文判断。” 16

Christian defenders of the usury ban in the centuries that followed — especially his namesake Calvin Elliott — had obvious problems with Calvin’s stance. The one argument Elliott uses to undercut Calvin is to suggest that his writing on this subject “is wanting in that positive air of assured certainty” that one finds in hisInstitutes.17Wanting in what positive air? It is hard to imagine how Calvin could have written with more certainty. In truth, Calvin weighs into this subject with such jaw-dropping bravado that, seemingly overnight, he would help take usury off the table as a subject of any real controversy in Protestant domains, at least those forms of usury not “repugnant both to Justice and to Charity.” 18

在随后的几个世纪里，高利贷禁令的基督教辩护人 —— 尤其是与他同名的加尔文·艾略特 —— 对加尔文的立场有明显的不满。埃利奥特用来削弱加尔文的一个论据是，他在这个问题上的文章 “缺乏那种有把握的积极空气”，人们在他的《机构》（Institutes）中发现了这一点。17想要什么积极空气？很难想象加尔文如何能写得更有把握。事实上，加尔文以如此令人瞠目结舌的豪言壮语进入这个话题，似乎一夜之间，他将帮助把高利贷从新教领域的任何真正争论的话题中剔除，至少是那些不 “违背正义和慈善” 的高利贷形式。 18

Given his acceptance of lending at interest, Calvin did not share the epoch’s widespread animus toward Jews. In his writings, he treated Jewish arguments respectfully and objectively, so much so that Lutheran antagonists would accuse him of being a “Judaizer” or even a Jew himself.19

鉴于加尔文接受利息借贷，他并不认同那个时代对犹太人的普遍敌意。在他的著作中，他尊重并客观地对待犹太人的论点，以至于路德派的反对者会指责他是一个 “犹太化者”，甚至干脆就是一个犹太人。19

No one ever accused Luther of being either. True, when he broke from the Catholic Church, he looked to the Jews to support his new interpretation of the Bible. They, in turn, were encouraged by his rejection of the papacy for no other reason than it seemed to divide and weaken their enemies. But this uneasy détente would not hold. In his 1523 pamphlet “Jesus Christ Is the Born Jew,” Luther argued that since Christianity had been freed of its papal chains, there was no reason for Jews not to convert en masse. The Jews did not quite see it that way. They argued that the Talmud was a truer version of the Bible than Luther’s and suggested that perhaps he might convert to Judaism.

从来没有人指责路德是这两种人。的确，当他与天主教会决裂时，他寻求犹太人支持他对圣经的新解释。反过来，他们也被他对教皇制度的拒绝所鼓舞，原因无非是这似乎可以分裂和削弱他们的敌人。但这种不安的缓和关系并没有维持下去。在 1523 年的小册子《耶稣基督是天生的犹太人》中，路德认为，既然基督教已经摆脱了教皇的枷锁，犹太人就没有理由不集体皈依。犹太人并不完全这么看。他们认为，《塔木德》是比路德的《圣经》更真实的版本，并建议他或许可以皈依犹太教。

Increasingly frustrated by their obstinacy, Luther turned on the Jews with a vengeance. In 1543, he published “On the Jews and Their Lies,” a 65,000-word treatise more elaborately angry than anything any pope or church doctor had written in the last fifteen centuries. Fueling Luther’s rage, although not explaining it, was his hostility toward usury. The pamphlet contains no fewer than twenty-five distinct attacks on the Jews for this one practice alone.

路德对他们的顽固态度越来越感到沮丧，他对犹太人采取了报复性的态度。1543 年，他发表了《论犹太人和他们的谎言》，这是一篇长达 6.5 万字的论文，比过去 15 个世纪以来任何教皇或教会医生所写的文章都要详尽愤怒。为路德的愤怒推波助澜的是他对高利贷的敌意，尽管这并不是其原因。在这本小册子里，仅仅关于高利贷就有至少 25 个对犹太人的不同攻击。

Luther does not tread gently. “Their breath stinks with lust for the Gentiles’ gold and silver,” he writes of his once almost-allies, “for no nation under the sun is greedier than they were, still are, and always will be, as is evident from their accursed usury.” 20Lending with interest was the least of their intergenerational failings. “They are steeped in greed, in usury,” he warns, “they steal and murder where they can and ever teach their children to do likewise.” 21This language would resonate down the German centuries. Paul Johnson, author of the definitiveHistory of the Jews, describes the treatise as “the first work of modern anti-Semitism, and a giant step forward on the road to the ‘Holocaust.’” 22

路德并没有轻描淡写。他写道 ：“他们对外邦人的金银财宝充满了欲望，因为太阳底下没有一个民族比他们更贪婪，过去是，现在是，将来也是，从他们可恶的高利贷就可以看出。” 20带息贷款是他们代际的最小错误。他警告说 ：“他们沉浸在贪婪中，沉浸在高利贷中，他们在可以偷窃和谋杀的地方偷窃和谋杀，并永远教导他们的孩子也这样做。” 21这种语言在德国几个世纪以来产生了共鸣。权威性的《犹太人史》（History of the Jews）的作者保罗·约翰逊（Paul Johnson）将这篇论文描述为 “现代反犹太主义的第一部作品，在通往‘大屠杀’的道路上迈出了一大步”。22

As Luther saw it, the Jews profaned the Bible by locating their justification for usury within its pages, specifically the “stranger” exemption in Deuteronomy 23:20. “They not only practice usury — not to mention the other vices — but they teach that it is a right which God conferred on them through Moses. Thereby, as in all the other matters, they slander God most infamously.” 23

在路德看来，犹太人把他们放高利贷的理由放在《圣经》的书页里，特别是《申命记》23:20 中的 “陌生人” 豁免权，从而亵渎了《圣经》。“他们不仅实施高利贷 —— 更不用说其他恶习 —— 而且还教导说这是上帝通过摩西赋予他们的权利。因此，正如在所有其他问题上一样，他们对上帝的诽谤是最臭名昭著的。” 23

As keen as Luther was on government intervention, he saw no hope of the state solving his Jewish problem. “Our princes and rulers sit there and snore with mouths hanging open,” he writes of the compromised German authorities, “and permit the Jews to take, steal, and rob from their open money bags and treasures whatever they want.” 24Meanwhile in England, still another Protestant split-off, rulers were doing a good deal more than snoring. The most notable of them, Henry the VIII, was on the verge of passing into law the “Act ‘In restraint of usury.’” 25Although its intent is not easily fathomed in the name, this bill represented the first time a major Christian state gave the green light to usury, albeit with a 10 percent annual limit.

尽管路德热衷于政府干预，但他认为国家解决他的犹太人问题没有希望。“我们的王子和统治者坐在那里，张着嘴打鼾”，他在谈到妥协的德国当局时写道，“允许犹太人从他们敞开的钱袋和财宝中拿走、偷窃和抢劫他们想要的东西。” 24同时在英国，还是另一个新教分裂的国家，统治者做了很多比鼾声更大的事情。其中最引人注目的亨利八世即将通过 “限制高利贷法案”。25尽管从名字上看其意图不容易理解，但该法案代表一个主要基督教国家首次为高利贷开绿灯，尽管每年有 10% 的限额。

In the Muslims’ continued defense of usury, the educational siteMissionIslamdeclares of this time and place in Christian history, “It was now possible for anyone to decide whether something was right or wrong.” 26One can hardly fault our Muslim friends for thinking so.

也就是在基督教历史的这个时间和地点，穆斯林继续为高利贷辩护。《伊斯兰宗旨》（Mission Islam）宣称，“现在任何人都可以决定一件事是正确的还是错误的。” 26我们的穆斯林朋友这样想也无可厚非。

eightI Stand Here for Law 我站在这里是为了法律

NOT LUTHER, NOT CALVIN, NOT BOCCACCIO, NOT DANTE, NOT AQUINAS, not Aristotle, not all of them together have shaped the popular perception of the usurer as much as has a glover’s son from small-town England. William Shakespeare was not yet thirty-five when he wroteThe Merchant of Venice, and although he surely knew a moneylender or two — his father dabbled — he may not have known a Jew.

不是路德、不是卡尔文、不是博卡乔、不是但丁、不是阿奎那斯、不是亚里士多德，他们所有人都没有像英国小镇上的一个胶工的儿子那样塑造了大众对高利贷者的看法。威廉·莎士比亚在写《威尼斯商人》时还不到 35 岁，尽管他肯定认识一两个放债人 —— 他的父亲也在放债 —— 但他可能一个犹太人都不认识。

When Shakespeare was coming of age in the late sixteenth century, there were officially no Jews in all of England. They had been expelled some three centuries earlier after two hundred uneasy years on the island. The first Jews in any number to reach England came in the wake of William’s incursion in 1066. By this time, their identity as the world’s usurers had become more or less fixed. Ironically, as usury laws eased in England during the next two centuries, Jews became less essential and more expendable. In 1278, according to one report, some members of the community stood accused of “coin clipping,” 1a subtle shaving of a coin that allowed the shaver to pocket some percentage of the precious metal and still exchange the coin at face value. This was obviously not appreciated by the locals. They reportedly hanged three hundred of the offenders. In 1290, they drove the entire Jewish population from the island.

当莎士比亚在十六世纪末成年时，整个英格兰正式没有犹太人。他们在岛上生活了两百多年后，于三个世纪前被驱逐出境。第一批到达英格兰的犹太人是在 1066 年威廉的入侵之后。此时，他们作为世界高利贷者的身份已经或多或少地固定下来。具有讽刺意味的是，在接下来的两个世纪里，随着英国高利贷法律的放宽，犹太人变得不再重要，而更容易被消耗掉。在 1278 年，根据一份报告，该社区的一些成员被指控 “剪币”，1一种对硬币进行微妙的刮削，使刮削者可以将一些百分比的贵金属收入囊中，并仍按面值兑换硬币。这显然没有得到当地人的赞赏。据报道，他们绞死了 300 名罪犯。1290 年，他们将所有犹太人赶出了该岛。

The English Jews dispersed throughout Europe and some found safe harbor in the Iberian peninsula. This did not last. Little did for Europe’s Jews. By the late fifteenth century, the Spanish Inquisition, a state-sponsored affair, made life untenable for Spain’s Jewish population, even those who had converted to Christianity. In 1482 Pope Sixtus IV attempted to intervene in this royal witch hunt, but without success. His demands that those accused of heresy receive due process fell on Ferdinand’s willfully deaf ears, and by century’s end the Jews of Spain had been exterminated or expelled.

英国犹太人分散在欧洲各地，有些人在伊比利亚半岛找到了安全港。这并没有持续下去。对欧洲的犹太人来说，这种情况几乎没有。到了十五世纪末，西班牙的宗教裁判所，一个国家支持的事件，使西班牙的犹太人的生活无法维持，即使是那些已经皈依基督教的人。1482 年，教皇西斯图斯四世试图干预这场皇家猎巫行动，但没有成功。他要求那些被指控为异端的人接受适当的程序，但费迪南故意充耳不闻，到本世纪末，西班牙的犹太人已经被灭绝或驱逐。

For most of the sixteenth century, Europe’s Jews were buffeted about by the winds of the Reformation and Counter-Reformation. They had to feel as lost and luckless as they had in the desert circa 1200 BC. Toward century’s end, as the reformers’ zeal exhausted itself, pressures eased, even in England. True, in AD 1552, Parliament had reinstated the usury ban lifted seven years earlier, calling the practice “a vyce most odious and detestable,” 2but in 1571, under Elizabeth, the usury ban was rescinded once and for all.

在十六世纪的大部分时间里，欧洲的犹太人被宗教改革和反宗教改革的风吹得晕头转向。他们不得不像公元前 1200 年左右在沙漠中一样感到迷失和无奈。到了世纪末，随着改革者的热情耗尽，压力有所缓解，甚至在英国。的确，在公元 1552 年，议会恢复了七年前取消的高利贷禁令，称这种做法是 “最可恶、最令人厌恶的行为”，2但在 1571 年，在伊丽莎白领导下，高利贷禁令被彻底废除了。

That lending at interest was now legal in England did not mean that it was popular everywhere. Puritan divines would rail against usury and usurers for decades to come, if not centuries, and the prejudice against Jews faded no more quickly than did the stigma against money lending. Young Shakespeare had to absorb a good deal of the controversy, which was now millennia old and continent wide. This cultural bias finds its most storied expression inHamlet, when Polonius advises his son Laertes of the seductions that await a student in Paris:

有偿放贷现在在英国是合法的，但并不意味着它在各地都很流行。清教徒的神学家们将在未来的几十年里，甚至几个世纪里，对高利贷和高利贷者进行抨击，对犹太人的偏见也没有比对放贷的污名更快消退。年轻的莎士比亚不得不吸收大量的争论，这些争论现在已经有几千年的历史，而且在大陆范围内。这种文化偏见在《哈姆雷特》（Hamlet）中找到了最传奇的表达方式，当波洛涅斯建议他的儿子拉厄斯在巴黎的学生中等待诱惑时：

Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
For loan oft loses both itself and friend,
And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.3

既不是借款人，也不是放款人；
因为贷款经常会失去自己和朋友，
而借贷会使畜牧业的边缘变得暗淡。 3

Shakespeare pulled the plot forMerchantfrom an Italian collection calledIl Pecorone, meaning “The Simpleton,” written two centuries prior.4As to the sensibility, however, that was fresh, bold, and uniquely his own. The action of the play unfolds in contemporary Venice, a city that Shakespeare had never visited. Englishmen thought of Venice in those days much as Henry James and Thomas Mann would three centuries later — dark, decadent, exotic. For all of the city’s storied darkness, however, Shakespeare portrays its citizens as brightly as if they were Englishmen — honorable, upright, and loyal to a fault.

莎士比亚的《威尼斯商人》的情节来自两个世纪前写的意大利文集Il Pecorone，意思是 “傻子”。 4至于感性，那是新鲜、大胆和独特的他自己。该剧的行动在当代威尼斯展开，这是一个莎士比亚从未去过的城市。当时的英国人对威尼斯的看法就像三个世纪后的亨利·詹姆斯和托马斯·曼一样 —— 黑暗、颓废、异国情调。然而，对于这个城市的所有传奇性的黑暗，莎士比亚把它的公民描绘得像英国人一样明亮 —— 可敬、正直、忠诚到极点。

Young Bassanio needs money to woo the fair and seriously affluent Portia, whom he dearly loves. The title character, Antonio, is eager to lend his friend Bassanio the money he needs. Although confident that the ships he has commissioned will soon return to Venice with profits many times the requested loan, Antonio lacks the up-front cash. To get the money, Antonio turns to literature’s most well-known usurer and one of its most memorable characters, the Jew, Shylock. He may be cold and cruel, but Shylock is nobody’s fool. In an aside, upon being introduced to Antonio, he sums up fifteen hundred years’ worth of growing enmity:

年轻的巴萨尼奥需要钱来追求他深爱的美丽而严重富裕的鲍西亚。安东尼奥急于借给他的朋友巴萨尼奥所需的钱。尽管安东尼奥相信他委托的船只很快就会回到威尼斯，而且利润是所要求的贷款的好几倍，但他缺乏前期的现金。为了得到这笔钱，安东尼奥求助于文学作品中最著名的高利贷者和最令人难忘的人物之一，犹太人夏洛克。他可能是冷酷无情的，但夏洛克绝对不是傻瓜。在被介绍给安东尼奥时，他在一旁总结了一千五百年来不断增长的敌意：

How like a fawning publican he looks. I hate him for he is a Christian, but more for that in low simplicity he lends out money gratis and brings down the rate of usance here with us in Venice. If I catch him once upon the hip, I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him. He hates our sacred nation, and he rails, even there where merchants must do congregate, on me, my bargains and my well-won thrift, which he calls interest. Cursed be my tribe, if I forgive him.5

他看起来多么像一个献媚的公仆。我恨他，因为他是一个基督徒，但更多的是恨他在低级的简单中免费借出钱财，使我们在威尼斯借款收益下降。如果我一旦抓住他的把柄，我就会把我对他的古老怨恨养大。他憎恨我们神圣的国家，他甚至在商人必须聚集的地方对我和我的特价商品以及我得来的节俭进行抨击，他称之为利息。如果我原谅他，我的部落将受到诅咒。5

The quarter of the city where merchants “must do congregate” lies beyond the walls of the consigned Jewish quarter. That quarter took its name from the Venetian word forslag, a material found in abundance in this, the old foundry area of Venice.6That word wasgettoorgheto. The ghetto system spread to other cities in the Italian peninsula, as did the word itself. Its purpose was to allow Jews to participate in the city’s commercial life, where they were useful, but to exclude them from its social life, where they were not. For all its implicit indignity, the ghetto provided Jews something of a refuge and one that enabled them to sustain their culture. Although Shakespeare erred in a few details about the life of a Jewish moneylender, he gave Shylock an arresting and authentic personality, the first multidimensional one for a Jew in Western literature.

商人们 “必须聚集” 的城市街区位于受托的犹太区的城墙之外。该区的名称来自威尼斯语中的slag，这是一种在威尼斯的旧铸造区发现的大量材料。6这个词是getto或gheto。犹太区系统传播到意大利半岛的其他城市，正如这个词本身一样。其目的是允许犹太人参与城市的商业生活，在那里他们是有用的；同时还要把他们排除在社会生活之外，在那里他们是没用的。就其所有隐含的羞辱而言，犹太区为犹太人提供了某种庇护，使他们能够维持其文化。尽管莎士比亚在关于犹太放债人生活的一些细节上犯了错误，但他赋予了夏洛克一个引人注目的真实人格，这是西方文学中第一个多维度的犹太人。

Elizabethan playgoers would surely have identified with Antonio, but even the folks in the cheap seats could have understood the Jew’s grudge against him. The merchant does not deny that he has spit on Shylock and called him a dog. He does not ask for Shylock’s friendship, just his money. In the spirit of Deuteronomy, he expects Shylock to lend it as though to “thine enemy” and to exact a penalty beyond the interest if he does not meet his obligation. Loan or no loan, Antonio has no intention of changing his ways toward this Jew or any other. Shylock gets the message, as is evident in the penalty that he demands of this “prodigal Christian,” namely, “an equal pound of your fair flesh” [Act 1, Scene 3]. Overconfident Antonio readily consents to this demand over Bassanio’s heated objection.

伊丽莎白时代的看戏人肯定会认同安东尼奥，但即使是坐在廉价座位上的人也能理解犹太人对他的怨恨。商人并不否认他曾向夏洛克吐口水并称他为狗。他不要求夏洛克的友谊，只要求他的钱。本着《申命记》的精神，他希望夏洛克把钱借给 “你的敌人”，如果他不履行他的义务，他将要求支付利息以外的罚款。不管借不借，安东尼奥都不打算改变他对这个犹太人或其他任何人的态度。夏洛克得到了这个信息，从他对这 “浪荡的基督徒” 要求的惩罚中可以看出，即 “与你的公平同等的一磅肉” （第一幕，第三场）。在巴萨尼奥的激烈反对下，过于自信的安东尼奥欣然同意了这个要求。

译注：《威尼斯商人》剧中关键词汇 a pound of flesh（一磅肉）是惯用语，形容合法但不合情理的要求或苛索，如：The service provider extracts its pound of flesh from its customers by charging additional fees.

Not surprisingly, some Shakespeare scholars have imputed a barely latent homosexuality to Antonio’s sacrificial affection for Bassanio. Except for one wrinkle, this would not be noteworthy, as academic critics have attempted to “out” just about every character in world literature up to and including Felix and Oscar in Neil Simon’sThe Odd Couple. What makes this assertion interesting, as famed homosexual poet W. H. Auden was quick to notice, is that Shakespeare “must have been familiar with the association of usury with sodomy of which Dante speaks in the Eleventh (sic) Circle of the Inferno.” 7The two are thought to be sins against nature. Antonio, perhaps like his creator, has flirted with both.

毫不奇怪，一些莎士比亚学者将安东尼奥对巴萨尼奥的牺牲性感情归结为一种几乎不存在的同性恋。除了一个问题，这并不值得注意，因为学术批评家们试图 “淘汰” 世界文学中几乎所有的角色，包括尼尔·西蒙的《怪夫妇》中的菲利克斯和奥斯卡。正如著名的同性恋诗人 W·H·奥登迅速注意到的那样，使这一论断变得有趣的是，莎士比亚 “一定熟悉但丁在《地狱》第十一层（原文如此）中谈到的高利贷与鸡奸的关联。” 7这两者被认为是违背自然的罪恶。安东尼奥也许就像他的创造者一样，对这两者都有兴趣。

In one of the play’s subplots, Bassanio’s friend Lorenzo has struck up a serious relationship with Shylock’s daughter Jessica. Few critics note the most basic message implicit in their affair, namely, that Jews are part of the family. They are not the usurious swine that later generations of Europeans, Germans in particular, would portray them.

在该剧的一个分镜头中，巴萨尼奥的朋友洛伦佐与夏洛克的女儿杰西卡建立了严肃的关系。很少有评论家注意到他们的恋情中隐含的最基本信息，即犹太人是家庭的一部分。他们并不是后世的欧洲人，特别是德国人所描绘的高利贷猪猡。

In Elizabethan England, for all of the discrimination against them, Jews moved through the world with more respect and more rights than blacks did in America just fifty years ago. At least they did in Shakespeare’s world. As the plot works itself out, all of Antonio’s ships are lost, and he defaults on his obligation. Shylock, the nightmare usurer, seeks literal satisfaction of his bond. A lesser playwright would have given him the snarling silliness of a Silas Barnaby, theBabes in Toylandvillain who tried to foreclose on the little old woman who lived in the shoe. Shakespeare instead allows Shylock to establish his shared humanity through a passage of sufficient power that it would forever subvert the urge to anti-Semitism in the English-speaking world.

在伊丽莎白时代的英国，尽管存在对他们的歧视，但犹太人在那个世界上的活动比五十年前美国的黑人更受尊重，享有更多权利。至少在莎士比亚的世界里他们是这样。随着剧情的发展，安东尼奥的所有船只都丢失了，他违背了自己的义务。夏洛克，这个噩梦般的高利贷者，要求从字面上满足他的债券。如果不是这样的剧作家，他就会像《玩具园里的婴儿》中的西拉斯·巴纳比（Silas Barnaby）那样咆哮愚蠢，他试图取消住在鞋里的小老太太的抵押品。莎士比亚却让夏洛克通过一段有足够力量的话语来确立他的共同人性，这将永远颠覆英语世界中反犹太主义的冲动。

Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? Fed with same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer, as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge.” [Act 3, Scene 1]

“犹太人不是有眼睛吗？犹太人不是有手、器官、尺寸、感官、情感、激情吗？用同样的食物喂养，能被同样的武器伤害，患同样的疾病，用同样的方法医治，用同样的冬天和夏天来温暖和冷却，难道基督徒不是这样吗？如果你刺伤我们，我们不会流血吗？如果你给我们挠痒痒，我们不笑吗？如果你毒害我们，我们不死吗？你若错误对待我们，我们岂能不复仇。” （第三幕，第一场）

The courtroom scene that follows suggests why the English-speaking countries would eventually dominate the world’s economy and why Jews would prosper in those countries as nowhere else. To succeed, the capitalist enterprise hinges on the rule of law. Its entrepreneurs, minorities included, must be able to depend on the efficacy and fairness of that law. This understanding originated in Mosaic law and was transmitted to Europe through the active agency of Christianity. Although usury laws were still imperfect and evolving in mid-millennium Europe, the attention paid to those laws by both secular and ecclesiastical authorities testified to the moral seriousness of the commercial enterprise.

接下来的法庭场景表明，为什么英语国家最终会主导世界经济，为什么犹太人在这些国家会像其他地方一样繁荣。资本主义企业要想成功，关键在于法治。其企业家，包括少数民族，必须能够依赖该法律的效力和公平性。这种理解起源于摩西法，并通过基督教的积极推动传到欧洲。尽管高利贷法律在千禧年中期的欧洲仍不完善且在不断发展，但世俗和教会当局对这些法律的关注证明了商业企业在道德方面的严肃性。

Shylock understands this, and he fully expects Christian courts to honor his contract. “The duke shall grant me justice,” he assures Antonio. “I’ll have my bond” [Act 3, Scene 3]. Noble Antonio accepts the imperatives of the system as well. Even though it means his death, he is prepared to fulfill the contract into which he willingly entered. “Make no more offers, use no farther means,” he tells the duke. “But with all brief and plain conveniency let me have judgment and the Jew his will” [Act 4, Scene 1]. In thatMerchant of Veniceis a comedy, the audience understands that Antonio will not die, and Shylock will not have his revenge. As the plot turns, Bassanio’s beloved Portia shows up in court disguised as an esteemed young “doctor of the law” by the name of Balthasar (a curious turn, as men played women’s parts in Shakespearean theater). “I stand here for law,” Shylock assures the young jurist there to offer his authoritative opinion on the difficult case at hand [Act 4, Scene 1].

夏洛克明白这一点，他完全期望基督教法庭能履行他的合同。“公爵会给予我公正的待遇”，他向安东尼奥保证。“我会得到我的担保” （第三幕，第三场）。高贵的安东尼奥也接受了这个制度的要求。即使这意味着他的死亡，他也准备履行他自愿签订的合同。他对公爵说 ：“不要再提条件，不要用更多的手段”，他说。他对公爵说 ：“但要简短明了地让我作出判断，让犹太人得到他的意愿” （第四幕，第一场）。由于《威尼斯商人》是一部喜剧，观众明白安东尼奥不会死，夏洛克也不会报仇。随着剧情的发展，巴萨尼奥心爱的鲍西娅伪装成一位受人尊敬的年轻 “法学博士” 出现在法庭上，他的名字叫巴尔塔萨（一个奇怪的转变，因为在莎士比亚的戏剧中，男人扮演女人的角色）。“我站在这里是为了法律”，夏洛克向这位年轻的法学家保证，他将对手头的棘手案件提供权威的意见。（第四幕，第一场）

Although acknowledging that the law is on Shylock’s side, Balthasar makes a distinctly Christian plea: “Therefore, Jew, though justice be thy plea, consider this, that, in the course of justice, none of us should see salvation: we do pray for mercy.” Shylock will have none of it. “I crave the law,” he insists.

虽然承认法律是站在夏洛克一边的，但巴尔塔萨提出了一个明显的基督教恳求。“所以，犹太人，虽然你所要求的是公道，可是请你想一想，要是真的按照公道执行起赏罚来，谁也没有死后得救的希望；我们既然祈祷着上帝的慈悲，就应该按照祈祷的指点，自己做一些慈悲的事。” 夏洛克不会接受的。他坚持说 ：“ 我自己做的事，我自己当！我只要求法律允许我照约执行处罚。” （此段引用的是朱生豪的译文）

Bassanio, now flush after his marriage to Portia, offers Shylock twice his investment and much more if he will spare Antonio’s life. When Shylock refuses, Bassanio begs Balthasar to put the law aside. Balthasar denies the request, arguing that it would set a dangerous precedent to do so. “A Daniel come to judgment! Yea, a Daniel!” Shylock gushes about the “wise young judge.” It is at this point that Balthasar serves up more justice than Shylock desires. Yes, he can have the pound of flesh, but not a drop of blood with it. Balthasar also reminds Shylock and the audience that the law, although executed precisely, is not without its inequalities as written. An “alien” who attempts to take the life of a “citizen,” even if done legally, forfeits his entire estate, half to the intended victim and half to the state.

巴萨尼奥在与鲍西娅结婚后，现在身家丰厚，他向夏洛克提供了两倍于他的投资和更多的钱，只要他能放过安东尼奥的生命。当夏洛克拒绝时，巴萨尼奥恳求巴尔萨萨把法律放在一边。巴尔塔萨拒绝了这个请求，认为这样做会开一个危险的先例。“一个丹尼尔来审判! 是的，一个丹尼尔！” 夏洛克对这位 “聪明的年轻法官” 赞不绝口。就在这时，巴尔塔萨提供了比夏洛克所希望的更多的正义。是的，他可以得到那一磅肉，但不能得到一滴血。巴尔塔萨还提醒夏洛克和观众，法律虽然得到了准确的执行，但也并非没有书面的不平等。一个企图夺取 “公民” 生命的 “外国人”，即使是合法的，也会丧失他的全部财产，一半给预定的受害者，一半给国家。

The modern audience watches the denouement uncomfortably. In his mercy, Antonio allows Shylock to keep half of his estate on two conditions: one is that he bequeath the estate to Jessica, now married and converted to Christianity; the second is that he, too, become a Christian. The Elizabethan audience, however, would feel no such discomfort. They would interpret Antonio’s gift as he intended it, a token of mercy: the great Christian gift of redemption, Shylock’s one chance for salvation.

现代的观众看着这个结局感到很不舒服。安东尼奥出于怜悯，允许夏洛克保留他一半的财产，但有两个条件：一是他要把财产遗赠给杰西卡，她现在已经结婚并皈依了基督教；二是他也要成为一名基督徒。然而，伊丽莎白时代的观众不会感到这种不适。他们会按照安东尼奥的意图来解释他的礼物，这是一种仁慈的象征：基督教的伟大救赎礼物，夏洛克唯一的救赎机会。

For a century after its initial performance, no one thought to reviveTheMerchant of Venice. In 1701 George Granville brought a mutilated version to stage calledThe Jew of Venice. Although Granville gave Shylock top billing, he stripped him of his soul and turned him into the stock Jewish villain that audiences of that era expected. In one telling scene, after Bassanio and friends offer toasts at dinner to eternals like friendship and love, this Shylock toasts the glories of compound interest: “My money is my mistress! Here’s to Interest Upon Interest.” 8

在其首次演出后的一个世纪里，没有人想到要《威尼斯商人》重演。1701 年，乔治·格兰维尔将一个残缺不全的版本搬上舞台，名为《威尼斯的犹太人》。虽然格兰维尔给夏洛克安排了最重要的工作，但他剥夺了他的灵魂，把他变成了那个时代的观众所期望的犹太恶棍。在一个有说服力的场景中，当巴萨尼奥和朋友们在晚宴上为友谊和爱情等永恒的事物举杯时，这个夏洛克为复利的辉煌举杯，“我的钱是我的情妇!” 8

It was not until 1741 thatThe Merchant of Venicehad a serious revival. The person responsible was an Irishman from Donegal named Charles Macklin. That the English thought even less of the Irish than they did of Jews may have helped Macklin get in character. If that affinity were not enough, Macklin immersed himself in Jewish history and culture, even visiting the coffee houses in London where “the unforeskinned race” 9held forth, stock-jobbing and exchanging money. By all accounts, Macklin returned the power to Shylock and wiped away all traces of comic villainy from his character. The Shylock Macklin portrayed was malignant, menacing, and dark, and he played that part for the next forty years, until he could no longer remember the lines.

直到 1741 年，《威尼斯商人》才出现了严肃的复兴。负责的人是一个来自多尼戈尔的爱尔兰人，名叫查尔斯·麦克林。英国人对爱尔兰人的看法甚至不如他们对犹太人的看法，这可能有助于麦克林进入角色。如果这种亲和力还不够，麦克林还让自己沉浸在犹太历史和文化中，甚至还去了伦敦的咖啡馆，在那里 “没有皮肤的种族” 9坚持工作，做股票和换钱。从各方面来看，麦克林把权力还给了夏洛克，并从他的角色中抹去了所有滑稽的恶棍的痕迹。麦克林塑造的夏洛克是恶毒的、有威胁的、黑暗的，他在接下来的四十年里一直扮演着这个角色，直到他再也记不住台词为止。

Another century would pass before British actors began to portray Shylock sympathetically. This had much to do with the growth of nineteenth-century liberalism, not just cultural but economic. By this time, lending money at interest was a given. A sophisticated audience would have had a hard time grasping the Venetian anxiety about the same. Nineteenth-century America witnessed no fewer than one hundred productions ofMerchant—— some of them sympathetic, some less so.

又过了一个世纪，英国演员才开始同情地扮演夏洛克的角色。这与十九世纪自由主义的发展有很大关系，不仅仅是文化上的，还有经济上的。此时，借钱生息已是必然。一个成熟的观众会很难理解威尼斯人对同样问题的焦虑。十九世纪的美国见证了不下一百部《威尼斯商人》的制作 —— 其中有些是令人同情的，有些则是不那么令人同情的。

The most celebrated of the American Shylocks that century was Edwin Booth. His father of the same name had been a successful actor in London before abandoning his family and absconding to America with a Covent Garden flower girl — think Eliza Dolittle — with whom he would have ten children. Edwin was the fourth of their six sons.10His little brother, John, would have his greatest fame on the stage of the Ford Theater in Washington. It was there he uttered his memorable line in Latin, “Sic semper tyrannis.” Twelve days later an unappreciative audience of Union soldiers shot and killed brother John.

那个世纪最著名的美国高卢人是埃德温·布斯。他的同名父亲曾是伦敦一名成功的演员，后来抛弃家庭，带着考文特花园的花季少女 —— 就像伊丽莎·杜立德一样 —— 潜逃到美国，与她生了十个孩子。埃德温是他们六个儿子中的第四个。10他的弟弟约翰将在华盛顿的福特剧院的舞台上获得最大声誉。正是在那里，他说出了那句令人难忘的拉丁语 ：“Sic semper tyrannis” （永远的暴君）。12 天后，一个不怀好意的联邦士兵观众开枪打死了弟弟约翰。

Just two years after the assassination of Lincoln, Edwin debuted at the Winter Garden in a sumptuous presentation ofThe Merchant of Venice. Booth played Shylock not as a tragic Jewish figure but as a greedy capitalist, an increasingly common target in theatrical New York. Writes critic John Gross of Booth’s perspective, “There was no reason not to believe the moneylender when he said that Antonio’s chief offense in his eyes was bringing down the rate of interest ‘here with us in Venice.’” 11

就在林肯遇刺两年后，埃德温在冬季花园剧院首次上演了《威尼斯商人》的华美演出。布斯扮演的夏洛克不是一个悲剧性的犹太人物，而是一个贪婪的资本家，一个在纽约戏剧界越来越常见的目标。评论家约翰·格罗斯在谈到布斯的观点时写道 ：“当放债人说安东尼奥在他眼里的主要罪行是‘使我们在威尼斯借款收益下降’时，我们没有理由不相信他。”

Among those who saw Booth at the Winter Garden was the venerable American poet and literary critic William Cullen Bryant. He wrote a review of the performance under the title “Shylock Not a Jew.” Observed Bryant, “It is true that money-changers once spat on in the ghetto are now hugged in the palace.” Bryant cites here the Rothschilds, who were, in fact, Jewish, and the Goulds, who were decidedly not. “But it is not so much that the prejudice against the Jews has ceased but that the love of money has increased — not that the Jews have become as Christians, but that the Christians have become as Jews.” 12That same year, a continent away, Karl Marx released the first volume of his comprehensive masterwork,Das Kapital, a work rooted in almost exactly the sentiment that inspired Bryant’s unease, but with a rather different solution.

在冬季花园观看过布斯的人中，有一位可敬的美国诗人和文学评论家威廉·卡伦·布莱恩特。他以 “夏洛克不是犹太人” 为题写了一篇演出评论。布莱恩特说 ：“确实，曾经在犹太区被唾弃的货币兑换商现在在皇宫里被拥抱”。布莱恩特在这里引用了罗斯柴尔德家族，他们实际上是犹太人，而古尔德家族则明显不是。“但是，与其说是对犹太人的偏见停止了，不如说是对金钱的热爱增加了 —— 不是犹太人变得像基督徒一样，而是基督徒变得像犹太人一样。 ” 12同年，在一个大陆之外，卡尔·马克思发布了他的综合巨著《资本论》（Das Kapital）的第一卷，这部作品几乎完全植根于激发布莱恩特不安的情绪，但有一个相当不同的解决方案。

nineProdigals and Projectors 败家子和投机者

IF KARL MARX HAD AN URGRGE TO UPEND THE ESTABLISHED ORDER, ADAM Smith had the urge to establish exactly what that order was. As the fellow who hammered out the concept of a new economic man, his name was almost too perfect. A smith was someone who forged something refined out of something raw. Adam was, of course, the first man. In 1723, when young Adam came howling into existence, “Smith” was no longer just a profession, but a name. In England, thanks to the advance of democratic capitalism, even the humblest citizens had distinct identities and names of their own, first and last. Smith got his name from the old man. A Scottish attorney, the senior Adam Smith died before his son was born. Beyond the name, Smith the elder and the Smiths before him had bequeathed young Adam a keen sense of self and an economic system that encouraged its exercise.

如果说卡尔·马克思有一种颠覆既定秩序的冲动，那么亚当·斯密则有一种确定这种秩序到底是什么的冲动。作为敲定新经济人概念的人，他的名字几乎太完美了。铁匠（斯密，史密斯，Smith）是指从原始的东西中锻造出精致的东西的人。当然，亚当是第一个男人（跟夏娃一起吃苹果的那个男人）。1723 年，当年轻的亚当嚎叫着出现时，“斯密” 不再只是一个职业，而是一个名字。在英国，由于民主资本主义的发展，即使是最卑微的公民也有自己独特的身份和名字，首尾呼应。斯密从老人那里得到了他的名字。老人亚当·斯密是一位苏格兰律师，他在儿子出生前就去世了。除了名字之外，老斯密和他之前的斯密家族还为小亚当留下了敏锐的自我意识和鼓励其发挥的经济体系。

Smith put his genius on full display in his masterwork,An Inquiry into theNature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations, published in the milestone year of 1776. He was the first political philosopher to establish that free individuals making independent decisions in their own self-interest constituted a viable economic system, one that produced better outcomes than any system any planner could hope to design. A champion oflaissez-faire—— a concept the French introduced but subsequently ignored — Smith rejected prohibitions against usury. This was not surprising. What was surprising, inexplicable really, was that he waxed wobbly on one key point in the usury debate. For reasons equally unclear, upstart Jeremy Bentham zeroed in on this inconsistency in his memorable and occasionally hilarious attack on the good “Dr. Smith,” one of the more entertaining philosophical spitting matches of the era.

斯密在他的代表作《国富论》（Wealth of Nations: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations）中充分展示了他的天才，该书于 1776 年发表，具有里程碑意义。他是第一个确定自由人为了自己的利益做出独立决定的政治哲学家，构成了一个可行的经济体系，这个体系产生的结果比任何计划者希望设计的体系都要好。作为 “自由放任” 的倡导者 —— 一个法国人提出但后来被忽视的概念 —— 斯密拒绝了禁止高利贷的规定。这并不令人惊讶。令人惊讶的是，令人费解的是，他在高利贷辩论中的一个关键点上摇摆不定。由于同样不清楚的原因，后起之秀杰里米·本瑟姆在他对善良的 “斯密博士” 进行的令人难忘且偶尔搞笑的攻击中，将这一不一致的问题归结为那个时代更有趣的哲学吐槽比赛之一。

InWealth of Nations, Smith provides a quick history on English usury laws from the time of Henry VIII. As mentioned, the much-married Henry removed the ban and declared all interest above 10 percent unlawful. His son, Edward VI, in a spate of what Smith calls “religious zeal,” put the ban back in place. His half sister Elizabeth revoked the ban and set the legal rate of interest once again at 10 percent. James I lowered the rate to 8 percent, which was then reduced to 6 percent soon after the Restoration and to 5 percent by Queen Anne. Smith observes that all of these rate changes “seem to have been made with great propriety” 1and followed market rates. As a result, they tended to not retard economic growth in England, which Smith saw as trending upward since the time of Henry VIII.

在《国富论》中，斯密提供了一段关于亨利八世时期英国高利贷法律的快速历史。如前所述，结婚多年的亨利取消了禁令，宣布所有超过 10% 的利息都是非法的。他的儿子爱德华六世在斯密所说的 “宗教狂热” 的刺激下，重新实施了这项禁令。他同父异母的妹妹伊丽莎白撤销了禁令，并再次将法定利率定为 10%。詹姆斯一世将利率降至 8%，复辟后不久又降至 6%，安妮女王将其降至 5%。斯密观察到，所有这些利率变化 “似乎都是非常恰当的” 1并遵循市场利率。因此，它们往往不会阻碍英国的经济增长，而斯密认为英国的经济增长自亨利八世时期以来一直呈上升趋势。

By Smith’s era, the great majority of loans at interest were made in money, which Smith saw not as “barren,” as Aristotle famously did, or idle but as potentially bountiful. What the borrower received was not so much money as “money’s worth,” the ability to put that money to work in some productive endeavor. Of course, not everyone did. Smith makes the by then well-understood distinction between those who used the borrowed money to consume and those who used it to invest.

在斯密的时代，绝大多数贷款都是有利息的，斯密不像著名的亚里士多德那样认为钱是 “贫瘠的”，或者是 “闲置的”，而是潜在地 “富足的”。借款人得到的不是钱，而是 “钱的价值”，是把钱用于某种生产性工作的能力。当然，不是每个人都这样做。斯密对那些用借来的钱进行消费的人和那些用钱进行投资的人进行了当时人们所熟知的区分。

From the lender’s perspective, all loans at interest were made as though to an investor. The lender expected to get the principal back along with “a certain annual rent for the use of it” 2regardless of what the borrower did with the money. The borrower who used the loan for consumption, alas, acted “the part of a prodigal, and dissipates in the maintenance of the idle what was destined for the support of the industrious.” Smith was confident, however, that the industrious outnumbered the prodigals. Pre-Darwinian logic dictated as much. “The man who borrows in order to spend will soon be ruined,” Smith explains, “and he who lends to him will generally have occasion to repent of his folly.” 3

从贷款人的角度来看，所有贷款的利息都是像给投资者一样。贷款人期望得到本金和 “一定的使用年租金” 2，而不管借款人如何使用这些钱。把贷款用于消费的借款人，唉，“表现得像个败家子，把本该用于支持勤劳的人的钱耗费在维持闲人身上”。然而，斯密相信，勤劳的人比浪荡的人多。前达尔文主义的逻辑决定了这一点。斯密解释说 ：“为了消费而借钱的人很快就会被毁掉，而借给他的人一般总有机会为自己的愚蠢而忏悔。” 3

As coherent and as finely reasoned asWealth of Nationsis, Smith makes an oddly illiberal argument on the subject of government-set interest rates. Bottom line — he has no problem with them. In fact, he argues that the authorities should keep those rates as restrictively low as possible, just slightly above the lowest market rate. If the legal interest rate in Great Britain were to be set much higher, Smith feared that lenders would look to those borrowers willing to pay high rates, namely, the “prodigals and projectors.” 4

正如《国富论》一样，斯密在政府设定的利率问题上提出了奇怪的非自由主义论点。一句话 —— 他对这些利率没有异议。事实上，他认为，当局应尽可能地将这些利率保持在限制性的低水平上，仅略高于最低的市场利率。如果英国的法定利率被定得更高，斯密担心贷款人会把目光投向那些愿意支付高利率的借款人，即 “败家子和投机者”。4

As Smith explains, a projector is someone who undertakes new projects. Bentham describes them as those who “strike out into any new channel, and more especially into any channel of invention.” 5For us, they are venture capitalists. Prodigal is well enough understood. The ledger on their historic performance runs long, lively, and consistently in the red. Dante knowingly puts them in theInferno’s fourth circle. And yet as keen a judge of sin as Dante was, he would not have known in which circle to put a projector. In fact, he would have had no reason to put them in theInfernoat all. Smith, however, thought of projectors much as he did prodigals — reckless souls who would soak up whatever capital was available.

正如斯密所解释的那样，投机者是从事新项目的人。本瑟姆将他们描述为那些 “向任何新渠道出击的人，尤其不惜发明渠道进而出击的人。” 5对我们来说，他们是风险资本家。败家子倒是广为人知。他们历史业绩的账本很长，很活泼，而且一直处于亏损状态。但丁明知故犯地把他们放在《地狱》的第四层。然而，像但丁这样敏锐的罪恶判断者，他不会知道把投机者放在哪个层里。事实上，他根本没有理由把他们放在《地狱》中。然而，斯密对投机者的看法就像他对败家子的看法一样 —— 不计后果的灵魂，他们会吸收任何可用的资本。

If the legal interest rate were to be kept low, Smith reasons, projectors and prodigals would have to compete with “sober people.” 6Unlike the prodigals and projectors, the sober were not “likely to waste and destroy” what they had been given. If the return on investment were even close to comparable — and restrictive interest rates would insure they were — bankers would invest in the tried and true endeavors of the dependably sober. “A great part of the capital of the country,” argues Smith, would be “thus thrown into the hands in which it is most likely to be employed with advantage.” 7

如果要保持较低的法定利率，斯密的理由是，投机者和败家子将不得不与 “清醒的人” 竞争。6与败家子和投机者不同，清醒者不 “可能浪费和破坏” 他们获得的东西。如果投资回报率甚至接近于可比性 —— 限制性利率将确保它们是可比的 —— 银行家们将投资于那些可靠的清醒者的久经考验的事业。“国家的大部分资本”，斯密认为，“将被扔到它最有可能被利用的手中。” 7

In his bold and often funnyDefence of Usury, written a decade afterWealth ofNations, the irreverent Bentham all but gags on this defection from orthodoxy by the high priest of classical liberal economics. A generation younger than Smith, and a class or two above him by birth, Bentham was never wanting in self-confidence. A whiz kid from the get-go, he had started his study of Latin at the age of three and while still in his twenties was commissioned to write the British government’s official rebuttal to the Declaration of Independence, penned by fellow prodigy Thomas Jefferson, five years Bentham’s senior.

在《国富论》十年后写下的大胆而又有趣的《高利贷的辩护》中，不苟言笑的本瑟姆对这位古典自由主义经济学的大祭司偏离正统的行为几乎嗤之以鼻。本瑟姆比斯密年轻一代，出身比他高一两级，他从不缺乏自信。他从一开始就是个奇才，三岁就开始学习拉丁文，在二十多岁的时候就被委托撰写英国政府对（美国）《独立宣言》的官方反驳，该宣言是由比本瑟姆大五岁的神童托马斯·杰斐逊撰写的。

A philosopher and reformer, Bentham is often credited with fathering utilitarianism, a school of thought that traces its roots back to Epicurus but that blossomed in nineteenth-century England.8In his treatiseIntroduction to thePrinciples of Morals, Bentham laid down the principle of “utility.” He judged an action’s value by its capacity to generate happiness, which he thought of as the presence of pleasure and the absence of pain. The idea of an act being right or wrong had no purchase with Bentham. To distinguish between the two would require a moral legislator, presumably a supernatural one, and Bentham had moved beyond that hypothesis. Like Smith, but through different eyes, Bentham saw the inarguable utility of free-market economics, but he went well beyond Smith in highlighting the utter futility of a usury prohibition. Indeed, after Bentham got through trashing it, no serious intellectual would take up its defense again.

作为一名哲学家和改革家，本瑟姆经常被认为是功利主义之父，这个学派的根源可以追溯到伊壁鸠鲁，但在十九世纪的英国开花结果。 8在他的论文《道德原则简介》（em>Introduction to the Principles of Morals）中，本瑟姆提出了 “效用” 的原则。他根据一个行为产生幸福的能力来判断其价值，他认为幸福是指有快乐和没有痛苦。一个行为是正确的还是错误的想法在本瑟姆看来是没有意义的。区分这两者需要一个道德立法者，大概是一个超自然的立法者，而本瑟姆已经超越了这个假设。与斯密一样，但通过不同的眼睛，本瑟姆看到了自由市场经济无可辩驳的效用，但他在强调禁止高利贷的完全徒劳方面远远超过了斯密。事实上，在本瑟姆完成了对它的抨击之后，没有一个严肃的知识分子会再为它辩护。

Bentham had a problem with the very wordusury, which he thought capable, through sheer connotation, of stirring the passions in unpleasant ways. “Usury is a bad thing,” he teases, “and as such ought to be prevented: usurers are a bad sort of men, a very bad sort of men, and as such ought to be punished and suppressed.” 9This was the supposition that even sophisticated eighteenth-century Englishmen took for granted, having inherited it from their progenitors, and they from theirs. It pained him that this ancient grudge against usury and usurers, real and fictional — Shylock comes to mind here — had wormed its way into the national pysche:

本瑟姆对 “高利贷” 这个词有意见，他认为这个词能够通过纯粹的内涵，以令人不快的方式挑起人们的激情。“高利贷是一件坏事”，他调侃道，“因此应该防止。高利贷者是一种坏的人，一种非常坏的人，因此应该受到惩罚和镇压。” 9这是一个假设，即使是成熟的十八世纪英国人也认为这是理所当然的，他们从祖先那里继承了这个假设，而他们也从祖先那里继承了。让他感到痛苦的是，这种对高利贷和高利贷者的古老怨恨，不管是真实的还是虚构的 —— 这里想到的是夏洛克 —— 已经潜移默化地进入了国民的精神世界：

Now, I question, whether, among all the instances in which a borrower and a lender of money have been brought together upon the stage, from the days of Thespis to the present, there ever was one, in which the former was not recommended to favour in some shape or other, either to admiration, or to love, or to pity, or to all three; and the other, the man of thrift, consigned to infamy.10

现在，我怀疑，从里斯皮斯（Thespis）时代到现在，在所有借钱的人和放钱的人被带到舞台上的例子中，前者从来都是以某种形式出现的正面人物，或者被钦佩，或者被爱，或者被怜悯，或者三种都有；而后着，节俭的人一律被打入冷宫。 10

Bentham concedes that in no time or place has money lending been a popular profession. The psychology behind the resentment he puts in the simplest of terms: “The children who have eat [sic] their cake are the natural enemies of the children who have theirs.” 11Writ large, Bentham elaborates, those who have sacrificed the future to the present envy those who have sacrificed the present for the future. This envy is sublimated at the time of the loan, of course, but as the due date approaches the lender morphs in the borrower’s eyes from benefactor to tyrant. “It is an oppression for a man to reclaim his own money,” Bentham observes wryly. “It is none to keep it from him.” 12Were Bentham alive today, this is precisely the kind of takeaway message he would draw from just about any home foreclosure story on the six o’clock news.

本瑟姆承认，在任何时间和地点，放贷都不是一个受欢迎的职业。他把怨恨背后的心理学用最简单的语言表达出来： “吃了蛋糕的孩子是拥有蛋糕的孩子的天敌。” 11大体上，本瑟姆阐述了，那些为了现在而牺牲未来的人，嫉妒那些为了未来而牺牲现在的人。当然，这种嫉妒在贷款时得到了升华，但随着到期日的临近，贷款人在借款人眼中从恩人变成了暴君。“对一个人来说，收回自己的钱是一种压迫，"Bentham 诙谐地说道。” 12如果本瑟姆今天还活着，这正是他从六点新闻的任何房屋止赎故事中得出的启示。

Only among Christians, and in Christian times, however, was money lending proscribed. So Bentham argues, conveniently overlooking the original proscription against usury in Deuteronomy. His anti-Christian bias showing, he wonders how it was that his forebears had labored so long under so transparently flawed an idea. Here he is at his most amusingly acerbic, if not exactly his most accurate. He observes that when Christianity broke away from Judaism, “it came to be discovered that the distance between the mother and the daughter church could not be too wide.” As to money-lending in particular, “this Jewish way of getting it was too odious to be endured.” As a consequence Christians left the Jews to gather money any way they could, and when Christians needed to raise revenue, the “method pretty much in vogue” was simply “to squeeze it out of them.” 13

然而，只有在基督徒中，在基督教时代，放债才被禁止。本瑟姆这样认为，同时方便地忽略了《申命记》中对高利贷的最初禁令。他的反基督教偏见显示，他想知道他的祖先是如何在如此明显有缺陷的想法下工作了这么久。这里是他最有趣、最尖锐的时候，如果不是他最准确的话。他指出，当基督教脱离犹太教时，“人们发现，母亲和女儿教会之间的距离不可能太大”。特别是在放贷方面，“犹太人的这种获取方式太令人厌恶了，无法忍受”。因此，基督徒让犹太人以任何方式筹集资金，而当基督徒需要筹集资金时，相当流行的方法 “只是从他们那里榨取资金”。13

As rough as Bentham was on his Christian ancestors, he was rougher still on Aristotle, “that celebrated heathen, who, in all matters wherein heathenism did not destroy his competence, had established a despotic empire over the Christian world.” Despite all the money that passed through Aristotle’s hands, “more perhaps than through the hands of any philosopher before or since,” 14Aristotle had failed in his most essential quest:

就像本瑟姆对他的基督教祖先非常粗暴一样，他对亚里士多德更加粗暴，“那个有名的异教徒，在所有异教没有破坏他的能力的事情上，在基督教世界里建立了一个专制的帝国。” 尽管经过亚里士多德之手的钱财，“也许比以前或以后任何哲学家之手都多”，14亚里士多德在他最基本的追求上失败了：

[He] had never been able to discover, in any one piece of money, any organs for generating any other such piece. Emboldened by so strong a body of negative proof, he ventured at last to usher into the world the result of his observations, in the form of an universal proposition, that all money is in its nature barren.15

（亚里士多德）从未能够在任何一块钱中发现产生任何其他这种钱的器官。在如此强大的反面证据的鼓舞下，他终于大胆地将他的观察结果以一个普遍命题的形式推向世界，即所有货币在本质上都是贫瘠的。15

In a single comic paragraph, Bentham undermines the anti-usury infrastructure of the last six centuries. No one before or since has given any classical philosopher such a public spanking and, in this case, such a well-deserved one. Bentham, however, follows his wit a bit too far afield. Where he strays —— a routine error among the Enlightenment’s best and brightest — is in imputing the basest of motives to those who have come before him, especially Christians. He declares, and he seems to mean it, that the acceptance of Aristotle’s usury position was driven by the anti-Jewish faction among Christian philosophers. This is nonsense. In his airy dismissal of the Christian-Aristotelian fusion, the bedrock of the Enlightenment that followed, his prejudice trumps his perception.

在一个滑稽的段落中，本瑟姆破坏了过去六个世纪的反高利贷基础设施。在这之前或之后，没有人给过任何一位古典哲学家如此公开的打屁股，而且，在这种情况下，绝对是活该。然而，本瑟姆跟随他的智慧走得有点太远了。他偏离的地方 —— 这是启蒙运动中最好和最聪明的人的常规错误 —— 是将最卑劣的动机归咎于他之前的人，特别是基督徒。他宣称，而且他似乎是认真的，接受亚里士多德的高利贷立场是由基督教哲学家中的反犹太派别推动的。这简直是胡说八道。在他对基督教与亚里士多德的融合 —— 随后的启蒙运动的基石 —— 的轻描淡写的否定中，他的偏见战胜了他的认知。

When he turns to the details of usury law, Bentham does not trouble himself with the question of whether lending money at interest was right or wrong. In England, at least, that question had not been on the table since “a suppurating tumour” 16dispatched teenage king Edward VI heavenward more than two centuries earlier. Usury, in fact, no longer even meant lending at interest. The contemporary meaning was much more arbitrary, namely, the attempt to charge more interest on a loan than the government had decided was either moral or proper. Bentham wasn’t buying that definition either.

当他转向高利贷法律的细节时，本瑟姆并没有为借钱付利息是对还是错的问题而烦恼。至少在英国，自从两个多世纪前 “一个化脓的肿瘤” 16将少年国王爱德华六世送上天堂以后，这个问题就再也没有被摆上桌面。事实上，“高利贷”，甚至不再是指借贷利息。当代的含义更加武断，即试图对一笔贷款收取比政府决定的道德或适当的更多的利息。本瑟姆也不相信这个定义。

“There can be no such thing as usury,” Bentham reasons, “for what rate of interest is there that can naturally be more proper than another.” 17He cites the wide-ranging experience of different countries and different times. Official interest rate maximums varied dramatically from era to era and place to place. There was nothing proper about any of these limits, nothing moral either. Other than a lingering prejudice against moneylenders, Bentham could see no reason why, in adjusting the relative interests of lenders and borrowers, the government always favored the borrower. Even in England, he observes, “The lender’s advantage is for ever to be clipped, and pared down, as low as it will bear. First it was to be confined to ten per cent, then to eight, then to six, then to five, and now lately there was a report of its being to be brought down to four.” 18

“不可能有高利贷这回事”，本瑟姆的理由是，“因为没有什么利率能自然地比另一个利率更合适。” 17他引用了不同国家和不同时代的广泛经验。官方利率的上限在不同的时代和不同的地方有很大的不同。这些限制没有任何适当的东西，也没有任何道德的东西。除了对放债人挥之不去的偏见，本瑟姆看不出有什么理由在调整贷款人和借款人的相对利益时，政府总是倾向于借款人。他指出，即使在英国，“放款人的利益也将永远被削减，并被压缩到它所能承受的最低限度。首先，它被限制在 10%，然后是 8%，然后是 6%，然后是 5%，现在最近有报告说它将被降到 4%。” 18

Bentham saw the same prejudice at work in the prohibition of compound interest “as a sort of usury.” He failed to see the logic of a law that protected a creditor’s right to collect on a loan but that denied him any relief if the debtor failed to pay on time. “The gain, which the law in its tenderness thus bestows on the defaulter,” writes Bentham, “is an encouragement, a reward, which it holds out for breach of faith, for iniquity, for indolence, for negligence.” 19

本瑟姆在禁止复利 “作为一种高利贷” 的规定中看到了同样的偏见。他看不到这样的逻辑：法律保护债权人收取贷款的权利，但如果债务人没有按时还款，他就得不到任何补偿。Bentham 写道 ：“法律以其温柔的方式给予违约者的收益，是一种鼓励，一种奖励，它为失信、不义、懒惰、疏忽而提供的。” 19

The illogic of British usury law manifested itself even more clearly in the case of the pawnbroker. Despite the fact that the pawnbroker had the borrower’s collateral firmly in hand, he could legally charge interest as high as 12 percent. And his customers were those whom usury laws were designed to protect — the indigent and the simpleminded — active subsets of the genus prodigal.

英国高利贷法律的不合逻辑性在典当行的案例中表现得更加明显。尽管典当行牢牢掌握着借款人的抵押品，但他可以合法地收取高达 12% 的利息。而他的客户正是高利贷法律旨在保护的对象 —— 贫困者和头脑简单者 —— 败家子的活跃子集。

Even here, Bentham could see no need to regulate. As long as a prodigal had something to pledge, even if he could find “none of those monsters called usurers to deal with him,” Bentham was confident that he would not lie quiet. Instead, he would do what he had to do to get money, occasionally activities more injurious to himself and to society than borrowing. “The tacking of leading-strings upon the backs of grown persons, in order to prevent their doing themselves a mischief,” writes Bentham in unaccented libertarian, “is not necessary either to the being or tranquillity of society.” 20The best protection for prodigals and the indigent alike he saw as an open competition among lenders, bankers, and pawnbrokers that would at least keep the rates down.

即使在这里，本瑟姆也认为没有必要进行监管。只要败家子有东西可以抵押，即使他能找到 “那些被称为高利贷者的怪物中没有一个能和他打交道”，本瑟姆相信 “他不会干脆躺着不动”。相反，他将做他必须做的事情来获得金钱，偶尔会有比借贷更有害于自己和社会的活动。“在成年人的背上系上绳索，以防止他们自己做坏事”，本瑟姆用不带口音的自由主义写道，“这对社会的存在和安宁都是不必要的。” 20他认为对败家子和穷人的最佳保护是贷款人、银行家和典当商之间的公开竞争，至少可以使利率下降。

Writing in 1787, another momentous year in America history, Bentham thought the official effort to stem the natural flow of money from lender to borrower as futile as King Canute’s effort to stem the flow of the tides. In Russia, where he was living at the time, evasion of the law had become normative. Although the legal limit was 5 percent, the people who wanted money paid what the market demanded — in that time and place roughly 8 to 10 percent. No sooner would the lender draw up a legal contract for 5 percent than he and the borrower would cut a side deal for the 3 or 4 percent differential. Writes Bentham, “The whole system of laws on this subject is perfectly, and very happily, inefficacious.” 21In Russia, as elsewhere, money found its natural level.

写于 1787 年，美国历史上另一个重要的年份，本瑟姆认为官方阻止金钱从贷方到借方的自然流动的努力就像卡努特国王阻止潮汐流动的努力一样徒劳。在他当时居住的俄国，逃避法律已经成为常态。虽然法律规定的上限是 5%，但想要钱的人都是按市场要求支付的 —— 在那个时代和地方，大概是 8% 到 10%。贷款人一起草 5% 的法律合同，他和借款人就会就 3% 或 4% 的差额达成一项附带协议。本瑟姆写道 ：“关于这个问题的整个法律体系是完全无效的，而且非常令人高兴。” 21在俄国，和其他地方一样，货币找到了其自然水平。

The futility of regulating interest rates seemed such a given, especially from a free-market perspective, that Adam Smith’s waffling struck him as borderline heretical. In his uniquely comic style, Bentham tries to account for how “so great a master” could have fallen into so obvious an error. He writes, in seeming irony, “You heard the public voice, strengthened by that of law, proclaiming all round you, that usury was a sad thing, and usurers a wicked and pernicious set of men.” 22In fact, however, this is likely what had happened: Smith had so deeply absorbed society’s prejudice against usurers that he could not find it within himself to purge it.

管制利率的徒劳似乎是一个既定事实，特别是从自由市场的角度来看，亚当·斯密的摇摆不定让他觉得是边缘的异端。本瑟姆以其独特的喜剧风格，试图解释 “如此伟大的大师” 如何会陷入如此明显的错误。他以看似讽刺的口吻写道 ：“你听到公众的声音，在法律的支持下，在你周围宣布，高利贷是一件可悲的事情，高利贷者是一群邪恶和有害的人。” 22然而事实上，这可能是已经发生的事情。斯密已经深深地吸收了社会对高利贷者的偏见，以至于他无法在自己的内心深处找到清除这种偏见的办法。

Smith’s support of rate regulation was irritating enough, but it was his distrust of “projectors” that inspired Bentham to new heights of pique. “You heard from one at least of those quarters,” Bentham adds, “that projectors were either a foolish and contemptible race, or a knavish and destructive one.” Bentham analyzes what it is that projectors do and why lenders should expect a higher rate of return when investing in their projects: “No new trade, no trade carried on in any new channel, can afford a security equal to that which may be afforded by a trade carried on in any of the old ones.” 23

斯密对费率管制的支持已经够让人生气的了，但正是他对 “投机者” 的不信任，激发了本瑟姆新的愤怒。“你至少从其中一个方面听到了”，本瑟姆补充说，“投机者要么是一个愚蠢和可鄙的种族，要么是一个狡诈和破坏性的种族。” 本瑟姆分析了投机者的作用，以及为什么贷款人在投资他们的项目时应期望获得更高的回报率。“任何新的贸易，在任何新的渠道中进行的贸易，都不能提供与在任何旧的渠道中进行的贸易所能提供的相等的保障。” 23

Bentham makes a compelling case that none of Britain’s great industrial breakthroughs “could have existed at first but in the shape of a project.” Today’s everyday convenience was yesterday’s innovation, Bentham continues. These were all the result not of some rash speculation but of some “rare endowment of genius.” The notion that some legislator “of the most perfect ignorance” 24would be granted the power to pass judgment on the credit-worthiness of a project about which he knew nothing appalled Bentham, who did well to die before the 111th U.S. Congress was seated. As he saw it, if such legislators had had their way, the British would still be eating acorns and wearing animal hides. Smith’s refusal to agree astonished Bentham:

本瑟姆提出了一个令人信服的理由，即，没有任何英国伟大的工业突破 “最初不是以投机形式存在”。今天的日常便利是昨天的创新，本瑟姆继续说道。这些都不是一些轻率的猜测的结果，而是一些 “罕见的天才禀赋” 的结果。一些 “完全无知” 的立法者24将被授予权力，对一个他一无所知的项目的信用价值作出判断，这种想法使本瑟姆感到震惊，他在第 111 届美国国会就任前就已经去世了。在他看来，如果这样的立法者一意孤行，英国人仍然会吃着橡子，穿着兽皮。斯密的拒绝让本瑟姆大吃一惊：

“No,” I think I hear you saying, “I will not thank projectors for it, I will rather thank the laws, which by fixing the rates of interest have been exercising their vigilance in repressing the temerity of projectors, and preventing their imprudence from making those defalcations from the sum of national prosperity which it would not have failed to make, had it been left free.” 25

“不”，我想我听到你说，“我不会为此感谢投机者，我宁可感谢法律，因为法律通过确定利率，一直在行使其警惕性，压制投机者的胆量，并防止他们轻易从国家繁荣的总额中进行投机倒把 —— 正因为投机者被管制，这些才没有发生。” 25

Having taken Smith to the philosophical woodshed, Bentham claims that he did so as a form of tough love. The ever-cocky young scholar expresses the marvelously presumptuous hope that in his next edition the master would make the corrections that he has recommended. Smith never would. Although rumors circulated that Smith had come around to Bentham’s view, there was never any proof of it. Given the sharp edge of Bentham’s wit and his eagerness to draw blood, Smith had better sense than to engage in a public spat.

在把斯密带到哲学的柴房后，本瑟姆声称他这样做是一种严厉的爱。这位一贯狡猾的年轻学者表达了一个奇妙的自以为是的希望，即在他的下一版中，这位大师会做出他建议的修正。斯密永远不会这样做。尽管有传言说斯密已经接受了本瑟姆的观点，但从未有任何证据。考虑到本瑟姆的机智和他对流血的渴望，斯密才不愿意参与公开的争吵。

No doubt, this round went to Bentham. Logic was clearly on his side. But history has been kinder to Smith. More than two hundred years later he is still being studied and taught, while Bentham has slipped into obscurity. In lesser hands, utilitarianism devolved into pretty much whatever the utilitarian-in-chief thought was the common good. Bentham’s heirs include Robert Owen, who gave us the wordsocialism, and the still-extant Peter Singer, who has made “animal liberation” intellectually respectable, at least at Princeton.

毫无疑问，这一回合本瑟姆胜出。逻辑显然在他一边。但历史对斯密更友好。两百多年后，他仍在被研究和教授，而本瑟姆则已默默无闻。在更少的人手中，功利主义演变成了几乎所有功利主义者认为是公共利益的东西。本瑟姆的继承人包括罗伯特·欧文，他为我们提供了 “社会主义一” 词，以及仍然存在的彼得·辛格，他使 “动物解放” 在智力上得到尊重，至少在普林斯顿。

The reason for Smith’s intellectual endurance can be found in his first major work,The Theory of Moral Sentiments, published in 1759. Unlike Bentham, Smith built his economic philosophy the old-fashioned way — on a comprehensive moral and ethical foundation. Although theologically adventurous — his work was a mix of stoicism and Christianity — Smith saw morality as much more than a mere calculus of pleasure and pain. On the contrary, he stood firm for a natural law, one that had been given to mankind “for the direction of our conduct in this life.” 26As to the source of that law, he did not hedge: “Those important rules of morality are the commands and laws of the Deity, who will finally reward the obedient, and punish the transgressors of their duty.” 27

斯密之所以能在思想上经受住考验，可以在他的第一部重要著作《道德情操论》中找到，该书于 1759 年出版。与本瑟姆不同，斯密以老式的方式建立了他的经济哲学 —— 在全面的道德和伦理基础上。尽管在神学上具有冒险精神 —— 他的作品是斯大林主义和基督教的混合体 —— 但斯密认为道德远不止是快乐和痛苦的计算。26至于该法律的来源，他并没有避讳。“那些重要的道德规则是神的命令和法律，他将最终奖励顺从的人，惩罚违背职责的人。” 27

Given his grounding, Smith was much more likely than Bentham to err on the side of mercy. He also understood something fundamental about free enterprise that Bentham did not: namely, that the “self-command” essential to its success had to be rooted in a larger ethic. Michael Novak, who contributed the highly useful phrasedemocratic capitalismto our vocabulary, summarizes Smith’s and his own take on this ungainly but extraordinary system: “Precisely because rational self-interest does not always result in moral outcomes, religious (and other) values are indispensable to democratic capitalism.” 28Although Smith would not live to see the day in which there were insufficient “values” to sustain the system, Novak would, and Bentham would be at least partly to blame.

鉴于他的基础，斯密比本瑟姆更有可能在慈悲方面犯错。他还了解一些本瑟姆所不了解的关于自由企业的基本情况：即对自由企业的成功至关重要的 “自我指挥” 必须植根于更大的道德规范。迈克尔·诺瓦克（Michael Novak）为我们的词汇表贡献了一个非常有用的短语 “民主资本主义”，他总结了斯密和他自己对这个不讨好但不寻常的系统的看法 ：“正因为理性的自我利益并不总是产生道德的结果，所以宗教（和其他）价值是民主资本主义所不可或缺的。” 28虽然斯密不会活着看到有一天没有足够的 “价值” 来维持这个系统，但诺瓦克会，而本瑟姆至少要承担部分责任。

tenTulips 郁金香

THE YEAR THAT ADAM SMITH SR. MARRRRIED MARGRGARET F. DOUGLAS in Kircaldy, Scotland — 1720 — was quite possibly the most economically unstable in Western Europe since the Norman invasion in 1066. Both France and England were swept up in parallel mania. The French one, called the “Mississippi Bubble,” had almost nothing to do with Mississippi. The English one, called the “South Sea Bubble,” had even less to do with the South Seas. Both, however, were genuine bubbles. When they burst, as bubbles inevitably do, the thousands of people left holding soap and air would never forgive the dastardly projectors who launched these bubbles skyward. Young Adam must have gotten an earful.

亚当·斯密在苏格兰基尔卡迪与玛格丽特·杜格拉斯结婚的那一年，即 1720 年，很可能是自 1066 年诺曼人入侵以来西欧经济最不稳定的时期。法国和英国都被卷进了平行的狂热中。法国的狂热被称为 “密西西比泡沫”，与密西西比州几乎毫无关系。英国的泡沫被称为 “南海泡沫”，与南海的关系更小。然而，两者都是真正的泡沫。当它们破灭时，正如泡沫不可避免的那样，成千上万的人拿着肥皂和空气，永远不会原谅那些将这些泡沫发射到天空的卑鄙的投机者。年轻的亚当一定是听得津津有味了。

Although much more consequential, the Mississippi and South Sea Bubbles have attracted less popular attention than a bubble-like mania that gripped the northern Netherlands nearly a century before the French and English agitation. To understand that phenomenon, it is helpful to understand the republic that created it and the financial instruments that helped create that republic. The most essential of those instruments was the bond. The market that developed for the sale of those bonds, built on the international banking infrastructure, empowered Europe’s nation-states and widened the divide between commerce in the West and commerce in the rest of the world.

尽管密西西比和南海泡沫的影响要大得多，但与法国和英国骚动前近一个世纪笼罩荷兰北部的泡沫式狂热相比，密西西比和南海泡沫吸引的大众关注要少得多。为了理解这一现象，有必要了解一下创造它的共和国和帮助创造该共和国的金融工具。这些工具中最重要的是债券。为销售这些债券而发展起来的市场，建立在国际银行基础设施之上，增强了欧洲民族国家的能力，扩大了西方商业和世界其他地区商业之间的鸿沟。

As with banking, the bond market traces its origins to the city-states of northern Italy. In an increasingly complex marketplace, there is a refreshing simplicity about the way bonds work. In Italy, the city-states would issue bonds to pay their debts, typically the debts attendant on waging war. In today’s terms, a citizen might buy a 100,000-lirabond at a fixed rate, or “coupon,” of 3 percent. This investment promised a payback of 3,000liraper year. In Florence, the government more or less forced citizens to buy these bonds.1Happily for everyone, the obligatory nature of the purchase excused the citizens from the usury ban. Better still, the government — and the church — allowed them to sell the bonds to their fellow citizens if they needed liquidity, meaning cash.

就像银行业一样，债券市场的起源可以追溯到意大利北部的城邦。在一个日益复杂的市场中，债券的运作方式有一种令人耳目一新的简单性。在意大利，城邦会发行债券来支付他们的债务，通常是发动战争所带来的债务。用今天的话说，一个公民可能会以 3% 的固定利率或 “息票” 购买 100,000 里拉的债券。这项投资承诺每年可获得 3,000 里拉的回报。1令人高兴的是，购买债券的义务性质使公民免受高利贷禁令的影响。更妙的是，政府 —— 和教会 —— 允许他们在需要流动资金，也就是现金时，将债券卖给他们的同胞。

If Florence had been successfully smashing its enemies and seemed to be marching toward peace and prosperity, citizens would see these bonds as good long-term investments. Bondholders would have little trouble finding buyers if they chose to sell. The ensuing excess of demand over supply would push the market price of the bond above its “par” value. The coupon, however, would remain fixed. So if an investor paid 120,000lirafor the bond, his annual return of 3,000lirawould yield 2.5 percent.

如果佛罗伦萨成功地击溃了敌人，并且似乎正在向和平与繁荣迈进，公民会将这些债券视为良好的长期投资。如果债券持有人选择出售，他们不难找到买家。随之而来的供不应求将推动债券的市场价格高于其 “面值”。然而，息票将保持固定。因此，如果投资者为该债券支付 120,000 里拉，他的年回报率为 3,000 里拉，收益率为 2.5%。

If, on the other hand, the war were going badly, and Florence’s survival seemed at risk, bondholders would be inclined to sell their bonds. There would not be many takers. One selling point would be higher yield. A 100,000-lirapar-value bond bought at 60,000lirastill promised a 3,000-liraannual return. The purchaser would have to weigh this 5 percent return against the likelihood of default. What might prompt the purchase is what we call todayasymmetricalinformation. In other words, the buyer had the inside skinny on the war’s outcome and invested accordingly. In an era when information could move no faster than a pigeon, the ability to transmit that information more swiftly and surely than the competitors could make a huge difference.

另一方面，如果战争进展不顺利，佛罗伦萨的生存似乎受到威胁，债券持有人会倾向于出售他们的债券。没有多少人愿意接受。售价高一个点意味着更高的收益。一张面值 100,000 里拉的债券以 60,000 里拉的价格买入，仍可获得 3,000 里拉的年回报。购买者将不得不权衡这 5% 的回报与违约的可能性。可能促使购买的是我们今天所说的 “信息不对称” （asymmetrical information）。换句话说，买方掌握了战争结果的内部消息，并据此进行投资。在一个信息传播速度不比鸽子快的时代，比竞争对手更迅速、更可靠地传递信息的能力可以产生巨大的差异。

It should be noted that all of these financial instruments came online in a fully Catholic Europe. Likewise in 1500, all of the world’s great commercial centers — Venice, Florence, Bruges, Antwerp, London — paid fealty to Rome. The Protestant Reformation ——paceMax Weber — did not create capitalism. It only seemed that way when, after the split, the Catholic Church identified its interests with the old-world mercantilism of the Spanish Empire.

应该指出的是，所有这些金融工具都是在一个完全天主教的欧洲上线的。同样，在 1500 年，世界上所有伟大的商业中心 —— 威尼斯、佛罗伦萨、布鲁日、安特卫普、伦敦 —— 都对罗马表示效忠。新教改革并没有创造资本主义。只是在分裂之后，天主教会将其利益与西班牙帝国的旧世界重商主义相提并论，才显得如此。

Spain and France did, in fact, mimic the Italian model to finance their wars but with less success. The problem was that an authoritarian nation had less incentive to honor its bond obligations than a competitive, commercial citystate. Throughout the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, Spain periodically defaulted on its bonds, and this understandably scared investors away. Investors had more consistent success with Spain’s principal antagonist throughout this period, the provinces of the northern Netherlands. In 1581, seven of these provinces unified to create the Republic of the Seven United Provinces.

事实上，西班牙和法国确实模仿了意大利的模式来为其战争融资，但却不太成功。问题是，与一个有竞争力的商业城市国家相比，一个专制国家履行其债券义务的动力较小。在整个十六世纪和十七世纪，西班牙定期拖欠其债券，这可以理解为吓跑了投资者。在这一时期，投资者在西班牙的主要对手 —— 荷兰北部各省身上取得了更为稳定的成功。1581 年，这些省份中的七个省份联合起来，成立了七省联合共和国。

To finance its on-again, off-again wars of liberation against Spain, the United Provinces adapted the Italian financial models and expanded on them. Among the most significant Dutch innovation was the limited-liability joint stock company. The first of these, the United Dutch Chartered East India Company (the Dutch shorthand for which was VOC), attracted more than a thousand investors upon its chartering in 1602. Government sponsorship and monopoly status gave investors confidence in the firm’s eventual success, and “limited liability” assured them that they could lose no more than they had invested.

为了资助其时断时续的对西班牙的解放战争，联合省采用了意大利的金融模式，并对其进行了扩展。荷兰最重要的创新是有限责任股份公司。其中第一个公司，即荷兰联合特许东印度公司（荷兰的简称是 VOC），在 1602 年获得特许后吸引了一千多名投资者。政府的赞助和垄断地位使投资者对公司的最终成功充满信心，而 “有限责任” 保证他们的损失不会超过他们的投资。

The mission of the VOC was legitimate: to consolidate Dutch trading operations in the East Indies and exploit the opportunities the islands offered.2Given the sizable start-up costs, initial returns were less than stellar. The VOC, in fact, paid no dividends at all until 1610, and those were paid in the form of spices. In 1609, frustrated by the VOC’s failure to deliver, prominent Dutch businessman Isaac le Maire and his pals formed a secret cabal to squeeze what money could be had out of this stasis.
