What they did was quietly borrow shares from other shareholders for a fee, with the promise to return the shares at a future date. They then sold those shares at market value and stealthily talked down the company’s future prospects, scaring others into selling their shares and driving down the share price 12 percent over the next months. Le Maire and his coconspirators then bought shares at the lower market price, returned them to the lenders, and pocketed the difference.

VOC 的使命是合法的：巩固荷兰在东印度群岛的贸易业务，并利用这些岛屿提供的机会。2鉴于可观的启动成本，初始收益并不理想。事实上，VOC 在 1610 年之前根本没有支付任何红利，而那些红利是以香料的形式支付的。1609 年，著名的荷兰商人艾萨克·勒梅尔（Isaac le Maire）和他的伙伴们组成了一个秘密小团体，想从这种僵局中榨出什么钱来。他们所做的是悄悄地从其他股东那里借来股票，并承诺在未来的某一天归还这些股票。然后，他们以市场价值出售这些股票，并隐蔽地谈论公司的未来前景，吓唬其他人出售他们的股票，并在接下来的几个月里将股价拉低 12%。勒梅尔和他的同谋们随后以较低的市场价格买入股票，并将其返还给贷款人，然后将差额收入囊中。

In essence, Le Maire and his fellow “bears” had “shorted” the market. This took the VOC shareholders by surprise, as they had no prior experience with shorting or bears. As one might suspect, the strategy, once revealed, did not particularly amuse them. In fact, they took Le Maire to court and tied him up there for the rest of his career.

实质上，勒梅尔和他的 “熊” 伙伴们已经 “做空” 了市场。这让 VOC 的股东们大吃一惊，因为他们之前没有做空或熊市的经验。正如人们所猜测的那样，这一策略一旦曝光，并没有让他们感到特别高兴。事实上，他们把勒梅尔告上法庭，并把他的余生都绑在那里。

By 1612, it had dawned on just about everyone that the VOC was not about to buy back anyone’s shares in the near future. As with bonds in Florence, those seeking liquidity had no choice but to sell shares of their stock to other would-be investors. And so was born the world’s first stock market. Among its first regulations was to ban selling short. The state, however, did not exactly outlaw futures trading. Rather, it declared all futures contracts legally unenforceable. This understanding helped incite the mania in question.

到 1612 年，几乎所有人都意识到，VOC 不会在短期内回购任何人的股票。就像佛罗伦萨的债券一样，那些寻求流动性的人别无选择，只能将他们的股票卖给其他潜在的投资者。于是，世界上第一个股票市场诞生了。它的第一批法规是禁止卖空。然而，国家并没有完全取缔期货交易。相反，它宣布所有的期货合约在法律上是不可执行的。这种理解反倒煽动了可疑的狂热。

In between founding the first joint stock company and the first stock market, the resourceful Dutch introduced the world’s first modern central bank, the Amsterdam Exchange Bank, orWisselbank.3The United Provinces, like other small European countries, lacked the muscle and the square mileage to establish and enforce a dominant currency. As a result, the currencies of no fewer than fourteen other countries circulated throughout the new republic. The Dutch cleared up the confusion by creating a central clearinghouse to store their depositors’ money, in whatever currency, and standardize exchange rates. A buyer with his money on deposit could purchase an item from a seller simply by having his account debited at theWisselbankand the seller’s credited the same amount.

在创立第一家股份公司和第一个股票市场之间，足智多谋的荷兰人引入了世界上第一家现代中央银行 —— 阿姆斯特丹交易银行（或称 “卫斯尔银行”，Wisselbank）。 3联合省和其他欧洲小国一样，缺乏在方圆几十里上建立和实施主导货币的实力。结果，不少于 14 个其他国家的货币在整个新共和国内流通。荷兰人通过建立一个中央结算中心来储存储户的钱，不管是什么货币，并使汇率标准化，从而消除了这种混乱。带着存款的买方只需在阿姆斯特丹交易银行的账户中扣款，并在卖方的账户中存入相同的金额，就可以从卖方那里购买一件物品。

Unlike most central banks that would follow, theWisselbankkept enough metallic reserve, or specie, on hand to honor its depositors’ demands, should they all have chosen to liquidate at once. This prevented any potential runs on the bank and helped make the bonds of the United Provinces the most secure in Europe throughout the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Soft-money advocates might complain that such “full reserve” banking did not allow for credit creation, now seen as the defining characteristic of a bank. Hard-money advocates might respond that it created credit enough that this tiny republic would dominate world commerce for two hundred years after the bank’s founding. Along the way, the Dutch pioneered the various credit instruments — futures, options, selling short, and the like — that helped make the Amsterdam market the center of the financial world.

与后来的大多数中央银行不同，卫斯尔银行手头有足够的金属储备 —— 或者说货币，以满足其存款人的要求 —— 如果他们都选择立即清算的话。这防止了任何潜在的银行挤兑，并有助于使联合省的债券在整个十七世纪和十八世纪成为欧洲最安全的债券。软货币倡导者可能会抱怨说，这种 “全额准备金” 银行业务不允许创造信贷，而信贷现在被视为银行的决定性特征。硬通货倡导者可能会回应说，它创造了足够多的信贷，以至于这个小共和国在银行成立后的两百年里一直主导着世界商业。一路走来，荷兰人开创了各种信贷工具 —— 期货、期权、卖空等，帮助阿姆斯特丹市场成为金融世界的中心。

The dynamics of the Dutch system encouraged the kind of active citizen participation in markets seen nowhere before. By the early 1600s, the Netherlands had become a nation of day traders. One reason for this development, usually overlooked by economists, is a cultural one, namely, that the majority of the republic’s churchgoers embraced Calvinism, the first major Christian movement to accept usury as normative. Soon enough, the Calvinist Dutch Reformed Church would attain privileged status, meaning that to be a public official one first had to be a communicant in the church; not necessarily a pious one, but a communicant nonetheless.4

荷兰制度的活力鼓励公民积极参与市场，这在以前是没有的。到十六世纪初，荷兰已经成为一个日间交易的国家。这一发展的一个原因，通常被经济学家所忽视，是一个文化原因，即共和国的大多数教会信徒接受了加尔文主义，这是第一个接受高利贷为规范的主要基督教运动。很快，加尔文主义的荷兰改革教会就获得了特权地位，这意味着要成为一名公职人员，首先必须是教会的教徒；不一定是虔诚的教徒，但起码是教徒。

In cities like Amsterdam and Haarlem, the everyday seductions of urban life — Amsterdam’s famed red-light district,De Wallen, dates back to the four­teenth century — worked to keep piety to a minimum. Urban moral fiber was further frayed by an outbreak of bubonic plague that ripped through the United Provinces in 1634, wiping out some 15 percent of the populous before subsiding three years later. A giddy fatalism set in behind the plague, and the survivors seemed eager to embrace the here and now, especially at the clusters of taverns, called colleges, where the traders met to make their deals. “In the midst of all this misery,” a Dutch historian would later write, “people were caught by a special fever, by a particular anxiety to get rich in a very short period of time.”

在阿姆斯特丹和哈勒姆等城市，城市生活的日常诱惑 —— 阿姆斯特丹著名的红灯区（De Wallen），可以追溯到十四世纪 —— 它努力使虔诚降到了最低。1634 年爆发的鼠疫横扫联合省，使城市的道德感进一步崩溃，大约 15% 的人口被消灭，三年后才消退。瘟疫过后，一种眩晕的宿命论开始出现，幸存者似乎急于拥抱此时此地，特别是在商人们聚会做交易的酒馆里，即所谓的 “学院”。一位荷兰历史学家后来写道 ：“在所有这些苦难中，人们被一种特殊的热潮所吸引，被一种在很短的时间内致富的特别焦虑所吸引。”

If international trade exposed the citizens to deadly new viruses, it also exposed them to more benign life forms, none more amiable than the tulip. Fifty years earlier the average Dutch citizen could not have told a tulip from a tomato, both sixteenth-century imports — the tulip from Turkey and the tomato from South America.5Blame what happens next on the French. In the 1630s or thereabouts, French women, fashion-mad even then, had begun to adorn the tops of their gowns with fresh flowers. Their wealthier beaus competed to woo the eligible among them with the most exotic plants on the market, tulips here having an aesthetic edge over tomatoes.

如果说国际贸易使公民接触到了致命的新病毒，那么它也使他们接触到了更多良性的生命形式，其中最亲和的莫过于郁金香。50 年前，普通的荷兰公民无法区分郁金香和西红柿，两者都是十六世纪的进口品 —— 郁金香来自土耳其，西红柿来自南美。5将接下来发生的事情要怪法国人。在 1630 年代左右，法国妇女，即使在当时也是时尚狂，已经开始用新鲜的花朵来装饰她们的礼服顶部。她们的富家公子们竞相用市场上最奇特的植物来吸引她们中的佼佼者，郁金香在这里比西红柿更具有美学优势。

True to form, once a modest demand began to develop, the Dutch managed to commoditize tulip sales.6Common bulbs were sold in standard units of a pound. Contracts for “pound” goods did not distinguish among individual bulbs any more than a wheat contract distinguished among shafts of wheat. Since the bulbs could be safely delivered only in a three-month period beginning in June — after the bulbs’ brief photo-op flowering in April or May —— a purchase after September and before the following June was by necessity a futures contract. By 1636, the peak year of the plague, an informal tulip futures market had grown up in the Amsterdam colleges.

按照惯例，一旦开始出现适度的需求，荷兰人就会马上设法将郁金香销售商品化。6普通的球茎是以一磅为标准单位出售。用 “磅” 作为单位签订的货物合同没有对单个球茎进行区分，就像小麦合同对麦穗的大小没有区分一样。由于球茎只能在 6 月开始的三个月内安全交付 —— 在球茎于 4 月或 5 月短暂的美丽花期之后 —— 9 月之后、到来年 6 月之前的购买必然是一份期货合同。到 1636 年，也就是瘟疫最严重的那一年，阿姆斯特丹的 “学院” 里已经形成了一个非正式的郁金香期货市场。

The futures market in tulip bulbs functioned much the way futures markets function today. The buyer of the bulbs and the seller agreed to a contract, one that bound them to exchange bulbs for money on a specified settlement date at a settlement price — the official price bulbs were selling for at the end of the day on the settlement date. The difference between this spontaneous futures market and contemporary ones is the absence of controls. Sales were between individuals. The individuals did not require margin deposits to assure compliance. Nor were the contracts continuously “marked to market” as they are today — that is, repriced daily to capture day-to-day fluctuations. And deep down, the traders knew that if things really went awry, the courts would not enforce the contracts. The rules, in fact, were few and rough-hewn. As economist Peter Garber observes, “Typically the buyer did not currently possess the cash to be delivered on the settlement date, and the seller did not currently possess the bulb.” 7

郁金香球茎的期货市场运作方式与今天的期货市场运作方式差不多。郁金香球茎的买方和卖方同意签订一份合同，该合同约束他们在指定的结算日以结算价 —— 即结算日结束时球茎的官方售价 —— 将球茎换成钱。这种自发的期货市场与当代期货市场的区别在于缺乏控制。销售是在个人之间进行的。这些人不需要保证金以确保遵守规定。合约也不像今天这样连续 “标价” —— 即每天重新定价以捕捉每日的波动。在内心深处，交易员们知道，如果事情真的出了问题，法院不会强制执行这些合同。事实上，这些规则很少，而且是粗制滥造的。正如经济学家彼得·加伯所观察到的，“通常情况下，买方目前并不拥有将在结算日交付的现金，而卖方目前也不拥有球茎。” 7

What happened next is long on myth and short on documentation. The price spike began with a particularly beautiful and rare form of mutated tulip and spread to common tulips soon thereafter.8That there were no actual tulips to be bought or sold only seemed to feed the mania. This all took place before there were any sporting events to bet on in the otherwise dreary, plague-ridden winter months of 1636–1637. Prices mounted steadily from November through February, flattened for a moment, and then suddenly, inexplicably, plunged. Think roller coaster. The tulip mania was over before anyone could figure out how it began.

接下来发生的事情充满了神话色彩，却缺乏文献记载。8没有真正的郁金香可供买卖，这似乎助长了狂热。这一切都发生在 1636 年和 1637 年沉闷的、瘟疫肆虐的冬季，在有任何体育赛事可以投注之前。价格从 11 月到 2 月稳步上升，有一段时间趋于平稳，然后突然莫名其妙地暴跌。就像过山车一样，郁金香狂热在人们还没有弄清它是如何开始的时候就已经结束了。

On February 24, 1637, florists meeting in Amsterdam proposed that would-be buyers who entered contracts after November 30, 1636, be allowed to opt out on payment of 10 percent of the sale price to the seller. By April, provincial and city governments were stepping in, enabling buyers to get out of contracts by paying some small fraction of the contract price. This would not be the last time overly protective governments bailed out imprudent investors.

1637 年 2 月 24 日，在阿姆斯特丹开会的花商提议，允许 1636 年 11 月 30 日之后签订合同的潜在买家在向卖家支付 10% 的售价后选择退出。到了 4 月，各省市的政府开始介入，使买方可以通过支付合同价格的一小部分来解除合同。这不会是最后一次由过度保护的政府来救助不谨慎的投资者。

Curiously, the tale of Dutch tulip mania slipped into history’s fog for the next two centuries, until the 1841 publication of a book by British journalist Charles Mackay,Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds. Mackay’s account of ruined tulip investors and severe nationwide shock found a receptive audience among those who did not much like capitalism and/or the Dutch, a pool large enough to assure the book best-seller status.9

奇怪的是，在接下来的两个世纪里，荷兰郁金香狂热的故事一直在历史的迷雾中溜走，直到 1841 年英国记者查尔斯·麦凯的一本书出版，《非凡的大众妄想和人群的疯狂》。马凯对毁掉的郁金香投资者和全国范围内的严重震荡的描述，在那些不喜欢资本主义和（或）荷兰人的人群中中找到了接受者，这个群体足以保证该书的畅销地位。9

Mackay was not the first author to let the facts stand in the way of a good story. His retelling simply does not track with contemporary Dutch accounts or with transaction records. Tales of woe are conspicuously absent from period literature, and the tulip business rebounded nicely. The tulip unblushingly emerged not as a symbol of folly but as the nation’s iconic flower. As Garber observes, the players had no equity, less sense, and an abiding belief that the state would rescue them from their folly, which it did. “This was no more than a meaningless winter drinking game,” says Garber, “played by a plague-ridden population that made use of the vibrant tulip market.” 10

马凯并不是第一个让事实挡住一个好故事的作者。他的复述根本不符合当代荷兰人的说法或交易记录。当时的文学作品中明显没有悲惨的故事，而郁金香的生意却很好地回升了。郁金香毫不掩饰地出现了，它不是愚蠢的象征，而是国家的标志性花卉。正如加伯所观察到的，参与者没有公平，更没有理智，他们始终相信国家会把他们从愚蠢中拯救出来，而国家也确实这样做了。加伯说 ：“这不过是一个由一个被瘟疫困扰的人口利用充满活力的郁金香市场来玩的毫无意义的冬季饮酒游戏。” "10

What kept the tulip mania at the game level was the absence of an expansive monetary policy by the state. The various local governments may have bailed the players out, but they did not put their money in the game. The same can definitelynotbe said of the governments in early eighteenth-century France and England. Their participation assured that the ensuing bubbles would be huge and their fallout toxic.

使郁金香狂热保持在游戏水平的是国家没有采取扩张性货币政策。各个地方政府可能救助了玩家，但他们并没有把钱投入游戏。十八世纪初的法国和英国的政府可绝对不能这么说。他们的参与保证了随后的泡沫将是巨大的，其后果是有毒的。

elevenBubbles 泡沫

THE LONDON OF THE EIGHTEENTH CENTURY WOULD HAVE CHALLENGED even Dante’s imagination. The visitor did not have to go far to find a lively cockfight. Bearbaiting and bullbaiting spectacles were as casually attended — and bet on — as NFL and NBA games are today. For the adventurous, there were more imaginative contests involving donkeys, monkeys, and dogs (don’t ask). The stock-jobbers and projectors in ’change alley felt right at home in this kind of environment. For those weary of betting on bears, bulls, and monkeys there was always a new project to invest in, like a perpetual-motion machine or a new gizmo to extract lead from silver.1

十八世纪的伦敦甚至会对但丁的想象力构成挑战。游客不必走远就能找到热闹的斗鸡场。猎熊和猎牛的场面就像今天的美国橄榄球联盟和 NBA 比赛一样，被随意地参加和投注。对于喜欢冒险的人来说，还有涉及驴子、猴子和狗（不要问）的更富想象力的比赛。在这种环境中，股票交易员和的投机者们在交易所里感到很自在。对于那些厌倦了在熊、牛和猴子身上下注的人来说，总有一个新的项目可以投资，比如永动机或从银中提取铅的新玩意。1

As in Amsterdam a century earlier, speculators did not hesitate to hawk goods they did not yet possess. The trick was “to sell the bearskin before catching the bear.” Those who sold short were thus known as “bearskin jobbers,” which very likely gave us “bears” and “bear markets.” In the baiting contests, the opposite of bears, who fought cagily, were the bulls, who just plowed right ahead. Staged animal fights have long since been banned — ask Michael Vick — but the language endures.

正如一个世纪前的阿姆斯特丹，投机者毫不犹豫地兜售他们尚未拥有的商品。诀窍是 “在抓到熊之前卖出熊皮”。因此，那些卖空的人被称为 “卖熊皮的人”，这很可能给了我们新词汇，“熊” 和 “熊市”。在诱饵竞赛中，与熊相反的是公牛，他们狡猾地战斗，直接向前冲。舞台上的动物搏斗早已被禁止 —— 问问迈克尔·维克吧 —— 但这种语言却一直存在。

Although born into an aboveboard Scottish banking family, John Law found his true calling in London’s seamy underground. One contemporary described him “as nicely expert in all manners of debaucheries.” 2In April 1694, this twenty-three-year-old gambler and ladies’ man extraordinaire strode angrily out of a Bloomsbury tavern, followed by one Edward Wilson. Having had serious words about a woman they both professed to love, the pair had decided, in classic barroom fashion, to take it outside. There, in Bloomsbury Square, the two drew their swords. The fight did not last but a minute. Law lunged forward and, so said the court brief, “inflicted one mortal wound of the breadth of two inches and depth of five inches, of which said wound the said Edward Wilson then and here instantly died.” 3

虽然出生在一个光明正大的苏格兰银行家庭，但约翰·劳（John Law）却是在伦敦肮脏的地下世界发现了他的真正使命。一位当代人形容他 “是各种放荡行为的专家”。21694 年 4 月，这位 23 岁的赌徒和猎艳高手愤怒地走出布鲁姆斯伯里的一家酒馆，后面跟着一位爱德华·威尔逊。在对一个他们都声称爱的女人进行了严肃的谈话之后，这俩人决定以典型的酒吧风格，把它带到外面去。在那里，在布鲁姆斯伯里广场，两人拔出了剑。这场战斗没有持续一分钟。罗向前扑去，正如法庭简报所说，“造成了一个宽 2 英寸、深 5 英寸的致命伤”，所述的伤口使所述的爱德华·威尔逊当时并在这里立即死亡。3

Law was arrested in a day and within two weeks was prosecuted and sentenced. As he rotted in the Newgate jail, just days away from his own public hanging, even Law, ever the optimist, could not have foreseen a future in which he would one day almost single-handedly transform France’s economic system into the most powerful in the world and would himself stand astride that system — at least for a moment — as its Bernanke, its Geithner, its Buffet, all in one.

劳在一天之内被捕，并在两周之内被起诉和判刑。当他在纽盖特监狱里快要烂掉的时候，离他自己的公开绞刑只有几天时间了，即使是劳，永远是个乐观主义者，也不可能预见到这样的未来：有一天，他几乎以一己之力将法国的经济体系转变为世界上最强大的经济体系，而他自己将站在这个体系中 —— 至少有那么一会儿 —— 成为伯南克、盖特纳、巴菲特的合体。

First, Law had to escape from Newgate, and this he did with a little bit of help from his friends. They spirited him out of England and into Amsterdam, a congenial climate for an unrepentant rake like the young Law. There he took up gambling once again, but not at all recklessly. A mathematics prodigy, he studied the odds and played accordingly. Within a few years, he had a small fortune. By the time he made his way to France, twenty years after the Bloomsbury incident, he had amassed a serious fortune.

首先，劳必须从新门监狱逃出来，他在朋友的帮助下做到了这一点。他们把他带出了英国，来到了阿姆斯特丹，对于像劳这样年轻的且不思悔改的流氓来说，这里是一个很好的环境。在那里，他再次开始了赌博，但并不肆无忌惮。作为一个数学神童，他研究了赔率，并据此进行游戏。没过几年，他就有了一笔小钱。在布鲁姆斯伯里事件发生 20 年后，当他前往法国时，他已经积累了一笔巨额财富。

During his years in exile, Law found his ambition as well and studied the Amsterdam bank and its markets with the same zeal and skill as he did dice odds.4Ten years after his escape, he penned his thoughts on the benefits of a credit-based economy in a forty-thousand-word treatise that established his reputation as a first-rate theorist. In 1705, he used the treatise as leverage to grease his return to Scotland, where he hoped to implement the system of his design. At the time, however, Scotland was negotiating a union with England, which was not yet ready to write off the murder of Wilson as a youthful indiscretion.

在流亡的几年里，罗也找到了自己的雄心壮志，并以研究骰子赔率一样的热情和技巧研究阿姆斯特丹银行及其市场。 4逃亡十年后，他在一篇四万多字的论文中写下了他对基于信用的经济的好处的想法，确立了他作为第一流理论家的声誉。1705 年，他用这篇论文作为筹码，促使他返回苏格兰，希望在那里实施他设计的制度。然而，当时苏格兰正在与英格兰谈判建立联盟，而英格兰还没有准备好将威尔逊的谋杀案作为年轻人的轻率行为来处理。

After another ten years of exile and rejection, Law finally found a country willing to experiment with his capital-S system. France had little left to lose. Knee-deep in debt, its economy slogged forward with little hope of extrication. Law charmed the Duke of Orleans — who was running the country until child king Louis XV came of age — into letting him launch a national bank, the Banque Generale. Even better for Law, the duke obliged his request to issue paper money, the first in French history.5At this time, Law merely proposed to add fluidityto the system. The bank notes could be exchanged for coin at any time. To improve confidence in the new paper currency, the duke declared counterfeiting a capital — from the Latin caput, meaning “head” —— offense. He also instructed his tax collectors to send their money to Law in paper. Law was in business.

在又经历了十年的流放和拒绝之后，劳终于找到了一个愿意试验他的资本制度的国家。法国已经没有什么可失去的了。它深陷于债务之中，经济艰难地向前发展，几乎没有脱困的希望。劳吸引了奥尔良公爵 —— 在还是孩子的国王路易十五成年之前，他一直在管理这个国家 —— 让他发起一个国家银行，即 “通用银行” （Banque Generale）。5这时，劳只是提议增加系统的流动性。纸币可以在任何时候兑换成硬币。为了提高人们对新纸币的信心，公爵宣布造假是一种严重的罪行。他还指示他的收税人将他们的钱以纸质形式寄给罗。劳开始营业了。

This was all well and good to a point, but Law, ever the adventurer, wanted more. His goal was to create wealth, not just move it around more easily. Inspired by the Dutch experience, he decided to merge his bank with a nearly bankrupt overseas trading company, the French Mississippi Company, which had a mission comparable to the Dutch East India Company’s. What it did not have was a chance of pulling a dime’s worth of profit out of pestilential swamps of Louisiana, even if its principal city had been named after Law’s patron, the Duke of Orleans.

这在一定程度上是很好的，但约翰·劳，永远是个冒险家，想要更多。他的目标是创造财富，而不仅仅是更容易地转移财富。受荷兰经验的启发，他决定将他的银行与一家几乎破产的海外贸易公司 —— 法国密西西比公司合并，该公司的使命与荷兰东印度公司的相似。它没有机会从路易斯安那州的瘟疫沼泽地中获得一毛钱的利润，即使其主要城市是以罗的赞助人奥尔良公爵的名字命名的。

Still, the Louisiana territory was so vast and so far away that a high-powered salesman like Law could imbue the newCompagnie D’Occidentwith the smell of potential riches. Having a government-issued monopoly status helped in the credibility department. No one could doubt Law’s pull. If this were not enough, and initially it wasn’t, Law promised investors that they could return bonds at par value in six months if they chose to redeem them.6This was an incredible bargain, given that eighteen months after launch, bonds were selling at only half of par. The French had never dealt in futures before, and they found the concept irresistible. Everyone wanted in.

尽管如此，路易斯安那州的领土是如此广阔和遥远，像劳这样的高权重推销员可以为新的 “西方公司” 注入潜在财富的气息。拥有政府颁发的垄断地位有助于提高可信度。没有人可以怀疑劳的影响力。6这是一个令人难以置信的便宜货，因为在推出 18 个月后，债券的价格只有面值的一半。法国人以前从未从事过期货交易，他们发现这个概念是无法抗拒的。每个人都想加入。

To raise even more capital, the French government allowed Law to issue fifty thousand more shares in this international venture at an affordable par value of only 500livres. To make the shares more attractive, Law introduced a new wrinkle that would haunt markets for the next three centuries: investors could buy “on margin.” 7In other words, they only had to put 75 of the 500livres’ par value down. The rest they could borrow, not from a bank or a brokerage house, but from the company itself — and on E-Z terms, twelve monthly installments, adding up to a total of 550livres. No one complained about the 10 percent nut. Two centuries earlier Martin Luther had thought that the worst a nation’s princes could do in the face of a usurious epidemic was to “sit there and snore with mouths hanging open,” but the French princes did the Germans one better. They weren’t snoring; they were investing. The preteen king was a major shareholder in Law’s operation.

为了筹集更多的资金，法国政府允许劳在这个国际企业中再发行 5 万股股票，面值仅为 500 里弗尔（livre）。7换句话说，他们只需将 500 里弗尔面值的 75% 投入。其余的钱他们可以借，不是从银行或经纪公司，而是从公司本身 —— 而且是以 E-Z 条款，12 个月分期付款，总共 550 里弗尔。没有人抱怨那 10% 的 “果仁壳”。两个世纪前，马丁·路德认为，面对高利贷的流行，一个国家的王子最糟糕的做法是 “坐在那里，张着嘴打鼾”，但法国的王子比德国人做得更好。他们不是在打鼾；他们是在投资。这位年轻的国王是劳的主要股东。

The year 1719 was a big one for Law. In January, the duke absorbed theBanque Generaleand renamed it theBanque Royalewith Law at the helm and its notes guaranteed by the Crown. In May, Law acquired the East India Company and the China Company and reorganized the whole overseas megillah as theCompagnie des Indeswith a monopoly on all French trade outside Europe. In July, theCompagniepurchased from the Crown the right to mint its coins. By October, theCompagniehad assumed the power to collect all taxes.8

1719 年对劳来说是个大日子。1 月，公爵吸收了通用银行，并将其更名为 “皇家银行” （Banque Royale），由劳掌舵，其票据由王室担保。5 月，劳收购了东印度公司和中国公司，并将整个海外大公司改组为东印度公司（Compagnie des Indes），垄断了法国在欧洲以外的所有贸易。7 月，公司从王室购买了铸造硬币的权利。8

With the money from the shares pouring in, Law made an unprecedented and utterly implausible move that same year: he decided to buy all of France’s debt, making him, in effect, the nation’s only creditor. To sweeten the deal for the Crown he lowered the interest rate from 4 percent to 3. On the upside, payments on the debt provided Law’s company a steady cash flow. On the down side, it was close to the only cash flow the company had.

随着股票带来的资金不断涌入，劳在同年做出了一个史无前例、完全不可思议的举动：他决定购买法国的所有债务，实际上使他成为国家的唯一债权人。为了给王室带来甜头，他把利率从 4% 降到了 3%。从正面看，债务的支付为罗的公司提供了稳定的现金流。从坏的方面看，这几乎是该公司唯一的现金流。

Investors were happily oblivious to where Law’s money was coming from. By the beginning of 1720, Law had issued more than 600,000CompagnieD’Occidentshares, worth 300 millionlivresat their par value. Only now, shares were selling for more than thirty times par and rising.9To describe the wealth of these charmed shareholders, a new word entered the world’s vocabulary:millionaire. Unbeknownst to the millionaires, however, the company’s revenues from overseas, including those from its dabbling in slavery and tobacco, could not begin to justify the share prices.

投资者们兴高采烈地忘了劳的钱是从哪里来的。到 1720 年初，劳已经发行了 60 多万股股票，按面值计算价值 3 亿里弗尔。9为了描述这些富有魅力的股东的财富，一个新词进入了世界的词汇 ：“百万富翁”。然而，这些百万富翁不知道的是，公司从海外获得的收入，包括从涉足奴隶制和烟草业获得的收入，根本不足以证明其股价的合理性。

On January 5, 1720, Law was named Controller-General of Finances, with a power equivalent to prime minister.10He was already collecting the nation’s taxes, minting its coins, printing its paper money, managing its central bank, directing all of its overseas trade, and overseeing the affairs of Louisiana, a territory half the size of the present-day United States. These were heady accomplishments for any man, let alone an illegal immigrant on the lam for murder.

1720 年 1 月 5 日，罗被任命为财政总监，其权力相当于首相。 10他已经在收集国家的税收，铸造硬币，印刷纸币，管理中央银行，指导所有的海外贸易，并监督路易斯安那州的事务，该地区的面积相当于今天美国的一半。对于任何一个人来说，这些都是令人振奋的成就，更不用说一个因谋杀而逃亡的非法移民了。

Across the English Channel, the British looked on anxiously as their most feared rival boomed, or at least seemed to. TheWeekly Journal’s Paris correspondent shared Law’s accomplishments with his no-doubt envious audience back in England: “By his wise management, in a very short time, the national debts have been paid, taxes removed, art encouraged, commerce improved, and credit restored: in one word, the nation rescued from ruin.” 11The British would not sit by idly and watch France surpass them. They would launch a bubble of their own.

在英吉利海峡彼岸，英国人焦急地看着他们最可怕的对手蓬勃发展，或者至少是看起来如此。《周刊》的巴黎记者与他在英国的听众分享了劳的成就 ：“通过他的明智管理，在很短的时间内，国家的债务得到了偿还，税收被取消，艺术得到了鼓励，商业得到了改善，信用得到了恢复…… 一句话，国家从毁灭中得到了拯救。” 11英国人不会坐视法国超越他们。他们将推出自己的泡沫。

On April 14, 1720, in London, John Blunt, a chubby shoemaker’s son from Rochester, England, offered two million pounds’ worth of new stock in his South Seas Company at the market price of three hundred pounds. Following Law’s example, he, too, offered easy financing, 20 percent down and the rest payable in bimonthly installments.12

1720 年 4 月 14 日，在伦敦，来自英国罗切斯特的胖胖的鞋匠儿子约翰·布朗特，以 300 英镑的市场价格提供了价值 200 万英镑的南海公司的新股票。效仿劳的做法，他也提供了便捷的融资，首付 20%，其余部分按双月分期支付。12

The South Seas Company had been formed a decade earlier with an avowed intention of opening South America to British trade. The fact that the Spanish and the Portuguese had carved this territory up between them two centuries earlier did not discourage the company’s projectors. Ignorance helped. The less Blunt knew about the actual state of South American trade, the better he could sell it. Among the early investors to this company were Isaac Newton, Jonathan Swift, and King George I.

南洋公司在十年前成立，明确表示要向英国贸易开放南美洲。西班牙人和葡萄牙人在两个世纪前就把这块领土瓜分了，但这并没有让公司的策划者们气馁。无知也有帮助。布拉特对南美贸易的实际状况了解得越少，他就越能推销它。在这家公司的早期投资者中，有艾萨克·牛顿、乔纳森·斯威夫特和国王乔治一世。

In its first decade as a trading company, the South Seas Company managed to do little more than ship a few slaves from Africa to South America and see its profits eaten up by Spanish taxes. By 1715, Blunt had managed to persuade the Prince of Wales to name him governor of the company. He quietly reoriented its mission toward his own strengths, namely, bribery and market manipulation. Like Law, he saw opportunity where others only saw problems: specifically in England’s crushing debt. Daniel Defoe, the author ofRobinsonCrusoeand the company’s chief pamphleteer, laid the blame for the debt on twenty years of bloody war. “Now we see our treasures lost,” he wrote, “our funds exhausted, all our public revenues sold, mortgaged and anticipated, the whole kingdom sold to usury.” 13It would not be until the late twentieth century that “entitlements” supplanted war as the great debt generator.

在作为贸易公司的第一个十年里，南洋公司除了将一些奴隶从非洲运到南美洲之外，几乎没有做什么，而且其利润也被西班牙的税收所吞噬。到 1715 年，布朗特设法说服威尔士亲王任命他为公司的总督。他悄悄地将公司的任务调整为他自己的优势，即贿赂和市场操纵。与劳一样，他在别人只看到问题的地方看到了机会：特别是在英格兰的沉重债务中。《罗宾逊》(Robinson)的作者丹尼尔·笛福(Daniel Defoe)和该公司的首席小册子作者，将债务的责任归咎于二十年的血腥战争。他写道 ：“现在我们看到我们的财宝丢失了，我们的资金耗尽了，我们所有的公共收入都被出售、抵押和预期，整个王国被卖给了高利贷。” 13直到二十世纪末，“权利” 才取代战争，成为巨大债务的来源。

By 1720 that debt had reached the then-astonishing sum of thirty-one million pounds. Blunt’s plan was to raise money, as Law had done, to purchase that debt. Among the targeted shareholders were the government’s creditors. They would exchange their annuities for shares in the South Sea Company at a higher market rate. To make the plan attractive to the government, he would reduce its creditors to one, his company, and its interest rate from 5 percent to 4. To make the plan attractive to the people who ran the government, the peers and MPs, he would sell them “notional” stock — no money down and criminally easy terms — that they could cash in if the share price rose.

到 1720 年，这笔债务已经达到了当时令人惊叹的三千一百万英镑。布朗特的计划是像劳那样筹集资金，以购买这些债务。目标股东中包括政府的债权人。他们将以较高的市场价格用他们的年金换取南海公司的股份。为了使该计划对政府有吸引力，他将把政府的债权人减少到一个，即他的公司，并将其利率从 5% 降到 4%。 为了使该计划对管理政府的人，即同行和国会议员有吸引力，他将向他们出售 “名义” 股票 —— 没有首付，而且条件宽松，如果股价上涨，他们可以兑现。

Even with Parliament in his pocket, Blunt had to outbid the wary Bank of England for the contract, among the dumber auctions in the history of finance. This challenge was made all the more difficult because Blunt had no money. He could raise it only by selling the shares prepurchase and using the equity to buy the debt. As a contemporary historian wrote, “’Twas his avowed maxim, a thousand times repeated, that the advancing by all means of the price of the stock, was the only way to promote the good of the company.” 14Blunt had one other advantage over the bank. He had no legal or political limits on his ability to offer shares. He could sell as many as he chose or give them away. Indeed, he showered the Houses of Lords and Commons with shares. His enemies in the House of Lords warned against “the pernicious practice of stock-jobbing which produced irreparable mischief in diverting the genius of the people from trade and industry” 15but to no avail. Blunt prevailed, and the deal was sealed.

即使议会在他的口袋里，布朗特也必须为这份合同向警惕的英格兰银行出价，这是金融史上最愚蠢的拍卖之一。这一挑战变得更加困难，因为布朗特没有钱。他只能通过出售预购的股票，用股权购买债务来筹集资金。正如一位当代历史学家所写的那样，“这是他公开的格言，重复了一千次，即通过一切手段提高股票价格，是促进公司利益的唯一途径。” 14布朗特对银行还有一项优势。他在发售股票的能力上没有任何法律或政治限制。他可以随心所欲地出售或赠送股票。事实上，他向上议院和下议院赠送了股票。他在上议院的敌人警告说，“炒股的恶习产生了不可弥补的危害，使人们的天才从贸易和工业中转移出来。” 15但没有任何作用。钝器占了上风，交易已经板上钉钉。

As with theCompagnie D’Occident, the South Sea Company could prosper only as long as there were more people willing to buy more shares. To expand the pool, Blunt offered the eighteenth-century equivalent of subprime loans: 10 percent down and the rest in 10 percent installments spread over four years. Now, everyone wanted in. “I have enquired of some that have come from London, what is the religion there?” Jonathan Swift wrote from abroad. “They tell me it is South Sea stock.” 16

与 “西方公司” 一样，南海公司只有在有更多人愿意购买更多股份的情况下才能繁荣。为了扩大资金，布朗特提供了相当于十八世纪的次级贷款。首付 10%，其余部分在四年内分期支付 10% 的费用。现在，每个人都想加入。“我问过一些从伦敦来的人，那里的宗教是什么？” 乔纳森·斯威夫特从国外写道，“他们告诉我，是南海的股票。” 16

In France, meanwhile, Law had come across a problem he did not anticipate. Surprised at the size of their profits, the newly minted millionaires were cashing out and buying precious metals. They failed to consider, rued Law, that “the stocks actually surpassed in value all the gold and silver which will ever be in the Kingdom.” 17To protect his fragile system, Law waxed tyrannical. He outlawed the wearing of diamonds without permission, the making or selling of gold objects, and the storing of gold or silver beyond a bare minimum. To enforce the law, he recruited informers and authorized thegendarmesto search people’s homes for booty beyond the government limit. Enlightenment wit Voltaire, then just in his twenties, called this crackdown “the most unjust edict ever rendered” and the “final limit of a tyrannical absurdity.” 18It did not exactly instill confidence in the investor class. Nor would it when FDR did much the same, some two hundred years later.

同时，在法国，劳遇到了一个他没有预料到的问题。新的百万富翁们对他们的利润规模感到惊讶，纷纷套现并购买贵金属。他们没有考虑到，劳说，“这些股票的价值实际上超过了王国里所有的黄金和白银。” 17为了保护他脆弱的系统，劳变得非常暴虐。他禁止未经许可佩戴钻石，禁止制造或出售黄金制品，禁止储存超过最低限度的黄金或白银。为了执行法律，他招募告密者，并授权宪兵在人们的家中搜查超出政府规定的战利品。启蒙思想家伏尔泰，当时只有 20 多岁，称这种镇压是 “有史以来最不公正的法令”，是 “暴政荒谬的最后极限”。18它并没有完全给投资者阶层带来信心。大约两百年后，当 FDR 做同样的事情时，也不会如此。

When the share prices began to falter, Law offered to buy the shares back at a price fixed above market, a promise he could not begin to honor if people took the offer seriously. They did, and he couldn’t, but then again he did control the printing presses. He ordered nine of them to start rolling overtime to print the billions inlivresnecessary to meet the shareholder demand for cash.19This whole system was spinning madly out of control, and there was nothing sane that Law could do to stop it.

当股价开始动摇时，劳提出以高于市场的固定价格回购股票，如果人们认真对待这一提议，他就无法开始兑现这一承诺。他们这样做了，而他却不能这样做，但他又控制了印刷厂。他命令九台印刷机开始加班加点地印刷数十亿里弗尔，以满足股东对现金的需求。19这整个系统正疯狂地失去控制，而劳没有任何理智的做法可以阻止它。

As night follows day, hyperinflation followed the infusion of excessive paper money. And as day follows night, bad behavior followed hard on heels of hyperinflation. Nothing seemed grounded anymore. So why not gamble, why not carouse? Why not sell your body if you have already sold your soul? And if you have run out of money of your own, why not take it from others? The French had never seen such highway robbery, and not just figuratively. Almost on a daily basis, the robbers’ victims were being fished from the Seine.20

就像黑夜跟随白天一样，恶性通货膨胀紧随过度纸币的注入。就像白天跟着黑夜，不良行为紧随恶性通货膨胀之后。似乎没有什么东西是有根基的了。因此，为什么不赌博，为什么不狂欢？如果你已经出卖了你的灵魂，为什么不出卖你的身体？如果你自己的钱用完了，为什么不从别人那里拿钱？法国人从来没有见过这样的公路抢劫，而且不仅仅是比喻。20

The violence, in turn, led to a rise in vigilantism and public justice. The Count of Horn, a distant, dilettantish young cousin of the Duke of Orleans, got to see justice up close. Having squandered his fortune on the stock market, he and two buddies robbed and murdered a broker. The young count got caught.

这种暴力反过来又导致了治安维持会和公共司法的崛起。霍恩伯爵是奥尔良公爵的一个遥远的、轻率的年轻表弟，他近距离地看到了正义。他在股票市场上挥霍了自己的财富后，和两个伙伴抢劫并谋杀了一名经纪人。这位年轻的伯爵被抓住了。

The wheels of justice turned swiftly in those days — and in this case, literally. In a week of eleven murders, the court decided to set an example. No hanging for the count, no beheading — he would be broken on the wheel. “Do you suffer much on the wheel?” asked the naïve young count. The answer to that question was a resoundingly painful yes. The count was stripped, stretched out on a huge barrel, and rolled to death slowly, all before a large and appreciative crowd. For entertainment, this beat bearbaiting any day. “I have often wished that these banknotes were consigned to hell-fire,” a contemporary wrote. “It is impossible to describe all the evil that has resulted from them.” 21One wonders if Aristotle and Aquinas and Luther saw this kind of spectacle at the end of usury’s road.

在那些日子里，正义之轮迅速转动 —— 在这个案件中，简直就是如此。在发生 11 起谋杀案的一周内，法院决定树立一个榜样。没有绞刑，没有斩首 —— 他将在被绑在车轮上。“在轮子上很痛苦吗？” 天真的年轻伯爵问。这个问题的答案是一个响亮的痛苦的答案。伯爵被剥光衣服，在一个巨大的木桶上伸展开来，慢慢地滚到死，这一切都发生在一大群欣赏者面前。就娱乐而言，这随时都能胜过捕熊游戏。“我经常希望这些钞票被送入地狱之火”，一位当代人写道。21人们想知道亚里士多德、阿奎那和路德是否在高利贷道路的尽头看到了这种场面。

Following the count’s grisly execution, Law began to crack down on speculation and its attendant sins. It was, of course, way too late. It was too late for any remedy. Before 1720 had come to an end, the duke and his council had pulled Law’s notes from circulation, returned the country to gold and silver, and sent Law whence he came — into exile. As if in punishment for the nation’s year of living prodigally, France was struck hard by a plague that had come from the Middle East. In January 1721, the bug shipped out aboard a convoy bound for New Orleans. Of the one thousand would-be colonists, two hundred survived. On both sides of the Atlantic, the French made the connection: at the end of the day, God trumps mammon.

在伯爵惨遭处决后，法律开始打击投机及其附带的罪恶。当然，这已经太晚了。任何补救措施都已经太晚了。在 1720 年结束之前，公爵和他的议会已经将劳的纸币从流通中撤出，使国家恢复了黄金和白银，并将劳送回了他来的地方 —— 流亡。仿佛是对国家这一年来挥霍无度的惩罚，法国遭到了一场来自中东的瘟疫的沉重打击。1721 年 1 月，虫子们搭乘船队前往新奥尔良。在一千名可能的殖民者中，有两百人幸存下来。在大西洋两岸，法国人建立了这样的联系：在一天结束时，上帝胜过玛门。

Some good portion of fleeing French money found its way to England as Law’s bubble was imploding, but there is never enough money in the universe to keep a bubble afloat for long. Blunt overreached much as Law had done and only a month or two behind him. He had his friends in government ban rival joint-stock companies. The move had the opposite effect from what was intended. It projected weakness, not strength. It shook public confidence, and that was all it took to puncture the illusion.

当劳的泡沫破裂之时，有相当一部分逃离的法国资金逃到了英国，但宇宙中永远没有足够的钱来维持泡沫的长期存在。布朗特的做法和劳的做法一样过火，而且只比他晚一两个月。他让他在政府中的朋友禁止竞争对手的股份制公司。此举产生了与预期相反的效果。它显示了软弱，而不是强大。它动摇了公众的信心，而这正是刺破假象的关键所在。

Jonathan Swift worked out his anxiety in his classicGulliver’s Travels, which he started writing as the bubble was bursting.22In the book, Gulliver is on the way to the South Seas when he is overtaken by a violent storm that leaves him stranded, exhausted, and numb from shock. No doubt but that the British investing class could identify. “There never was such distraction and undoing in any country,” one contemporary wrote. “Not a penny stirring.” 23

乔纳森·斯威夫特在他的经典作品《格列佛游记》中解决了他的焦虑，他在泡沫破灭时开始写这本书。 22在书中，格列佛在前往南洋的途中遭遇了一场猛烈的风暴，使他陷入困境，筋疲力尽，并因震惊而麻木。毫无疑问，但英国的投资阶层可以认同。“在任何国家都没有这样的分心和失败”，一位当代人写道。“一文不值。” 23

Given the unchanging nature of the human condition, the shareholders blamed the directors of the South Sea Company — not, of course, their own cupidity — and turned to the government for relief, never mind that the government had been in the tank from the get-go. Although the majority of Parliament members had owned shares in 1720 (many of these outright bribes), that did not stop this august body from looking for a scapegoat — but, of course, never too hard. As to Blunt, he, too, was kicked out of town, his head, luckily, still on his shoulders. If this weren’t bad enough, the plague struck England too. An editorial in the newspaperPost Boymay have gotten it right:

鉴于人类条件的不变性，股东们指责南海公司的董事们 —— 当然不是指责他们自己的杯具 —— 并转向政府寻求救济，别忘了政府从一开始就在油箱里。尽管大多数议会成员在 1720 年都拥有股份（其中许多是赤裸裸的贿赂），但这并不能阻止这个庄严的机构寻找一个替罪羊 —— 当然，永远不会太难。至于布朗特，他也被踢出了城，幸运的是，他的头还在他的肩上。如果这还不够糟糕，瘟疫也袭击了英国。报纸上的一篇社论可能说对了：

The public calamities, which men naturally look upon as proceeding wholly from natural causes, ought to be considered by those who hold the faith as decrees of the providence of a just and merciful God . . . licentiousness and corruption, the fatal fruits of irreligion, reign everywhere; men give themselves up to insatiable avarice; usury and fraud are openly practiced; there is no longer any curb strong enough to restrain covetousness.24

公众的灾难，人们自然地认为完全是由自然原因引起的，但持有信仰的人应该将其视为公正和仁慈的上帝的旨意…… 放荡和腐败，这些非宗教的致命果实，到处都是；人们为贪得无厌的贪婪而放弃自己；高利贷和欺诈行为公开进行；不再有任何足以抑制贪婪的约束。24

As easy it is to blame Law or Blunt, they merely directed the mania along a given path. As economic historian Thomas Woods observes, “Only expansionary monetary policy can account for these phenomena.” 25And only the government can expand the supply of money. Once that supply is liberated, the resulting inflationary pressure deforms not only the economy of a society but also the psychology. Swift chose his words carefully. In the fervor they inspired, these manias mimicked the superficial trappings of a religion. In both England and France, given that fervor, it made a certain amount of sense to participate at least cautiously in a government-endorsed scheme seemingly modeled on the successful Dutch East India Company. As has been shown in these last few years, government-endorsed schemes still have the power to enthuse the ungrounded.

尽管责备劳或布朗特很容易，但他们只是把狂热引导到一条特定的道路上。正如经济史学家托马斯·伍兹所观察到的，“只有扩张性的货币政策才能解释这些现象。” 25而只有政府才能扩大货币的供应。一旦这种供应被解放出来，由此产生的通货膨胀压力不仅使一个社会的经济发生变形，而且也使人们的心理发生变形。斯威夫特谨慎地选择了他的话语。在他们激发的狂热中，这些狂热模仿了宗教的表面外衣。在英国和法国，鉴于这种狂热，至少谨慎地参与一个似乎是以成功的荷兰东印度公司为模式的政府认可的计划是有一定意义的。正如过去几年所显示的那样，政府支持的计划仍然有能力使没有基础的人兴奋起来。

twelveThe Family Business 家族生意

ANY NUMBMBER OF FAMILIES HAD A STAKE IN THE OUTCOME OF EVENTS ON the lush, green fields of Belgium that June day in 1815, the eighteenth. Nearly seventy thousand families from England, Prussia, and the Netherlands had sent their sons to fight under the various banners of the Seventh Coalition. An equal number or more sent their sons off to fight under the revived standard of the French Empire. But no family was paying closer attention to the battle that was about to be waged than a little-known clan that hailed from Germany. Although the paterfamilias, Mayer, had died three years earlier, his five grown sons had made this battle possible. If Napoleon kept his French army in the field the old-fashioned way — by plunder — Wellington kept his allied troops fed and armed the modern way, through debt. Debt prevailed. The Battle of Waterloo would make the reputation of the brothers who arranged it, and their astonishing work would forever change the way wars were financed and fought.1

1815 年 6 月 18 日，在比利时郁郁葱葱的田野上，无数个家庭都在焦急地等待结果的消息。来自英国、普鲁士和荷兰的近七万个家庭派他们的儿子在第七次联盟的各种旗帜下作战。同样数量的家庭或更多的家庭将他们的儿子送去在法兰西帝国复兴的标准下作战。但是，没有一个家庭比一个来自德国的鲜为人知的部族更关注即将展开的战斗了。虽然父亲迈尔三年前已经去世，但他的五个成年儿子使这场战斗成为可能。如果说拿破仑以老式的方式 —— 通过掠夺使他的法国军队保持在战场上，那么威灵顿则以现代的方式 —— 通过债务使他的盟军获得食物和武器。债务占了上风。滑铁卢战役将使安排这场战役的兄弟俩声名鹊起，他们惊人的工作将永远改变战争的筹资和作战方式。1

Mayer Amschel Rothschild was born in 1744 in the city that Martin Luther hated above all others, Frankfurt. “Frankfurt is the golden and silver hole through which everything that springs and grows, is minted or coined here, flows out of Germany,” he had written two centuries earlier. “If that hole were stopped up we should not now have to listen to the complaint that there are debts everywhere and no money; that all lands and cities are burdened with taxes and ruined with interest payments.” 2If anything, Luther would have had more to grouse about in the eighteenth century.

梅耶·阿姆谢尔·罗斯柴尔德 1744 年出生在马丁·路德最讨厌的城市，法兰克福。他在两个世纪前写道 ：“法兰克福是一个金色和银色的洞，所有在这里涌现和成长的东西，在这里铸造的硬币，都会从德国流出去。如果这个洞被堵住了，我们现在就不会听到这样的抱怨：到处都是债务，没有钱；所有的土地和城市都被税收所累，被利息支付所毁。” 2如果有机会的话，路德在十八世纪会有更多抱怨。

Mayer was not too keen on Frankfurt either. Although born just four years before Jeremy Bentham, Mayer came of age in a largely Lutheran city that seemed centuries removed from Bentham’s London. Among the city’s more memorable public displays was a mural called theJudensau, “the Jew’s sow.” The mural depicted a group of Jews subjecting a pig to various acts lewd even by today’s standards. Above that unlovely image was one of a dead baby, his body punctured by countless knife wounds. Its caption told how “in the year 1475” Jews allegedly killed two-year-old Simon of Trent in a ritual murder,3except, of course, it did not use the wordallegedly. Welcome to Frankfurt! The city’s most celebrated native son and a contemporary of Mayer’s, the writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, thought it entirely telling that the murals “were not the product of private hostility, but erected as a public monument.” 4

迈尔对法兰克福也不太感冒。虽然比杰里米·本瑟姆只早出生了四年，但迈尔是在一个基本上属于路德教的城市长大的，与本瑟姆的伦敦似乎相差了几个世纪。在这座城市更令人难忘的公共展示中，有一幅名为 “犹太人的母猪” （Judensau）的壁画，描绘了一群犹太人对一头猪的各种淫秽行为，即使以今天的标准来看也是如此。在这幅不可爱的图画上面是一个死去的婴儿，他的身体被无数的刀伤所刺穿。它的标题讲述了 “1475 年犹太人如何在一次仪式上杀死了两岁的特伦特的西蒙”。3当然，它没有使用 “传闻” （allegedly）的字眼。欢迎来到法兰克福! 这座城市最著名的土生土长者和梅耶的同代人、作家约翰·沃尔夫冈·冯·歌德认为，这些壁画 “不是私人敌意的产物，而是作为公共纪念碑竖立起来的。” 4

Mayer Rothschild inhabited a world of unpleasant surprises. He and his sons would tread as lightly through it as Shylock did through his. Even after the family had accumulated more than forty stately homes throughout Europe and wealth beyond counting, the Rothschilds trod lightly. “They begrudge us Jews the eyes in our heads,” Mayer’s son Amschel would write well after the family had grown rich, “[and want] to drink our blood.” 5The derangement in their native Germany two centuries after Mayer’s birth would prove even the most anxious among them something other than paranoid.

梅耶·罗斯柴尔德居住在一个充满不愉快的世界。他和他的儿子们会像夏洛克在他的世界里一样轻而易举地穿过它。即使在家族在欧洲各地积累了 40 多处庄严的住宅和难以计数的财富之后，罗斯柴尔德家族仍然轻装上阵。梅耶的儿子阿姆谢勒在家族变得富有之后写道 ：“他们嘲笑我们犹太人头上的眼睛，（并）想喝我们的血。” 5 梅耶出生两个世纪后，他们家乡德国发生的混乱将证明他们中最焦虑的人也不是偏执狂。

Stacked deck or not, the Rothschilds played a damned shrewd hand. The governing classes of the surrounding region — princes, archdukes, electors — served the Rothschilds the way savings and loan execs would the Salomon Brothers two centuries hence. They were the market’s fools, the ones whose ignorance and prodigality made wiser men rich. The fact that the region’s affluent often spent more than they made served up opportunities for those who made more than they spent. The fact that they did much of their business in Frankfurt opened doors for the Rothschilds.

无论是否做了手脚，罗斯柴尔德家族都打出了一手非常精明的牌。周边地区的管理阶层 —— 王子、大公、选民 —— 为罗斯柴尔德家族服务，就像两个世纪后储蓄和贷款执行官为所罗门兄弟服务一样。他们是市场的傻瓜，他们的无知和挥霍使更聪明的人发财。该地区的富人往往花的比赚的多，这一事实为那些赚的比花的多的人提供了机会。他们在法兰克福做了很多生意，这一事实为罗斯柴尔德家族打开了大门。

By this time, even in Luther’s Germany, usury was no longer an issue. German bankers routinely lent at interest, and almost no one felt the need to repent.6For all of Germany’s progress, however, Jews retained a widespread reputation for being more astute at the business of money changing and money lending than their Christian peers. This reputation cut both ways. Writing well after the Rothschilds had come to dominate European finance, Max Weber could describe the “politically and speculatively oriented” Jewish approach to business as “pariah capitalism” and compare it unfavorably to the hearty “Protestant ethic” of his fellow Germans.

这时，即使在路德的德国，高利贷也不再是一个问题。6然而，尽管德国取得了所有的进步，犹太人在换钱和放钱的业务上比他们的基督徒同行更精明，从而保留了广泛的声誉。这种声誉是双向的。在罗斯柴尔德家族主宰欧洲金融业之后，马克斯·韦伯在写作中可以将 “以政治和投机为导向” 的犹太人的商业方式描述为 “贱民资本主义”，并将其与他的德国同胞的 “新教伦理” 进行不利的比较。

For sure, Mayer Rothschild knew his way around money. He had lifted his family from its pious and humble roots by acquiring an expertise in rare coins and medals. The people who collected what Mayer dealt were inevitably well heeled and occasionally deeply in debt. Mayer expanded his business to meet their needs. The neediest of this clientele was Crown Prince Wilhelm of Hesse, later Wilhelm IX, for whom Mayer served as court Jew in all but official title. Wilhelm’s leading exports, as American schoolchildren once knew, were those dread Hessian soldiers. By arranging financing for Wilhelm, Mayer helped put the soldiers in the field. As the eighteenth century neared its end, his service to Wilhelm and fellow travelers helped make Mayer one of the wealthiest Jews in Frankfurt, a status his sons would quickly render trivial.

可以肯定的是，梅耶·罗斯柴尔德深谙金钱之道。他通过习得对稀有钱币和奖章方面的专业知识，将他的家族从虔诚和卑微的根源中解脱出来。收集迈尔所经营的东西的人不可避免地都是有钱人，偶尔也会深陷债务。梅尔扩大了他的业务，以满足他们的需求。这些客户中最需要的是黑森州的威廉王储，也就是后来的威廉九世，迈尔为他充当宫廷犹太人，除了官方头衔。正如美国小学生曾经知道的那样，威廉的主要出口产品是那些可怕的黑森州士兵。通过为威廉安排融资，迈尔帮助将这些士兵送上战场。随着十八世纪接近尾声，他对威廉和同行的服务使迈尔成为法兰克福最富有的犹太人之一，他的儿子们很快就会把这种地位变得微不足道。

For all his good fortune, Mayer had no greater bounty than these five sons. His dutiful wife Gutle bore him a child very nearly every year from 1771 to 1992. Of the nineteen or so children they brought into the world, ten lived to adulthood, a depressingly typical survival rate in the eighteenth century. Of the ten, five were boys — Amschel, Salomon, Nathan, Carl, and James. In the relentlessly male-oriented Rothschild household, those five sons would learn the rules from the old man — and repeat them among themselves — until they became gospel. No rule was more important or more nearly prophetic than the one Mayer shared with Amschel on his deathbed: “Keep your brothers together, and you will become the richest people in Germany.” 7In honoring this request, the boys would surpass even Mayer’s grandiose ambitions.

对于他所有的好运气，迈尔没有比这五个儿子更丰厚的财富。从 1771 年到 1992 年，他孝顺的妻子古特莱几乎每年都为他生下一个孩子。在他们带来的十九个左右的孩子中，有十个活到了成年，这在十八世纪是一个令人沮丧的典型存活率。在这十个孩子中，有五个是男孩 —— 阿姆谢尔、所罗门、内森、卡尔和詹姆斯。在无情的男性导向的罗斯柴尔德家庭中，这五个儿子将从老人那里学习规则 —— 并在他们之间重复这些规则 —— 直到它们成为福音。没有什么规则比梅尔在临终前与阿姆谢尔分享的那条规则更重要或更接近预言。 “团结你的兄弟们，你就会成为德国最富有的人。” 7在遵守这一要求的过程中，这些孩子甚至超过了梅耶尔的宏伟抱负。

While still healthy, Mayer was not above hectoring the lads, especially Nathan, the borderline black sheep who would one day become the most powerful of all Rothschilds, his father included. “To begin with, all our correspondents complain about you, Dear Nathan,” he wrote to his third son, recently decamped to England, “and say that you are so disorganized when sending consignments.” This he followed with a more universal axiom: “They say that without good order a millionaire can go broke the more business he does, because the whole world is not, or not very, honest.” 8

在身体仍然健康的情况下，梅耶并不吝啬对孩子们的指责，尤其是内森，这个边缘的害群之马，有一天会成为所有罗斯柴尔德家族中最有权力的人，包括他的父亲。“首先，我们所有的通讯员都在抱怨你，亲爱的内森”，他给他的第三个儿子写道，他最近去了英国，“并说你在寄送货物时非常混乱。” 他接着说了一个更普遍的公理 ：“他们说，如果没有良好的秩序，一个百万富翁可能会破产，他做的生意越多，因为整个世界都不诚实，或不太诚实。” 8

On another occasion, Mayer chided Nathan for absorbing too many unproductive loans and not disclosing them. “If you have many bad debts, which God forbid, and enter them as if they are good, that is simply to pretend that you are rich.” 9Had Wall Street heeded this advice in the twenty-first century, there would have been no subprime crisis.

在另一个场合，梅耶责备内森吸收了太多无益的贷款而没有披露它们。“如果你有很多坏账，这是上帝所不允许的；而你把它们当作好的来输入，那简直就是在假装你很有钱。” 9如果华尔街在二十一世纪听从了这个建议，就不会有次贷危机。

Some of the advice Mayer gave, however, mined the darker shafts of the Jewish consciousness. These words of wisdom were singular in their focus: “Our late father taught us,” Salomon reminded Nathan, “that if a high-placed person enters into a partnership with a Jew, he belongs to the Jew.” 10Harsher still was Mayer’s oft-repeated survival dictum, “If you can’t make yourself loved, make yourself feared.” 11The Rothschilds did just that, but before they could hope to intimidate Europe, they first had to win the Battle of Waterloo.

然而，梅耶给出的一些建议挖掘了犹太人意识中较黑暗的部分。这些智慧之言的重点很单一 ：“我们已故的父亲教导我们”，萨洛蒙提醒内森，“如果一个高职位的人与一个犹太人建立伙伴关系，他就属于这个犹太人。” 10更严厉的是梅尔经常重复的生存箴言 ：“如果你不能让人们爱你，那就让人们怕你。” 11罗斯柴尔德家族就是这样做的，但在他们希望恐吓欧洲之前，他们首先必须赢得滑铁卢之战。

By the time Napoleon broke out of exile on St. Helena for his final surge, the brothers Rothschild had positioned themselves all across Europe. Amschel had taken over the Frankfurt Bank. Salomon had launched his operation in Vienna. Nathan had moved to London. Carl set up shop in Naples, and James had made Paris home. Nathan had proved the cleverest of them all. Historians still puzzle over how this obscure merchant banker, not yet forty, who had only recently been a minor textile exporter, came to be the man who rescued Europe from Napoleon. “My brother in London is the commanding general,” Salomon would write at the time, “I am his field marshal.” 12

当拿破仑从圣赫勒拿岛的流放地爆发出最后的高潮时，罗斯柴尔德兄弟已经在欧洲各地布局。阿姆谢尔已经接管了法兰克福银行。萨洛蒙在维也纳开展了他的业务。内森搬到了伦敦。卡尔在那不勒斯开店，而詹姆斯把巴黎当成了家。事实证明，内森是他们中最聪明的。历史学家们仍然不明白，这个默默无闻的商业银行家，还不到 40 岁，最近才成为一个小的纺织品出口商，是如何成为把欧洲从拿破仑手中拯救出来的人。“我在伦敦的兄弟是统帅”，所罗门当时写道，“我是他的元帅。” 12

The Duke of Wellington needed help. Although Britain had the soundest and most transparent finances in the world, the seemingly endless wars against a foe who could throw his whole people’s army into battle had drained its treasury. In February 1813, Wellington was reporting that he could “scarcely stir out of my house on account of the public creditors waiting to demand payment of what is due to them.” 13Appointed official financier in 1814, Nathan had much to offer besides good connections and industrial strengthchutzpah. A recovering smuggler, he and his brothers knew how to gather specie from all over the continent and get it to Wellington in spendable form. The brothers’ trust in each other and their ability to communicate quickly and securely among themselves made all the difference. More so than the Medici or any family that preceded them, the Rothschildsfrèresformed the first real multinational corporation.

威灵顿公爵需要帮助。尽管英国拥有世界上最健全和最透明的财政，但与一个可以将其整个人民的军队投入战斗的敌人进行的看似无休止的战争已经耗尽了它的国库。1813 年 2 月，威灵顿报告说，他 “几乎无法走出家门，因为公共债权人在等着要求支付他们应得的东西。” 131814 年被任命为官方金融家，除了良好的关系和实力雄厚的厚脸皮，内森还有很多。作为一个正在恢复实力的走私者，他和他的兄弟们知道如何从整个大陆收集标本，并将其以可消费的形式送到惠灵顿。兄弟们的相互信任以及他们之间快速和安全的沟通能力使一切变得不同。与美第奇家族或之前的任何家族相比，罗斯柴尔德家族的兄弟们形成了第一个真正的跨国公司。

In regard to the battle’s outcome, at least as it affected the Rothschilds, a sea of myth surrounds an almost imperceptible outcropping of truth. The story was widely believed, and may still be, that Nathan quit the battlefield as soon as victory was assured, braved the stormy English channel in his frantic trip home, and commenced to buy stocks on a depressed English market, knowing that the good news to come would elevate their price. He is alleged to have pocketed as much as 135 million pounds by his cunning.

关于这场战役的结果，至少在它影响到罗斯柴尔德家族的时候，一片神话的海洋围绕着一个几乎难以察觉的真相露头。这个故事被广泛相信，现在也可能是，内森在胜利得到保证后立即离开了战场，在回家途中冒着暴风雨穿过英吉利海峡，开始在低迷的英国市场上购买股票，因为他知道即将到来的好消息会抬高它们的价格。据称，他通过自己的狡猾，将多达 1.35 亿英镑收入囊中。

The real story has none of the drama or the profits. In fact, the Rothschilds felt about Wellington’s quick and decisive victory much the way Halliburton must have after Schwartzkopf’s unexpectedly quick and decisive victory in the Gulf War. The months, maybe years, of steady work to come had been shortened to days. Even worse for the Rothschilds, they had bought up all that specie when it was scarce and the prices high. Unloading it postwar would be difficult and expensive. Offsetting the losses were Nathan’s very real purchases in the London bond market at war’s end, but the profits from these deals were nowhere near those of myth.14The tensions during this period tested the brothers’ legendary synergy.

真实的故事没有任何戏剧性和利润。事实上，罗斯柴尔德家族对惠灵顿的快速和决定性胜利的感受，与哈利伯顿在海湾战争中取得出乎意料的快速和决定性胜利后的感受差不多。未来几个月，也许几年的稳定工作被缩短为几天。对罗斯柴尔德家族来说，更糟糕的是，他们在货币稀缺、价格高涨的时候买下了所有这些货币。战后卸货将是困难和昂贵的。抵消损失的是内森在战争结束时在伦敦债券市场上非常真实的购买，但这些交易的利润远远没有达到神话的水平。14这段时期的紧张局势考验了兄弟俩传奇般的协同作用。

If their finances suffered at Waterloo, the brothers’ reputation did not. The battle had transformed them from an obscure clan of ghetto Jews to the Bonapartes of the banking world, Nathan in particular. The payoff came three years after Waterloo, when one of the still-broke allies, namely, Prussia, turned to the newly famous Rothschilds to dig them out of their hole. It was not the size of the subsequent bond offering that made history but the conditions. Nathan had the nerve to demand of the Prussian government “some security beyond the mere good faith of government.” 15

如果他们的财务状况在滑铁卢受到影响，兄弟俩的声誉却没有。这场战役使他们从一个不起眼的犹太人部落变成了银行界的波拿巴家族，尤其是内森。滑铁卢战役后三年，当一个仍在崩溃的盟国，即普鲁士，转向新近闻名的罗斯柴尔德家族，帮助自己逃离自己挖出的坑时，回报就来了。创造历史的不是随后发行的债券的规模，而是条件。内森有胆量要求普鲁士政府 “在政府的诚意之外提供一些担保。” 15

Mere good faith? How those words from an upstart Jew must have rankled in Berlin, and Nathan was just warming up. He insisted that any loan be secured by a mortgage on Prussian royal domains, that the loan originate in London, that bonds be issued not just in London but also in Frankfurt, Berlin, Amsterdam, Hamburg, and Vienna — and all in sterling. These demands were as revolutionary as they were insulting, but the impoverished Prussians had little choice. As Mayer used to remind the lads, “It is better to deal with a government in difficulty than one that has luck on its side.” 16

更有诚意？一个后起之秀的犹太人的这些话在柏林一定很生气，而这只不过是内森刚刚开始热身。他坚持认为，任何贷款都要以普鲁士王室领地为抵押，贷款要在伦敦发放。债券不仅要在伦敦发行，还要在法兰克福、柏林、阿姆斯特丹、汉堡和维也纳发行，而且都要用英镑。这些要求既是革命性的，又是侮辱性的，但贫穷的普鲁士人没有什么选择。正如迈尔经常提醒小伙子们的那样，“与一个有困难的政府打交道，比与一个运气好的政府打交道要好。” 16

Yes, Virginia, conspiracy theories predated the Internet, and in the nineteenth century no people attracted more conspiracy chatter than the Rothschilds. They were Jewish by origin, international by design, and richer than Croesus, three triggers then and now. They were the Bilderbergs, the CFR, the Jekyll Island crowd, the neocons, all in one family. That they married largely among themselves — cousins, nothing too kinky here — and entrusted only male heirs with positions of power heightened the intrigue surrounding them. “The Rothschilds are the wonders of modern banking,” an American observer wrote in 1835. “We see the descendants of Judah, after a persecution of two thousand years, peering above kings, rising higher than emperors, and holding a whole continent in the hollow of their hands. The Rothschilds govern a Christian world.” 17

是的，弗吉尼亚，阴谋论早于互联网，在十九世纪，没有人比罗斯柴尔德家族更吸引阴谋论的讨论。他们是犹太裔，还是故意转成国际性的，比克罗伊索斯还要富有，无论当时还是现在都是三个板机。他们是毕德堡（Bilderbergs）、外交关系理事会（CFR）、哲基尔岛（Jekyll Island）人群、新教徒，都是一个家族。他们主要在自己之间结婚 —— 表兄妹，这里没有什么太奇怪的地方 —— 并且只把权力职位委托给男性继承人，这加剧了围绕他们的阴谋论。“罗斯柴尔德家族是现代银行业的奇迹”，一位美国观察家在 1835 年写道。“我们看到犹大的后裔，在经历了两千年的迫害之后，在国王之上窥视，比皇帝更高，并将整个大陆握在他们的手中。罗斯柴尔德家族统治着一个基督教世界。” 17

Writing his fiction four years after Waterloo, Sir Walter Scott projected the Rothschilds six centuries back into history. “These Gentiles, cruel and oppressive as they are, are in some sort dependent on the dispersed children of Zion,” explainsIvanhoe’s fair Rebecca to her money-lending father. “Without the aid of our wealth they could neither furnish forth their hosts in war nor their triumphs in peace; and the gold which we lend them returns with increase to our coffers.” 18

在滑铁卢战役的四年后，沃尔特·斯科特爵士写下了他的小说，将罗斯柴尔德家族的历史推到了六个世纪之前。“这些外邦人，虽然残酷而压迫，但在某种程度上依赖于锡安的分散的孩子” 《艾文荷》里公平的丽贝卡向她放债的父亲解释道。“没有我们财富的帮助，他们既不能在战争中出动他们的队伍，也不能在和平中取得胜利；我们借给他们的金子也会增加到我们的库房。”

Given their pivotal role at Waterloo, some sizable cohort of otherwise smart people would accuse the Rothschilds of inciting every military adventure up to and including Pearl Harbor. What the conspiracy-minded overlooked, however, was the Rothschilds’ business model. Waterloo had changed it. They were no longer traders but fund managers, tending to a large and growing portfolio of government bonds. They did not need war. They did not want it. War puts bondholders in jeopardy. If the originator of the bond ended up in the shape, say, of Italy or Germany circa 1945, a whole lot of people were going to be left with a whole lot of useless paper. By mid-century, the Rothschilds had become peacemongers, and this the Confederate States of America would learn the hard way.

鉴于他们在滑铁卢的关键作用，一些相当规模的其他聪明人会指责罗斯柴尔德家族煽动每一次军事冒险，甚至包括珍珠港。然而，那些有阴谋论的人忽视了罗斯柴尔德家族的商业模式。滑铁卢改变了它。他们不再是交易员，而是基金经理，照顾一个庞大且不断增长的政府债券组合。他们不需要战争。他们也不希望发生战争。战争使债券持有人处于危险之中。如果债券的发起人最后变成了，比如说，1945 年左右的意大利或德国，那么一大批人就会被留下一大堆无用的纸张。到本世纪中叶，罗斯柴尔德家族已经成为和平使者，而这一点，美国联邦调查局将以艰难的方式学到。

At the American Civil War’s commencement, the Confederates had good reason to believe that the Rothschilds would put their financial muscle behind the Southern cause. August Belmont, the Rothschilds’ man in New York, served as the Democratic Party’s national chairman. He had strenuously opposed Abraham Lincoln’s candidacy in 1860 and his “fatal policy of confiscation and forcible emancipation.” 19So outspoken was Belmont that Union sympathizers naturally assumed that the Rothschilds would back the South. Not surprisingly given the time and place, some were less than PC in their response. “Belmont, the Rothschilds and the whole tribe of Jews . . . have been buying up confederate bonds,” warned theChicago Tribune.20Others envisioned their enemy as an unholy trinity of “Jews, Jeff Davis, and the devil.” 21The fact that the South had tasked its Jewish secretary of state, Judah Benjamin, with recruiting Britain to the cause did little for interfaith harmony north of the Mason-Dixon Line.

在美国内战开始时，南军有充分的理由相信，罗斯柴尔德家族会在南方的事业中投入他们的财政力量。罗斯柴尔德家族在纽约的人奥古斯特·贝尔蒙担任民主党全国主席。他极力反对亚伯拉罕·林肯在 1860 年的候选资格及其 “致命的没收和强制解放政策”。19贝尔蒙如此直言不讳，联盟的同情者自然认为罗斯柴尔德会支持南方。鉴于当时的时间和地点，一些人的反应并不令人惊讶。20还有人将他们的敌人设想为 “犹太人、杰夫·戴维斯和魔鬼的三位一体”。21南方让其犹太国务卿朱达`本杰明负责招募英国加入这一事业，这一事实对马斯逊·迪克森线以北的宗教间和谐没有什么帮助。

If politics makes strange bedfellows, war makes stranger ones. When the Rothschilds first staked out a position in American finance in the 1830s, a surprisingly tenuous position at that, Southern pols did not exactly set up the folding chairs and pass out the lemonade. The governor of Mississippi was quick to denounce Nathan, the “Baron Rothschild,” with all the cultural clichés at his disposal. Said the governor, “The blood of Judas and Shylock flows in his veins . . . and unites the qualities of both his countrymen.” 22

如果说政治会产生奇怪的关系，那么战争会产生更奇怪的关系。当罗斯柴尔德家族在十九世纪 30 年代首次在美国金融界占据一席之地时 —— 其实只不过是一个令人惊讶的脆弱地位 —— 南方的政治家们并没有完全摆好折叠椅和递上柠檬水。密西西比州的州长很快就用他所掌握的所有文化陈词滥调来谴责内森这个 “罗斯柴尔德男爵”。这位州长说 ：“他的血管里流淌着犹大和夏洛克的血液…… 并结合了他两个同胞的品质。” 22

The Rothschilds proved coy in this unlikely courtship. Whether they had qualms about slavery is unknown, but they most certainly had qualms about underwriting a nation unlikely to meet its debt obligations. The South had money problems from Fort Sumter on. Although its citizens responded eagerly to the Confederacy’s first two bond offerings, foreign investors balked. Without an international assist, there were very real limits to the South’s ability to finance itself. The semifeudal nature of southern society did not do wonders for regional liquidity.

罗斯柴尔德家族在这场不可能的求爱中表现得很腼腆。他们是否对奴隶制有顾虑不得而知，但他们对为一个不可能履行其债务义务的国家提供担保肯定有顾虑。从萨姆特堡开始，南方就遇到了资金问题。尽管其公民对联邦的头两次债券发行反应热烈，但外国投资者却望而却步。在没有国际援助的情况下，南方的融资能力受到了非常现实的限制。南方社会的半封建性质对地区流动性没有什么好处。

To compensate, the Confederates collaborated with a French merchant banking house on a scheme that was almost very clever. The firm floated a bond on the South’s behalf that was redeemable not in specie — there was precious little of that — but in cotton, which was abundant. The terms were generous. The bonds had a 7 percent coupon and a maturity of twenty years.23Better still, or so it seemed, the purchaser could redeem the bond in cotton at the prewar price of six pence a pound. The British textile industry depended on southern cotton. By withholding supply, the South could drive up the price of cotton and make the cotton-backed bonds attractive to investors.

为了补偿，南军与一家法国商业银行合作制定了一个几乎非常聪明的计划。该公司代表南方发行了一种债券，该债券不是以实物 —— 当时的实物很少 —— 而是以丰富的棉花来赎回，条件很优厚。23更好的是，似乎是这样，购买者可以以战前每磅六便士的价格用棉花赎回债券。英国的纺织业依赖于南方的棉花。通过扣留供应，南方可以推高棉花价格，使棉花支持的债券对投资者有吸引力。

This was all going swimmingly until the Union seized the port of New Orleans just one year into the war. Now, to cash in the bonds for the cotton collateral, a British merchant would have to run a formidable Union blockade. The only thing heading south at this point was the value of the bonds. With foreign capital drying up, the Confederates decided to print their way into liquidity. Before the war was through, they would distribute 1.7 billion increasingly worthless Confederate dollars. Although the Union was also printing money generously, the South was setting a standard of fiscal promiscuity that would not see its equal until Weimar, Germany. As inevitably happens in these circumstances, inflation shot through the roof. A loaf of bread that cost ten cents at war’s beginning would have costfour hundredConfederate dollars at war’s end. People were going hungry.

这一切都进行得很顺利，直到战争开始仅一年时间，联邦就夺取了新奥尔良港。现在，为了兑现棉花抵押品的债券，英国商人将不得不面对联邦的强大封锁。这时，唯一往南走的就是债券的价值了。随着外国资本的枯竭，南军决定以印刷的方式获得流动资金。在战争结束前，他们将分发 17 亿越来越不值钱的联邦元。虽然联邦也在慷慨地印钱，但南方正在建立一个财政混乱的标准，这在德国魏玛之前是不会出现的。在这种情况下，通货膨胀不可避免地发生了，通货膨胀突破了屋顶。一条在战争开始时只需 10 美分的面包，在战争结束时要花费 400 美元的联邦军。人们正在挨饿。

The Rothschilds “would help decide the outcome of the American Civil War,” writes the clan’s definitive historian, Niall Ferguson, “by choosing to sit on the sidelines.” 24That choice proved prescient. Those loyal enough or reckless enough to invest in Confederate bonds paid for their loyalty and/or their imprudence with their life savings. The North refused to honor the South’s debts. And its banks were not about to redeem the “greybacks” with anything, even cotton. As the Rothschilds well understood, and would come to experience firsthand, a lost cause inevitably results in lost fortunes.

罗斯柴尔德家族 “将帮助决定美国内战的结果”，该家族的权威历史学家尼尔·弗格森写道，“他们选择坐视不理。” 24这一选择被证明具有前瞻性。那些足够忠诚或鲁莽地投资于南方邦联债券的人，为他们的忠诚和（或）他们的轻率付出了一生的积蓄。北方拒绝履行南方的债务。它的银行也不打算用任何东西，甚至是棉花来赎回 “灰背”。正如罗斯柴尔德家族所理解并将亲身体验到的那样，一个失败的事业不可避免地会导致财富的损失。

thirteenThe Socialism of Fools 傻瓜的社会主义

HEINRICH HEINE WAS BORN JEWISH IN DUSSELDORF FIVE YEARS AFTER the birth of James, the youngest of Mayer Rothschild’s five surviving sons. In 1811, James, not yet twenty, moved to Paris to stake out a position there. Six years later, he opened a merchant banking house, de Rothschild Frères, and soon enough, predictably enough, alchemized himself from teenage dross into the most powerful banker in France.

海因里希·海涅是在詹姆斯出生五年后在杜塞尔多夫出生的犹太人，他是梅耶·罗斯柴尔德五个幸存儿子中最小的一个。1811 年，还不到 20 岁的詹姆斯搬到了巴黎，在那里占有一席之地。六年后，他开设了一家商业银行 —— 罗斯柴尔德兄弟公司。很快，可以预见的是，他会将自己从少年时的渣滓炼成了法国最强大的银行家。

Heine, too, found his way to Paris. For a German Jew in the nineteenth century, his was, if anything, the road more traveled by, the revolutionary road. He dabbled in banking under the watchful eye of Uncle Salomon in Hamburg and then dallied a while studying law in Bonn and Berlin, but the City of Light beckoned. Along the way, Heine underwent a total cultural makeover. He took to writing poetry, shucked his Judaism, changed his name from Hayyim to Heinrich, got himself baptized a Lutheran, and started flirting with socialism.1

海涅也找到了去巴黎的路。对于十九世纪的德国犹太人来说，如果说他是走了一条更多的路，那就是革命之路。在汉堡，他在萨洛蒙叔叔的注视下涉足银行业，然后在波恩和柏林学习了一段时间的法律，但光明之城在召唤他。一路上，海涅经历了一次彻底的文化改造。他开始写诗，放弃了犹太教，把名字从哈伊姆改为海因里希，让自己接受路德教的洗礼，并开始与社会主义调情。1

Fueling his animus toward the capitalist enterprise was its identification with Judaism, a faith he had come to loathe as much as he loathed his old unhip self. The Gentile French Left had been pushing this identification for a generation before Heine arrived. In an 1808 treatise, Francois Fourier described commerce as “the source of all evil” and Jews as “the incarnation of commerce.” 2Pierre-Joseph Proudhon, the world’s first self-labeled anarchist, a man who bequeathed the world the axiom “Property is theft,” accused the Jews of transforming the European bourgeoisie into a likeness of themselves, “obstinate, infernal . . . the enemy of mankind.” 3A Fourier disciple, Alphonse Toussenel, wrote the first book-length exposé of Jews as usurious conspirators against humanity.

他对资本主义企业的敌意来自于对犹太教的认同，他开始厌恶这种信仰，就像他厌恶以前那个没有教养的自己。在海涅到来之前，法国的外邦人左翼已经在一代人的时间里推动了这种认同。在 1808 年的一篇论文中，弗朗索瓦·傅立叶将商业描述为 “一切罪恶之源”，而犹太人则是 “商业的化身”。2皮埃尔·约瑟夫·蒲鲁东，世界上第一个自称无政府主义者的人，一个为世界留下 “财产即盗窃” 公理的人，指控犹太人把欧洲资产阶级变成了他们自己的模样，“顽固，属于地狱…… 人类的敌人”。 3傅立叶的弟子阿尔方斯·图森内尔写了第一本关于犹太人是反人类的高利贷阴谋者的长篇揭露。

A lyric poet of growing reputation, Heine discovered that his cultural self-hatred played well in Paris’s aptly named Left Bank, and he was not shy about expressing it. In 1822, he described the three great evils plaguing the world as “poverty, pain, and Jewishness.” 4As he saw it, the incarnation of the Jewish malady was the Rothschild family. Being close at hand, James, now a baron, caught most of the abuse. Heine called him “Herr von Shylock in Paris” and claimed, with a straight face, that he had once seen a stockbroker bow to James’s chamber pot. He argued, only half in jest, that the Vatican had eased up on Jews because the pope was in hock to the Baron James. Said Heine most famously, “There is only one God — Mammon. And Rothschild is his prophet.” 5This much said, loud and often, Heine did not shy from cozying up to the Rothschilds for their patronage and to his uncle Salomon for an allowance. Even then, at the peak of its popularity, poetry did not pay well.

作为一名声誉日隆的抒情诗人，海涅发现他的文化自我憎恨在巴黎的左岸发挥得很好，而且他毫不吝啬地表达出来。4在他看来，犹太病的化身就是罗思柴尔德家族。由于近在咫尺，詹姆斯，现在的男爵，受到了大部分的辱骂。海涅称他为 “巴黎的夏洛克先生”，并直言不讳地声称，他曾看到一个股票经纪人向詹姆斯的夜壶鞠躬。他辩称，梵蒂冈对犹太人的态度有所缓和，因为教皇与詹姆斯男爵勾结，这只是半开玩笑。海涅最有名的说法是 ：“只有一个上帝 —— 玛门。5说到这里，海涅毫不吝啬地向罗斯柴尔德家族讨好，以获得他们的赞助，向他的叔叔萨洛蒙讨要津贴。即使在那时，在其流行的高峰期，诗歌的报酬也不高。

As influential as Heine was in his day, he would serve as warm-up act for a young man he befriended in Paris, one whose confused sense of self would transform the world, and not necessarily in a happy way. “What the two men had in common,” historian Paul Johnson notes, “was their extraordinary capacity for hatred.” 6Johnson traces this dubious talent to their status as apostate Jews driven by unresolved self-doubt. Of the two, Heine’s young friend Karl Marx was the more driven, the more hateful. About one hundred million corpses later, the world is still paying for his identity issues.

正如海涅在他的时代所具有的影响力一样，他将为他在巴黎结识的一个年轻人充当暖场演员，这个人的混乱的自我意识将改变世界，而且不一定是以一种快乐的方式。历史学家保罗·约翰逊指出 ：“这两个人的共同点是他们具有非凡的仇恨能力。” 6约翰逊将这种可疑的才能追溯到他们作为被未解决的自我怀疑所驱动的叛教犹太人。在这两个人中，海涅的年轻朋友卡尔·马克思更有动力，更有仇恨。大约一亿具尸体之后，世界仍在为他的身份问题付出代价。

Like Hazel Motes, the confused protagonist of Flannery O’Connor’s 1952 novelWise Blood, Marx ended up recreating the structures of his parents’ religion but without Yahweh at the center. Motes started the Church Without Christ. Marx went further. He started the Church Without God. As this bearded messianic German envisioned the future, an elite priesthood would interpret the iron laws of his secular Torah, while his self-created society moved dynamically and inexorably toward its apocalyptic end. As Dostoevsky said by way of Sartre, “In a world without God anything is permitted.”

就像弗兰纳里·奥康纳（Flannery O'Connor）1952 年的小说《智者之血》（Wise Blood）中困惑的主人公哈泽尔·莫茨（Hazel Motes）一样，马克思最终重新创建了他父母的宗教结构，但没有雅威作为中心。莫茨创办了无基督教会。马克思走得更远。他建立了没有上帝的教会。正如这个大胡子的德国弥赛亚人所设想的未来，一个精英神职人员将解释他的世俗托拉的铁律，而他自创的社会则动态地、不可阻挡地走向世界末日。正如陀思妥耶夫斯基通过萨特所说 ：“在一个没有上帝的世界里，什么都是允许的。”

In the way of background, it was Marx’s father who converted to Lutheranism largely as a way to improve his career chances. As it happens, he, too, changed his name to Heinrich, in his case from Herschel. The last name he changed from Mordechai to Marx. Karl Heinrich Marx was born to Heinrich and Henriette in Trier, in 1818, the third of seven children. Although his father was something of a deist, Marx grew up Christian. Upon graduation from the equivalent of high school, his diploma noted that Marx’s “knowledge of Christian teachings and principles is clear and properly based. He also knows the history of Christian church to a great extent.” 7

在背景方面，马克思的父亲皈依路德教，主要是为了改善他的职业机会。碰巧的是，他也把自己的名字改成了海因里希，原名是赫歇尔。他的最后一个名字也从摩德凯改成了马克思。卡尔·海因里希·马克思于 1818 年出生于特里尔的海因里希和亨利特，是七个孩子中的第三个。虽然他的父亲是个神学家，但马克思从小就信奉基督教。从相当于高中的学校毕业时，他的毕业证书指出，马克思 “对基督教教义和原则的认识很清楚，而且有正确的依据。他还在很大程度上了解基督教会的历史。” 7

After graduating, Marx was expected to study law, his father’s profession. He proved to have as little interest in law as Heine and preferred, like his older friend, to try his hand at poetry, though without comparable success. Where he did succeed, like many college students before and since, was in discarding his fragile Christian faith. Reads one indicative verse, “I have lost heaven/ And know that for sure/ My soul, once faithful to God/ Now is destined for hell.” 8Unless God proves merciful beyond the call of duty, Marx likely foresaw his future.

毕业后，马克思被期望学习法律，即他父亲的职业。事实证明，他对法律的兴趣和海涅一样小，而且像他的老朋友一样，更愿意尝试写诗，尽管没有取得类似的成功。他成功的地方，就像之前和之后的许多大学生一样，是抛弃了他脆弱的基督教信仰。有一首诗是这样写的 ：“我已经失去了天堂 / 而且知道肯定的是 / 我的灵魂曾经忠于上帝 / 现在注定要下地狱。” 8除非上帝证明他的仁慈超出职责范围，马克思可能已经预见到他的未来。

While still in his twenties, this newly minted atheist and aspiring socialist turned his fury on the faith of his fathers. Marx did so in response to an essay written by one Bruno Bauer, a prominent leftist and unblushing anti-Semite, in which Bauer insisted that Jews abandon Judaism for the human liberation movement. Marx compressed his thoughts into two essays published in 1844 under the title “On the Jewish Question.” He did not reject Bauer so much as transcend him. According to the respectful Marx, Bauer had packaged his biases “audaciously, trenchantly, wittily, and with profundity, in a style of writing what is as precise as it is pithy and vigorous.” 9The problem with Bauer, as Marx saw it, was that he transformed the question of Jewish emancipation into a purely religious question.

当他还在二十多岁的时候，这个新晋的无神论者和有抱负的社会主义者把他的怒火转向了他父辈的信仰。马克思这样做是为了回应布鲁诺·鲍尔（Bruno Bauer）写的一篇文章，他是一个著名的左派人士，也是一个不折不扣的反犹主义者，在这篇文章中，鲍尔坚持认为犹太人应该放弃犹太教，投身人类解放运动。马克思把他的想法压缩在 1844 年发表的两篇文章中，标题是《论犹太人问题》。他并没有反驳鲍尔，而是超越了他。据尊敬的马克思说，鲍尔把他的偏见 “大胆地、尖锐地、机智地、深刻地包装起来，其写作风格既精确又简练，充满活力。” 9在马克思看来，鲍尔的问题在于他把犹太人解放的问题变成了一个纯粹的宗教问题。

Marx believed the problem to be more fundamental. “For us,” writes Marx, “the question of the Jew’s capacity for emancipation becomes the question: What particular social element has to be overcome in order to abolish Judaism?” 10To answer this question, Marx insisted on looking beyond the “Sabbath Jew,” Bauer’s target, to the “everyday Jew.” According to Marx, ego and self-interest were what motivated the nine-to-five Jew, guided as he was by the Mosaic law, a document created largely to solve practical problems. Marx had not studied the Torah as a lad, but that did not stop him from reading between its lines. He dismissed the monotheism of Judaism and described the religion instead as “the polytheism of the many needs, a polytheism which makes even the lavatory an object of divine law.” 11

马克思认为这个问题更为根本。“对我们来说”，马克思写道，“犹太人的解放能力问题变成了问题。为了废除犹太教，必须克服什么特殊的社会因素？” 10为了回答这个问题，马克思坚持把目光从鲍尔的目标 “安息日犹太人” 转向 “日常犹太人”。根据马克思的观点，自我和自我利益是激励朝九晚五的犹太人的原因，因为他受到摩西律法的指导，而摩西律法是一份主要为解决实际问题而制定的文件。马克思小时候没有学习过《圣经》，但这并不妨碍他阅读其中字里行间的含义。他否定了犹太教的一神论，而将该宗教描述为 “许多需求的多神论，这种多神论甚至使厕所成为神法的对象。” 11

“What is the worldly religion of the Jew?” he asks. “Huckstering. What is his worldly God? Money.” The way to “make the Jew impossible” would be to abolish the preconditions for huckstering. Without huckstering, Marx argues, the Jew’s “religious consciousness would be dissipated like a thin haze in the real, vital air of society.” 12

“犹太人的世俗宗教是什么？” 他问道。答 ：“胡作非为。” 又，“什么是他们世俗的上帝？” 答 ：“钱。” “使犹太人不可能” 的方法是废除胡作非为的前提条件。马克思认为，如果没有胡作非为，犹太人的 “宗教意识就会像薄薄的雾气一样在社会的真实的、有活力的空气中消散。” 12

Marx saw in Judaism an egotistic, antisocial strain that had infected society at large. Time and again, he interprets Judaism not as a theological movement but as a financial one. “The practical Jewish spirit has become the practical spirit of the Christian nations,” he claims. “The Jews have emancipated themselves insofar as the Christians have become Jews.” 13This is an argument that would not have troubled Martin Luther, still another German law school drop out. Acceptance of Jews, Marx argues, comes to the degree that Christians mimic their usurious ways: “The god of the Jews has become secularized and has become the god of the world.” 14

马克思在犹太教中看到了一种感染了整个社会的利己主义、反社会的倾向。他一次又一次地把犹太教解释为不是一个神学运动，而是一个金融运动。“实用的犹太精神已经成为基督教国家的实用精神”，他声称，“就基督徒成为犹太人而言，犹太人已经解放了自己。” 13这是一个不会困扰马丁·路德的论点，他还是另一个德国法律学校的辍学生。马克思认为，对犹太人的接受程度来自于基督徒对他们高利贷方式的模仿。14

Marx does not mention John Calvin. As a twenty-six-year-old, he may not yet have been aware of the split between Luther and Calvin on the usury question — Calvin, of course, being much more tolerant. That makes all the more impressive Marx’s citation of the world’s most aggressively Calvinist region as the one where “the practical domination of Judaism over the Christian world” 15has become most evident. That region just happened to be New England.

马克思并没有提到约翰·加尔文。作为一个 26 岁的年轻人，他可能还没有意识到路德和加尔文在高利贷问题上的分歧 —— 当然，加尔文的容忍度更高。这比较明显，既然马克思引用世界上最积极的加尔文主义地区作为 “犹太教对基督教世界的实际统治” 15的重点例子。这个地区恰好是新英格兰。

Marx saw salvation for Jews and for society at large only after society had “succeeded in abolishing the empirical essence of Judaism — huckstering and its preconditions.” 16This would be no easy task. By his lights, huckstering was shorthand for the entire capitalist enterprise, and capitalism was code for Judaism. “The social emancipation of the Jew,” he concludes wryly, “is the emancipation of society from Judaism.” 17

马克思认为，只有在社会 “成功地废除了犹太教的经验性本质 —— 胡作非为及其前提条件” 之后，犹太人和整个社会才能得到拯救。16这将不是一件容易的事。根据他的观点，叫卖是整个资本主义企业的简称，而资本主义是犹太教的代号。他诙谐地总结说 ：“犹太人的社会解放，就是社会从犹太教中解放出来。” 17

Marx had arrived in Paris only a year before he published these essays. His political philosophy was still in its larval stage. It would be another four years before he cowroteThe Communist Manifestoand another twenty before he published his masterwork,Das Kapital. But one can see the wheels turning here. He dedicated three times as many words to “On the Jewish Question” as he did to theManifesto. In the latter, he mostly just replaced the wordJew—— which does not appear at all — withbourgoisie.

马克思在发表这些文章前一年才到达巴黎。他的政治哲学仍处于萌芽阶段。又过了四年，他才撰写了《共产党宣言》，又过了二十年，他才发表了他的代表作《资本论》（Das Kapital）。但人们可以看到这里的车轮在转动。他在《论犹太人问题》中的字数是《宣言》的三倍。在后者中，他主要是用 “中产阶级” （bourgoisie）代替了 “犹太人” （Jew）。

By 1848, a revolutionary year that shook the Rothschild houses to their foundations, Marx may well have absorbed a sentiment then current in the radical community, namely, that “anti-Semitism is the socialism of fools.” 18Lenin himself would repeat this phrase often, but it was not nearly as liberal as it sounded. Savvy leftists did not suddenly reject the stereotyping of Jew as exploitive hucksters. Rather, they came to believe that such hucksterism was epidemic and had to be treated systematically.

到了 1848 年，这一年的革命使罗斯柴尔德家族的根基受到震动，马克思很可能已经吸收了当时在激进派社区流行的一种情绪，即, “反犹太主义是傻瓜的社会主义”。 18列宁本人会经常重复这句话，但它并不像它听起来那样自由。精明的左派人士并没有突然拒绝犹太人作为剥削者的定型观念。相反，他们开始相信，这样的胡作非为是一种流行病，必须系统地加以处理。

And yet Marx could never quite purge the image of the stereotypic Jewish moneylender from his rhetorical bag of tricks. His description of the capitalist inDas Kapitalreads like the stage direction for Shylock in a Third Reich production ofThe Merchant of Venice: “Fanatically bent upon the exploitation of capital, he relentlessly drives human beings to production for production’s sake.” 19Tellingly, Marx appends a footnote to the above passage, in which he refers to the “usurer” as “the perennially renewed form of capitalist.” 20Writing in the late–nineteenth-century London, whereMerchanthad become a West End staple, “usurer” had one very specific meaning, and Marx exploited it.

然而，马克思始终无法从他的修辞伎俩袋中清除刻板的犹太放债人形象。他在《资本论》中对资本家的描述就像第三帝国制作的《威尼斯商人》中对夏洛克的舞台指导 ：“他热衷于于对资本的剥削，无情地驱使人类为生产而生产。” 19引人注目的是，马克思为上述段落附加了一个脚注，其中他把 “高利贷者” 称为 “常年更新的资本家形式”。 "20在十九世纪末的伦敦写作，商人已经成为西区的主食，“高利贷” 有一个非常具体的含义，而马克思利用了它。

As Paul Johnson observes, “It is true to say that Marx’s theory of communism was the end-product of his theoretical anti-Semitism.” 21In truth, his anti-Semitism reads like a toxic mix of cultural self-hatred and warmed-over Luther. One senses here a passing of the torch. Having transcended their animus against usury, the popes had passed it on to Luther, and his followers bequeathed it to Marx. FromDas Kapitalonward, Marx’s disciples would wage the most relentless attack on the larger usurious enterprise and, when it served their purposes, the “fanatically bent” usurers themselves.

正如保罗·约翰逊所观察到的，“可以说，马克思的共产主义理论是他理论上反犹太主义的最终产物。” 21事实上，他的反犹太主义读起来像是文化自我憎恨和暖化的路德之间的有毒混合物。人们在这里感觉到了火炬的传递。在超越了对高利贷的敌意之后，教皇把它传给了路德，而他的追随者又把它留给了马克思。从《资本论》开始，马克思的弟子们将对更大的高利贷事业进行最无情的攻击，而且，当它符合他们的目的时，对 “狂热地弯曲” 的高利贷本身进行攻击。

fourteenThe Country of Religiosity 宗教之国

KARL MARX HAD LITTLE USE FOR AMERICA. FROM WHAT HE KNEW IT was “pre-eminently the country of religiosity,” 1and yet it seemed to be the one nation that had been most thoroughly corrupted by the Judaic spirit. Two strikes against America right there. The “free inhabitant” of New England, Marx writes in “On the Jewish Question,” is convinced “that he has no other destiny here below than to become richer than his neighbor.” When he travels, he worries “only of interest and profit.” The world for the New England Yankee is “no more than a Stock Exchange.” 2As to idols, he has but one, and that is, of course, mammon. One sees in Marx’s rant a precocious anti-Americanism that would deform the thinking of the international Left for the next 165 years and counting.

卡尔·马克思对美国没有什么好感。据他所知，美国是 “最主要的宗教国家”，1但它似乎是一个被犹太教精神腐蚀得最彻底的国家。对美国的两个攻击就在这里。马克思在《论犹太人问题》中写道，新英格兰的 “自由居民” 相信，“他在下面没有其他的命运，只能比他的邻居更富有。” 当他旅行时，他担心的 “只是利益和利润”。对新英格兰洋基人来说，世界 “不过是一个证券交易所”。2至于偶像，他只有一个，那当然就是玛门。人们在马克思的咆哮中看到了一种早熟的反美主义，这种反美主义将在接下来的 165 年里使国际左派的思维发生畸变。

What Marx almost assuredly did not know is that two hundred years earlier, the very first New Englanders had taken a serious stab at the social scheme he was in the process of formulating. Plymouth Plantation governor William Bradford describes here the outcome of the colony’s ambitious “from each according to his ability, to each according to his needs” experiment:

马克思几乎肯定不知道的是，两百年前，第一批新英格兰人已经认真尝试了他正在制定的社会计划。普利茅斯种植园总督威廉·布拉德福德在这里描述了该殖民地雄心勃勃的 “各尽所能，各取所需” 的实验结果：

The experience that was had in this common course and condition, tried sundry years and that amongst godly and sober men, may well evince the vanity of that conceit of Plato’s and other ancients applauded by some of later times; that the taking away of property and bringing in community into a commonwealth would make them happy and flourishing; as if they were wiser than God. For this community (so far as it was) was found to breed much confusion and discontent and retard much employment that would have been to their benefit and comfort. For the young men, that were most able and fit for labour and service, did repine that they should spend their time and strength to work for other men’s wives and children without any recompense. The strong, or man of parts, had no more in division of victuals and clothes than he that was weak and not able to do a quarter the other could; this was thought injustice. The aged and graver men to be ranked and equalized in labours and victuals, clothes, etc., with the meaner and younger sort, thought it some indignity and disrespect unto them. And for men’s wives to be commanded to do service for other men, as dressing their meat, washing their clothes, etc., they deemed it a kind of slavery, neither could many husbands well brook it.
