Upon the point all being to have alike, and all to do alike, they thought themselves in the like condition, and one as good as another; and so, if it did not cut off those relations that God hath set amongst men, yet it did at least much diminish and take off the mutual respects that should be preserved amongst them. And would have been worse if they had been men of another condition. Let none object this is men’s corruption, and nothing to the course itself. I answer, seeing all men have this corruption in them, God in His wisdom saw another course fitter for them.3

在这种共同的进程和条件下，在虔诚和清醒的人中试行了多年的经验，可以很好地说明柏拉图和其他古人的那种被后来的一些人所称赞的自负的虚妄；即剥夺财产并将社区纳入一个共同的国家会使他们幸福和繁荣；仿佛他们比上帝更聪明。因为这种共同体（就其本身而言）被发现滋生了许多混乱和不满，并延缓了许多对他们有利和舒适的就业。因为那些最能干、最适合劳动和服务的年轻人，对他们花时间和力量为别人的妻子和孩子工作而没有任何回报感到不满。强壮的人，或有能力的人，在食物和衣服的分配上并不比那些弱小的，不能做四分之一的人多；这被认为是不公正的。年老的人在劳动和食物、衣服等方面与较小的人平起平坐，被认为是对他们的一种侮辱和不敬。对于男人的妻子被命令为其他男人做服务，如为他们为肉刷上调料，洗衣服等，他们认为这是一种奴役，许多丈夫也不能容忍。在所有人都一样拥有，都一样做的问题上，他们认为自己的情况也一样，一个人和另一个人一样好；因此，如果它没有切断上帝在人与人之间设定的那些关系，但它至少会大大减少和取消他们之间应该保持的相互尊重。如果他们是另一种情况的人，情况就会更糟。没有人反对这是人的堕落，而与进程本身无关。我回答说，看到所有的人都有这种堕落，上帝以他的智慧看到了另一条更适合他们的道路。3

Freed from the theoretical, Americans set about creating a distinctive and largely spontaneous commercial culture. Self-interest would drive it and self-control would restrain it. The Judeo-Christian legacy would inform that self-control and inspire it, but always imperfectly, given the fallen nature of man. The relative absence of external control would allow this dynamic to work itself out and, in the process, forge the most productive industrial enterprise in world history, but the balance between forces would always be a delicate one.

从理论中解放出来后，美国人开始创造一种独特的、基本自发的商业文化。自我利益将推动它，自我控制将约束它。犹太教·基督教的遗产将告知这种自我控制，并激励它，但鉴于人的堕落本性，总是不完美的。由于相对缺乏外部控制，这种动力可以自行发挥作用，并在此过程中形成世界历史上最富有成效的工业企业，但各种力量之间的平衡始终是一个微妙的问题。

fifteenTime Is Money 时间就是金钱

IN HIS WORTHY BOOKFINANCING THE AMERICAN DREAM, LENDOL CALDER nicely debunks the “myth of lost economic virtue.” 1Calder argues persuasively that each generation believes that its own is uniquely corrupt and looks to the generation before it as a debt-free Eden. Not so. “From Plymouth Rock to the present,” writes Calder, “American dreams have usually required a lien on the future.” 2Even the Pilgrims lamented that debt was a “heavy burthen” 3upon them.

在他值得一读的书《资助美国梦》（FINANCING THE AMERICAN DREAM）中，伦多尔·卡尔德（LENDOL CALDER）很好地揭穿了 “失去经济美德的神话”。 1卡尔德有说服力地认为，每一代人都认为自己的一代是独一无二的腐败，并把上一代人视为无债一身轻。事实并非如此。“从普利茅斯岩石到现在”，卡尔德写道，“美国梦通常需要对未来进行留置。” 2甚至朝圣者也感叹债务是他们身上 “沉重的负担” 3

What has changed is the way that Americans have financed that future. In the beginning of the American experiment there was very little of what we would think of as money. The early settlers rarely saw gold or silver and did not even know what paper money was. Much commerce relied on barter, the exchange of one good for another.

改变的是美国人为这个未来融资的方式。在美国实验之初，很少有我们所认为的货币。早期的定居者很少看到黄金或白银，甚至不知道纸币是什么。许多商业活动依靠的是易货贸易，即以一种物品换取另一种物品。

A strictly barter economy is limited by what economists call “a double coincidence of wants.” 4A colonist who wanted to buy corn but had only an old draft horse to trade would have to find someone with a surplus of corn who needed an old draft horse. The emergence of a commodity that almost everyone saw as valuable had the power to liberate commerce. In the northern colonies, beaver fur and seashells served as media of exchange with the Indians, as did fish and corn, but none had full acceptance as “commodity money.” In the southern colonies, tobacco came close to filling that role. Tobacco, however, was an imperfect medium. If it had the advantage of being divisible, portable, and intrinsically useful, it had the disadvantage of being bulky, seasonal, and susceptible to the elements.5

严格意义上的易货贸易经济受到经济学家所说的 “需求的双重巧合” 的限制。4一个想买玉米但只有一匹老草马可以交易的殖民者，必须找到一个有多余玉米且需要老草马的人。一种几乎所有人都认为有价值的商品的出现，具有解放商业的力量。在北方殖民地，海狸皮和贝壳是与印第安人交换的媒介，鱼和玉米也是如此，但都没有被完全接受为 “商品货币”。在南方殖民地，烟草接近于填补这一角色。然而，烟草是一种不完美的媒介。如果说它有可分割、可携带和内在有用的优点，那么它的缺点是笨重、季节性强和容易受外界影响。5

As the economy grew, it became evident that even the most capacious fanny pack could not hold a tobacco bale. The two commodities that had passed all tests over the centuries were silver and gold, and in time gold and silver coins from foreign countries began to make their way into circulation in America. The most popular of these was the Spanish silver dollar. The worddollarderived fromthaler(pronouncedTAHL-er), the name given to coins first mined nearby and minted in Joachimsthal in Bohemia and originally known as Joachimsthalers. The milled Spanish dollars were easily cut into “bits,” or pieces of eight. Thustwo bitsbecame standard lingo for a quarter of a dollar. In that gold and silver were internationally recognized commodities, foreign coins served perfectly well as a medium of exchange. In fact, it was not until 1857 that Congress outlawed the commercial use of foreign coins.6

随着经济的发展，很明显，即使是最宽敞的腰包也装不下一包烟草。几个世纪以来，通过所有考验的两种商品是白银和黄金，随着时间的推移，来自外国的金币和银币开始进入美国的流通领域。其中最受欢迎的是西班牙银元 —— 这个词 dollar 来源于 thaler（读作 TAHL-er），这是最早在波西米亚的琼海附近开采和铸造的硬币的名字，最初被称为琼海银元。碾磨过的西班牙元很容易被切割成 “比特”，或八块。因此 “两比特” （two bits）成为四分之一美元的标准行话。由于黄金和白银是国际公认的商品，外国硬币完全可以作为一种交换媒介。6

The Western world had not seen government-issued paper money until colonial Massachusetts decided to improvise with it in 1690. After a military expedition to Quebec failed to pay for itself with the anticipated plunder, a government anxious to placate the disgruntled soldiers printed seven thousand pounds in paper notes. Future tax revenues would presumably allow the soldiers to redeem the notes within a few years in gold or silver. To bolster confidence in the notes, the government also promised to print no more paper money.7Not surprisingly, at least in retrospect, the government failed to redeem the soldiers’ notes and printed considerably more notes the following year. One sees the beginning of a national habit here.

西方世界还没有见过政府发行的纸币，直到 1690 年殖民地马萨诸塞州才决定用它来凑数。在一次对魁北克的军事远征未能用预期的掠夺物支付自己的费用后，一个急于安抚不满的士兵的政府印制了七千英镑的纸币。未来的税收收入大概可以让士兵们在几年内用黄金或白银赎回这些纸币。为了加强对纸币的信心，政府还承诺不再印刷纸币。7毫不奇怪，至少从现在来看，政府没能赎回士兵的纸币，并在第二年印了更多的纸币。人们在这里看到了一个国家习惯的开始。

British financier Sir Thomas Gresham could have foretold what happened next. In 1558, he sent a letter to young Queen Elizabeth as she was taking the throne, cautioning her that “good and bad coin cannot circulate together.” 8Under her father, Henry VIII, and her half brother, Edward VI, England had allowed its coinage to be debased by minting coins whose gold and silver content had been reduced but whose face value remained the same. Citizens knew enough to trade with the debased coins and hoard the good ones, those whose face value reflected their real value in gold or silver. From this letter came Gresham’s Law: “Bad money drives out good.”

英国金融家托马斯·格雷沙姆爵士可以预见到接下来发生的事情。1558 年，他在年轻的伊丽莎白女王登基时给她写了一封信，告诫她 “好币和坏币不能一起流通。” 8在她的父亲亨利八世和她同父异母的兄弟爱德华六世手下，英国允许其硬币贬值，铸造了一些金银含量减少但面值不变的硬币。公民们知道用贬值的硬币进行交易，并囤积好的硬币，即那些面值反映其真正价值的金银币。从这封信中可以看出格雷欣法则。“劣币驱逐良币”。

Although Gresham was granted naming rights three centuries after his famed letter, the concept is much older still. Consider the following from Aristophanes’sThe Frogs, written nearly two millennia before Gresham was born:

尽管格雷沙姆在他那封著名的信的三个世纪后被授予了命名权，但这个概念仍然要古老得多。请看阿里斯托芬的《青蛙》中的一段话，这段话写于格雷沙姆出生前近两千年。

The course our city runs is the same towards men and money.
She has true and worthy sons.
She has fine new gold and ancient silver,
Coins untouched with alloys, gold or silver,
Each well minted, tested each and ringing clear.
Yet we never use them!
Others pass from hand to hand,
Sorry brass just struck last week and branded with a wretched brand.
So with men we know for upright, blameless lives and noble names.
These we spurn for men of brass . . .

我们的城市对人和钱的态度是一样的。
她有真正的和值得的儿子。
她有精美的新金和古银，
没有经过合金、金或银的硬币，
每个都是精心铸造的，每个都经过测试，清脆响亮。
然而，我们从未使用过它们！
其他的从手中传到手中，
对不起，黄铜上周刚打过，烙上了一个可恶的品牌。
这样的人我们知道是正直的，无罪的生活和高贵的名字。
这些我们唾弃的人是黄铜……

Economists would eventually settle on the termfiat moneyto describe currency issues like that of Massachusetts. The term refers to money issued by government fiat — Latinfiat, “let it be done” —— that is, either not fully backed by a specific commodity or not backed at all. All fiat money is “bad money” according to Gresham’s Law. For the next several centuries, the progressive champions of fiat money would do battle with the stubborn dissidents who held out for commodity money, typically silver, gold, or both. As the dissidents came to learn, resisting the people who own the printing presses is likely to be a losing battle, especially when what they are printing is money.

经济学家最终会用 “法币” （或 “法定货币”，fiat money）一词来描述像马萨诸塞州的货币问题。这个术语指的是由政府法定货币发行的货币 —— 拉丁语 fiat，“让它去做” —— 也就是说，要么没有特定商品的完全支持，要么根本没有支持。根据格雷欣法则，所有法定货币都是 “坏钱”。在接下来的几个世纪里，法定货币的进步倡导者将与顽固的持不同意见者进行斗争，他们坚持商品货币，通常是白银、黄金，或两者。正如持不同政见者所了解的那样，抵制拥有印刷机的人很可能是一场失败的战斗，特别是当他们所印刷的是货币时。

In America going forward, credit and the attitude toward it would evolve on two distinct fronts, micro and macro, personal and institutional. The inherited Christian distaste for usury would forever color our attitudes about credit, debt, and related issues, both small and large. At the same time, the promise of the American dream and good old-fashioned prodigality would continue to undermine both personal and national resolve up to the present. This historic duality can be traced through the lives of two of America’s most distinctive founding fathers, Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson.

在美国的未来，信贷和对它的态度将在两个不同的方面发展，微观和宏观，个人和机构。继承下来的基督教对高利贷的厌恶将永远影响我们对信贷、债务和相关问题的态度，无论大小。同时，美国梦的承诺和老式的挥霍行为将继续破坏个人和国家的决心，直到现在。这种历史性的双重性可以通过美国最独特的两位开国元勋本杰明·富兰克林和托马斯·杰斐逊的生活来追溯。

Born in Boston in 1706 and educated in Calvinist-oriented Presbyterianism, Benjamin Franklin ran away to Philadelphia as a seventeen-year-old and there emerged as the apotheosis of the commercial American citizen. Even though his easy living in Paris would unnerve the literally Puritanical John Adams, Franklin was no prodigal. He deserved his rewards after seventy years of playing by the rules — rules that he did more to codify than anyone since Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John.

本杰明·富兰克林 1706 年出生于波士顿，在以加尔文主义为导向的长老会中接受教育，17 岁时跑到费城，在那里成为美国商业公民的神化。尽管他在巴黎的轻松生活会让清教徒约翰·亚当斯感到不安，但富兰克林并不是败家子。经过 70 年的循规蹈矩，他应得的回报 —— 他比马太、马克、卢克和约翰之后的任何人都更多地编纂了这些规则。

Franklin called his primary medium of instructionPoor Richard’s Almanack, after the book’s fictional author, Richard Saunders. Franklin began publishing the almanac in 1732 when he was just twenty-six years old and continued for the next quarter century, selling as many as ten thousand copies a year. Each edition contained the basics that one would expect in any almanac — a calendar, weather data, astrological and astronomical information, even demographics — but what distinguished it were Franklin’s insights into the life well lived, many of which dealt with debt and credit.

富兰克林称他的主要教学媒介为《穷理查年鉴》（Poor Richard's Almanack），以该书的虚构作者理查德·绍徳斯（Richard Saunders）命名。富兰克林于 1732 年开始出版年鉴，当时他只有 26 岁，并在接下来的四分之一个世纪里持续出版，每年的销量高达一万本。每一版年鉴都包含人们期望的基本内容 —— 日历、天气数据、星象和天文信息，甚至人口统计学 —— 但它的与众不同之处在于富兰克林对美好生活的见解，其中许多内容涉及债务和信贷。

It was Franklin who introduced into our common language the wonderfully succinct equation “Time is money.” 9This concept has at least as much power now as it did then.

正是富兰克林将 “时间就是金钱” 这一奇妙而简洁的公式引入了我们的共同语言。9这一概念现在至少和当时一样有力量。

As a case in point, in the 2005 Academy Award–winning filmCrash, director Paul Haggis gives the film’s critical punch line to young thug Anthony, played by rapper Ludacris. After a van full of Thai stowaways have fallen into his lap, Anthony chooses to not sell them into servitude. Instead, in his moment of personal redemption, he sets them free in Chinatown. “Come on now!” he yells as he hustles them out of the van. “This is America. Time is money. Chop, chop!” Only after the 2005 “immigrant” riots in France did at least some European intellectuals begin to appreciate the cohesive power of this understanding, the core virtue of what their peers deride as America’s money culture.

作为一个例子，在 2005 年奥斯卡奖获奖影片《崩溃》（Crash）中，导演保罗·哈吉斯将影片的关键一环交给了说唱歌手卢达克里斯（Ludacris）扮演的年轻暴徒安东尼。在一辆满载泰国偷渡者的货车落入他的手中后，安东尼选择不把他们卖给别人做奴隶。相反，在他的个人救赎时刻，他在唐人街释放了他们。“现在出来吧！” 他一边喊着，一边把他们从车里拉出来。“这里是美国。时间就是金钱。快，快！” 只有在 2005 年法国的 “移民” 骚乱之后，至少有一些欧洲知识分子开始欣赏这种理解的凝聚力，即，他们的同行嘲笑美国的金钱文化的核心美德。

Franklin’s understanding of this equation was double-edged. “Waste neither time nor money,” he urges, “but make the best use of both.” 10The notion of wasting time is obvious enough. Franklin considered such waste “the greatest prodigality.” He observes that a worker who can earn ten shillings a day throws away five shillings if he sits idly half the day.

富兰克林对这个等式的理解是双刃剑。他敦促说 ：“既不要浪费时间，也不要浪费金钱，而是要最好地利用两者。” 10浪费时间的概念已经很明显。富兰克林认为这种浪费是 “最大的挥霍”。他观察到，一个每天能挣 10 先令的工人如果闲坐半天就会扔掉 5 先令。

In that same essay, “Advice to a Young Tradesman,” he makes the more intriguing point that “credit is money.” He explains that a lender whose money sits idly loses the time value of that money. Without mentioning Aristotle by name, he undermined the Aristotelian theory that money is barren years before Jeremy Bentham would. “Remember that money is of the prolific, generating nature,” Franklin writes. “Money can beget money, and its offspring can beget more, and so on.” 11

在同一篇文章《给年轻商人的建议》中，他提出了一个更耐人寻味的观点 ：“信用就是金钱”。他解释说，一个贷款人的钱如果闲置在那里，就会失去这些钱的时间价值。在没有提到亚里士多德的名字的情况下，他在杰里米·本瑟姆之前多年就破坏了亚里士多德的理论，即 “货币是贫瘠的”。请记住，“金钱具有多产、生成的性质”，富兰克林写道。“钱可以生钱，它的后代可以生出更多的钱，以此类推。” 11

It is likely that Franklin knew his Shakespeare better than he knew Aristotle. If so, he would have certainly been aware of Polonius’s well-worn advice to “neither a borrower nor a lender be,” but that doesn’t mean he abided by it. InPoor Richard, as seen, he endorses the lending of money, and his feelings about borrowing are mixed to the point of incoherence.

富兰克林对莎士比亚的了解很可能比对亚里士多德的了解还要深。如果是这样，他肯定知道波洛涅斯那句老生常谈的忠告 ：“既不做借贷者，也不做放贷者”，但这并不意味着他遵守了它。在《穷理查年鉴》中，正如我们所看到的，他赞同借钱，而他对借钱的感觉是混合的，甚至是不连贯的。

Time and again, Franklin warns the reader of the perils of borrowing money: “He that goes a-borrowing goes a-sorrowing” ; “Rather go to bed supperless than rise in debt” ; and even more emphatically, “The second vice is lying, the first is running into debt.” 12And yet, improbably enough, Franklin also instructs the reader in the value of borrowing money. “The use is all the advantage there is in having money,” he wrote in 1736. “For six pounds a year you may have the use of one hundred pounds, provided you are a man of known prudence and honesty.” 13

富兰克林一次又一次地警告读者借钱的危险。“借钱的人就会借钱” ； “宁可不吃晚饭睡觉，也不要欠债起床” ；甚至他更为强调的是，“第二个恶习是撒谎，第一个恶习是欠债”。12然而，不可思议的是，富兰克林也向读者说明了借钱的价值。他在 1736 年写道 ：“使用是拥有金钱的所有好处”，他说。他在 1736 年写道 ：“只要你是一个已知的谨慎和诚实的人，每年花 6 英镑就可以使用 100 英镑。” 13

Franklin goes so far as to develop an ethic around the borrowing of money. “Never keep borrowed money an hour beyond the time you promised,” he insists, timeless advice for all users of credit cards. Always the pragmatist, he worries that a late payment will “shut up your friend’s purse for ever.” 14He frets too that the very appearance of idleness or self-indulgence will make lenders wary and the borrower less credit worthy. Although not a churchgoer, he retained an active belief in a Christian God, one who would reward or punish him based on how he lived that life. And yet Franklin seems more concerned about what his fellow citizens will think about him than what God does, God being less likely to lend money at 6 percent per annum.

富兰克林甚至围绕借钱形成了一种道德规范。他坚持认为，“永远不要把借来的钱保留在你承诺的时间之外” （不要逾期，按时还钱），这是对所有信用卡用户的永恒建议。他始终是个实用主义者，他担心逾期付款会 “永远关闭你朋友的钱包”。14他还担心，懒惰或自我放纵的表象会使贷款人警惕，借款人的信用度降低。虽然不是教徒，但他保留了对基督教上帝的积极信仰，这位上帝会根据他的生活方式来奖励或惩罚他。然而，富兰克林似乎更关心他的同胞会怎么看他，而不是上帝怎么看他，上帝不太可能以 6% 的年利率放贷。

During the years Franklin was publishingPoor Richard, entrepreneurs were experimenting with deposit banking in the colonies. There had, in fact, been no banks of deposit in England until mid-seventeenth century. Prior to that, merchants tended to deposit their surplus gold in the king’s mint. In 1638, Charles I broke them of that habit when he “borrowed” 200,000 pounds of the merchants’ gold to finance an impending civil war.15The merchants eventually got their money back, but they had lost their confidence. They began instead to store their gold with private goldsmiths and would use the receipts as a convenient means of exchange. By the end of the civil war, some goldsmiths were issuing receipts for gold they did not have in store. Critics of what is called “fractional reserve banking” consider this the model for what was to come. Today, essentially all banks practice fractional reserve banking. In other words, they owe more money to their depositors than they have in reserve in their vaults. This sometimes causes problems.

在富兰克林出版《穷理查年鉴》的那几年，企业家们正在殖民地进行存款银行的试验。事实上，直到十七世纪中期，英国还没有存款银行。在此之前，商人们倾向于将他们的剩余黄金存入国王的铸币厂。1638 年，查理一世打破了他们的这一习惯，他 “借” 走了商人的 20 万英镑黄金，为即将到来的内战提供资金。15商人们虽然最终拿回了他们的钱，但他们已经失去信心。他们开始转而将黄金存放在私人金匠那里，并将收据作为一种方便的交换手段。到内战结束时，一些金匠开始为他们没有储存的黄金开具收据。被称为 “部分储备银行” 的批评者认为这就是未来的模式。今天，基本上所有的银行都实行部分准备金制度。换句话说，他们欠储户的钱多于他们在金库中的储备。这有时会导致问题。

The most prominent of the few private banks in the colonies was the Massachusetts Land Bank. Founded in 1740, it issued bank notes with land as the commodity in reserve. Given the illiquidity of land, people did not put a great deal of confidence in their ability to redeem the notes. This anxiety led to the creation of a rival silver bank whose notes were, allegedly at least, redeemable in silver.16The proliferation of these notes worried creditors who inevitably lost out in inflationary times. At the behest of Boston’s merchants and governor, Parliament quickly stepped in and shut both banks down.

殖民地为数不多的私人银行中最突出的是马萨诸塞州土地银行。该银行成立于 1740 年，发行以土地为储备商品的纸币。鉴于土地的流动性不强，人们对赎回票据的能力没有很大的信心。这种焦虑导致了一个敌对的银业银行的成立，据称该银行的票据至少可以用白银赎回。16这些纸币的泛滥让债权人担心，他们在通货膨胀时期不可避免地受到损失。在波士顿商人和州长的要求下，议会迅速介入并关闭了两家银行。

For a moment at least, these banks satisfied the public clamoring to have more money in circulation, a clamoring that never quite goes away. A hard-money advocate, Franklin suggested a half-serious solution to the problem. “If you will not be angry with me for giving it,” he advises his readers, “I promise you not to be offended if you do not take it.” 17Franklin observes that his fellow citizens spend roughly 200,000 pounds a year on imported goods, money that is thus lost to local circulation. If half of that is spent on necessities, another half, Franklin argues, goes to “superfluities.” He then offers a series of tips on how his readers might avoid those superfluous imports, most no more serious than “when you incline to drink rum, fill the glass half with water.” This strategy would put an additional 100,000 pounds in circulation much more honestly than by printing money. “Then,” he adds in all seriousness, “the merchants’ old and doubtful debts may be honestly paid off, and trading becomes surer thereafter, if not so extensive.” 18

至少在一段时间内，这些银行满足了公众对更多货币流通的喧嚣，这种喧嚣从未完全消失过。作为硬通货的倡导者，富兰克林对这个问题提出了一个半认真的解决方案。他建议他的读者说 ：“如果你们不因为我给了你们钱而生气的话，我保证如果你们不接受的话，我也不会生气。” 17富兰克林观察到，他的公民们每年大约花 20 万英镑购买进口商品，这些钱因此在本地流通中流失。富兰克林认为，如果其中一半花在必需品上，另一半则用于 “多余的东西”。然后他提供了一系列提示，告诉他的读者如何避免这些多余的进口商品，其中最严重的莫过于 “当你想喝朗姆酒时，把杯子里的一半装满水”。这一策略将使额外的 10 万英镑进入流通领域，比印钞票要诚实得多。“然后”，他严肃地补充说，“商人们的旧债和可疑的债务可能会被诚实地还清，此后的贸易会变得更有保障，即使不是那么广泛。” 18

The Revolutionary War, like all wars, tested everyone’s resolve to stick to hard money. To finance it, the Continental Congress issued fiat money with only the faintest resolve to redeem it in specie within seven years. As the war progressed, the Congress proceeded to print more and more “Continentals,” which became more and more worthless as each year went by. By the sixth year of war, Continentals were trading at 168 paper dollars to one dollar of specie, which gave rise to the expression “not worth a Continental.” 19

革命战争，像所有的战争一样，考验着每个人坚持硬通货的决心。为了筹措资金，大陆会议发行了法定货币，只下了一个最微弱的决心，即在七年内以实物赎回。随着战争的进行，国会开始印制越来越多的 “大陆币”，随着时间的推移，这些钱变得越来越不值钱。到了战争的第六年，大陆币的交易价格是 168 个纸币兑换 1 美元实物，这就产生了 “不值一个大陆” 的说法。19

Stung by the experience, and fiscally conservative by nature, the founding fathers moved back to a hard-money standard in drafting the Constitution. Article I, section 8 gives Congress the power “to coin money, regulate the value thereof, and of foreign coin.” Article I, section 10, meanwhile, forbids the states from coining money or making anything but gold and silver coin “a Tender in Payment of Debts.” Importantly, however, Article I, section 8 also grants Congress the power “to borrow money on the credit of the United States.”

受到经验的刺激，以及本质上的财政保守，开国元勋们在起草宪法时重新采用了硬通货标准。第一条第 8 款赋予国会 “铸造货币、调节货币价值和外国货币” 的权力。同时，第一条第 10 款禁止各州铸造货币或将金银币以外的任何东西作为 “偿债的货币”。然而，重要的是，第一条第 8 款还授予国会 “以美国的信用借款” 的权力。

In line with its constitutional powers, Congress passed the Coinage Act of 1792, which established a bimetallic standard for the United States. The two metals were silver and gold, with a fixed ratio of fifteen grains of silver to one of gold. This ratio reflected the market reality of 1792.20As happens with a bimetallic standard, though, market values change. And as the real value of gold gradually increased against silver, people began to stash their gold or melt it down, proving the truth of Gresham’s Law once again. By 1810, silver coins, foreign and domestic, were just about the only legal tender in circulation.

根据宪法规定的权力，国会通过了《1792 年硬币法案》，为美国建立了双金属标准。这两种金属是白银和黄金，其固定比例为 15 粒白银对 1 粒黄金。这个比例反映了 1792 年的市场现实。20不过，正如双金属标准所发生的那样，市场价值会发生变化。随着黄金对白银的实际价值逐渐增加，人们开始将他们的黄金藏起来或融化，再次证明了格雷欣法则的真理。到 1810 年，外国和国内的银币几乎是流通中唯一的法定货币。

A precocious holder of high public office, Thomas Jefferson anxiously watched the new republic find its financial footing. In 1776, when he had submitted the Declaration of Independence for Franklin’s review, he was less than half the Philadelphian’s age. Still, the difference in age had less of an effect on their respective characters than the difference in the environments that nurtured them. In the land-rich, cash-poor, morally ambiguous clime of antebellum Virginia, debt was something of a given for country gentlemen. And the older Jefferson got, the deeper he sank into it.

作为一个早熟的高级公职人员，托马斯·杰斐逊焦急地看着新的共和国找到它的财政基础。1776 年，当他提交《独立宣言》供富兰克林审阅时，他的年龄还不到这位费城人的一半。然而，年龄的差异对他们各自的性格的影响不如培养他们的环境的差异。在土地丰富、现金匮乏、道德模糊的前弗吉尼亚州，债务对乡村绅士来说是一种必然。而杰斐逊年纪越大，就越深陷其中。

Yet, curiously, the more mired he became in personal debt, the more philosophically opposed Jefferson grew to national debt. As a young man, he kept an open mind on the subject. “The existence of a nation having no credit is always precarious,” 21he wrote to James Madison in 1788, the year before the nation officially kicked into gear. “Were we without credit,” he confided to George Washington that same year, “we might be crushed by a nation of much inferior resources, but possessing higher credit.” To the Commissioners of the Treasury, again in 1788, he made a more compelling case: “I feel strongly the necessity of preserving the power to borrow.” 22

然而，奇怪的是，他越是深陷个人债务，杰斐逊在哲学上就越是反对国家债务。作为一个年轻人，他对这个问题保持着开放的态度。“一个没有信用的国家的存在总是不稳定的”，21他在 1788 年写给詹姆斯·麦迪逊的信中如此说道，就在国家正式启动的那一年。“如果我们没有信用”，同年他向乔治·华盛顿倾诉，“我们可能会被一个资源差得多、但拥有更高的信用的国家击垮。” 1788 年，他再次向财政部专员提出了一个更有说服力的理由。“我强烈地感到有必要保留借款的权力。” 22

In each of these communications, Jefferson tried to overcome his peers’ resistance to the borrowing of money. Still, he expressed reservations about using the nation’s credit, save for “absolute necessity,” and his experience in federal government would only fortify those reservations. In George Washington’s first term, Jefferson, as secretary of state, went head to head with Alexander Hamilton and his Federalist allies over the size and shape of government. In the process, he grew increasingly more wary of the aggrandizing and centralizing tendency of federal government. He saw money as the fuel for Federalist ambitions and pulled in the reins, or at least tried to.

在这些通信中，杰斐逊试图克服他的同行们对借钱的抵制。不过，他还是对使用国家的信贷表示保留，除非是 “绝对必要”，而他在联邦政府的经验只会强化这些保留。在乔治·华盛顿的第一个任期内，杰斐逊作为国务卿，与亚历山大·汉密尔顿和他的联邦主义盟友就政府的规模和形式进行了交锋。在这个过程中，他对联邦政府的膨胀和集权倾向越来越警惕。他认为金钱是联邦主义野心的燃料，并拉住了（金钱的）缰绳，或至少试图这样做。

In 1798, while serving as vice president under John Adams, he argued that the surest way to reduce the scope of national government would be to pass a constitutional amendment “taking from the Federal Government the power of borrowing.” 23If he’d had his way, he would also have denied the government the power of printing money or any other ungrounded legal tender. This would make waging war difficult, but he was beginning to wonder whether the power to borrow money or print it might actually lead to war. In a letter written fifteen years later, he made exactly that claim, arguing that the perpetuation of debt “has drenched the earth with blood.” On the other hand, a government that honored the natural right to be free of debts offered “a salutary curb on the spirit of war.” 24

1798 年，在约翰·亚当斯手下担任副总统时，他认为缩小国家政府范围的最可靠方式是通过一项宪法修正案，“从联邦政府手中夺取借贷权。” 23如果他能如愿，他也会剥夺政府印钞或任何其他没有根据的法定货币的权力。这将使发动战争变得困难，但他开始怀疑借钱或印钱的权力是否真的会导致战争。在 15 年后写的一封信中，他正是这样说的，他认为债务的持续存在 “已经让地球沾满了鲜血”。另一方面，一个尊重免于债务的自然权利的政府提供了 “对战争精神的有益抑制。” 24

While president, however, Jefferson made one grand gesture that not only exceeded his constitutional powers but also entailed a good deal of borrowing. Over considerable domestic opposition, he bought the Louisiana Territory at the equivalent of an international foreclosure sale. France needed the money to finance its interminable wars against Great Britain, and Jefferson wanted the property as buffer against the encroachments of the European powers.

然而，在担任总统期间，杰斐逊做出了一个伟大的举动，不仅超越了他的宪法权力，而且还涉及到大量的借贷。他不顾国内相当多的反对，以相当于国际拍卖会的方式购买了路易斯安那地区。法国需要这笔钱来资助其对英国无休止的战争，而杰斐逊则希望将这块土地作为抵御欧洲列强侵占的缓冲区。

Technically, the United States bought Louisiana not from France but from the underwriters of the deal’s eight million dollars in bonds, Hope and Company of Amsterdam and Barings and Company in London. Barings, the world’s most prominent merchant bankers at the time, did the deal despite the fact that the proceeds would allow Napoleon to continue his war against the country Barings called home. To close the deal, the United States cancelled nearly four million dollars in French debt and paid three million down in gold. In all fairness to Jefferson, a fertile, mineral-rich chunk of real estate three times larger than France made for some fairly substantial collateral.

从技术上讲，美国不是从法国，而是从这笔交易的八百万美元债券的承销商 —— 阿姆斯特丹的霍普公司和伦敦的霸菱公司那里购买了路易斯安那。霸菱公司是当时世界上最著名的商业银行，尽管这笔交易的收益会让拿破仑继续对霸菱公司所在的国家发动战争，但他们还是做了这笔交易。为了完成这笔交易，美国取消了近四百万美元的法国债务，并支付了三百万美元的黄金。对杰斐逊来说，公平地说，一块比法国大三倍的肥沃的、富含矿物质的房地产是一些相当可观的抵押品。

Five years after the purchase, Jefferson returned to his beloved country home, Monticello. Upon settling in, he could see that frost was playing havoc with his tobacco crop. He promptly informed his business agent that he would not be able to make his regular payments on the eight thousand dollars he had borrowed from a widow named Mrs. Tabb.25Then, all too typically, Jefferson threw his energies not into cash crops but into his gardens. The widow woman would have to wait.

购买五年后，杰斐逊回到了他心爱的乡村住宅 —— 蒙特塞洛。安顿下来后，他看到霜冻正在对他的烟草作物造成破坏。他立即通知他的商业代理人，他将无法定期支付他从一个名叫塔布夫人的寡妇那里借来的八千美元。25然后，非常典型地，杰斐逊没有把精力放在经济作物而是放在花园里。那个债主，也就是那个寡妇将不得不持续等待。

Jefferson would spend most of the remaining seventeen years of his life at Monticello or thereabouts, until he died so providentially on the fiftieth anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence — July 4, 1826, the same day on which the Declaration’s coauthor John Adams also died. For all his good work on the national scene, at home Jefferson was a chronic deadbeat. He stumbled from debt to debt, from financial crisis to financial crisis. Indeed, in the dictionary of American clichés, his picture should be the illustration next to the phrase “misplaced priorities.” Despite a recurrent inability to meet his overhead, he continued to spend his money on books, wine, horses, and especially that colossal money pit of a house.

杰斐逊将在他生命中剩下的 17 年中的大部分时间都是在蒙特塞洛或那里度过的，直到他在《独立宣言》签署 50 周年时去世 —— 1826 年 7 月 4 日，同一天《独立宣言》的共同作者约翰·亚当斯也去世。尽管他在国家舞台上做了很多好事，但在家里，杰斐逊是一个慢性病患者。他从一个债务到另一个债务，从财政危机到财政危机，步履蹒跚。事实上，在美国陈词滥调的字典里，他的照片应该是 “错置的优先权” 这句话旁边的插图。尽管经常无法满足他的开销，但他继续把钱花在书、酒、马，特别是那个巨大的钱坑的房子上。

To make ends meet, in 1817 Jefferson went to his good buddy at the Bank of the United States, its president Wilson Nicholas, and asked to borrow $6,000. Nicholas happily agreed to cosign for the loan, and the bank approved it. Six months later, in April 1818, Nicholas asked Jefferson to cosign on a $20,000 loan to Nicholas himself, at 12 percent annual interest, and Jefferson obliged.26Bad move. Nicholas defaulted and Jefferson was stuck with the debt. To get out from under, Jefferson took out another loan and persuaded his grandson and protégé, Jeff Randolph, to cosign. As collateral, Jefferson put up nearly 1,000 acres that would have passed to Randolph and, in so doing, stuck his descendants with the consequences of his own prodigality.

为了维持生计，1817 年，杰斐逊去找他在美国银行的好朋友，银行总裁威尔逊·尼古拉斯，要求借 6000 美元。尼古拉斯愉快地同意为这笔贷款作担保，银行也批准了这笔贷款。六个月后，1818 年 4 月，尼古拉斯要求杰斐逊联署向尼古拉斯本人贷款 2 万美元，年息 12%，杰斐逊答应了。26糟糕的行动。尼古拉斯违约了，杰斐逊被债务缠身。为了摆脱困境，杰斐逊又贷了一笔款，并说服他的孙子和门生杰夫·伦道夫(Jeff Randolph)进行担保。作为抵押，杰弗逊拿出了近 1000 英亩的土地，这些土地本来是要传给伦道夫的，这样一来，他的后人就不得不承担他自己挥霍的后果。

In his public life, at this same time, Jefferson was stepping up his attacks on the nation’s debt. In 1813, for instance, he lamented that “the aggregate body of fathers may alienate the labor of all their sons, of their posterity, in the aggregate, and oblige them to pay for all the enterprises, just or unjust, profitable or ruinous, into which our vices, our passions or our personal interests may lead us.” 27It would be too easy to accuse him of hypocrisy. More likely, he was projecting his own personal turmoil. He knew how unsettling debt could be. In 1820, after saddling his grandson with his own debt, he wrote, “It is incumbent on every generation to pay its own debts as it goes. A principle which if acted on would save one-half the wars of the world.” 28

在他的公共生活中，与此同时，杰斐逊正在加紧对国家债务的攻击。例如，在 1813 年，他感叹道 ：“父亲们的集合体可能会让他们所有的儿子、他们的后代的劳动，并迫使他们为我们的恶习、我们的激情或我们的个人利益可能导致我们的所有企业，不管是正义的还是不正义的，有利的还是有损的，支付费用。” 27如果指责他虚伪就太容易了。更有可能的是，他在投射自己的个人动荡。他知道债务是多么令人不安。1820 年，在让他的孙子背上自己的债务后，他写道 ：“每一代人都有责任在发展过程中偿还自己的债务。这一原则如果得到执行，就可以挽救世界上一半的战争。” 28

One restless night in January in the last year of his life, the distressed eighty-two-year-old Jefferson was lying awake, desperately trying to plot the family’s financial redemption, when an idea descended upon him, in his daughter’s words, “like an inspiration from the realm of bliss.” 29The family would sponsor a lottery. For as little as one dollar, an everyday Joe could have the chance to secure a large swath of Jefferson property. Jefferson hoped to raise sixty thousand dollars, enough to pay off the debts and allow him and his daughter to live out their days in something like comfort. Jefferson even harbored the hope that the state of Virginia would purchase the tickets and burn them all, as a way of acknowledging Jefferson’s years of public service.

在他生命的最后一年一月的一个不安的夜晚，苦恼的八十二岁的杰弗逊躺在床上，拼命地谋划着家庭的经济救赎，这时一个想法降临到他身上，用他女儿的话说，“就像来自极乐世界的灵感。” 29这个家庭将赞助一种彩票。只要花一美元，一个普通人就有机会获得杰斐逊的大片财产。杰斐逊希望能筹集到六万美元，足以偿还债务，让他和他的女儿在类似于舒适的环境中度过余生。杰斐逊甚至希望弗吉尼亚州能够购买这些门票并将其全部烧毁，以此来感谢杰斐逊多年来的公共服务。

As a younger man, this is exactly the kind of entitlement that would have set his democratic teeth on edge. Unfortunately for Jefferson, the young legislators of Virginia inherited that spirit and rejected the lottery. “I see in the failure of this hope, a deadly blast of all my peace of my mind during my remaining days,” he wrote to Jeff Randolph. “For myself I should not regard a prostration of fortune, but I am overwhelmed at the prospect of the situation in which I may leave my family.” 30

作为一个年轻的人，这正是那种会让他的民主牙齿咬紧的权利。对杰斐逊来说，不幸的是，弗吉尼亚的年轻立法者们继承了这种精神，拒绝了彩票的做法。“我在这一希望的失败中看到，在我剩下的日子里，我所有的安宁都被致命的打击了”，他给杰夫·伦道夫写道。“对我自己来说，我不应该认为是命运的一蹶不振，但我对我可能离开家庭的情况感到不知所措。” 30

It is instructive to compare Jefferson’s postpresidency with Harry Truman’s. Upon leaving office, Truman drove to Missouri in his own car and settled in the humble Independence home he and his wife had once shared with his mother-in-law. Not wanting to demean the office of president, he turned down all corporate and commercial offers. In this era before presidential golden parachutes, he lived on his army pension and the proceeds from his memoir. “Had it not been for the fact that I was able to sell some property that my brother, sister, and I inherited from our mother,” he said in 1957, “I would practically be on relief, but with the sale of that property I am not financially embarrassed.” 31No, economic virtue was not left behind in the nineteenth century.

将杰斐逊的后任与哈里·杜鲁门的后任进行比较是很有启发的。离任后，杜鲁门开着自己的车来到密苏里州，在他和妻子曾经与岳母合住的简陋的独立屋中定居下来。他不想贬低总统的职位，拒绝了所有公司和商业的邀请。在这个没有总统金色降落伞的时代，他靠军队的养老金和他的回忆录的收入生活。“如果不是因为我能够卖掉我的兄弟、姐妹和我从母亲那里继承的一些财产”，他在 1957 年说，“我实际上是靠救济，但由于卖掉了那些财产，我在经济上并不窘迫。” 31不，经济美德在十九世纪并没有被遗弃。

sixteenJackson Days 杰克逊时代

IF THERE WAS ONE THING ABOVE OTHERS THAT HARD-MONEY ADVOCATES disliked about the Bank of the United States, it was the kind of cluster back scratch described in the previous chapter: Ex-president Thomas Jefferson asks bank president Nicholas to borrow $6,000. Nicholas cosigns, his board approves. Six months later, Nicholas asks Jefferson to cosign a $20,000 loan to Nicholas himself, the board approves. These deals went down in 1817 and 1818 respectively. The Second National Bank of the United States had opened for business in January 1817. The back scratchers did not waste time.

如果说硬通货主义者对美国银行有一个更不喜欢的地方的话，那就是上一章中描述的那种集群式的背刮。前总统托马斯·杰斐逊要求银行总裁尼古拉斯借 6000 美元。尼古拉斯签名，他的董事会批准。6 个月后，尼古拉斯要求杰斐逊为尼古拉斯本人联署一笔 2 万美元的贷款，董事会批准。这些交易分别在 1817 年和 1818 年进行了。美国第二国家银行已于 1817 年 1 月开张营业。后面的人并没有浪费时间。

Jefferson had been mugged by his own self-inflicted reality. In 1791, he had opposed the establishment of the First Bank of the United States. As secretary of state, he had attempted to persuade President Washington to veto the bank bill then pending, as it “violated the laws of mortmain, alienage, forfeiture and escheat, distribution and monopoly” 1and many other laws that Washington likely understood little better than the contemporary reader. More fundamentally, Jefferson distrusted a centralized, monopoly banking operation, even if it were to be 80 percent privately owned.

杰弗逊曾被他自己造成的现实打劫过。1791 年，他曾反对建立美国第一银行。作为国务卿，他曾试图说服华盛顿总统否决当时悬而未决的银行法案，因为它 “违反了抵押、转让、没收和遗留、分配和垄断的法律” 1以及其他许多法律，华盛顿可能比当代读者更了解它们。更根本的是，杰斐逊不信任集中的、垄断的银行业务，哪怕它是 80% 的私人拥有。

Secretary of Treasury Alexander Hamilton thought otherwise, and his opinion prevailed. Congress granted the bank a twenty-year charter in 1791. Among its powers was the printing of bank notes to counter a presumed shortage of specie — gold and silver coins — then in circulation.2These bank notes could be used to pay taxes on a par with specie, and this endowed them with a status very much like legal tender. At the time, the government collected revenues almost exclusively through excise taxes, basically a sales tax on products produced domestically, and customs duties, a sales tax on products produced abroad.

财政部长亚历山大·汉密尔顿（Alexander Hamilton）不这么认为，而且他的意见占了上风。国会在 1791 年授予该银行 20 年的特许权。2这些纸币可以用来支付与纸币相同的税收，这使它们具有非常类似法定货币的地位。当时，政府几乎完全通过消费税（基本上是对国内生产的产品征收的销售税）和关税（对国外生产的产品征收的销售税）来收取收入。

Even in the very first administration, however, revenues were insufficient to meet the needs of a growing federal government, and the new government took to borrowing from its new bank. This infusion of credit and paper money led inevitably to a spike in inflation and a growing resentment among the proto–Tea Party types of the day. When the bank bill came up for renewal in 1811, the battle lines in America’s oldest and most enduring civil war were drawn: the soft-money forces versus the hard. Although the makeup of the respective coalitions would change over time, the intensity rarely flagged. In 1811, the hard-money forces prevailed by a single vote in the House and in the Senate. The Bank of the United States ceased to be.

然而，即使在第一届政府中，收入也不足以满足不断增长的联邦政府的需要，新政府开始向新银行借款。这种信贷和纸币的注入不可避免地导致了通货膨胀的飙升，以及当时原茶党类型的不满情绪的增长。当银行法案在 1811 年被更新时，美国最古老和最持久的内战的战线被划定：软货币力量与硬货币力量。虽然各自联盟的构成会随着时间的推移而改变，但其激烈程度却很少减弱。1811 年，硬通货势力在众议院和参议院以一票之差取得胜利。美国银行不复存在。

Although philosopher George Santayana was not talking about central banking when he said, “Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it,” he might as well have been. In this case, he could have safely said “. . . are condemned to repeat it within the next five years.” That is how long it would take before the resurrection of the Bank of the United States. As it happened, the state-chartered banks that had begun to emerge even before the demise of the original Bank of the United States were severely tested by America’s only war, named for the year it began, 1812.

尽管哲学家乔治·桑塔亚纳(George Santayana)在说 “那些不记得过去的人注定要重蹈覆辙” 时，并不是在谈论中央银行，但他也的确可以这么说。在这种情况下，他完全可以说 “……注定要在未来五年内重蹈覆辙”。这就是美国银行复活所需的时间。果不其然，甚至在最初的美国银行消亡之前就已经开始出现的州政府特许银行受到了美国唯一一场战争的严峻考验，这场战争以其开始年份命名，即 1812 年。

Wars, of course, demand a great deal of money to finance, and the easiest ways to secure it are first to borrow it and then, if need be, to print it. The government did the former, and the state banks obliged them by doing the latter. The only problem was that the banks, especially those outside of fiscally conservative New England, did not have the specie — gold or silver — to back up their notes. In the years from 1811 to 1815, while the amount of specie in circulation declined slightly, the amount of bank notes nearly doubled. By demanding that their more reckless peers redeem their notes in specie, the New Englanders threatened the very existence of those banks and, by extension, the war effort.3

战争当然需要大量的资金来资助，而保证资金的最简单方法是首先借钱，然后在必要时印钱。政府做了前者，而国有银行则通过做后者来履行其义务。唯一的问题是，这些银行，特别是那些在财政上保守的新英格兰以外的银行，没有足够的货币 —— 黄金或白银 —— 来支持它们的票据。在 1811 年至 1815 年期间，虽然流通中的货币数量略有下降，但银行票据的数量几乎翻了一番。新英格兰人要求他们更鲁莽的同行以实物赎回他们的纸币，威胁到了这些银行的生存，进而威胁到了战争努力。3

The U.S. government solved the problem by permitting all banks to suspend specie payments. Although contractually obligated to do so, the banks no longer had to redeem outstanding notes in gold or silver. Just twenty-five years earlier, the framers drafted Article I, section 10, of the United States Constitution, the so-called Contract Clause, expressly to prohibit states from granting private relief to favored individuals or institutions. Now, their successors were using the power of the U.S. government to do the very same thing they denied the states.4

美国政府通过允许所有银行暂停支付纸币来解决这个问题。尽管在合同上有义务这样做，但银行不再需要用黄金或白银赎回未偿还的票据。就在 25 年前，制定者起草了美国宪法第一条第 10 款，即所谓的合同条款，明确禁止各州向受宠的个人或机构提供私人救济。现在，他们的继任者正在利用美国政府的权力来做他们曾经不让各州做的事情。4

“You never want a serious crisis to go to waste,” 5presidential advisor Rahm Emanuel would argue two centuries later. The supporters of a central bank did not need Emanuel to tell them this. They exploited the economic chaos of the war and the postwar period — the specie suspension remained in effect until 1817 — to militate for a renewed Bank of the United States. That was one solution. The other solution, the hard-money solution, and a hard political decision as well, would have been to compel all banks to redeem their notes in specie. This would have forced many banks to close. Their unbacked notes would have been liquidated, and the “good money” that had been driven underground would have come back out of hiding.

“你永远不希望严重的危机被浪费掉”，5总统顾问拉姆·伊曼纽尔（Rahm Emanuel）在两个世纪后会这样认为。中央银行的支持者不需要伊曼纽尔来告诉他们这些。他们利用战争和战后时期的经济混乱 —— 暂停发行纸币的做法一直持续到 1817 年 —— 来推动重新建立美国银行。这是一个解决方案。另一个解决方案，即硬通货解决方案，也是一个艰难的政治决定，就是迫使所有银行以实物赎回其票据。这将迫使许多银行关闭。他们的无担保票据将被清算，被驱赶到地下的 “好钱” 将重新出来躲藏。

By chartering a Second Bank of the United States, Congress chose to play for time. For the first eighteen months of its existence, the new central bank, if anything, encouraged the inflation that the war had engendered and failed to rein in the more promiscuous of the state banks. So much money was in play, in fact, that the New York stock-jobbers who had been trading curbside for a century or more decided it was time to come inside. They rented a space at 40 Wall Street for two hundred dollars a month, and on March 8, 1817, grandly renamed their organization “New York Stock & Exchange Board.” 6

通过特许成立美国第二银行，国会选择了玩时间游戏。在其存在的头 18 个月里，新的中央银行，如果说有什么鼓励了战争引起的通货膨胀，并且没有控制住更多的州银行的混乱。事实上，如此多的资金在运作，以至于在路边交易了一个多世纪的纽约股票经纪人决定是时候进去了。他们以每月 200 美元的价格在华尔街 40 号租了一个空间，并在 1817 年 3 月 8 日隆重地将他们的组织更名为 “纽约证券交易委员会”。6

By mid-1818, however, officials of the Second Bank and responsible parties in the Monroe administration realized they had little choice but to call the party to a halt. The bonds that had been sold to European investors to finance the Louisiana deal were coming due — four million dollars’ worth in gold or silver. As the government’s fiscal agent, the bank had to call in its loans to commercial banks and insist that they repay in specie. The ensuing contraction — and it was huge — completed America’s first artificial boom-bust cycle. There would be many more.

然而，到了 1818 年中期，第二银行的官员和门罗政府的负责人意识到，他们没有什么选择，只能叫停这场宴会。为资助路易斯安那交易而出售给欧洲投资者的债券即将到期 —— 价值四百万美元的黄金或白银。作为政府的财政代理人，银行不得不收回其对商业银行的贷款，并坚持要求它们以货币偿还。随之而来的收缩 —— 而且是巨大的收缩 —— 完成了美国第一次人为的繁荣·萧条循环。以后还会有更多。

Wrote hard-money economist William Gouge of the Panic of 1819, “The Bank was saved, and the people were ruined.” 7The panic did, however, spawn a new movement, one that would soon enough find its champion in Andrew Jackson. Jackson would defiantly take up the cause of sound money and go after central bankers the way he had the Seminoles, but the banking tribe would prove a good deal harder to tame.

硬通货经济学家威廉·古格（William Gouge）在谈到 1819 年的恐慌时写道 ：“银行得救了，而人民被毁了。” 7然而，这场恐慌确实催生了一场新的运动，一场很快会找到其支持者的安德鲁·杰克逊（Andrew Jackson）。杰克逊将勇敢地承担起健全货币的事业，并像对付塞米诺尔人那样对付中央银行家，但事实证明，银行业的部落是很难驯服的。

Andrew Jackson was undeniably a man of many talents, but it is hard to imagine which of them the modern Democratic Party remembers at its annual Jackson Day celebrations. A new off-Broadway musical,Bloody BloodyAndrew Jackson: The Concert Version, nicely captures the contemporary liberal take on Old Hickory. As John Lahr observes in hisNew Yorkerreview, Jackson is played as “gun-toting, Indian hating, land-grabbing Old Stonewall, who ‘put the “man” in manifest destiny.’” 8So fixed is this image that the playwrights feel free to parody it.

无可否认，安德鲁·杰克逊是个多才多艺的人，但很难想象现代民主党在每年的杰克逊日庆祝活动中会记住其中哪一个。一部新的非百老汇音乐剧《血淋淋的安德鲁·杰克逊，剧场版》（Bloody BloodyAndrew Jackson: The Concert Version），很好地抓住了当代自由派对老希克里的看法。正如约翰·拉尔在他的《纽约客》评论中所观察到的那样，杰克逊被扮演成 持枪、憎恨印第安人、抢夺土地的老斯通沃尔一样的人物，是个能决定他人生死的家伙。 8这种形象是如此固定，以至于剧作家们可以随意模仿。

Jackson’s life story is well enough known. Born fighting in 1767 to Scotch Irish parents, he served as a teenage courier in the Revolutionary War, almost died in captivity, lost both his parents as a result of the war, taught himself law, got himself elected to Congress, was appointed colonel in the Tennessee militia, fought lots of Indians, won the Battle of New Orleans, married a married woman, engaged in some thirteen duels, many of them defending his wife’s honor, killed at least one of the duelers, took a few bullets himself, and, oh yes, owned some 150 slaves.

杰克逊的生平事迹已经足够出名。他生于 1767 年，父母是苏格兰爱尔兰人，在革命战争中担任少年信使，差点死在俘虏中，因战争而失去双亲，自学法律，自己被选入国会，被任命为田纳西州民兵上校。与许多印第安人作战，赢得了新奥尔良战役，娶了一个已婚妇女，参与了大约 13 次决斗，其中许多是为了捍卫他妻子的荣誉，至少杀死了一个决斗者，自己也挨了几颗子弹，而且，哦，是的，拥有大约 150 个奴隶。

Contemporary Democrats would find little more to celebrate in Jackson’s economic program than they have in his slave owning. Jacksonians favored lean, tight governments, the smaller and closer to home the better. They saw the primary role of government as the upholding of property rights. As translated to banking, this philosophy argued for the separation of bank and state, a move from inflationary paper money to pure specie, and 100 percent reserve banking in the place of the fractional reserve alternative.9God cannot possibly allow the dead to spy on their living descendants, because if, by some miracle, Jackson got to heaven, watching the TARP rollout in 2008 would have been pure hell.

当代民主党人在杰克逊的经济计划中几乎找不到比他拥有奴隶更值得庆祝的东西。杰克逊主义者赞成精干、紧凑的政府，规模越小、离家越近越好。他们认为政府的主要作用是维护财产权利。在银行业方面，这种哲学主张银行和国家分离，从通货膨胀的纸币转向纯粹的货币，并以 100% 的准备金银行取代部分准备金银行。 9上帝不可能允许死者监视他们活着的后代，因为如果杰克逊奇迹般地上了天堂，在 2008 年看到 TARP 的推出对他来说将是纯粹的地狱。

Beyond ideology, Jackson had political gripes with the Second Bank. He suspected that its autocratic president, Philadelphia blue blood Nicholas Biddle, was using the bank’s power and money to defeat his 1828 presidential bid.10In 1824, Jackson had won a plurality of both popular and electoral votes but lost to John Quincy Adams when the election was thrown to the House of Representatives. Jackson was more than a little suspicious about how this “corrupt bargain” had come to pass. In 1828, when he contested Adams’s bid for reelection, the bank was sufficiently indiscreet in its get-out-the-vote effort that it alarmed even its supporters.

除了意识形态，杰克逊对第二银行还有政治上的不满。他怀疑第二银行的独裁总裁，费城蓝血人尼古拉斯·比德尔，正在利用银行的权力和金钱来挫败他 1828 年的总统竞选。101824 年，杰克逊赢得了多数的民众和选举人票，但在选举被扔到众议院时输给了约翰·昆西·亚当斯。杰克逊对这种 “腐败的交易” 是如何实现的多多少少有些怀疑。1828 年，当他对亚当斯的竞选连任提出异议时，该银行在争取选票的努力中足够轻率，甚至使其支持者感到震惊。

At the time, Biddle had even more power than a Federal Reserve president does today. The federal government appointed just five of his twenty-five directors. Neither the Congress nor the president had any control over the bank’s operation, save to withdraw the government’s funds or to decline renewal of its charter when it expired. In 1828, Biddle worried about neither of these possibilities. He was the master of his own universe. In the summer of 1832, toward the end of Jackson’s first term, Biddle’s mastery was confirmed when both houses of Congress voted to recharter the bank.11

在当时，比德尔的权力甚至比今天的美联储主席还要大。联邦政府只任命了他的二十五名董事中的五名。国会和总统都没有对银行的运作有任何控制权，除了可以撤回政府的资金，或在其章程到期时拒绝更新。在 1828 年，比德尔对这些可能性都不担心。他是他自己世界的主人。1832 年夏天，在杰克逊的第一个任期即将结束时，当国会两院投票重新授予银行特许状时，比德尔的主宰地位得到了确认。11

Shortly before a close vote in the House, Congressman Samuel Carson of North Carolina changed his mind and votedforthe recharter bill. When he inquired, Attorney General Roger Taney learned that Carson had just received a $20,000 loan from the bank. “Now I do not mean to say that he was directly bribed,” 12wrote Taney. He blamed instead the proximity of this “mammoth money power” to so many needy public functionaries. The ever-judicious Taney would later be appointed chief justice of the Supreme Court.

在众议院接近表决前不久，北卡罗来纳州的众议员塞缪尔`卡森改变了主意，投票支持重新特许权法案。当他询问时，司法部长罗杰·塔尼得知卡森刚刚从银行获得了一笔 2 万美元的贷款。“现在我并不是说他被直接贿赂了”，12塔尼写到。他反而指责这种 “巨大的金钱力量” 与这么多有需要的公共职能部门的关系密切。一向公正的塔尼后来被任命为最高法院的首席法官。

In July of that year, Jackson vetoed the recharter bill and did so in thundering terms. “It is to be regretted that the rich and powerful too often bend the acts of government to their selfish purposes,” Jackson began, and he kept hammering from there. He argued that distinctions will always exist in society, but when the law adds “artificial distinctions,” the humbler members of society “have a right to complain of the injustice of their government.” 13He then delegated to himself — and to Congress as well, if its members chose to exercise it — the power to rule on the constitutionality of an issue. Biddle actually welcomed the speech. He considered it so over the top that in November the voters would surely reject Jackson and his “manifesto of anarchy” and “relieve the country from the dominion of these miserable people.” 14Not for the last time would a central banker misread the mood of the country. Jackson easily beat Henry Clay in the November election and promptly turned his attention to Biddle.

同年 7 月，杰克逊否决了重新授权法案，并以雷霆万钧的语气进行了否决。“令人遗憾的是，富人和有权势的人经常使政府的行为屈从于他们的自私目的”，杰克逊一开始就这样说，而且他从那里一直敲打。他认为，社会上总是存在着区别，但当法律增加了 “人为的区别” 时，社会上较卑微的成员 “有权抱怨他们政府的不公正”。13然后他把对一个问题的合宪性进行裁决的权力下放给自己，如果国会成员选择行使这一权力，也可以下放给国会。比德尔实际上欢迎这个演讲。他认为这太夸张了，在 11 月，选民肯定会拒绝杰克逊和他的 “无政府主义宣言”，把国家从这些可悲的人的统治下解救出来。14一个中央银行家误读国家的情绪并不是最后一次了。杰克逊在 11 月的选举中轻松击败了亨利·克莱，并迅速将注意力转向比德尔。

The bank still had four years left on its charter and ample resources to manage a future override of a Jackson veto. Not shy about taking matters into his own hands — during the Seminole wars, he had taken Florida without anyone’s permission — Jackson decided to pull the federal deposits from the Bank of the United States and put them in reliable state banks. “My object, sir, is to save the country, and it will be lost if we permit the bank to exist,” 15Jackson told his dissenting secretary of treasury. He gave the order to withdraw beginning October 1, 1833. When questioned by his own supporters as to motive, especially given that he could veto any future effort to recharter, Jackson contended that the bank would “buy up all Congress” if its survival were threatened. Not wanting to risk that, Jackson intended to take “the means of corruption” 16out of Biddle’s hands.

该银行的章程还剩四年，而且有足够的资源来管理未来推翻杰克逊的否决权。杰克逊并不羞于将事情掌握在自己手中 —— 在塞米诺尔战争期间，他曾在未经任何人允许的情况下占领了佛罗里达州 —— 他决定从美国银行提取联邦存款，并将其存入可靠的州立银行。15杰克逊对他持异议的财政部长说 ：“我的目标是拯救国家，如果我们允许银行存在，它就会失去”。他下达了从 1833 年 10 月 1 日开始撤退的命令。当他自己的支持者质疑他的动机时，特别是考虑到他可以否决任何未来重新特许的努力，杰克逊辩称，如果银行的生存受到威胁，它将 “买下所有国会”。杰克逊不想冒这个险，他打算把 “腐败的手段” 16从比德尔手中拿走。

Biddle struck back. A week after the order went out to remove deposits, Biddle met with his board in Philadelphia. “Nothing but the evidence of suffering abroad will produce any effect in Congress,” 17Biddle told the directors. By “abroad” he did not mean overseas. He meant abroad as in “abroad in the land.” And “suffering” he meant literally. Americans, he believed, had to see the consequences of a credit clampdown if they were to turn against Jackson, and Congress had to feel their pain. The directors heeded Biddle’s call to arms, called in loans, and tightened credit.

比德尔反击了。在清除存款的命令发出一周后，比德尔在费城与他的董事会会面。“除了国外的痛苦证据外，没有什么能在国会产生任何效果”，17比德尔告诉董事。他所说的 “国外” 并不是指海外。他指的是 “在国外的土地上” 的国外。而 “痛苦” 他是指字面上的意思。他认为，美国人必须看到信贷紧缩的后果，如果他们要反对杰克逊，国会必须感受到他们的痛苦。董事们听从了比德尔的号召，调用了贷款，并收紧了信贷。

The battle came to a head in the spring of 1834. The old general knew a thing about strategy. He turned to theGlobe, a newspaper that preached “the true faith,” 18meaning whatever Jackson wanted it to print. Using the paper as megaphone, Jackson shared his concerns with the citizens of the then just twenty-four states that Biddle had turned the bank into a “permanent electioneering engine.” 19For this and sundry other good reasons, he told the people, he had decided to withdraw the government’s deposits.

1834 年春天，战斗进入了高潮。这位老将军对战略很有研究。他求助于《全球》（Globe），一份宣扬 “真正信仰” 的报纸，18意思是杰克逊希望它刊登什么它就登什么。杰克逊把报纸当作传声筒，与当时仅有的 24 个州的公民分享他的担忧，即比德尔把银行变成了一个 “永久的选举引擎”。19由于这个和其他一些好的理由，他告诉人民，他决定撤回政府的存款。

A century before FDR’s fireside chats, Jackson was the first president to make such a direct appeal to the people. In the process, he so thoroughly outmaneuvered his opponents that they cried foul. John Calhoun, the vice president during Jackson’s first term, placed Jackson’s appeal “among the alarming signs of the times which portend the overthrow of the Constitution and the approach of despotic power.” 20Not to be out-demagogued, Henry Clay echoed Calhoun’s charge of despotism and insisted that if Congress did not act boldly, “The fatal collapse will soon come on, and we shall die — ignobly die — base, mean, and abject slaves.” 21

在富兰克林·D·罗斯福的炉边谈话之前的一个世纪，杰克逊是第一位向人民作出这种直接呼吁的总统。在这个过程中，他如此彻底地战胜了他的对手，以至于他们叫苦不迭。杰克逊第一个任期内的副总统约翰·卡尔霍恩（John Calhoun）将杰克逊的呼吁列为 “时代的警讯之一，预示着宪法被推翻和专制权力的来临。” 20亨利·克莱不甘示弱，响应卡尔霍恩的专制主义指控，坚持认为如果国会不大胆行动，“致命的崩溃将很快到来，而我们将死去 —— 无知地死去 —— 卑微、卑劣和卑贱的奴隶。” 21

Calhoun and Clay made these accusations on the floor of the Senate. In this rough-and-tumble era, no one would have accused them of Jackson-bashing. “Bashing” back then meant walking onto the Senate floor, as South Carolina congressman Preston Brooks did in 1856, and beating Massachusetts senator Charles Sumner very nearly to death with the fat end of a cane, while a gun-wielding fellow congressman held off bystanders.

卡尔霍恩和克莱在参议院会议上提出了这些指责。在这个动荡不安的时代，没有人会指责他们抨击杰克逊。当时的 “抨击” 是指走进参议院，就像南卡罗来纳州议员普雷斯顿·布鲁克斯在 1856 年所做的那样，用手杖的肥头大耳将马萨诸塞州参议员查尔斯·萨姆纳打得几乎死去，而一名持枪的同僚则挡住了旁观者。

Calhoun and Clay could afford to attack Jackson because, as senators, they held six-year terms and were not elected directly by the people in any case. Congressmen had no such insulation. On April 4, 1834, an election year, the House voted that the deposits should remain in the state banks and that the Bank of the United States ought not be rechartered. “I have obtained a glorious triumph,” Jackson crowed. “That mammoth of corruption and power” had finally been “put to death.” 22

卡尔霍恩和克莱能够承受对杰克逊的攻击，因为作为参议员，他们的任期为六年，而且在任何情况下都不是由人民直接选举的。国会议员则没有这样的保障。1834 年 4 月 4 日，一个选举年，众议院投票决定，存款应留在州银行，美国银行不应重新注册。“我已经取得了一个光荣的胜利”，杰克逊欢呼道。“那头腐败和权力的猛兽终于被‘处死’了。” 22

A month after Jackson left office, just as his vice president and now successor Martin Van Buren was easing into power, commercial houses in New York started failing — exchange brokers, stock-jobbers, real estate speculators. It would take five years for America to fully recover from the Panic of 1837.23Nearly two hundred years later, history has offered no definitive proof as to why the crash happened, but what was undeniable even then was that the party in power would catch the heat. A pattern had begun to establish itself.

杰克逊卸任后一个月，正当他的副总统、现在的继任者马丁·范布伦缓缓上台时，纽约的商业机构开始倒闭 —— 交易所经纪人、股票经纪人、房地产投机商。23近两百年后，历史没有提供关于崩溃发生原因的确切证据，但不可否认的是，即使在那时，执政党也会受到影响。一个模式已经开始建立起来了。

On the plus side, the Panic cleared out an awful lot of financial deadwood — overextended banks, shaky investments, hairy speculations. Van Buren, meanwhile, withdrew the government’s money from all the “pet” state banks and stored it in pure specie in government vaults. For the first and only time in American history, the government had established an independent treasury system, free from any entanglement with the nation’s banks and with all of its finances grounded in hard money. These halcyon days would extend for twenty years, until the Civil War made printing “greenbacks” once again seem like an attractive way to cover the national debt.

从好的方面看，这次恐慌清除了大量的金融死角 —— 过度扩张的银行、不稳定的投资、毛茸茸的投机。与此同时，范布伦将政府的钱从所有的 “宠物” 州立银行中撤出，并将其以纯货币形式储存在政府的金库中。这是美国历史上第一次也是唯一一次，政府建立了一个独立的国库系统，摆脱了与国家银行的任何纠缠，其所有的财政都以硬通货为基础。这段美好的日子将持续 20 年，直到内战使印刷 “绿钞” 再次成为支付国债的诱人方式。

As to the Bank of the United States, it continued on as a wobbly state-chartered bank and contributed its own share to the Panic of 1837. Biddle finally stepped down in 1839, and the bank closed just two years later. Biddle died in 1844 in Philadelphia at age fifty-eight, a year before the seventy-eight-year-old Jackson. But the idea of a central banker did not die with him. No silver bullet, no stake in the heart, no president could keep that idea dead.

至于美国银行，它作为一家摇摆不定的州政府特许银行继续存在，并在 1837 年的恐慌中贡献了自己的一份力量。比德尔终于在 1839 年下台，两年后银行就关闭了。比德尔于 1844 年在费城去世，享年五十八岁，比七十八岁的杰克逊早一年。但中央银行家的想法并没有随他而去。没有银弹，没有心存芥蒂，也没有总统能让这个想法死去。

seventeenA Mountain Load of Debt 堆积如山的债务

ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE ARRIVED IN THE UNITED STATES IN MAY 1831, the third year of the Jackson presidency. At the time he was a twenty-five-year-old French dandy, but one with a remarkably keen eye. He left nine months later. Three years after that he produced the enduring classic that we know asDemocracy in America. Neither before nor since has anyone captured the American psyche with such precision.

亚历克西斯·德·托克维尔（Alexis De Tocqueville）于 1831 年 5 月到达美国，那是杰克逊担任总统的第三年。当时，他是一个 25 岁的法国花花公子，但他有一双非常敏锐的眼睛。九个月后他离开了。三年后，他写出了经久不衰的经典之作，我们称之为《美国的民主》。在此之前和之后，都没有人能够如此准确地捕捉到美国人的心理。

Tocqueville conceded that there was nothing unique about American character traits. He had known of people in other countries who were hardworking, restless, ambitious, religious, egalitarian, and individualistic. He had not known, however, nor had the world seen, a whole nation of such people. To understand those people one had to understand the paradox of equality, and this Tocqueville assessed early on.

托克维尔承认，美国人的性格特征并不独特。他知道其他国家的人勤奋、不安分、有野心、有宗教信仰、平等主义和个人主义。然而，他不知道，世界上也没有见过，一整个国家的这种人。要了解这些人，就必须了解平等的悖论，而这一点托克维尔很早就进行了评估。

As Tocqueville observed, in a society where aristocratic privileges have been abolished and where all career paths are open to anyone willing to work hard, the citizen could readily delude himself into thinking “that he is born to no common destinies.” 1Although Tocqueville did not dwell on the question of credit, he understood why Americans would avail themselves of it. “When an immense field for competition is thrown open to all,” he continues, “when wealth is amassed or dissipated in the shortest possible space of time amid the turmoil of democracy, visions of sudden and easy fortunes, of great possessions easily won and lost, of chance under all its forms haunt the mind.” Under these circumstances, “The present looms large . . . and men seek only to think about tomorrow.” 2

正如托克维尔所观察到的，在一个废除了贵族特权的社会中，所有的职业道路都向任何愿意努力工作的人开放，公民很容易自欺欺人地认为 “他生来就没有共同的命运”。1尽管托克维尔没有纠缠于信用问题，但他理解美国人为什么会利用信用。他继续说 ：“当一个巨大的竞争领域向所有人开放时，当财富在民主的动荡中在尽可能短的时间内积累或消散时，突然而轻松的财富、容易赢得和失去的巨大财产、各种形式的机会的景象在脑海中萦绕。” "在这种情况下，“目前的情况很重要…… 而人们只想考虑明天。” 2

Charles Dickens had a more malign view of America’s flirtation with debt. In his sour grapes tour of America ten years after Tocqueville’s, Dickens added “the love of ‘smart’ dealing” 3to the causes of the nation’s periodic insolvency. Although Dickens surely overstates the problem, he did not invent it. Visiting in the wake of the Panic of 1837, he points out the consequences of the various swindles and “defalcations” (his word, meaning a category of bad acts that taint a particular debt such that it cannot be discharged in bankruptcy). “This smartness,” he contends, “has done more in a few years to impair the public credit, and to cripple the public resources, than dull honesty, however rash, could have effected in a century.” 4

查尔斯·狄更斯(Charles Dickens)对美国对债务的调戏有更恶毒的看法。在托克维尔十年后的美国之行中，狄更斯将 “对‘聪明’交易的热爱” 3列入国家定期破产的原因。尽管狄更斯肯定夸大了这个问题，但他并没有发明这个问题。在 1837 年的恐慌之后，他指出了各种诈骗和 “亏空” （defalcations，他的措辞，意思是指一类玷污特定债务的不良行为，使其不能在破产中被免除）的后果。他认为，“这种聪明才智在几年内对损害公共信用和削弱公共资源所起的作用，比迟钝的诚实（无论多么轻率）在一个世纪内所起的作用还要大。” 4

Dickens talked specifically about “that ill-fated Cairo,” 5the Illinois town at the confluence of the Ohio and the Mississippi Rivers. The attempt by speculators to make Cairo the rival of St. Louis was undone, Dickens claims, by “gross deceits.” When revealed, these deceits eroded confidence in America and discouraged foreign investment. This all, of course, is at least partially true. The fact that Cairo today has three thousand people compared to the nearly three million in metropolitan St. Louis suggests that the scheme to put Cairo on the map was not a roaring success. Still, it was the schemers and dreamers who unbound the West and built most of its cities. Had “dull honesty” been America’s defining characteristic, Chicago would still be a swamp and Kansas City a floodplain.

狄更斯特别谈到了 “那个命运多舛的开罗” 5，位于俄亥俄河和密西西比河汇合处的伊利诺斯州小镇。狄更斯称，投机者试图使开罗成为圣路易斯的对手，但由于 “严重的欺骗” 而失败了。这些欺骗被揭露后，削弱了人们对美国的信心，阻碍了外国投资。当然，这一切至少有一部分是真的。今天开罗有三千人，而圣路易斯大都会有近三百万人，这一事实表明，把开罗放在地图上的计划并没有取得巨大的成功。然而，正是这些阴谋家和梦想家解除了西方的束缚，并建造了其大部分城市。如果 “沉闷的诚实” 是美国的决定性特征，那么芝加哥仍然是一片沼泽，堪萨斯城仍然是一片洪泛区。

It was not just foreign social critics who were fretting out loud about the easy acceptance of debt by both individuals and governments. Mark Twain told of a speculator overheard boasting, “I wasn’t worth a cent two years ago, and now I owe two millions of dollars.” 6Famed orator Edward Everett — he whose two-hour speech at Gettysburg was eclipsed by President Lincoln’s two-minute address — blamed the Panic of 1857 on “a mountain load of debt” assumed by citizens, communities, businesses, and governments in unwitting concert. Everywhere Everett looked he saw a “natural proclivity to anticipate income, to buy on credit, to live a little beyond our means.” 7

不仅仅是外国的社会批评家对个人和政府轻易接受债务的行为大声发愁。马克·吐温（Mark Twain）讲述了一个被偷听到的投机者的吹嘘 ：“两年前我还不值一文钱，现在我欠了两百万美元。” 6著名演说家爱德华·埃弗雷特 —— 他在盖茨堡的两小时演讲被林肯总统的两分钟演讲所掩盖 —— 将 1857 年的恐慌归咎于公民、社区、企业和政府在不知不觉中共同承担的 “沉重的债务”。无论在哪里，他都看到了一种 “预期收入的自然倾向，赊账买东西，有点超出我们的能力。” 7

For better or worse, a variety of businesses emerged in nineteenth-century America to accommodate those who lived beyond their means. Although pawnbroking had been common in both the Greek and Roman empires, as well as in Europe, the first American pawnshops did not open, at least legally, until the early decades of the 1800s. The late start had as much to do with demographics as with local customs. Pawnbroking is an urban business. The broker needs a critical mass of wage earners to make the business model work. New York City recognized its first legal pawnshop in 1803. By 1897 that number had climbed to 134. Said one crusading journalist toward century’s end, “The city can no more dispense with the pawnbroker than it can with the baker or the milkman.” 8

无论好坏，十九世纪的美国出现了各种各样的业务，以满足那些生活无着的人。尽管典当业在希腊和罗马帝国以及欧洲都很普遍，但美国的第一家当铺直到十九世纪初的几十年才开业，至少是合法的。起步晚与人口数量和当地习俗有很大关系。典当业是一项城市业务。经纪人需要有足够数量的工薪阶层来使商业模式运作。纽约市在 1803 年承认了它的第一家合法典当行。到 1897 年，这一数字已攀升至 134 家。在本世纪末，有一位讨伐的记者说 ：“城市不能像对待面包师或送奶工那样，城市不能没有典当行。” 8

That model was simple enough and remains so. A customer needs cash. She — most nineteenth-century customers were women — brings an item to the pawnshop that she thinks has value. The pawnbroker assesses it with an eye to its potential resale value. Experienced pawnbrokers, as many a disappointed customer can attest, have remarkably good eyes. They have seen and heard everything. The pawnbroker then loans the customer money at an interest rate typically limited by law and holds the item as collateral. If the customer repays the loan on time with interest, she gets the item back. If she extends the loan, all the better for the pawnbroker. If the customer does not finally repay the loan, the pawnbroker resells the item.9

这种模式很简单，现在仍然如此。一位顾客需要现金。她 —— 大多数 19 世纪的顾客都是女性 —— 将一件她认为有价值的物品带到当铺。典当行对其进行评估，并关注其潜在的转售价值。经验丰富的典当行，正如许多失望的顾客可以证明的那样，有着非常好的眼光。他们已经看到和听到了一切。然后，典当行以通常受法律限制的利率向客户贷款，并持有该物品作为抵押品。如果客户按时还款并支付利息，她就能拿回物品。如果她延长贷款期限，对典当行来说就更好了。如果顾客最终没有偿还贷款，典当行将物品转卖。9

The institution took root in American cities because of the advantages to the customer. There was no humiliating interview as there would have been for a charity, no credit checks, no elaborate contracts. The drawback, of course, was the interest rate. Although most American states had adopted usury laws, now defined as excessive interest, there could be no real consensus on what “excessive” meant.

该机构在美国城市扎根，因为它对顾客有好处。没有像慈善机构那样的羞辱性面试，没有信用检查，没有复杂的合同。当然，缺点是利率。尽管美国大多数州都通过了高利贷法律，现在被定义为过高的利息，但对 “过高” 的含义没有真正的共识。

New York City, for instance, allowed 2 percent monthly interest on loans over one hundred dollars, but 3 percent under that amount.10Although this did not seem fair to reformers, small loans consumed as much of a pawnbroker’s time as large ones but with less return. To get around legal usury limits, pawnbrokers often charged a variety of fees that could run annual interest rates up as high as 300 percent. In the second half of the century, when the reformers started opening their own charity pawnshops, not unlike theMonte di Pietaof medieval Italy, even they had to charge as much as 1.5 percent a month to meet their minimal overhead.

例如，纽约市允许 100 美元以上的贷款月息为 2%，但低于这一数额的贷款月息为 3%。10尽管这在改革者看来并不公平，但小额贷款与大额贷款一样消耗典当行的大量时间，而且回报较少。为了规避法律上的高利贷限制，典当行经常收取各种费用，年利率可高达 300%。在本世纪下半叶，当改革者开始开设他们自己的慈善当铺时，与中世纪意大利的慈悲山（Monte di Pieta）不一样的是，即使他们不得不每月收取高达 1.5% 的费用，以满足他们最低的管理费用。

In a historical note, the universal pawnshop symbol of three suspended golden balls can be traced back to the Medici coat of arms. To share in the magic of the Medici name, lesser lenders simply ripped off their logo. The unauthorized spread of this symbol represents what is likely the first documented case of trademark infringement. Speaking of infringement, American publishers were ripping off Dickens’s work without paying royalties, which helps explain why he was such an ungracious guest.

从历史上看，三个悬空的金球的通用典当行标志可以追溯到美第奇的纹章。为了分享美第奇名字的魔力，较小的贷款人只是简单地撕掉了他们的标志。这个符号未经授权的传播代表了可能是第一个有记录的商标侵权案例。说到侵权，美国出版商盗用狄更斯的作品而不支付版税，这有助于解释为什么他是一个如此不友好的客人。

As convenient as they were, pawnshops had no monopoly on lending to the working classes of nineteenth-century America. In New York City, for instance, an estimated two-thirds of the lending was done by small loan agencies. These shops flirted with legality throughout most of the century, especially in those jurisdictions that enforced an interest ceiling less than 10 percent. To turn a profit on small loans with high default rates, these agencies had to charge 20 percent interest per annum or more. As collateral, they accepted chattel mortgages or attached a worker’s wages, the latter being themodus operandiof today’s payday loan operations.

尽管当铺很方便，但它们并没有垄断对十九世纪美国工人阶级的贷款。例如，在纽约市，估计有三分之二的贷款是由小型贷款机构完成的。在整个世纪的大部分时间里，这些商店都在合法的范围内徘徊，特别是在那些强制执行低于 10% 的利息上限的司法管辖区。为了从违约率高的小额贷款中获利，这些机构不得不收取 20% 或更高的年利率。作为抵押品，他们接受动产抵押贷款或附上工人的工资，后者是今天发薪日贷款业务的操作手法。

As one might expect, these small agencies did not enjoy a particularly favorable press. In fact, some time in the late nineteenth century, reformers adapted the slur on real estate speculators, “land shark,” to the more memorable “loan shark” applied to small lenders. Despite the mob connotations of the phrase, these lenders rarely, if ever, broke legs. Generally, the worst pain they inflicted on a deadbeat borrower was to sic a “bawlerout” on them. Almost always a female, the bawlerout would try to catch the defaulter in front of friends or coworkers and — you guessed it — bawl her out. Shame was still a viable currency in the nineteenth century.

正如人们所期望的那样，这些小型机构并没有享受到特别有利的新闻。事实上，在十九世纪末的某个时候，改革者将对房地产投机者的蔑称 “地产鲨鱼” （Land shark）改编为更令人难忘的 “高利贷鲨鱼” （Loan shark），适用于小贷款人。尽管这个短语有暴徒的含义，但这些放贷者很少会亏本。一般来说，他们对不守信用的借款人造成的最严重的痛苦是给他们派上一个 “呼叫器” （bawlerout），几乎总是女性，嚎啕大哭者会试图在朋友或同事面前抓住违约者，然后 —— 你猜对了 —— 把她嚎啕大哭。在十九世纪，羞耻心仍然是一种可行的货币。

Borrowers often turned to loan sharks to settle up debts incurred through a seductive new phenomenon known as installment buying. In the early part of the nineteenth century, this phenomenon was reserved for people of means and was offered by retailers as something of a minor honor. Not until the 1880s did the working classes get in on the game. To recruit them, large retailers hired “pullers-in,” middlemen who spoke the customer’s language, literally, and introduced them to the wonders of buying on the installment plan, American-style.11

借款人经常求助于高利贷，通过一种被称为分期付款的诱人新现象来清偿债务。在十九世纪早期，这种现象是为有经济能力的人准备的，并由零售商作为一种小荣誉提供。直到十九世纪 80 年代，工人阶级才开始参与到这个游戏中。为了招募他们，大型零售商雇用了 “拉人”，这些中间人说着顾客的语言，从字面上看，他们向顾客介绍了美国式的分期付款计划的好处。

Late-century American cities were more diverse than they had ever been or have been since. New arrivals, and they came by the shiploads on a daily basis, did not show up wearing Kobe Bryant jerseys with iPods on their belt. They came as strangers to a strange land and appreciated the rope-showing service of the retailers’ middlemen. A memoirist of the period recounts how one female middleman — middleperson? —— sold the writer’s mother a sewing machine, then showed up once a week for the next twenty-five years to collect the twenty-five cent installment owed, in the process becoming a close family friend.12

世纪末的美国城市比过去和现在都更加多元化。新来的人，他们每天都是一船一船地来，并没有穿着科比·布莱恩特的球衣，带着 iPod 出现。他们像陌生人一样来到一个陌生的地方，并感谢零售商的中间人提供的绳子展示服务。当时的一位回忆录作家讲述了一位女性中间人 —— 中间人？ —— 如何向作家的母亲出售一台缝纫机，然后在接下来的 25 年里每周出现一次，收取所欠的 25 美分的分期付款，在此过程中成为家庭的亲密朋友。

At the time, when people thought of installment credit they thought first of sewing machines. To be clear, Isaac Singer did not invent the sewing machine, never claimed to. He was too busy fathering children in any case — twenty-four with five different women, only two of whom he married. What the Singer Manufacturing Company did invent was the formalized installment plan. The company sold more than 250,000 sewing machines in 1876 alone, roughly half of the machines sold nationwide and most of these “on time.” 13No technology has affected domestic America more.

当时，当人们想到分期付款信贷时，首先想到的是缝纫机。说白了，艾萨克·辛格并没有发明缝纫机，也从未声称发明了缝纫机。无论如何，他太忙于生孩子了 —— 与五个不同的女人生了 24 个孩子，其中只有两个人结婚。辛格制造公司所发明的是正式的分期付款计划。该公司仅在 1876 年就售出了超过 25 万台缝纫机，约占全国售出机器的一半，其中大部分是 “按时” 售出的。13没有任何技术对美国国内影响更大。

For most of the nineteenth century, buying one’s home on time was thought radical to the point of being taboo. The orthodox approach was for a family to save its money until it could afford to buy a house and then purchase one. The building-and-loan associations changed all that. “I met with several kinds of associations in America of which I confess I had no previous notion,” Tocqueville would write, “and I have often admired the extreme skill with which the inhabitants of the United States succeed in proposing a common object for the exertions of a great many men and in inducing them voluntarily to pursue it.” 14By happenstance, Tocqueville visited Philadelphia — “the only city in the world where it has occurred to people to distinguish the streets by numbers and not by names” 15—— in the same year that America’s first savings-and-loan association was founded there, 1831. By 1893, there were nearly six thousand such associations.16

在十九世纪的大部分时间里，按时买房被认为是激进到了禁忌的程度。正统的做法是，一个家庭把钱存起来，直到有能力买房，然后再买房。建筑和贷款协会改变了这一切。托克维尔写道 ：“我在美国遇到了几种协会，我承认我以前对这些协会一无所知，我经常对美国居民成功地为许多人提出一个共同目标并促使他们自愿追求这一目标的极端技巧感到钦佩。” 14通过偶然的机会，托克维尔访问了费城 —— “世界上唯一一个人们用数字而不是名字来区分街道的城市” 15—— 同年，美国的第一个储蓄和贷款协会在这里成立。到 1893 年，有近六千个这样的协会。16。

In the beginning, they were just that — associations. Indeed, many had no offices or salaried officials, let alone Learjets parked in company hangars. Would-be homebuyers would buy shares in the association in the amount equal to the money they hoped to borrow. The homebuyers were allowed to pay the association the cost of the shares over time, and they also paid 6 percent interest on the money borrowed.17Without intending to, the associations had pioneered the amortization of home loans.

一开始，他们只是一个协会。事实上，许多协会没有办公室或受薪官员，更不用说停在公司机库的里尔飞机了。有意买房的人将购买协会的股份，其金额相当于他们希望借到的钱。17在无意中，这些协会开创了房屋贷款的摊销方式。

Amortizationderives from the Middle Englishamortisen, meaning “to kill” —— a meaning that might resonate with people burned in the recent subprime crisis. More generally, amortization has come to mean the payment of interest and principal together in fixed monthly installments. Although moralists were troubled by the voluntary assumption of debt, rigorous installment plans for essential items had the effect of making families more, not less, conscientious in the budgeting of their income. If they wanted to stay in their homes, they had to put money aside each month. To work, this system of payment needed honorable mortgage lenders and a morally responsible customer base.

“摊销” 源自中古英语 amortisen，意思是 “杀死” —— 这个意思可能会让在最近的次贷危机中受到伤害的人产生共鸣。更广泛地说，摊销是指以固定的月度分期付款方式将利息和本金一起支付。尽管道德家们对自愿承担债务感到不安，但严格的基本项目分期付款计划的效果是使家庭在预算收入方面更加自觉，而不是更加不自觉。如果他们想呆在自己的家里，就必须每个月把钱留出来。为了发挥作用，这种支付系统需要有荣誉感的抵押贷款人和有道德责任感的客户群。

In 1890, the U.S. census estimated the private debt of the nation’s households to be eleven billion dollars. The superintendent of the census was sufficiently unnerved by the proof of America’s “debt-creating mania” that he pleaded with his fellow citizens to come “to their sober senses” and launch a new era of “retrenchment and debt-paying.” 18Although this plea may sound judgmental by contemporary standards, Tocqueville thought such moralizing the proper role of the public official. Government had the obligation, he reasoned, to “teach that wealth, fame, and power are the rewards of labor, that great success stands at the utmost range of long desires, and that there is nothing lasting but what is obtained by toil.” 19

1890 年，美国的人口普查估计全国家庭的私人债务为 110 亿美元。人口普查监督员对美国 “创造债务的狂热” 的证明感到非常不安，他恳求他的同胞们 “清醒地认识到” 并启动一个 “缩减和偿还债务” 的新时代。18尽管按照当代标准，这种恳求可能听起来很有判断力，但托克维尔认为这种道德说教是公共官员的恰当角色。他认为，政府有义务 “教导人们，财富、名声和权力是劳动的回报，巨大的成功就在长期欲望的最大范围内，除了通过劳动获得的东西，没有什么是持久的。” 19

Although Tocqueville acknowledged the role of the church in inspiring “a love of the future” and conceded that Americans “wish to be as well off as they can in this world without forgoing their chance of another,” 20he underestimated the power of the pulpit and the public opinion it generated. Christianity exercised a useful restraining influence throughout the nine­teenth century. “Debt is an inexhaustible fountain of dishonesty,” warned popular late-nineteenth-century evangelist Henry Ward Beecher in righteous indignation. “It has opened in the heart every fountain of iniquity; it has besoiled the conscience, it has tarnished the honor, it has made the man a deliberate student of knavery, a systematic practitioner of fraud.” 21This famed abolitionist had no more use for loan sharks than he did for slave traders, and he was one out of thousands preaching the same message.

尽管托克维尔承认教会在激发 “对未来的热爱” 方面的作用，并承认美国人 “希望在这个世界上尽可能过得好而不放弃另一个世界的机会。” 20他低估了讲坛的力量及其产生的公众意见。基督教在整个九到十世纪发挥了有益的抑制作用。“债务是取之不尽用之不竭的不诚实的源泉”，十九世纪末流行的传教士亨利·沃德·比彻义愤填膺地警告说。“它在人们心中打开了每一个不义之源；它玷污了良知，玷污了荣誉，它使人成为一个故意学习奴役的人，一个系统的欺诈者。” 21这位著名的废奴主义者对高利贷的利用不亚于对奴隶贩子的利用，而他是成千上万宣扬同一信息的人之一。

For all the inducements to indulge, most Americans managed to strike a balance between success in this world and access to the next. Artemus Ward, Abraham Lincoln’s favorite stand-up comic, wryly summed up the forces at war within the American soul. “Let us all be happy, and live within our means,” he joked, “even if we have to borrer money to do it with.” 22

对于所有放纵的诱因，大多数美国人设法在今世的成功和进入来世的机会之间取得平衡。亚伯拉罕·林肯最喜欢的相声演员阿特默斯·沃德（Artemus Ward）诙谐地总结了美国人灵魂中的战争力量。他开玩笑说 ：“让我们都快乐起来，量入为出，即使我们不得不用钱来做。” 22

eighteenCross of Gold 黄金十字架

THE ELECTION OF 1896 REPRESENTS THE MOST DRAMATIC PARTY REALIGNMENT in the history of American politics. The party of Jefferson, Jackson, and Grover Cleveland — hard-money men all — went soft. The transition was not an easy one. Said the party’s eventual nominee of the struggle, evoking the language of the Civil War, “Brother has been arrayed against brother, and father against son. The warmest ties of love and acquaintance and association have been disregarded.” 1

1896 年的选举代表了美国政治史上最引人注目的政党调整。杰斐逊、杰克逊和格罗弗·克利夫兰的政党 —— 所有的硬通货 —— 都变软了。这一转变并不容易。该党的最终被提名人在谈到这场斗争时说，他唤起了内战时期的语言 ：“兄弟与兄弟相残，父亲与儿子相残。最温暖的爱情、相识和联系的纽带被忽视了。” 1

The struggle centered not on war and peace or prohibition or segregation, all potentially hot topics, but on a single issue that could be summarized in a single word: gold. The insurgent soft-money forces, America’s debtor class, were rising up in righteous indignation against their creditors, the “few financial magnates who in a backroom corner the money of the world.” 2Standing in the way of the insurgents were the so-called Bourbon Democrats, who were alleged to do their financial masters’ bidding. What the insurgents demanded was nothing less than an abandonment of the gold standard. Said their thirty-six-year-old leader in the speech that would net him the party’s nomination, “You shall not press down upon the brow of labor this crown of thorns. You shall not crucify mankind upon a cross of gold.” 3

斗争的中心不是战争与和平、禁酒令或种族隔离这些潜在的热门话题，而是一个可以用一个词概括的问题 ：“黄金”。叛乱的软货币势力，即美国的债务人阶层，正在义愤填膺地反对他们的债权人，即，“少数在密室里把世界上的钱都藏起来的金融巨头”。2挡在起义者面前的是所谓的波旁民主党人，他们被指为他们的金融主人服务。叛乱者所要求的不外乎是放弃金本位。他们 36 岁的领袖在演讲中说，这将使他获得党的提名，“你们不能把这个荆棘的冠冕压在劳工的头上。你们不能把人类钉在黄金的十字架上。” 3

By this time the Republicans had already nominated William McKinley as their candidate for the presidency. But William Jennings Bryan, the “boy orator of the plains,” was savvy enough to know that he was facing a more formidable opponent than McKinley —— a more formidable opponent, for that matter, than the power broker behind McKinley, Mark Hanna. No, to win, Bryan would have to best the man whose power Hanna brokered, America’s most formidable banker ever and arguably the most powerful man in the world circa 1896, John Pierpont Morgan.

此时，共和党已经提名威廉·麦金利为其总统候选人。但是，威廉·詹宁斯·布莱恩，这个 “平原上的少年演说家”，有足够的智慧，知道他面对的是一个比麦金利更强大的对手 —— 比麦金利背后的权力经纪人马克·汉纳更强大的对手。不，要想获胜，布莱恩就必须战胜汉纳的掮客，即美国有史以来最强大的银行家，也可以说是 1896 年左右世界上最有权势的人，约翰·皮尔庞特·摩根。

The ascent of the house of Morgan gives a reassuring ecumenical coloring to the history of investment banking: they were the Protestants to the Medicis’ Catholics to the Rothschilds’ Jews. The Morgans, a term used here to include partners as well as family members, would also oversee, quite literally, the shift of the world’s financial power from London to New York. As with the Medicis and the Rothschilds, their story begins with a hardworking patriarch and reaches its ascendancy with a son.

摩根家族的崛起为投资银行的历史增添了令人欣慰的普世色彩：他们是美第奇家族的天主教徒和罗斯柴尔德家族的犹太人的新教徒。摩根家族，这个词在这里被用来包括合作伙伴和家庭成员，也将监督，相当程度上，世界的金融力量从伦敦转移到纽约。与美第奇家族和罗斯柴尔德家族一样，他们的故事从一个勤奋的族长开始，并通过一个儿子达到了登峰造极的目的。

In 1837, the year of the Panic, the year coincidentally that Pierpont was born, Baltimore merchant George Peabody (pronouncedPEE-buh-dee) moved to London. Already respected in international circles, Peabody opened a merchant house and began to do business. He traded in dry goods —— a catchall phrase for textiles, clothing, and the equally elusive “sundries” —— and financed other trades as well. Businesses like his were known as merchant banks, the progenitors of today’s investment banks.4Merchant bankers dealt exclusively with institutions and what we have come to call — isn’t there a better phrase? —— “high net-worth individuals.” They issued stocks and bonds, financed overseas trade, and brokered commodities among other services. Theirs was a world without teller windows or Christmas clubs or velvet rope lines in the lobby.

1837 年，也就是皮尔庞特出生的那一年，巴尔的摩商人乔治·皮博迪（发音为PEE-buh-dee）来到伦敦。皮博迪已经在国际圈子里受到尊重，他开了一家商行，开始做生意。他从事干货交易 —— 这是纺织品、服装和同样难以捉摸的 “杂物” 的总称 —— 同时也为其他行业提供资金。4商人银行家专门与机构和我们称之为 —— 难道没有更好的说法吗 —— “高净值个人” 打交道。他们发行股票和债券，为海外贸易提供资金，并在其他服务中为商品做中介。他们的世界没有出纳窗口，没有圣诞俱乐部，也没有大厅里的天鹅绒绳索队伍。

Not content to blend into London’s oaken woodwork, Peabody positioned himself as an American banker. This was risky. At the time Peabody was establishing himself, Dickens was writing home about America’s “gross deceits” and, yes, “defalcations,” and his was an opinion shared by many, if not most, London bankers. Defaults by various states on British loans were further tainting the British perspective on the American national government. When the Americans attempted to borrow from Britain in 1842, James de Rothschild sent its agents packing: “Tell them you have seen the man who is at the head of the finances of Europe, and he has told you that they cannot borrow a dollar, not a dollar.” 5

皮博迪并不满足于沉沦在伦敦，他将自己定位为美国银行家。这是有风险的。在皮博迪建立自己的时候，狄更斯正在写关于美国的 “严重欺诈”，是的，“欺诈”，他的观点得到了许多，甚至是大多数伦敦银行家的认同。各州对英国贷款的违约行为进一步玷污了英国人对美国国家政府的看法。当美国人在 1842 年试图向英国借款时，詹姆斯·德·罗斯柴尔德将其代理人打发走。“告诉他们，你已经见到了掌管欧洲财政的人，他告诉你，他们借不到一美元，一美元也借不到。” 5

Merchant bankers developed their reputations by delivering on the securities they sponsored. When officials in Peabody’s native Maryland defaulted on their obligation, they took Peabody’s credibility down with them. Friends shunned him. The best clubs blackballed him. “You and I will, I trust, see that happy day,” he wrote a fellow citizen, “when as formerly, we can own ourselves Americans in Europe, without a blush for the character of our country.” 6

商业银行家通过兑现他们所担保的证券来发展他们的声誉。当皮博迪的家乡马里兰州的官员不履行其义务时，他们把皮博迪的信誉也带坏了。朋友们避开了他。最好的俱乐部把他拉黑了。“我相信，你和我都会看到那幸福的一天”，他给一位同胞写道，“那时，我们可以像以前一样，在欧洲拥有自己的美国人，而不会为我们国家的性格感到脸红。” 6

Given the consequences for them — personally as well as for the body politic — if debts went unpaid, bankers have had a history of doing what they had to in order to set things straight. What Peabody and his partners at Barings did was to sponsor an image campaign back in Maryland on behalf of debt resumption. They were not above bribing influential citizens, Senator Daniel Webster fore­most among them, to endorse their campaign. “Your payment to Mr. Webster would not appear very well if it should get out,” 7wrote a senior Barings official to his American bagman in something of an understatement. Happily, the strategy worked. Interest payments were resumed, and the depreciated bonds Peabody had himself bought regained their value. He made a small fortune in the process and restored his reputation.
