考虑到如果债务得不到偿还对他们 —— 个人以及政治体 —— 的影响，银行家们历来都会做他们必须做的事情，以使事情得到纠正。皮博迪和他在霸菱公司的合伙人所做的是，在马里兰州为恢复债务赞助了一场形象宣传。他们不惜贿赂有影响力的公民，其中最重要的是参议员丹尼尔·韦伯斯特，以支持他们的运动。“你给韦伯斯特先生的钱如果传出去，就会显得很不光彩”，7一位霸菱公司的高级官员给他的美国包商写道，说得很轻巧。令人高兴的是，这一策略奏效了。利息支付恢复了，皮博迪自己买的贬值的债券也恢复了价值。他在这个过程中发了一笔小财，并恢复了他的声誉。

A bachelor with a predilection for prostitutes, Peabody had no legitimate heirs. As he grew older and less well, he began to cast about for a partner to carry on his business. Junius Spencer Morgan, a forty-year-old banker from Boston, came highly recommended. When he moved to England in 1854, Morgan took along his wife and his sickly adolescent son, John Pierpont. Peabody was a pain to work with, but the down-the-road payoff was sufficiently promising that Junius kept his gripes to himself. The Crimean War had driven up wheat prices, and the railroads that shipped the wheat were sharing in the good times. For the Brits who wanted to invest in America — at least a billion dollars had been pumped into railroads already — Peabody and Morgan were the go-to guys.8

皮博迪是一个偏爱妓女的单身汉，没有合法的继承人。随着他年龄的增长和身体状况的恶化，他开始四处寻找合作伙伴来继承他的事业。来自波士顿的 40 岁银行家朱尼厄斯·斯宾塞·摩根得到了强烈的推荐。1854 年移居英国时，摩根带着他的妻子和处于青春期的患病儿子约翰·皮尔庞特。皮亚博迪是个麻烦的人，但下一步的回报是很有希望的，朱尼厄斯把他的怨言藏在心里。克里米亚战争推动了小麦价格的上涨，而运输小麦的铁路公司也分享了这个好时光。对于想在美国投资的英国人来说 —— 至少已经有 10 亿美元被注入铁路 —— 皮博迪和摩根是首选。8

All good things come to an end, including, of course, the Crimean War. Wheat prices collapsed as surely as they had swelled. This set off a general panic in 1857. Gold payments out of New York banks were suspended, and Peabody found himself desperately overexposed. Only an emergency credit line of 800,000 pounds from the Bank of England saved the firm from tanking. This brush with disaster rattled Junius and his twenty-year-old son Pierpont, then working as an intern on Wall Street. “Let what you now witness make an impression not to be eradicated,” wrote the father to the son, one of many such missives, “slow & sure should be the motto of every young man.” 9

一切美好的事物都会结束，当然也包括克里米亚战争。小麦价格崩溃了，就像它们膨胀了一样。这引发了 1857 年的普遍恐慌。纽约银行的黄金支付被暂停，皮博迪发现自己已经绝望地过度暴露于风险之中了。只有英格兰银行提供的 80 万英镑的紧急信贷额度使公司免于破产。这次与灾难的擦肩而过使朱尼厄斯和他 20 岁的儿子皮尔庞特感到震惊，他当时在华尔街做实习生。“让你现在看到的东西留下不可磨灭的印象”，父亲给儿子写道，这是许多这样的信中的一封，“缓慢与确定（slow & sure）应该是每个年轻人的座右铭。” 9

For the next twelve years, the now healthy, strapping, confident Pierpont represented his father’s interests on Wall Street. Peabody had retired in 1864, and the firm now bore the name of J. S. Morgan & Co. In 1869, Pierpont made a move that set him apart from his peers and insinuated him into the American power structure in a way that no banker had been before. The prize at stake was of itself small potatoes, the 143-mile Albany & Susquehanna Railroad.10For hardball financier Jay Gould, however, the railroad represented a link in a chain that he was trying to hammer together. When the railroad’s founder, Joseph Ramsey, resisted his overture to buy it, Gould, himself just a year older than Pierpont, attempted a hostile takeover.

在接下来的 12 年里，现在健康、魁梧、自信的皮尔庞特在华尔街代表他父亲的利益。皮埃博迪于 1864 年退休，公司现在的名称是 J.S. 摩根公司。1869 年，皮尔庞特采取了一项行动，使他从同龄人中脱颖而出，并以一种以前没有银行家的方式进入美国的权力结构。所涉及的奖品本身就是小菜一碟，即 143 英里长的阿尔巴尼和苏斯奎汉纳铁路。10然而，对于强硬的金融家杰伊·古尔德来说，这条铁路是他试图敲定的一个链条上的一个环节。当铁路公司的创始人约瑟夫·拉姆齐（Joseph Ramsey）抵制他的收购提议时，比皮尔庞特仅大一岁的古尔德试图进行敌意收购。

In 1869, hostile did not mean “your lawyers yell at our lawyers” as it does today. Hostile meant recruiting an armed posse of 800 thugs off the streets of New York and shipping them upstate to do battle with Ramsey’s army of 450 hardened country boys. The battle climaxed with a literal head-on collision between the trains of the respective forces and a pitched battle in which at least ten people were shot, the Ramsey forces prevailing.

在 1869 年，敌对并不像今天这样意味着 “你们的律师对我们的律师大喊大叫”。敌对意味着从纽约街头招募 800 名暴徒的武装队伍，并将他们运到北部与拉姆齐的 450 名顽强的乡村男孩的军队作战。这场战斗的高潮是各自部队的火车迎面相撞，并发生了一场激烈的战斗，至少有 10 人被枪杀，拉姆齐的部队取得了胜利。

Pierpont did not play this way. He came in after the bones were set and the dead buried, bought six hundred shares of the railroad for his New York firm, got Ramsey his job back as president, and, as reward, asked only for a seat on the board of directors. At the time, this was a novel move. Bankers did not sit on boards. But as Pierpont realized, when you sit on the board, no one is going to take your business away.

皮尔庞特并没有这样玩。他在尸骨无存、死者入土为安之后，为他的纽约公司购买了六百股铁路股份，为拉姆齐找回了总裁的职位，作为回报，他只要求在董事会中占有一席之地。在当时，这是一个新举措。银行家是不参加董事会的。但正如皮尔庞特所意识到的，当你坐在董事会上时，没有人会抢走你的生意。

While his father remained in England, Pierpont continued to build the American end of the business. A devout Episcopalian and dogged moralist, he eschewed idleness, extravagance, and gambling. “Among robber barons,” writes Morgan biographer Ron Chernow, “he was unique in suffering an excess of morality.” 11His moral restraint served him well in 1873. Financier Jay Cooke, who had made his fortune with one hand in the government’s pocket, overreached on a railroad deal and precipitated the Panic of 1873. Drexel, Morgan — the name of Pierpont’s group — was secure enough to take advantage of the failures that followed. “I don’t think there is another concern in the country [that] can begin to show such a result,” 12wrote Pierpont to his father about the more than one million dollars in profit the firm pocketed in that panicky year.

当他的父亲留在英国时，皮尔庞特继续建立美国端的业务。作为一个虔诚的圣公会教徒和坚定的道德家，他摒弃了游手好闲、挥霍无度和赌博行为。摩根传记作者罗恩·切尔诺（Ron Chernow）写道 ：“在强盗大亨中，他是唯一遭受道德过剩的人。” 11他的道德克制在 1873 年对他很有用。金融家杰伊·库克（Jay Cooke）一手托着政府的口袋发了财，他在一笔铁路交易上做得太过火了，引发了 1873 年的恐慌。德雷克塞尔、摩根 —— 皮尔庞特集团的名称 —— 足够安全，可以利用随后的失败。“我不认为在这个国家还有其他的企业可以开始显示这样的结果”，12皮尔庞特给他父亲写道，在那恐慌的一年里，公司的利润超过了一百万美元。

Over the next twenty years, with Cooke out of the way, Pierpont made the name J. P. Morgan synonymous with wealth and power. Fond as he was of moral order, he proceeded to “morganize” one business after another, particularly the railroads. When a mismanaged railway fell into receivership, he would step in on behalf of its investors, often British, streamline the business, reorganize it, and transfer control to himself. “In reorganizing railways,” observes Chernow, “[Morgan] ascended to a new plateau of power, beyond what any other private businessman had yet achieved.” 13

在接下来的 20 年里，随着库克的退出，皮尔庞特使 J.P. 摩根这个名字成为财富和权力的代名词。由于他喜欢道德秩序，他开始将一个又一个企业 “摩根化”，特别是铁路。当一条管理不善的铁路陷入破产管理时，他将代表其投资者（通常是英国人）出面，精简业务，进行重组，并将控制权移交给自己。“在重组铁路的过程中”，切尔诺说，“摩根登上了权力的新高峰，超越了任何其他私人商人所取得的成就。” 13

When panic struck again in 1893, the resulting failures opened up a host of new power opportunities, including the rescue of a floundering new high-tech outfit called General Electric. The panic would also offer Morgan a different kind of opportunity, the grandest one of his career. In the way of background, the United States had resumed the gold standard in 1879. Despite widespread fears of a liquidity crisis, the 1880s proved to be arguably the most productive decade in American history.14While prices fell, wages soared. This resulted in an increase in savings and capital formation, which in turn fed the nation’s hunger to industrialize. Hard-money advocates may have resented the National Banking Acts (passed during the Civil War and left in place), but otherwise the 1880s were as close as America ever got to alaissez-faireeconomy.15The Democrats who accused George W. Bush of running alaissez-faireshop would have amused the critics of a real free-market champion like Democrat Grover Cleveland.

当恐慌在 1893 年再次袭来时，由此产生的失败开辟了一系列新的权力机会，包括拯救一个陷入困境的新高科技企业 —— 通用电气。恐慌还为摩根提供了一个不同的机会，这是他职业生涯中最伟大的一次。在背景方面，美国在 1879 年恢复了金本位制。尽管人们普遍担心会出现流动性危机，但十九世纪 80 年代被证明是美国历史上最富有成效的十年。14虽然价格下跌，但工资却飙升。这导致了储蓄和资本形成的增加，这反过来又满足了国家对工业化的渴求。硬通货倡导者可能对《国家银行法》（在内战期间通过并保留下来）感到不满，但除此之外，1880 年代是美国最接近 “自由放任” 经济的时期。 15那些指责小布什经营 “自由放任” 商店的民主党人，会让像民主党人格罗弗·克利夫兰这样的真正自由市场冠军的批评者感到高兴。

In 1890, during the gap in Cleveland’s split presidency, the nation’s soft-money party, the Republicans, decided to muck with success — three times. First, they passed the Sherman Silver Purchase Act, whose effect was to put America back on a bimetallic standard, a sure way to make “Gresham” a household word once again. Second, they passed the McKinley Tariff Act of 1890, which hiked the price of imports and reawakened inflation. And third, the New York subtreasury began to settle accounts with bank notes instead of gold. The cheapening of America’s money alarmed America’s creditors abroad. Still smarting from the anti-Americanism he had experienced as a teen in England, and wanting to preserve the nation’s honor, Morgan applied enough pressure to get the Silver Act repealed in 1893.

1890 年，在克利夫兰分任总统的间隙，国家的软货币党，即共和党，决定与成功过不去 —— 三次。首先，他们通过了《谢尔曼白银购买法》，其效果是将美国重新置于双金属标准之上，这无疑使 “格雷欣” 再次成为一个家喻户晓的词。第二，他们通过了 1890 年的《麦金利关税法》，提高了进口价格，重新唤醒了通货膨胀。第三，纽约副财政局开始用纸币而不是黄金结算。美国货币的廉价化使美国的海外债权人感到震惊。摩根仍然对他十几岁时在英国经历的反美主义耿耿于怀，并希望维护国家的荣誉，他施加了足够的压力，使白银法案在 1893 年被废除。

The indebted farmers of the West and South had no use for the tariff, but they welcomed the inflation that came with a cheapened currency. This they saw as the best way to balance their books with the big-city bankers, about as welcome in their world as boll weevils. So deep was the hostility that several Western states outlawed bankers, and Texas banned them altogether. The contempt for Wall Street only heightened with the Panic of 1893, as it has after every panic, and the farmers began to militate for a fresh supply of cheap currency. TheAtlanta Constitutionpreached, “The people of this country, outside the hotbeds of goldbuggery and Shylockism, don’t care how soon gold payments are suspended.” 16

西部和南部负债累累的农民对关税没有用处，但他们欢迎随着货币贬值而来的通货膨胀。他们认为这是与大城市银行家平衡账目的最佳方式，在他们的世界里，银行家就像棉铃虫一样受欢迎。这种敌意如此之深，以至于西部的几个州宣布银行家为非法，而德克萨斯州则完全禁止他们。对华尔街的蔑视随着 1893 年的恐慌而加剧，就像每一次恐慌之后一样，农民们开始为新的廉价货币供应而奋斗。《亚特兰大宪法》宣扬 ：“在黄金走私和夏洛克主义的温床之外，这个国家的人民并不关心黄金支付多久会中止。” 16

As theConstitutionimplied, though admittedly without much tact, Jews had made their presence felt on Wall Street. Many of them had begun, like Nathan Rothschild, as dry-goods merchants. Among them were the German-Jewish founding fathers like the Lehmans in Alabama, Lazard in New Orleans, Kuhn and Loeb in Cincinnati, and Goldman in Pennsylvania.17By the turn of the century, Wall Street had become culturally bipolar, with Kuhn Loeb and the Jews occupying one pole and J. P. Morgan and the WASPs the other.

正如《宪法》暗示的那样，虽然承认没有什么技巧，但犹太人已经在华尔街感受到了他们的存在。他们中的许多人像内森·罗斯柴尔德一样，开始是干货商人。他们中的德裔犹太创始人，如阿拉巴马州的雷曼家族、新奥尔良的拉扎德、辛辛那提的库恩和勒布，以及宾夕法尼亚州的高德曼。 17在世纪之交，华尔街已经成为文化上的两极，库恩·勒布和犹太人占据了一极，J·P·摩根和 WASP（世界和平组织）则是另一极。

Despite his own distaste for certain Jewish banking houses, Morgan may have defused a good deal of the populist anti-Semitism by emerging as the public face of the gold standard.

尽管摩根自己对某些犹太银行家很反感，但他作为金本位制的公众形象出现，可能已经化解了大量的民粹主义反犹太主义。

In 1895, the United States found itself, in Morgan’s words, “on the brink of the abyss of financial chaos.” 18For a variety of reasons, the United States Treasury was hemorrhaging gold. The government was weeks away from being unable to honor its debts. The one man in the world who could save the gold standard took a train down to Washington and, without invitation, demanded to see the president, Grover Cleveland. When Cleveland obliged him, Morgan laid out an ambitious scheme in which the Morgan and Rothschild houses would collaborate to secure 3.5 million ounces of gold, half or more from Europe, and exchange it for roughly sixty-five million dollars’ worth of thirty-year gold bonds.

1895 年，美国发现自己，用摩根的话说，“处于金融混乱的深渊边缘”。18由于各种原因，美国财政部正在大量流失黄金。政府离无力偿还债务还有几周时间。世界上唯一能拯救金本位制的人坐火车到了华盛顿，在没有邀请的情况下，要求见总统格罗弗·克利夫兰。当克利夫兰答应他时，摩根提出了一个雄心勃勃的计划，摩根和罗斯柴尔德家族将合作获得 350 万盎司的黄金，其中一半或更多来自欧洲，并将其换成价值约 6,500 万美元的 30 年期黄金债券。

When the deal went down, the financial markets responded enthusiastically. The hinterlands, however, were manifestly less pleased. The populists did not know why America needed a gold standard in the first place. To them Cleveland was little more than a tool “of Jewish bankers and British gold.” 19Even the New YorkWorld, obviously indifferent to New York’s changing demographics, picked up on the anti-Semitism, calling Morgan’s syndicate a pack of “bloodsucking Jews and aliens.” 20Not above a little race-baiting himself, albeit with a literary tone, William Jennings Bryan asked the clerk of the House to read aloud Shylock’s bond fromThe Merchant of Venice.21In Bryan’s cross of gold analogy, it was Morgan who played the role of Pontius Pilate. His unspoken sin was to have reminded his fellow citizens that America was still a debtor nation.

当交易进行时，金融市场反应热烈。然而，内陆地区显然不那么高兴。民粹主义者不知道为什么美国首先需要一个金本位。对他们来说，克利夫兰只不过是 “犹太银行家和英国黄金的工具”。19甚至纽约的《世界》，显然对纽约的人口结构变化无动于衷，捡起了反犹太主义，称摩根的集团是一群 “吸血的犹太人和外星人”。20威廉·詹宁斯·布莱恩(William Jennings Bryan)也不甘示弱，要求众议院的书记员大声朗读《威尼斯商人》中夏洛克的债券。 21在布莱恩的黄金十字架比喻中，扮演本丢·彼拉多角色的是摩根。他的无言之罪是提醒他的同胞，美国仍然是一个债务国。

A Republican, Morgan used his considerable influence to steer the Republicans to the gold standard. At the Republican convention in June 1896, Morgan’s man at the convention, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, laid out the game plan for Hanna and McKinley: stick to gold, stop talking about greenbacks and silver, and the Morgan forces will work for you; abandon gold, and the Morgans will work against you.22Morgan, they knew, had backed Cleveland. They would not secure his support simply by appealing to his Republicanism. With the Democrats headed in the opposite direction, Hanna and McKinley saw the political value in hewing to the Morgan line.

作为一名共和党人，摩根利用他相当大的影响力，引导共和党人采用金本位制。在 1896 年 6 月的共和党大会上，摩根在大会上的人，马萨诸塞州的参议员亨利·卡伯特·洛奇，为汉纳和麦金利制定了游戏计划：坚持使用黄金，停止谈论绿钞和白银，摩根的力量将为你工作；放弃黄金，摩根人将反对你。 22他们知道，摩根已经支持克利夫兰。他们不会仅仅通过呼吁他的共和主义来获得他的支持。随着民主党人向相反的方向发展，汉纳和麦金利看到了坚持摩根路线的政治价值。

On the other side of the aisle, the Panic of 1893 had made Cleveland’s bid for renomination unlikely, and his blessing of the Rothschild-Morgan deal had made it unthinkable. Economic downturns, no matter their cause, have always stirred the American people to righteous wrath, and in this case the populists were quick to exploit it. Bryan, however, brought something else to the party — his Midwest pietism. For the last generation, the Democrats had been thelaissez-faireparty, both socially and culturally. In Cleveland’s first campaign, 1884, the Republicans had notoriously identified his party with “rum, Romanism, and rebellion.” In 1896, under Bryan, the Democrats pulled a political one-eighty. They shifted, in today’s terminology, from the economic right to the left and from the cultural left to the right. To say the least, this confused the base.

在过道的另一边，1893 年的大恐慌使克利夫兰不可能竞选连任，而他对罗斯柴尔德·摩根交易的祝福又使其无法想象。经济衰退，无论其原因如何，总是会激起美国人民的义愤，在这种情况下，民粹主义者很快就利用了这一点。然而，布莱恩给该党带来了其他东西 —— 他的中西部虔诚主义。在过去的一代中，民主党在社会和文化方面都是 “自由放任” 党。在克利夫兰的第一次竞选中，即 1884 年，共和党人臭名昭著地将他的政党与 “朗姆酒、罗马教和叛乱” 联系起来。1896 年，在布莱恩的领导下，民主党在政治上取得了胜利。用今天的术语来说，他们从经济右派转向左派，从文化左派转向右派。至少可以这么说，这让基层民众感到困惑。

The electoral map dramatically changed coloration from 1892 to 1896. In 1892 Cleveland had won most of the big industrial states with heavy Catholic populations, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Illinois. He also swept the South — Southerners would vote for a “yaller dog” before they would vote for a Republican — and beat Benjamin Harrison, the incumbent Republican. In 1896, Bryan held the South but McKinley carried New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Illinois, as well as every contiguous state in an arc from North Dakota to Maine, and won the election.23In subsequent elections, both parties moved to a mushy progressive center, and the difference between them blurred. This may account for the falloff in voter turnout as well. Too much echo, not enough choice.

从 1892 年到 1896 年，选举地图的色彩发生了巨大的变化。1892 年，克利夫兰赢得了大多数天主教人口众多的工业大州，包括纽约、新泽西、康涅狄格和伊利诺伊。他还横扫了南方 —— 南方人在投票给共和党人之前会先投票给 “雅乐狗” —— 并击败了现任的共和党人本杰明-哈里森。在 1896 年，布莱恩守住了南方，但麦金利在纽约、新泽西、康涅狄格和伊利诺伊，以及从北达科他州到缅因州的弧形范围内的每一个毗连州，都赢得了选举。23在随后的选举中，两党都向一个模糊的进步中心移动，它们之间的差异变得模糊。这可能也是选民投票率下降的原因。太多的回声，没有足够的选择。

In the seventy-five years between the fall of the Second Bank of the United States and the rise of the Federal Reserve, J. P. Morgan was the closest thing America had to a central banker. Unlike official central bankers, however, Morgan had his own chips on the table, and in 1907, he got to play his last big hand before the Feds nationalized the game.24In October of that year, while attending the Episcopal convention in Virginia, the market started wobbling.

在美国第二银行倒台和美联储崛起的七十五年间，J.P. 摩根是美国最接近中央银行家的人。然而，与官方中央银行家不同的是，摩根有自己的筹码，在 1907 年，他在美联储将游戏国有化之前，有机会玩了最后一手大牌。24当年 10 月，在弗吉尼亚州参加圣公会会议时，市场开始摇摆不定。

Seventy years old and semiretired, Morgan boarded his private railroad car and headed back to the Street.

七十岁、半退休的摩根登上了他的私人铁路车厢，回到了大街上。

As in every such occasion, there are a thousand reasons offered as to why the markets crashed and rarely ever a consensus. Some laid the blame on President Theodore Roosevelt. Teddy had, in fact, kept the financiers off balance, Morgan included, with his frequent criticism of them as “great male­factors of wealth” and his threats to check their power. More honest than most pols, he would later concede that his “assaults and exposures” may have helped precipitate the panic.

就像在每一个这样的场合，人们对市场崩溃的原因有一千个理由，但很少有共识。一些人把责任归咎于西奥多·罗斯福总统。事实上，泰迪经常批评金融家是 “巨大的财富因素”，并威胁要遏制他们的权力，从而使金融家们失去了平衡，包括摩根。他比大多数政治家更诚实，他后来承认，他的 “攻击和暴露” 可能有助于催生恐慌。

The trust companies deserved their share of the blame as well. These companies managed the trust accounts — wills, estates, and the like — that banks at that time could not. Though usually conservative, the more adventurous had found the law’s loopholes and begun to speculate. As happens, especially with amateurs, the speculators failed to anticipate certain risks — in this case, for instance, a collapse in copper shares — and the tightly coupled Wall Street institutions began to derail.

信托公司也应受到谴责。这些公司管理着当时银行无法管理的信托账户 —— 遗嘱、遗产和类似物品。虽然通常很保守，但更多的冒险者发现了法律的漏洞，并开始进行投机。正如所发生的那样，特别是对业余爱好者而言，投机者未能预见到某些风险 —— 例如，在这种情况下，铜股的崩溃 —— 而紧密结合的华尔街机构开始脱轨。

Enter J. Pierpont Morgan stage right. What he did over the next few weeks has become the stuff of legend. He literally strode Wall Street like a colossus, “the embodiment of power and purpose,” said his awestruck son-in-law, Herbert Saterlee. “The thing that made his progress different from that of all the other people was that he did not dodge or walk in or out, or halt or slacken his pace. He simply barged along, as if he had been the only man going down Nassau Street hill past the subtreasury.” Morgan summoned bankers, trust presidents, industrialists, government officials, and when he called, they came. When he demanded money to stem the bleeding in the markets, they provided it. “Within two weeks,” writes Chernow, “he saved several trust companies and a leading brokerage house, bailed out New York City, and rescued the Stock Exchange.” 25

进入 J.P 摩根的舞台。在接下来的几周里，他的所作所为已经成为传奇的内容。他就像一个巨人一样在华尔街漫步，“是权力和目的的化身”，他的女婿赫伯特·萨特利惊讶地说。“使他的进展与所有其他人不同的是，他没有躲避，没有走进或走出，也没有停顿或放慢步伐。他只是一路狂奔，仿佛只有他一个人从拿骚街的山上经过副库房。” 摩根召集了银行家、信托公司总裁、工业家、政府官员，他一叫，他们就来了。当他需要钱来阻止市场上的出血时，他们就提供了。“在两周内”，切尔诺写道，“他拯救了几家信托公司和一家领先的经纪公司，拯救了纽约市，并拯救了证券交易所。” 25

Even the progressives of the era — Woodrow Wilson and Theodore Roosevelt among them — were awed by the job that Morgan had done. His efforts, however, got them to wondering how much better a central bank could do the same. With a properly constituted “Federal Reserve,” they reckoned, the nation might never experience a market crash again.

即使是那个时代的进步人士 —— 伍德罗·威尔逊和西奥多·罗斯福也对摩根所做的工作感到震惊。然而，他的努力让他们开始思考，一个中央银行能做得多好。他们认为，如果有一个适当的 “联邦储备”，国家可能永远不会再经历市场崩溃。

nineteenWizard of Finance 金融魔法师

IF THERE WAS ANY ONE EVENT THAT TRIGGGGERED THE PANIC OF 1907, it was an attempt to corner the stock of United Copper, an attempt that failed rather spectacularly. Among the investors in that would-be corner was one Charles W. Morse. A classic Wall Street wheeler-dealer, Morse had succeeded in cornering the New York ice market a decade earlier — with a little help from Tammany Hall — and earned himself the sobriquet “the Ice King.” 1

如果说有什么事件引发了 1907 年的恐慌，那就是有人试图垄断联合铜业的股票，这种尝试的失败相当惊人。在这一企图的投资者中，有一个叫查尔斯·W·莫尔斯的人。作为一个典型的华尔街商人，莫尔斯在十年前成功地垄断了纽约的冰块市场 —— 在坦慕尼厅的帮助下 —— 并为自己赢得了 “冰王” 的美誉。1

On the heels of the panic, the political class, as it typically does, went looking for scoundrels to prosecute. Morse fit the bill as well as anyone. He was promptly convicted of bank fraud and sentenced to fifteen years in a federal penitentiary in Atlanta. He arrived in January 1910. Soon after checking in, he met another new arrival, a charming and ambitious wisp of an Italian immigrant. With impeccable old-world manners and only the slightest accent, the tiny Italian captivated Morse and was in turn captivated by him. Within ten years of their prison rendezvous, Morse’s advice and support would inspire his Italian friend to earn his own millions as well as the title “the wizard of finance.”

在恐慌过后，政治阶层像往常一样，去寻找可以起诉的恶棍。莫尔斯和其他人一样符合这个条件。他很快就被判定犯有银行欺诈罪，并被判处在亚特兰大的联邦监狱服刑 15 年。他于 1910 年 1 月抵达。入住后不久，他遇到了另一个新来的人，一个迷人的、雄心勃勃的意大利移民的一缕。这个小小的意大利人有着无可挑剔的旧世界的礼仪和最轻微的口音，吸引了莫尔斯，反过来也被他吸引了。在他们的监狱约会后的十年内，莫尔斯的建议和支持将激励他的意大利朋友赢得他自己的数百万美元，以及 “金融魔法师” 的称号。

The reader who guesses that the wizard in question was Amadeo Giannini guesses wrong. In 1910, Giannini was in San Francisco happily growing the Bank of Italy according to the rules. He had founded the bank six years earlier in a building whose previous tenant had been a saloon. Immediately after the earthquake in 1906, Giannini had cleverly hauled the bank’s vault to his home in then rural San Mateo. When a subsequent fire consumed most of San Francisco’s major banks, he was uniquely positioned to meet the city’s immediate liquidity needs — other than water — and earned a solid reputation in the process. In 1928, Giannini merged his expanding business with a Los Angeles bank and kept its rather grandiose name, Bank of America.

猜测这个的魔法师是阿马迪奥·贾尼尼的读者猜错了。1910 年，詹尼尼在旧金山愉快地按照规则发展着意大利银行。六年前，他在一栋大楼里创办了这家银行，而这栋大楼的前租户是一家沙龙。1906 年地震发生后，詹尼尼立即巧妙地将银行的金库拖到了他在当时圣马刁农村的家中。当随后的一场大火吞噬了旧金山的大多数主要银行时，他以独特的方式满足了该市除水以外的即时流动性需求，并在此过程中赢得了良好的声誉。1928 年，吉安尼将其不断扩大的业务与洛杉矶的一家银行合并，并保留了其相当宏伟的名字 —— 美国银行。

Giannini is the kind of financier that cities name schools after. San Francisco’s Giannini Middle School is testament to the same. No one, however, has named a school after Morse’s Atlanta friend, but his name endures nonetheless. One hears it much more than Giannini. In fact, one has heard the wizard’s name more in the last year or two than in the decade or two prior. That name, of course, is Ponzi.

吉安尼是那种城市以学校命名的金融家。旧金山的吉安尼尼中学就是一个证明。然而，没有人以莫尔斯的亚特兰大朋友的名字来命名学校，但他的名字却经久不衰。人们听到这个名字的次数比詹尼尼多得多。事实上，在过去的一两年里，人们听到这个巫师的名字要比之前的一二十年里多。当然，这个名字是庞氏。

In 1910, twenty-eight-year-old Charles Ponzi had boarded a southbound train from Montreal with five undocumented Italian immigrants. Just seventeen days earlier, Ponzi had been released from a Montreal prison, where he had served two years for forging a check. Fortune still was not smiling on Ponzi. He and his homeboys, hisgoombahs—— an American corruption ofcompaorcompare—— got busted together crossing into the U.S. The Italians testified against Ponzi, the alleged “coyote,” and were set free. Ponzi was sent to Atlanta for his fateful meeting with Morse.2

1910 年，28 岁的查尔斯·庞氏与五名无证意大利移民一起登上了从蒙特利尔南下的火车。就在 17 天前，庞兹从蒙特利尔监狱获释，他在那里因伪造支票而服刑两年。财富仍然没有向庞氏微笑。他和他的同乡，他的 goombahs —— 雇员，一种美国的 compa 或 compare 的变形 —— 一起在进入美国时被逮捕。2

Not inclined to physical work, Ponzi had grown up in an affluent Italian household, spoke several languages, and headed off to America only after squandering all his money at the gaming tables while at college in Rome. In America, he would redeem himself, or so he convinced his indulgent mother.3In 1912, however, when released from the federal pen in Atlanta, redemption did not seem near at hand.

不喜欢体力劳动的庞氏在一个富裕的意大利家庭中长大，会说几种语言，在罗马上大学时在赌桌上挥霍完所有的钱后才去了美国。31912 年，当他从亚特兰大的联邦监狱释放时，赎罪似乎并不近在眼前。

While bouncing around the South, looking for some quick way to make a fortune, Ponzi heard of a young woman desperately in need of skin grafts. A sentimentalist, he volunteered seventy-two square inches of his own skin to help patch her up. The account of his sacrifice made the local paper, and Ponzi sent a clipping of it to the warden back in Atlanta.4Though emotionally rewarding, his selfless act was not nearly redemptive enough, at least not on the terms that this lapsed Catholic hoped to be redeemed.

当庞氏在南方四处奔波，寻找一些快速发财的方法时，他听说一位年轻女子急需植皮。作为一个多愁善感的人，他自愿拿出自己 72 平方英寸的皮肤来帮助她包扎。他的牺牲记述上了当地报纸，庞齐把剪报寄给了亚特兰大的典狱长。4虽然在情感上得到了回报，但他的无私行为还不够赎罪，至少没有达到这位失足的基督徒希望得到的赎罪条件。

In 1917, after thirteen unproductive years in North America, Ponzi made his way back to his port of entry, Boston. A potential job as a clerk at an import-export firm attracted him. What held him in Boston was a woman he met soon after arriving. Ponzi married his American rose, Rose Maria Gnecco, within a year of their first meeting.5Without trying, she turned this capricious dreamer into a committed schemer, one determined to support her in the style he thought she deserved.

1917 年，在北美呆了 13 年后，庞氏回到了他的入境口岸波士顿。一家进出口公司的一份潜在的文员工作吸引了他。让他留在波士顿的是他在抵达后不久遇到的一个女人。庞氏与他的美国玫瑰，罗丝·玛丽亚·格内科(Rose Maria Gnecco)，在他们第一次见面之后的一年内结婚了。5无需努力，她就把这个任性的梦想家变成了一个坚定的阴谋家，一个决心以他认为她应得的方式支持她。

Ponzi found his inspiration in, of all places, his stamp collection. In 1906, the U.S. and some sixty-two other countries had gathered in Rome to find a hassle-free way to send mail across international borders. The solution they hit upon was built upon a standard note that could be redeemed for stamps in any participating country. Ponzi thought its very name — the International Reply Coupon — had marketing gravitas.

苦苦思索之后，庞氏找到了他的灵感，他的邮票收藏。1906 年，美国和其他约 62 个国家聚集在罗马，寻找一种跨越国际边界发送邮件的无障碍方式。他们找到的解决方案是建立在一种标准纸币上，可以在任何参与国兑换邮票。庞齐认为它的名字 —— 国际回邮券 —— 具有营销的意义。

Before the Great War, exchanging the coupon for stamps was equitable and straightforward. After the war, however, currency devaluation meant that a dollar could buy three times as many coupons in Italy as it could in the United States. With all of the other unsettled business after the war, no one had yet recalibrated the coupons. There was, of course, one minor draw­back to Ponzi’s scheme: although he could convert coupons to stamps, he could see no feasible way to convert either stamps or coupons to cash. That problem he put off thinking about. He was always stronger on dreams than details in any case.

在大战之前，用邮票兑换优惠券是公平而直接的。然而，战后，货币贬值意味着一美元在意大利可以买到比美国多三倍的邮票。由于战后所有其他未解决的事务，还没有人对邮票进行重新校准。当然，庞齐的计划有一个小的缺点：尽管他可以将优惠券转换成邮票，但他看不到将邮票或优惠券转换成现金的可行方法。这个问题他没有去想。在任何情况下，他的梦想总是比细节更重要。

In early December 1919, Ponzi stopped in to see pawnbroker Max Rosenberg at Uncle Ned’s Loan Shop. There he swapped some of Rose’s rings for cash to start his business. He tried to entice Rosenberg into investing, but Rosenberg had grown too used to holding collateral in hand.6He was not about to swap gold for paper.

1919 年 12 月初，庞兹在内德叔叔的贷款商店停下来见典当商马克斯·罗森伯格。在那里，他用罗斯的一些戒指换取了现金，以开始他的生意。他试图引诱罗森伯格进行投资，但罗森伯格已经太习惯于手握抵押品了。6他不打算用黄金换纸。

In the middle of December, Ponzi paid the state the fifty cents necessary to register the name of his new enterprise, and that same day the Securities Exchange Company opened for business in a musty upstairs office above School Street in downtown Boston. Before the new year was through, this cash-strapped son of Italy would make and lose millions.

12 月中旬，庞兹向州政府支付了注册其新企业名称所需的 50 美分，同一天，证券交易公司在波士顿市中心学校街楼上的一间发霉的办公室开业。在新的一年结束之前，这个现金紧张的意大利之子将赚取和失去数百万美元。

It all started slowly. In the first month, Ponzi had persuaded only eighteen people to invest, and they gave him all of $1,770 in cash. As he told them, he would invest their money in International Reply Coupons, make his profit by exploiting exchange rates, all perfectly legal, and then return their investment plus 50 percent within ninety days, forty-five if things went well.7Although the diminutive financier had no clue as of yet how to convert coupons to cash, he convinced himself that it could be done and brought that confidence to the table. The word seeped out, at first among Italian-Americans, and slowly, surely outward from there.

这一切开始得很慢。在第一个月，庞氏只说服了 18 个人进行投资，他们只给了他 1770 美元的现金。正如他告诉他们的那样，他将把他们的钱投资于国际回邮券，通过利用汇率来赚取利润，所有这些都是完全合法的，然后在九十天内归还他们的投资，再加上 50%，如果事情进展顺利的话，则是 45%。 7尽管这位矮小的金融家还不知道如何将优惠券转换成现金，但他相信自己可以做到，并将这种信心带到了谈判桌上。这句话一开始就在意大利裔美国人中流传开来，并慢慢地、肯定地从那里向外传播。

In March 1920, Ponzi attracted 110 investors who put down $25,000. Ponzi was able to redeem the rings from Rosenberg that he had pawned to start this business just a few months earlier. In April, when his initial investors realized that Ponzi was actually willing to pay 50 percent interest as promised, the news spread like the Spanish flu. That month 471 customers invested $140,000. Although a few of the early customers cashed in, most took another throw of the dice. In May, more than 1,500 investors ponied up $440,000. This was turning into real money.

1920 年 3 月，庞齐吸引了 110 名投资者，他们投入了 25,000 美元。庞兹得以从罗森伯格那里赎回他在几个月前为开展这项业务而典当的戒指。4 月，当他最初的投资者意识到庞兹实际上愿意按照承诺支付 50% 的利息时，这个消息就像西班牙流感一样传播开来。当月有 471 名客户投资了 14 万美元。尽管少数早期客户套现了，但大多数人又开始掷骰子了。5 月，超过 1500 名投资者投入了 44 万美元。这正在变成真正的钱。

On May 5 of that same year, two other Boston Italians made their first mark on American culture when they were arrested for the murder of Alessandro Berardelli, a security guard killed in a South Braintree payroll robbery three weeks earlier. What Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti had in common with Ponzi — beyond their good looks and shared ethnicity — was that they, too, were as guilty as sin.8Unlike his countrymen, however, Ponzi would not claim ethnic victimization. Even after his arrest, Ponzi reminded the press that he was a “hearty endorser of the established government.” 9Besides, when Ponzi looked at his heritage, he did not see the oppressed masses. He saw the Medici. He reminded one critic who questioned his background that “banking had its origin in Italy and that the bill of exchange was devised by Italians.” 10

同年 5 月 5 日，另外两名波士顿意大利人以谋杀亚历山德罗·贝拉尔代利（Alessandro Berardelli）的罪名被捕，一位警卫在三周前的南布伦特里工资抢劫案中被杀。尼古拉·萨科和巴托洛梅奥·万泽蒂与庞氏的共同点是，除了他们的长相和共同的种族之外，他们也是罪大恶极。8然而，与他的同胞不同，庞氏不会声称自己是种族受害者。即使在被捕后，庞氏还提醒媒体，他是一个 “既定政府的忠实支持者”。9此外，当庞齐审视自己的遗产时，他没有看到受压迫的大众。他看到的是美第奇家族。他提醒一位质疑他背景的批评家，“银行业起源于意大利，汇票是由意大利人设计的。” 10

In the summer of 1920, Ponzi was too busy counting money to worry about arrest. In June, 7,800 people invested $2.5 million with the Securities Exchange Company. In July, 20,000 investors plunked down $6.5 million. That $6.5 million had a value comparable to $69 million today. “Hope and greed could be read in everybody’s countenance [or] guessed from the wads of money nervously clutched and waved by thousands of outstretched fists!” Ponzi would later remember the experience. “Madness, money madness, the worst kind of madness.” 11

1920 年夏天，庞氏忙着数钱，无暇顾及逮捕。6 月，7800 人向证券交易公司投资 250 万美元。7 月，20,000 名投资者投入了 650 万美元。这 650 万美元的价值与今天的 6900 万美元相当。“从每个人的脸色中可以读出希望和贪婪，或从数以千计的人伸出的拳头紧张地攥着和挥舞着的一沓钱中可以猜到！” 庞氏后来回忆起这段经历，“疯狂，金钱的疯狂，最糟糕的疯狂”。11

Although one newspaper would note that “foreigners predominate” 12among the crowds, Ponzi’s appeal had long since transcended its ethnic base. At least five Boston police inspectors had bought in, as well as hundreds of ordinary cops. The average size of each investment suggests that the people buying in were not all bootblacks and paperboys. Ponzi had become a multi­cultural, multiclass phenomenon.

尽管一家报纸指出在人群中 “外国人占多数” 12，庞氏的吸引力早已超越了其种族基础。至少有五名波士顿警察检查员以及数百名普通警察买入。每项投资的平均规模表明，买入的人并不都是鞋匠和报务员。庞氏骗局已经成为一种多文化、多阶层的现象。

The nation’s social critics are likely to conclude, as Ponzi himself had, that “Nobody gave a rap for ethics” or that “we are all gamblers. We all crave easy money.” 13But even in 1920, the year that the Black Sox scandal broke, neither generalization was close to true. There were any number of people who were bothered by what Ponzi was doing and a greater number still savvy enough to stay away from School Street.

国家的社会批评家们很可能会像庞兹本人那样得出结论 ：“没有人给道德说情”，或者 “我们都是赌徒”。13但是，即使在 1920 年，即黑袜丑闻爆发的那一年，这两种概括也都接近真实。有很多人对庞兹的所作所为感到不安，更多的人则精明地远离学校街。

TheBoston Postsniffed a fraud early on. So did a posse of state and federal officials, most notably the state’s incorruptible bank examiner, Joseph Allen. Bostonian Clarence Walker Barron, the father of American financial journalism, was particularly critical. Even before he knew Ponzi was running a scheme, he considered the underlying currency manipulation immoral. Evoking images of medieval divines, he intoned, “When a man gets money from the government without performing a service, it is just the same as when a man takes money from an individual without performing service for that money.” 14TheBoston Globeadded a Darwinian twist to the same sentiment. “In those parts of the planet which nourish high-grade human stock,” theGlobeopined, “there is no such thing as living without working.” 15

《波士顿邮》报很早就嗅到了欺诈的气息。一批州和联邦官员也是如此，最引人注目的是该州廉洁的银行审查员约瑟夫·艾伦。波士顿人克拉伦斯·沃克·巴伦（Clarence Walker Barron）是美国金融新闻之父，他的批评尤为严厉。甚至在他知道庞氏在实施一个计划之前，他就认为背后的货币操纵是不道德的。他唤起了中世纪神职人员的形象，他说 ：“当一个人从政府那里得到钱而不提供服务时，这与一个人从个人那里得到钱而不为这些钱提供服务是一样的。” 14《波士顿环球报》对同一观点增加了达尔文式的扭曲。“在地球上那些滋养高级人类的地方”，《环球报》认为，“没有不劳而获的事情。” 15

The various investigations were, however, slow getting untracked. For one, Ponzi’s explanation of how he generated his revenue sounded credible. For another, he was not violating the state’s usury laws. If anything, he was the victim of the usurious demands of his clients, who expected 50 percent interest every ninety days.

然而，各种调查却迟迟没有进展。首先，庞氏对他如何创造收入的解释听起来很可信。另外，他并没有违反该州的高利贷法律。如果有的话，他是他的客户高利贷要求的受害者，他们期望每九十天获得 50% 的利息。

Soon enough, though, several newspapers and investigative agencies were hot on his case. By the end of July, under enormous pressure on all sides, Ponzi submitted his business for a public audit and agreed to stop taking investments. This was something of a relief to Ponzi, as the more investments he took, the deeper was the hole he dug for himself. He had long since given up hope of trading coupons for cash.16His investors, however, wanted to keep on believing. Depending on the rumor of the day, they would either storm his office hoping to get their original investment back or storm his office trying to invest some more. The air was slipping out of this bubble surprisingly slowly.

不过很快，几家报纸和调查机构就盯上了他。到 7 月底，在各方的巨大压力下，庞氏将他的业务提交给公众审计，并同意停止接受投资。这对庞氏来说是一种解脱，因为他接受的投资越多，他给自己挖的坑就越深。16然而，他的投资者想继续相信下去。根据当天的传言，他们要么冲进他的办公室，希望拿回他们原来的投资，要么冲进他的办公室，试图再投资一些。这个泡沫的空气正出乎意料地慢慢滑落。

A series of damning newspaper articles, including revelation of Ponzi’s early arrests, finally punctured it. The run on Ponzi’s operation ended up taking out a couple of Boston banks — and almost the whole Boston banking complex — so deeply was he invested in several of them. And truth be told, in the era of fractional reserve banking, the banks’ positions were nearly as exposed as Ponzi’s were.

报纸上的一系列谴责性文章，包括对庞氏早期被捕的揭露，最终戳穿了这一说法。庞氏的经营活动最终导致波士顿的几家银行和几乎整个波士顿的银行业综合体倒闭，他在其中几家银行的投资如此之深。说实话，在部分准备金制度的时代，银行的头寸几乎和庞氏的头寸一样暴露。

The denouement revealed a Ponzi as gracious and dapper as ever, and an America far more tolerant than historians credit it to be. In August 1920, Ponzi was arrested. The following month, in an incident that would crudely prefigure the attacks of September 11, 2001, Italian anarchists pulled a wagon filled with dynamite in front of J. P. Morgan’s headquarters at 23 Wall Street and let her rip. The ensuing blast killed more than thirty people, wounded hundreds more, and wrecked the interior of the Morgan building. This blast capped a year of terror bombings by the followers of anarchist Luigi Galleani.

结局显示，庞氏一如既往地亲切、潇洒，而美国也远比历史学家认为的那样宽容。1920 年 8 月，庞氏被逮捕。接下来的一个月，在一次粗略地预示着 2001 年 9 月 11 日袭击事件的事件中，意大利无政府主义者在摩根公司位于华尔街 23 号的总部前拉来一辆装满炸药的马车，让它爆炸。随后的爆炸造成 30 多人死亡，数百人受伤，并摧毁了摩根大楼的内部。这次爆炸为无政府主义者路易吉·加莱尼（Luigi Galleani）的追随者一年来的恐怖爆炸活动画上了句号。

In the same years that Ponzi was being tried first by the federal government and then by the state, so were Sacco and Vanzetti. As the Soviet propaganda arm projected the latter case, Sacco and Vanzetti were powerless immigrants persecuted for their unpopular political belief and ethnic origins. The Massachusetts legal establishment was the evil instrument of the pair’s “judicial murder.” 17And the twelve members of the jury who convicted the pair were bigots all, easily inflamed by the state’s disinformation campaign.

在庞氏先被联邦政府、后被国家审判的那些年，萨科和万泽蒂也被审判了。正如苏联的宣传部门对后一案件的预测，萨科和万泽蒂是无权无势的移民，因为他们不受欢迎的政治信仰和种族出身而受到迫害。马萨诸塞州的法律机构是这一对人 “司法谋杀” 的邪恶工具。17而给他们定罪的 12 名陪审团成员都是偏执狂，容易被国家的造谣运动激怒。

The treatment of Ponzi helps put a lie to this nonsense. Even after he was arrested and convicted, even after he had defrauded half the citizens of Boston, the crowds continued to cheer him on. In December 1920, a few days after his guilty plea in the federal case, theNew York Timesconceded, “There was something picturesque about him, something suggestive of the gallant about him.” The press and the people of Boston had gone easy on Ponzi, theTimesclaimed, due to “a lack of sympathy for those whom he robbed . . . [The victims] showed only greed — the eagerness to get much for nothing — and they had not one of Ponzi’s redeeming graces.” 18

对庞氏的处理有助于对这种无稽之谈进行澄清。即使在他被逮捕和定罪之后，即使在他诈骗了波士顿一半的公民之后，群众仍然为他欢呼。1920 年 12 月，在他在联邦案件中认罪的几天后，《纽约时报》承认 ：“他身上有一些如诗如画的东西，有一些暗示着他的英勇。” 《泰晤士报》称，新闻界和波士顿人民对庞氏的态度很宽容，因为 “对被他抢劫的人缺乏同情心。（受害者）只表现出贪婪 —— 渴望不劳而获 —— 他们没有一个庞氏的可嘉之处。” "18

As the Melonie Griffiths-Evans case in the opening chapter suggests, the people of Boston have changed less than their media have.

正如开篇中的梅洛妮·格里菲斯·埃文斯案所表明的那样，波士顿人的变化比他们的媒体变化要小。

twentyJekyll Island 杰基尔岛

THE MEETING OF THE TWO CHARLESES IN THE ATLANTA PEN WAS NOT THE most memorable financial confab of that year, 1910 — not by a long shot. That honor fell to a gathering of faux duck hunters on a small private island off the coast of Georgia. There were only six men in the group. The task of recruiting the hunters was given to Henry Pomeroy Davison, the handsome young senior partnerchezMorgan and a veritable rock star on Wall Street. That he invited some guests to go duck hunting attracted little attention. A born sportsman, Davison had graduated from deer and rabbits around his humble Pennsylvania boyhood home to moose in Maine and rhino on the White Nile.1

两位查尔斯在亚特兰大笔会上的会面并不是那一年（1910 年）最令人难忘的金融会议 —— 不是很远的距离。这一荣誉落在了乔治亚州海岸的一个私人小岛上的假鸭子猎人的聚会上。这群人中只有六个人。招募猎手的任务交给了亨利·波默罗伊·戴维森，这位年轻英俊的高级合伙人，绰号 “切兹·摩根”，是华尔街名副其实的摇滚明星。他邀请一些客人去打鸭子，这一点没有引起人们的注意。作为一个天生的运动员，戴维森已经从他在宾夕法尼亚州简陋的童年住宅周围的鹿和兔子发展到缅因州的麋鹿和白尼罗河上的犀牛。1

For at least four of the six, the trip to Georgia was draped in mystery. Each guest was instructed to show up at Hoboken Station on November 22 and there board the private railroad car, blinds drawn, of Senator Nelson Aldrich. Aldrich, they knew, was John D. Rockefeller’s man in the U.S. Senate and the father-in-law of Rockefeller’s son. He and Davison would accompany them on the journey to a destination that had been secured by J. Pierpont Morgan himself.

对于这六人中的至少四人来说，前往佐治亚州的行程被蒙上了一层神秘的色彩。每位客人都被要求于 11 月 22 日出现在霍博肯车站，并在那里登上参议员纳尔逊·奥尔德里奇的私人铁路车厢，拉上百叶窗。他们知道，奥尔德里奇是约翰·D·洛克菲勒在美国参议院的手下，是洛克菲勒儿子的岳父。他和戴维森将陪同他们前往一个由皮尔庞特·摩根本人担保的目的地。

Each guest arrived individually at the station as requested and kept his distance from the others during the journey to Brunswick, Georgia. There, the six men boarded a boat headed for Jekyll Island, a hunting retreat for the elite described by one magazine as “the richest, the most exclusive and most inaccessible club in the world.” 2The names among its fifty or so members, in addition to Morgan, included Rockefeller, Pulitzer, Astor, Vanderbilt, Gould, and others of the turn-of-the-century household variety.

每个客人都按要求单独抵达车站，并在前往佐治亚州布朗斯维克的途中与其他人保持距离。在那里，这六个人上了一艘前往杰基尔岛的船，这是一个精英人士的狩猎胜地，被一家杂志描述为 “世界上最富有、最独特和最难以接近的俱乐部”。2其 50 多名成员中，除摩根外，还有洛克菲勒、普利策、阿斯特、范德比尔特、古尔德和其他世纪之交的家庭成员。

For the next ten days, the six men and a small skeleton staff had the island to themselves. They emerged at retreat’s end with a document that, with a few modifications, would soon enough reshape the world of finance. For the record, the duck hunters owed their invitation to the Panic of 1907 and the man who calmed it. That crisis had found Morgan at the peak of his powers. As early biographer Frederick Lewis Allen noted, “Where there had been many principalities, there was now one kingdom, and it was Morgan’s.” 3Morgan had succeeded too well. Now more than seventy years old, he caused Wall Street and Washington to wonder what would happen in a future emergency if there were no Morgan among them. “Something has got to be done,” Senator Aldrich worried out loud. “We may not always have Pierpont Morgan with us to meet a crisis.” 4

在接下来的十天里，这六个人和一个小规模的骨干员工独占了这个岛屿。他们在撤退结束时带着一份文件出现，经过一些修改，该文件将很快重塑金融界的面貌。顺便说一句，猎鸭人的邀请要归功于 1907 年的恐慌和平息恐慌的人。那次危机使摩根处于权力的顶峰。正如早期传记作者弗雷德里克·刘易斯·艾伦所指出的，“以前有很多公国，现在有一个王国，那就是摩根的王国。” 3摩根已经成功得太厉害了。现在他已经七十多岁了，他让华尔街和华盛顿想，如果他们中没有摩根，在未来的紧急情况下会发生什么。“必须做点什么”，参议员奥尔德里奇大声担心道。“我们可能不会一直有皮尔庞特·摩根和我们一起应对危机。” 4

Neither Pierpont nor Wall Street had confidence that Pierpont’s forty-year-old son, Jack, had the banking chops to pick up where the old man left off. Although not incompetent, Jack Morgan was not his father. Besides, few Americans of any stripe were keen on a ruling Morgan dynasty.

皮尔庞特和华尔街都不相信皮尔庞特 40 岁的儿子杰克有能力接替老爷子的工作。尽管杰克·摩根并非无能，但他并不是他的父亲。此外，很少有美国人热衷于摩根王朝的统治。

Even before the panic, academia had been quietly militating for a solution to future crises that did not involve Morgan or any other independent agent. Leading the charge was a professor of economics at Columbia University, E. R. A. —— as in Edwin Robert Anderson — Seligman. The American-born Seligman had studied in Europe and picked up a little Marx along the way. He would not be the last academic economist so influenced. Over the winter of 1907–1908, he presided at three conferences, each of which called for the creation of that ultimate fix-all, a central bank. Seligman disdained “the horde of small competitors” 5that made American commerce, banking in particular, so difficult to manage by experts like himself.

甚至在恐慌之前，学术界就已经在悄悄地为解决未来的危机而努力，而这种解决方法并不涉及摩根或任何其他独立代理人。带头的是哥伦比亚大学的经济学教授 E.R.A. —— 即埃德温·罗伯特·安德森 —— 塞利格曼。出生于美国的塞利格曼曾在欧洲学习，并在学习过程中掌握了一点马克思的知识。他不会是最后一个受到如此影响的学术经济学家。在 1907 年和 1908 年的冬天，他主持了三次会议，每次会议都呼吁建立一个最终的万能工具 —— 中央银行。塞利格曼不屑于 “成群结队的小竞争者” 5，这使得美国的商业，尤其是银行业，很难由像他这样的专家管理。

Also speaking at the Columbia conference of 1907 was one Frank Vanderlip, a banker and former assistant secretary of treasury. He, too, argued that a competitive, decentralized banking system caused the panic, “one of the great calamities in history.” Vanderlip saw central control along scientific principles as a solution to a free and competitive market. His outspokenness on this issue earned him a round trip to Jekyll Island.

在 1907 年的哥伦比亚会议上发言的还有一位名叫弗兰克·范德利普的银行家和前助理财政部长。他也认为，一个竞争性的、分散的银行系统造成了恐慌，“这是历史上最大的灾难之一”。范德利普认为沿着科学原则的中央控制是解决自由和竞争市场的办法。他在这个问题上的直言不讳为他赢得了杰基尔岛的一次往返旅行。

Following Vanderlip at Columbia was Paul Warburg. Born into a Jewish banking family in Hamburg, Germany, Warburg married into the American Loeb family and moved to the United States in 1902 as a thirty-four-year-old partner in the investment banking house of his in-laws, Kuhn, Loeb & Company. No one in America knew central banking better than Warburg did. “Small banks constitute a danger,” 6he told those gathered at Columbia in arguing for the benefits of European-style banking. Warburg, in fact, had a problem with the whole idea of a free, self-regulating market. He hoped to replace Adam Smith’s “invisible hand” with the “best judgment of experts,” himself high among them. In 1910, Warburg, too, took up duck hunting on Jekyll Island.

在哥伦比亚大学跟随范德利普的是保罗·沃伯格。沃伯格出生于德国汉堡的一个犹太银行业家庭，嫁给了美国的勒布家族，并于 1902 年搬到了美国，成为其姻亲 Kuhn, Loeb & Company 投资银行的 34 岁合伙人。在美国，没有人比沃伯格更了解中央银行。“小银行是一种危险”，6他告诉聚集在哥伦比亚大学的人，争论欧洲式银行的好处。事实上，沃伯格对整个自由、自我调节的市场理念有异议。他希望用 “专家的最佳判断” 来取代亚当·斯密的 “看不见的手”，他自己就是其中的佼佼者。1910 年，沃伯格也在杰基尔岛打起了鸭子。

Aldrich kept the reform ball rolling in the Senate. He managed to get a minor banking bill, the Aldrich-Vreeland Act, passed in 1908. The reformers took note of a seemingly minor amendment to the bill that Aldrich’s fellow senators paid little heed to: the creation of a National Monetary Commission (NMC) to study proposals for restructuring the banking system. Wrote one reformer in theWall Street Journal, “In no other way can such education be effected more thoroughly and rapidly than by means of a commission . . . [that] would make an international study of the subject and present an exhaustive report, which could be made the basis for an intelligent agitation.” 7

阿尔德里奇在参议院继续推进改革。他设法使一个小的银行法案，即《奥尔德里奇·弗里兰法》，在 1908 年获得通过。改革者们注意到了奥尔德里奇的参议员们很少注意到该法案的一个看似次要的修正案：建立一个国家货币委员会（NMC）来研究重组银行系统的建议。一位改革者在《华尔街日报》上写道 ：“没有其他方法能比一个委员会更彻底、更迅速地实现这种教育了……” 7

。

Aldrich set up the NMC promptly in June 1908 and started agitating. Although various senators and representatives filled the seats in the conference room, the Aldrich-appointed staff did the real work. It was agreed from the beginning that the NMC would be run as a discreet, ecumenical alliance among Rockefeller, Morgan, and Kuhn, Loeb. On Morgan’s advice, Aldrich named Henry Davison chief advisor. “My idea is, of course, that everything should be done in the utmost quiet manner possible,” Aldrich told a colleague, “and without any public announcement.” 8

阿尔德里奇在 1908 年 6 月迅速成立了一家协会，并开始进行煽动。尽管各种参议员和代表坐满了会议室的座位，但由阿尔德里奇任命的工作人员做了真正的工作。从一开始就商定，NMC 将作为洛克菲勒、摩根和库恩、勒布之间的一个谨慎的、普世的联盟来运作。根据摩根的建议，奥尔德里奇任命亨利·戴维森为首席顾问。“当然，我的想法是，一切都应该以尽可能安静的方式进行”，奥尔德里奇对一位同事说，“而且不作任何公开宣布。” 8/p>

The NMC, its agents, and its allies spent the next two years hammering out proposals and winning support. To woo the reluctant bankers in the Midwest, the planners insisted that any new national bank would be decentralized through regional complexes. For those worried about private control, planners assured that the government would oversee the operation through an appointed governing board. To drive the message home, theWall Street Journallaunched a fourteen-part front-page series on the need for a central bank.9

NMC、其代理人和其盟友在接下来的两年里敲定了一些建议并赢得了支持。为了吸引中西部不情愿的银行家，规划者坚持认为，任何新的国家银行都将通过区域综合体进行分散管理。对于那些担心私人控制的人，规划者保证，政府将通过一个指定的管理委员会监督运作。为了使这一信息深入人心，《华尔街日报》在头版推出了一个由 14 个部分组成的关于中央银行必要性的系列报道。9

Feeling the need to goose the project along, Davison called the meeting at Jekyll Island. In addition to Aldrich, Warburg, and Vanderlip, A. Piatt Andrew and Benjamin Strong donned their hunter togs. Andrew was just finishing his tenure as assistant secretary of treasury and had served before that as a director of the United States mint. Indiana born, he had been educated at Princeton and in Europe and had taught economics at Harvard.

感觉到需要推动项目的进展，戴维森在杰基尔岛召开了会议。除了奥尔德里奇、沃伯格和范德利普之外，皮亚特·安德鲁和本杰明·斯特朗也穿上了他们的猎人服装。安德鲁刚刚结束其助理财政部长的任期，在此之前，他曾担任美国造币厂的董事。他出生于印第安纳州，曾在普林斯顿大学和欧洲接受教育，并在哈佛大学教授经济学。

Of the six men in attendance, none would prove more influential than Strong. Then the president of Banker’s Trust Company, the thirty-nine-year-old Strong owed his career to Davison, who had hired him six years prior, and to Davison’s boss, Morgan. Strong and Davison were the two Morgan men in attendance. Aldrich and Vanderlip were Rockefeller men. Warburg represented Kuhn, Loeb; and Andrew, an economist, was friendly to all camps.

在与会的六个人中，没有人比斯特朗更有影响力。现年 39 岁的斯特朗是银行家信托公司的总裁，他的职业生涯得益于六年前雇佣他的戴维森，以及戴维森的老板摩根。斯特朗和戴维森是出席会议的两个摩根人。奥尔德里奇和范德利普是洛克菲勒的人。沃伯格代表库恩、勒布；经济学家安德鲁则对所有阵营都很友好。

The only duck or wild turkey the men saw during the ten-day retreat was on their dinner plates. They ate well, their sole reprieve during sixteen-hour workdays. They even celebrated Thanksgiving together. Vanderlip would much later describe their shared time as “the highest pitch of intellectual experience that I have ever experienced,” 10but he kept this experience to himself. Before leaving, he and the others took a pledge of secrecy. It would be four years before anyone got wind of the meeting and twenty years before any of the men admitted being there. Given the secrecy and the seriousness of the enterprise, the swamps of Jekyll Island would serve as the primordial stew for a thousand conspiracy theories, some of which are close to accurate.

在十天的隔离中，这些人唯一看到的鸭子或野生火鸡出现在他们的餐盘里。他们吃得很好，这是他们在 16 个小时的工作日中唯一的喘息机会。他们甚至一起庆祝了感恩节。范德利普后来将他们的共同生活描述为 “我所经历的最高级别的智力体验”，10但他将这种体验留给自己。在离开之前，他和其他人做了一个保密的承诺。四年后才有人知道这次会议的消息，二十年后才有人承认去过那里。鉴于这种保密性和企业的严肃性，杰基尔岛的沼泽地将成为无数阴谋论的原始炖品，其中一些接近于准确。

Strong and Vanderlip drafted the “Aldrich Plan,” the document mentioned above that summarized the strategy agreed upon at the retreat. The plan called for the creation of a “national reserve association,” a sort of banker’s cooperative that replicated the function of a central bank without calling it such.11The association would have the authority to issue currency and lend to commercial banks. Although government appointees would sit on the association’s board, the bankers themselves would control it.

斯特朗和文得力普起草了《奥尔德里奇计划》，即上文提到的总结务虚会上商定的战略的文件。该计划要求建立一个 “国家储备协会”，这是一种银行家的合作社，它复制了中央银行的功能，但又不称它为中央银行。11该协会将有权发行货币并向商业银行放贷。尽管政府任命的人员将参加协会的董事会，但银行家们自己将控制它。

Aldrich had recommended a straightforward central bank on the European model, but the nonpoliticians knew better than he that a central bank could be more readily sold to the public if packaged as a decentralized bank.12That sell was complicated by the fact that the Democrats had taken Congress in 1910 and would take the White House in 1912.

阿尔德里奇曾建议按照欧洲模式建立一个直接的中央银行，但非政治家们比他更清楚，如果把中央银行包装成一个分散的银行，可以更容易向公众推销。 12由于民主党在 1910 年占领了国会，并将在 1912 年入主白宫，这一推销变得更加复杂。

The marketing campaign for the Aldrich Plan kicked off at a National Board of Trade meeting in January 1911. After a rousing speech in its favor by Andrew, delegates voted to back the plan. The group’s chairman then appointed a seven-person committee to market the plan, headed by none other than Warburg. The delegates, of course, had no knowledge that Andrew and Warburg had helped draft the document they were about to promote.

奥尔德里奇计划的营销活动在 1911 年 1 月的国家贸易委员会会议上启动。在安德鲁发表了支持该计划的振奋人心的演讲后，代表们投票支持该计划。该集团的主席随后任命了一个七人委员会来推销该计划，负责人正是沃伯格。当然，代表们并不知道安德鲁和沃伯格曾帮助起草了他们即将推广的文件。

To give the illusion of a grass-roots effort, the committee of seven launched a National Citizens League for the Creation of a Sound Banking System and headquartered it in Chicago, rather than New York.13While the Citizens League drummed up enthusiasm on Main Street, a parallel campaign was launched to win over Wall Street.

为了给人一种基层努力的错觉，七人委员会发起了一个创建健全银行系统的全国公民联盟，并将其总部设在芝加哥，而不是纽约。 13当公民联盟在主街鼓起热情的时候，一个平行的运动被发起，以争取华尔街。

Congress would prove more difficult. A three-time presidential loser by 1910, William Jennings Bryan still held sway over much of Congress. His soft-money supporters saw the hard-money hand of Morgan behind a central bank and resisted. To win over Congress, supporters of the plan would have to lose the Aldrich name and find a Democratic sponsor. Happily for them, Carter Glass, the head of the Banking Committee in the House, stepped up to champion the cause in the House.

国会将证明更加困难。到 1910 年，威廉·詹宁斯·布莱恩是三次总统选举的失败者，但他仍然对国会的大部分成员有影响力。他的软货币支持者看到了摩根在中央银行背后的硬货币之手，并加以抵制。为了赢得国会的支持，该计划的支持者必须失去奥尔德里奇的名字，并找到一个民主党的赞助商。令他们高兴的是，众议院银行委员会主席卡特·格拉斯挺身而出，在众议院倡导这一事业。

The House Democrats and now President Wilson insisted on changes. They demanded not only the appearance of decentralization, but also at least a smidgen of reality. There would be twelve private regional reserve banks in the system, and these would be placed under central political control. A Washington board, which included the treasury secretary and presidential appointees, would oversee the whole system.

众议院民主党人和现在的威尔逊总统坚持要改变。他们不仅要求表面上的权力下放，而且还要求至少有一丁点的现实。在这个系统中，将有 12 个私人区域储备银行，这些银行将被置于中央政治控制之下。一个包括财政部长和总统任命的华盛顿委员会将监督整个系统。

On March 31, 1913, J. P. Morgan died. On December 23, 1913, President Wilson smiled and signed into law the hybrid concoction that was to replace Morgan, the Federal Reserve. The Jekyll Island men smiled too, and they knew what they were smiling about. In analyzing the beast, they had figured out that the control of it could very well reside with the presidency of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York if that first president were shrewd and resourceful. They had just the man in mind. From 1914 until his death in 1928, their own Benjamin Strong would preside over the New York Federal Reserve and set the monetary policy for the nation. The Federal Reserve Act had not reduced the power of the duck hunters and their backers. It had merely reduced their responsibility.

1913 年 3 月 31 日，J. P. 摩根去世。1913 年 12 月 23 日，威尔逊总统微笑着将取代摩根的混合混合物 —— 美联储 —— 签署为法律。杰基尔岛的人也笑了，而且他们知道他们在笑什么。在分析这头野兽时，他们发现，如果纽约联邦储备银行的第一任行长精明强干，就可以很好地控制它。他们想到的正是这个人。从 1914 年到 1928 年去世，他们自己的本杰明·斯特朗将主持纽约联邦储备银行，为国家制定货币政策。联邦储备法并没有减少猎鸭人和他们的支持者的权力。它只是减少了他们的责任。

twenty-oneBirth of the Consumer 消费者的诞生

ON JUNE 19, 1877, THENEW YORK TIMESRAN AN ALL-CAP HEADLINE, “A SENSATION AT SARATOGA.” 1As the subhead went on to explain, the sensation was this: the Grand Union hotel in Saratoga Springs, New York, had changed its rules to exclude Jews and turned away the prominent Wall Street banker, Joseph Seligman.

1877 年 6 月 19 日，《纽约时报》发布了一个全标题 ：“萨拉托加的感应”。1正如副标题继续解释的那样，轰动效应是这样的：纽约萨拉托加泉的大联合酒店改变了规则，将犹太人排除在外，并拒绝了华尔街的著名银行家约瑟夫·塞利格曼。

The incident had to have been upsetting for Seligman. Forty years prior, he had immigrated to America from Germany as an eighteen-year-old and promptly gone to work as an itinerant peddler working the farmer beat in rural Pennsylvania. Seligman sold enough implements and sundries that he was able to send for his two brothers, William and James. In time, the brothers upgraded their enterprise from peddling merchandise to merchant banking and by the time of the Civil War, they had built one of the most formidable such houses in America. So deeply did Seligman identify with his adopted country that when his son was born eleven days after the fall of Fort Sumter, he named him after the Union general who defended the fort, Edward Robert Anderson.2Thus began the career of E. R. A. Seligman.

这件事对塞利格曼来说一定很难过。40 年前，他 18 岁时从德国移民到美国，并迅速成为宾夕法尼亚州农村的一个流动小贩，为农民打工。塞利格曼卖出了足够多的工具和杂物，使他能够给他的两个兄弟威廉和詹姆斯寄钱。随着时间的推移，兄弟俩将他们的企业从兜售商品升级为商业银行，到南北战争时，他们已经建立了美国最强大的此类机构之一。塞利格曼对他收养的国家的认同感如此之深，以至于当他的儿子在萨姆特要塞陷落 11 天后出生时，他以保卫该要塞的联邦将军爱德华·罗伯特·安德森的名字为他命名。2 由此开始了 E.R.A. 塞利格曼的职业生涯。

The younger Seligman was encouraged to believe in the American dream. Indeed, Horatio Alger Jr. tutored him as a child, and the dream does not get much purer than that. Although E. R. A. chose not to pursue his father’s career, he never strayed too far from Wall Street. As previously noted, he played a significant role in the birth of the Federal Reserve from his perch at Columbia University. Perhaps the leading public intellectual of his era, Seligman was eager to show the relevance of the economist in the everyday life of the republic. In 1925, when he got his chance, he would make the most of it. Before he was through, he would almost single-handedly legitimize personal credit and sire the consumer revolution.

年轻的塞利格曼被鼓励去相信美国梦。事实上，小霍雷肖·阿尔杰（Horatio Alger Jr.）在他小时候就对他进行了辅导，而梦想没有比这更纯粹的了。尽管 E.R.A. 塞利格曼选择不追求他父亲的事业，但他从未离华尔街太远。如前所述，他在哥伦比亚大学的职位上对美联储的诞生发挥了重要作用。也许是他那个时代领先的公共知识分子，塞利格曼急于展示经济学家在共和国日常生活中的相关性。1925 年，当他得到机会时，他将最大限度地利用它。在他结束之前，他几乎以一己之力使个人信贷合法化，并引发了消费革命。

If the sewing machine had introduced the working classes to installment buying, it had failed to make buying on credit respectable among the middle classes. InThe Century Dictionaryof 1889, for instance, the listing for “instalment plan” reads like a warning label. According to the entry, “the seller retains the ownership until payment, and stipulates for the right to retake the article, without return of some or any part of what has already been paid, if the buyer makes default in any instalment.” 3

如果说缝纫机将工人阶级引入了分期付款的购买方式，那么它却未能使赊账购买在中产阶级中得到尊重。例如，在 1889 年的《世纪辞典》中，“分期付款计划” 的列表读起来就像一个警告标签。根据该条目，“卖方在付款前保留所有权，并规定如果买方在任何分期付款中违约，则有权收回物品，而不退还已经支付的部分或任何部分。” 3

In his 1886 novelThe Minister’s Charge, popular author William Dean Howells has his protagonist learn that he can buy the suit he longs for “on the installment plan” if, that is, he does not mind shopping “on a degenerate street, in a neighborhood of Chinese laundries.” 4In his 1906 novelThe Jungle, Upton Sinclair dedicates almost as much anxious attention to his character’s installment purchases as he does to his packinghouse miseries.

在他 1886 年的小说《部长的职责》（The Minister's Charge）中，流行作家威廉·迪安·豪威尔斯（William Dean Howells）让他的主人公知道，他可以 “通过分期付款计划” 买到他渴望的西装，如果，他不介意 “在一条堕落的街道上，在一个中国洗衣店的街区购物的话”。4在他 1906 年的小说《丛林》（The Jungle）中，厄普顿·辛克莱尔对他角色的分期付款购买的关注几乎和他对包装厂的痛苦一样多。

Arguably the leading voice in the anticredit movement was then-popular novelist Irving Bacheller. In his 1912 best sellerCharge It, Bacheller lays out a philosophy that would have found favor with Martin Luther. His aptly named character Socrates Potter speaks for the author when he pontificates that “credit is the latest ally of the devil,” and that “the two words ‘charge it’ have done more harm than any other in the language.” 5

可以说，当时流行的小说家欧文·巴切勒是反信贷运动的领军人物。在他 1912 年的畅销书《收费》 “Charge It” 中，巴切勒阐述了一种会得到马丁·路德青睐的哲学。他的角色苏格拉底·波特(Socrates Potter)的名字恰如其分地代表了作者的观点，他说 ：“信用是魔鬼的最新盟友，‘收费’这个词比语言中的任何其他词都造成了更大的伤害。” 5

In his more ambitious 1910 novelKeeping Up with Lizzie, Bacheller boldly links corruption in the microeconomic order to a breakdown in the macroeconomic one. This linkage deserves exploration, even if Bacheller’s plot wanders all over the lot. As told, each of the town’s two leading grocers has indulged his child. These two young adults, Lizzie and Dan respectively, have learned to savor the high life at their fashionable colleges. When they return home, they try to keep up with each other. Their competition eventually sucks in the whole town. The grocers have to hike their prices to fund their children’s needs, and inflation follows. Just about everyone descends into debt. The townspeople mortgage their homes and file for bankruptcy. A young cashier at the bank embezzles eighteen thousand dollars to keep up and then blows his brains out in self-disgust.

在他 1910 年更有雄心的小说《跟上里兹》（Keeping Up with Lizzie）中，巴切勒大胆地将微观经济秩序的腐败与宏观经济秩序的崩溃联系起来。这种联系值得探讨，即使巴切勒的情节在很多地方徘徊。据悉，该镇的两个主要杂货商各自都放纵了自己的孩子。这两个年轻人，分别是丽兹和丹，已经学会了在他们时尚的大学里品味上流生活。当他们回到家时，他们试图跟上对方的步伐。他们的竞争最终吸纳了整个小镇的人。杂货商们不得不提高价格以满足孩子们的需求，通货膨胀随之而来。几乎所有的人都陷入了债务。镇民们抵押了他们的房子并申请了破产。银行的一个年轻出纳员为了维持生计，挪用了一万八千美元，然后在自我厌恶中爆了头。

Happily, Socrates Potter has been saving his money. He lectures the hapless prodigals before bailing them out and helping them restart their lives. Dan marries Lizzie. They return to the farm, and the town returns to normal. Memories of inflation, bankruptcies, and moral breakdown embed themselves in the town’s chastised collective consciousness.

很高兴，苏格拉底·波特一直在存钱。他在保释他们并帮助他们重新开始生活之前，对那些无能的败家子们进行了说教。丹与丽兹结婚。他们回到了农场，小镇也恢复了正常。通货膨胀、破产和道德崩溃的记忆嵌入了镇上受责备的集体意识中。

As sincere as he was, Bacheller was no Aristotle, no Aquinas, no Adam Smith. Despite widespread anxiety about the “morphine of credit,” neither he nor anyone in turn-of-the-century America spoke with universal authority. The nation’s moral thunder was strained through a thousand filters. All the nation’s social workers, newspaper editors, pastors, academics, and home economists together did not carry the weight of one run-of-the-mill medieval pope.6America’s pluralism was dissipating the message of the largely Protestant advocates of the social gospel.

尽管巴切勒很真诚，但他不是亚里士多德，不是阿奎那，不是亚当·斯密。尽管人们普遍对 “信贷的吗啡” 感到焦虑，但在世纪之交的美国，他和其他任何人都不具有普遍的权威。国家的道德雷声是经过千百次过滤的。所有国家的社会工作者、报纸编辑、牧师、学者和家庭经济学家加起来也没有一个中世纪教皇的分量。6美国的多元主义正在消解主要由新教倡导的社会福音的信息。

Still, the crusaders against debt might have prevailed were it not for the introduction of one new technology, the same technology, by the by, that helped undo America’s sexual morality — the automobile. In 1906, when Woodrow Wilson, then president of Princeton University, first sensed its potential, he feared for the nation’s future. Everyone would want a car, he reasoned. Few could afford them. The frustration would lead to socialism.7

尽管如此，如果不是因为一项新技术的引入，反对债务的十字军可能已经取得了胜利，顺便说一句，这项技术也帮助破坏了美国的性道德 —— 汽车。1906 年，当时任普林斯顿大学校长的伍德罗·威尔逊第一次感受到汽车的潜力时，他对国家的未来感到担忧。他推断，每个人都会想要一辆汽车。很少有人能买得起它们。沮丧将导致社会主义。7

Henry Ford helped head off the feared revolution. In 1903, he and a half dozen investors launched the Ford Motor Company.8In 1908, they rolled out the Model T Ford for $825, and overnight a new car seemed within reach of just about every wage-earning guy across the fruited plains. Many Americans, however, especially those disinclined to save their money, stood like Tantalus in their own self-imposed Hades, forever reaching for those keys only to see circumstances snatch them away. Banks offered little help. A car violated just about every traditional standard of sound commercial banking.

亨利·福特（Henry Ford）帮助掀起了一场令人恐惧的革命。81908 年，他们以 825 美元的价格推出了 T 型福特汽车，一夜之间，整个果园的每个工薪族似乎都能买到一辆新车。然而，许多美国人，特别是那些不愿意存钱的人，像坦塔罗斯一样站在他们自己打造的地狱里，永远地伸手去拿那些钥匙，却看到环境把它们抢走。银行提供的帮助很少。一辆汽车违反了健全商业银行的所有传统标准。

In an extended 1916 study, an independent consultant to Ford, Edward Rumely, offered a way around bank recalcitrance. “Because of certain facts of human nature,” he fairly observed, “there are always more people who will buy when they can pay for a thing gradually in the course of the next six months, than there are people with cash in their pockets to buy outright.” 9Rumely recommended that Ford stay out of the lending business for a variety of good reasons, but suggested instead that the Ford Motor Company set up a subsidiary banking company.

在 1916 年的一项扩展研究中，福特公司的独立顾问爱德华·鲁米利（Edward Rumely）提出了一个绕过银行的方法。“由于人性中的某些事实”，他公正地指出，“当他们能在未来六个月内逐步支付一件东西时，会购买的人总是比口袋里有现金可以直接购买的人多。” 9鲁梅利出于各种良好的理由建议福特公司不要参与贷款业务，而是建议福特汽车公司成立一家附属银行。

Henry Ford would have none of it. He believed in cash. His distaste for installment buying, bankers, banking, borrowing, lending — the whole financial enchilada — was becoming the stuff of legends. Accordingly, Ford sold all of its cars for cash to dealers. The dealers, however, were increasingly working with local finance companies to move their autos off the lot. This whole end of the business did not much concern Henry. In 1920, every other car in the world was a Model T. He had reason to believe that his cash-centric sales strategy was working.

亨利·福特不会同意的。他相信现金，虽然他对分期付款、银行家、银行业务、借款、贷款以及整个金融系统的厌恶，正在成为传说中的东西。因此，福特将其所有的汽车以现金形式卖给了经销商。然而，经销商们越来越多地与当地的金融公司合作，将他们的汽车运出停车场。整个业务的这一端与亨利没有多大关系。1920 年，世界上其他所有的汽车都是 T 型车。他有理由相信，他以现金为中心的销售策略是有效的。

Alfred P. Sloan was not feeling nearly as complacent. The rising executive at upstart General Motors understood that a credit-financing arm would help GM increase sales and stabilize production. It would also enable GM to cut into Ford’s market dominance among low-end buyers. And so in March 1919, the company took the plunge and launched the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.10

阿尔弗雷德·斯隆（Alfred P. Sloan）并不感到自满。这位新兴的通用汽车公司的高管明白，一个信贷融资部门将帮助通用汽车公司提高销量并稳定生产。它还将使通用汽车能够在低端买家中削减福特的市场支配地位。于是在 1919 年 3 月，该公司铤而走险，成立了 “通用汽车接受公司”。10

After a sharp postwar recession in 1920, which the still humble Federal Reserve let work itself out, the economy took off, and everyone wanted a car. By 1923, 46 percent of GM buyers were taking advantage of GMAC’s installment plans.11This not only put marginal buyers in the low-end market, but it also allowed middle-class drivers to “buy up.” By this time, young males had come to understand that a sharp-looking car could make them smarter, taller, and better-looking. And if it made them poorer in the process, it made them at leastlookwealthier. The status they were buying may have only been symbolic, but it worked.

1920 年，战后出现了急剧的经济衰退，当时还很谦虚的美联储让其自行解决。之后，经济开始起飞，每个人都想要一辆汽车。11这不仅使边缘买家进入了低端市场，而且还使中产阶级司机得以 “购买”。这时，年轻男性已经明白，一辆外观鲜明的汽车可以使他们更聪明、更高大、更漂亮。如果在这个过程中让他们变得更穷，至少可以让他们看起来更富有。他们所购买的地位可能只是象征性的，但它是有效的。

The anticredit forces were not about to be run over. Henry Ford led an unlikely coalition in resisting what one old-school merchant called “the Slimy Coils of Installment Evil.” 12For obvious reasons, savings banks still discouraged installment buying. In fact, they used the nation’s two thousand school-banking programs to educate these future depositors on the virtues of putting their money in banks. Union leaders worried about collecting their dues and fretted that strikes would be harder to call if their members had installment payments to meet. Clergy of all stripe railed against debt as they had been doing since Moses. And now, even America’s emerging socialist wannabes were joining the chorus.

反信贷力量并没有被碾压。 亨利·福特领导了一个不太可能的联盟，抵制一个老派商人所称的 “分期付款邪恶的粘性线圈”。12由于明显的原因，储蓄银行仍然不鼓励购买分期付款。事实上，他们利用全国两千多个校园银行项目来教育这些未来的储户，让他们了解把钱放在银行的好处。工会领导人担心收取他们的会费，并担心如果他们的成员有分期付款的要求，罢工就更难进行。各类神职人员都在抨击债务，正如他们自摩西以来一直在做的那样。而现在，甚至连美国新兴的社会主义崇拜者也加入了这个大合唱。

Not wanting to appear insensitive to a culture war it had helped launch, GM commissioned a study to explore the effects of installment selling on society.13If the results came back positive, GM could take credit for pioneering these credit innovations. If they came back negative, GM could profit by tightening its credit while simultaneously posing as guardian of the nation’s morals. And who more credible to undertake this study than the nation’s most prominent economist, E. R. A. Seligman?

通用汽车不想显得对自己帮助发起的文化战争无动于衷，于是委托进行一项研究，探讨分期付款销售对社会的影响。13如果研究结果是正面，通用汽车可以为这些信贷创新的先驱而邀功。如果结果是负面的，通用汽车可以通过收紧其信贷而获利，同时还可以冒充国家道德的守护者。还有谁比美国最杰出的经济学家塞利格曼更有资格进行这项研究呢？

Contemporary universities would be hard-pressed to find people on their faculties who think as Seligman did. Although no friend oflaissez-faireeconomics, he believed in progress and wasn’t afraid to say so. He understood that social progress was tied to economic performance. This worldview predisposed him to rule favorably on the credit issue, and this he did in his highly influential 1927 report,The Economics of Instalment[sic]Selling. Too confident to equivocate, Seligman argued that credit was helping drive the “business revolution” and constituted “a significant and valuable contribution to the modern economy.” 14

当代大学将很难找到像塞利格曼那样思考的人。虽然他并不是 “自由放任” 经济学的朋友，但他相信进步，而且不怕说出来。他明白，社会进步与经济表现息息相关。这种世界观使他倾向于在信贷问题上作出有利的裁决，他在 1927 年的报告《分期付款的经济学》(The Economics of Instalment [sic]Selling)中这样做了。塞利格曼太自信了，他认为信贷有助于推动 “商业革命”，并构成 “对现代经济的重要和有价值的贡献”。 14

Seligman went well beyond charts and graphs in making his case. He editorialized that the whole language of credit should be changed, not only to make the discussion more rational, but also to make credit more acceptable. At the time, economists tended to divide credit into two categories: “productive credit” that was advanced for income-producing products and “consumptive credit” for purchases that were bought largely for convenience or pleasure.

塞利格曼在阐述他的观点时，远远超出了图表的范畴。他发表社论说，应该改变整个信贷的语言，不仅使讨论更加合理，而且使信贷更容易被接受。当时，经济学家倾向于将信贷分为两类。“生产性信贷”，用于生产收入的产品，“消费性信贷” 用于购买主要是为了方便或享受的产品。

Seligman had real problems with the wordconsumptive. For one, it sounded like a disease. At the time, tuberculosis — the AIDS of its day, much feared and perversely fashionable — was routinely called consumption. For another,consumptivegave the impression that the product was consumed, as in used up and wasted. Seligman insisted that a much more useful word would beconsumer, as in “consumer’s credit.” The word stuck, and in no time America transformed itself from a nation of citizens to a nation of consumers. GM’s Sloan gave Seligman full credit for eroding the resistance of the nation’s bankers and businessmen to the credit revolution.15

塞利格曼对 “消费性” （consumptive）这个词确实有意见。首先，它听起来像一种疾病。在当时，肺结核 —— 那个时代的艾滋病，非常令人恐惧和反常的时尚 —— 也被常规地称为消费。另外，“消费性” 给人的印象是产品被消耗了，就像被用完和浪费了。塞利格曼坚持认为，一个更有用的词是 “消费者” （consumer），如 “消费者的信贷”。这个词立住了，美国很快就从一个公民的国家转变为一个消费者的国家。通用汽车公司的斯隆对塞利格曼的功劳给予了充分肯定，因为他削弱了国家的银行家和商人对信贷革命的抵制。15

Others took up the crusade where Seligman had left off. Notable among them was department store honcho Julian Goldman. When Goldman opened his first high-end store in 1916, he could see how middle-class reluctance to buy on time was limiting sales. Seligman’s book inspired him to devise an ad strategy that would overcome that reluctance. In one memorable 1928 ad, headlined “A factory or a fur coat,” Goldman followed Seligman’s lead in breaking down the moral distinction between productive and consumptive buying. The ad flattered the female purchaser into seeing herself as a “good business woman,” one who financed her “business” in the “only practical modern way.” 16Not only that, but her purchase of the fur coat would help stimulate the economy, put more money in circulation, and keep people employed. In 1930, Goldman published a book calledProsperity and Consumer Creditthat was grounded openly in Seligman’s theories.

其他人则在塞利格曼离开的地方开始了讨伐行动。其中值得注意的是百货公司的老总朱利安·戈德曼。当戈德曼在 1916 年开设他的第一家高端商店时，他看到了中产阶级不愿意及时购买是如何限制了销售的。塞利格曼的书启发他设计了一个广告策略，以克服这种不情愿的态度。在 1928 年的一个令人难忘的广告中，标题是 “工厂或皮草大衣”，戈德曼跟随塞利格曼的步伐，打破了生产性购买和消费性购买之间的道德区别。这则广告奉承了女性购买者，让她认为自己是一个 “好的女商人”，一个以 “唯一实用的现代方式” 为自己的 “生意” 提供资金的人。16不仅如此，她购买毛皮大衣还有助于刺激经济，让更多的钱投入流通，并保持人们就业。1930 年，戈德曼出版了一本名为《繁荣与消费信贷》的书，该书公开以塞利格曼的理论为基础。

Implicit in the history of credit and debit is a cultural reality that historians choose to avoid: from the nineteenth century forward, major innovators in the management of credit and debit were disproportionately Jewish, very much so. As the twentieth century progressed, this trend would continue. A parallel trend had developed as well: those who resisted credit innovation, both on Wall Street and off it, were disproportionately Protestant. Catholics played little role in this ongoing dialectic. Although Catholic doctrine did not discourage enterprise, Catholic culture in America subtly did. Beyond the brigand Joe Kennedy and the banker Amadeo Giannini, it would be hard to name a single Catholic of real consequence in the financial field, especially in the first half of the twentieth century.

隐含在信贷和借贷历史中的是一个历史学家选择回避的文化现实：从十九世纪开始，信贷和借贷管理的主要创新者是不成比例的犹太人，的确如此。随着二十世纪的发展，这一趋势将继续下去。一个平行的趋势也已经形成：那些抵制信贷创新的人，无论是在华尔街还是在华尔街以外，都是不成比例的新教徒。天主教徒在这种持续的辩证法中没有发挥什么作用。虽然天主教教义没有阻止事业，但美国的天主教文化却巧妙地阻止了事业。除了强盗乔·肯尼迪和银行家阿玛迪奥·贾尼尼之外，很难说出一个在金融领域有真正影响的天主教徒，尤其是在 20 世纪上半叶。

What was impressive about America, especially given the state of the world circa 1930, was how well its citizens, its financiers especially, kept this culture war civil. If the tension between Jews and Protestants — shorthand for the latter: WASP or “white shoe” —— was a constant, resentments were rarely given voice by either side. In his recent best sellerThe Israel Test, George Gilder attributes this to the fact that anti-Semitism “tends to wane under a growing and expanding capitalist system.” 17For those who disdained capitalism, Karl Marx most notably, this was merely a sign that Jewish values had corrupted an entire culture. Those who championed free enterprise, on the other hand, had to appreciate how well Jews played the game, even if it occasionally came at their expense. Says Gilder, “Americans should not conceal the triumphs of Jews on our shores but celebrate them as evidence of the superior freedoms of the U.S. economy and culture.” 18

美国令人印象深刻的是，特别是考虑到 1930 年左右的世界状况，它的公民，特别是它的金融家，如何很好地保持这场文化战争。如果说犹太人和新教徒之间的紧张关系 —— 简写为 WASP，或 “白鞋” —— 是一种常态，但任何一方的怨恨都很少被表达出来。在他最近的畅销书《以色列测试》（The Israel Test）中，乔治·吉尔德将此归因于反犹太主义 “在不断增长和扩大的资本主义制度下趋于减弱”。17对于那些蔑视资本主义的人，尤其是卡尔·马克思，这只是一个迹象，表明犹太价值观已经腐蚀了整个文化。另一方面，那些拥护自由企业的人不得不欣赏犹太人玩得有多好，即使偶尔会以他们为代价。吉尔德说 ：“美国人不应该掩盖犹太人在我们海岸的胜利，而应该庆祝他们，作为美国经济和文化优越自由的证据。” 18

On Main Street, open hostility seldom moved beyond the fringe. When it did, as in the Seligman hotel incident, it made headlines. Although denied certain club memberships and subjected to a variety of comparable slights, Jews felt secure enough in the rule of law to continue to innovate. Like the Rothschilds in the nineteenth century, however, the founding fathers of German-Jewish Wall Street — what author Stephen Birmingham famously described as “our crowd” —— tended to be circumspect. As successful as they had been, as closely as they mimicked the dress, speech, manners, and public altruism of their WASP counterparts, they could not quite take their success for granted. Still, it does Jewish-American culture an injustice to portray its businesspeople as victims. By the beginning of the twentieth century, they were warriors in an occasionally rough but usually civil war, fully capable of giving and taking.

在主街上，公开的敌意很少超越边缘地带。当它发生时，如在塞利格曼酒店事件中，它成为头条新闻。尽管犹太人被剥夺了某些俱乐部的会员资格，并受到各种类似的轻视，但他们对法治有足够的安全感，可以继续进行创新。然而，就像十九世纪的罗斯柴尔德家族一样，德裔华尔街的创始人 —— 作家斯蒂芬·伯明翰（Stephen Birmingham）著名地将其描述为 “我们的人群” —— 倾向于谨慎行事。尽管他们取得了成功，尽管他们严格模仿了他们的‘白鞋’同行的衣着、言语、礼仪和公共利他主义，但他们不能把他们的成功视为理所当然。尽管如此，将其商人描绘成受害者，对犹太裔美国人的文化是不公正的。到二十世纪初，他们是一场偶尔粗暴但通常是内战的勇士，完全有能力给予和接受。

As he did on any number of fronts, Henry Ford broke the civility mold. From 1919 to 1927, Ford published theDearborn Independentand expressed his views indirectly through its editors. TheIndependentcharged, among other things, that the national debt was a Jewish creation, which was slowly enslaving America. Ford saw the Federal Reserve as part of this larger plot and laid the blame on the one Jewish duck hunter, Paul Warburg. As to Jews, he thought of them as an “international nation” of people, whose internal cohesion gave them an unfair advantage in competition with the more individualistic Christians.19

正如他在许多方面所做的那样，亨利·福特打破了文明的模式。从 1919 年到 1927 年，福特出版了《迪尔伯恩独立报》（Dearborn Independent），并通过其编辑间接地表达了他的观点。该报指责说，除其他外，国债是犹太人创造的，它正在慢慢奴役美国。福特认为美联储是这一更大阴谋的一部分，并将责任归咎于一位犹太猎鸭人保罗·沃伯格。至于犹太人，他认为他们是一个 “国际民族” 的人，他们的内部凝聚力使他们在与更具个人主义的基督徒的竞争中具有不公平的优势。19

In 1920, theIndependentpublished the notoriousProtocols of the Learned Elders of Zion. At the time, this tract was widely believed to be the working document of a Jewish cabal plotting world domination. In reality, the Paris branch of the Russian secret police had taken an original document drafted to discredit the Jesuits and redrafted it to throw suspicion on the Jews and their allies in the anti-czarist ranks. Of the twenty-four protocols, one is titled “The Tyranny of Usury.” This protocol matter-of-factly describes how a state borrows money before purporting to explain how the dynamics of money lending have changed, seemingly as planned:

1920 年，《独立报》发表了臭名昭著的《锡安长老会协议》。当时，人们普遍认为这本小册子是一个犹太人阴谋统治世界的工作文件。实际上，俄国秘密警察的巴黎分部采用了一份为诋毁耶稣会而起草的原始文件，并将其重新起草，以怀疑犹太人和他们在反沙皇主义队伍中的盟友。在二十四份协议中，有一份名为 “高利贷的暴政”。这份协议实事求是地描述了一个国家是如何借钱的，然后声称要解释货币借贷的动态是如何改变的，似乎是按计划进行的：

So long as loans were internal the GOYIM only shuffled their money from the pockets of the poor to those of the rich, but when we bought up the necessary persons in order to transfer loans into the external sphere, all the wealth of States flowed into our cash-boxes and all the GOYIM began to pay us the tribute of subjects.20

只要贷款是对内的，GOYIM 就只是把他们的钱从穷人的口袋里洗到富人的口袋里，但当我们买下必要的人，以便把贷款转移到外部领域时，所有国家的财富都流入我们的钱箱，所有 GOYIM 开始向我们缴纳臣民的贡品。 20

If this sounds extreme today, in 1920 — after a century of Rothschild dominance in European money markets — it did not. Had J. P. Morgan also been Jewish, the paranoia that raged through Europe might have infected America as well. But Morgan saved the day once more. The debate over whether consumers should indebt themselves remained secular and civil and was largely settled by the end of the 1920s.

如果这在今天听起来很极端，在 1920 年 —— 在罗斯柴尔德在欧洲货币市场占据一个世纪的统治地位之后 —— 它并没有。如果 J.P. 摩根也是犹太人，肆虐欧洲的偏执狂可能也会感染到美国。但摩根又一次拯救了世界。关于消费者是否应该负债的争论仍然是世俗和民间的，并在二十世纪 20 年代末基本解决。

The June 1928 issue ofCentury Magazinerelates a history of installment credit that was both amusing and accurate. It tells the tale of the “Bad Boy” of the business world known as “Instalment Buying,” who was “despised by his affluent brother Cash Down, and his more respectable cousin Charge Account.” After years of abuse, the tables turned.

1928 年 6 月出版的《世纪杂志》讲述了一段既有趣又准确的分期付款信贷历史。它讲述了被称为 “分期付款购买” 的商业世界的 “坏孩子” 的故事，他被他富裕的兄弟 “Cash Down” 和他更体面的表弟 “Charge Account” 所鄙视。经过多年的虐待，情况发生了变化。

The Bad Boy grew up to be a fine member of society, and today leads the merchandising parade by many millions of dollars. He has changed his name and now appears in the best circles as the Acceptance or Finance Plan. . . . Scholarly economists laud his works; books are written about him, philosophies evolved, and he is gradually taking his place as a power in the land.21

坏小子长大后成为社会的优秀成员，今天以数百万美元的价格在商品销售队伍中领先。他已经改了名字，现在以接受或金融计划的名义出现在最好的圈子里…… 学术界的经济学家们称赞他的作品；关于他的书被写出来，哲学也得到了发展，他逐渐在这片土地上占据了自己的位置。21

By 1928, the spirit of borrowing to buy stuff had spilled over into Wall Street. It was about to suffer a setback.

到 1928 年，借钱买东西的精神已经蔓延到华尔街。它即将遭受挫折。

twenty-twoExpelling the Money Changers 驱逐货币兑换商

IF THERE IS ANY ONE IMAGE THAT EVOKES THE OCCASIONAL WHIMSY OF the New Deal, it is this one: President Franklin Delano Roosevelt sitting in his bedroom with Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., deciding what the daily price of gold would be. Imagine an antsy Gene Wilder as Morgenthau and a capricious Zero Mostel as Roosevelt. The scene that follows is reportedly true:

如果有任何一幅图像能够体现出新政的偶然性，那就是这幅图像。富兰克林·德拉诺·罗斯福总统与财政部长小亨利·摩根索坐在他的卧室里，决定每天的黄金价格。想象一下，焦急的吉恩·怀尔德扮演摩根索，任性的佐罗·莫斯特尔扮演罗斯福。下面的场景据说是真的：


FDR : Now, Henry, how much should we hike gold today?

罗斯福 : 现在，亨利，我们今天应该把黄金加价到多少？

MORGENTHAU : Uhhh, ten cents?

摩根 : 呃，10 美分？

FDR : Oh, Henry!

罗斯福 : 哦，亨利！

摩根 : Fifteen cents?

摩根 : 十五美分？

罗斯福 : Let’s go . . . twenty-one cents!

FDR : 我们走吧…… 21 美分！

MORGENTHAU (alarmed): Twenty-one cents?

摩根 :（惊呼）二十一美分？

FDR (jauntily waving cigarette holder): Three times seven — it’s a lucky number!

罗斯福 :（愉快地挥舞着烟嘴）3 乘以 7 —— 这是个幸运的数字！

Said fallen away New Dealer Raymond Moley, in a wee bit of an understatement, “Roosevelt gravely marred his image as a responsible statesman, by the early-morning bedside guesses with Morgenthau about what the price of gold was to be that day.’” 1

落魄的新经销商雷蒙德·莫里（Raymond Moley）轻描淡写地说 ：“罗斯福严重损害了他作为一个负责任的政治家的形象，因为他一大早就和摩根索在床边猜测那天的黄金价格是多少。” 1

Just five or so years earlier, America had sat astride the economic world, the repository of most of its gold and even more of its hope. The president at that time, Republican Calvin Coolidge, could not have differed more from FDR. In her breakthrough reassessment of the Depression,The Forgotten Man, Amity Shlaes nicely summarizes Silent Cal’s humility and restraint: “Coolidge had long ago determined that the world would do better if he involved himself less.” 2

就在五年多以前，美国还坐在经济世界的中心位置，是美国大部分黄金和更多希望的存放地。当时的总统，共和党人卡尔文·柯立芝(Calvin Coolidge)，与罗斯福没有什么不同。在她对大萧条的突破性重新评估《被遗忘的人》中，阿米蒂·施莱斯（Amity Shlaes）很好地总结了沉默的卡尔文的谦逊和克制。"2

Presidential discretion, Coolidge believed, led to economic stability.3Businesses, he believed, welcomed an administration whose approach to its business clientele mirrored what consumers would later see in a 1970s-era Holiday Inn ad campaign: no surprises. Businesses could plan more confidently if they could trust their government. This strategy seemed to be working. As vice president under Harding, Coolidge had seen how the administration’s hands-off approach to the downturn of 1920 had allowed businesses to cut their losses, trim their payrolls, and get back to work quickly. The years since had, by all accounts, been years of sustained and substantial growth, inspired in no small part by the explosive growth in the auto and radio industries.

柯立芝认为，总统的自由裁量权导致经济稳定。3他认为，企业欢迎一个对企业客户的态度与消费者后来在 1970 年代的假日酒店广告中看到的情况一致的政府：没有惊喜。如果企业能够信任他们的政府，他们就能更有信心地进行规划。这一战略似乎正在发挥作用。作为哈定的副总统，柯立芝看到了政府对 1920 年的经济衰退不闻不问的做法是如何让企业减少损失，缩减工资，并迅速恢复工作的。从各方面来看，此后的几年是持续和大幅增长的几年，这在很大程度上是受到汽车和无线电行业爆炸性增长的鼓舞。

As to the precipitating event that led to the crash of 1929, fingers point in a thousand directions, but a surprisingly high number of them point to still another private conclave among financial wizards, this one on the north shore of Long Island in August 1927.4In attendance were the chief central bankers from Germany, France, Britain, and the United States. Representing America was Benjamin Strong, president of the New York Federal Reserve and one of the Jekyll Island Six. Over the years, Strong had developed a deep personal relationship with Montagu Norman, the head of the Bank of England.

至于导致 1929 年崩盘的导火索，手指指向了无数个方向，但令人惊讶的是，其中有很多人指向了另一个金融奇才的私人会议，这个会议于 1927 年 8 月在长岛的北岸举行。 4出席会议的有德国、法国、英国和美国的首席中央银行家。代表美国的是本杰明·斯特朗（Benjamin Strong），他是纽约联邦储备委员会的主席，也是杰基尔岛六人组之一。多年来，斯特朗与英格兰银行行长蒙塔古·诺曼建立了深厚的个人关系。

Not too long before the meeting, Britain had returned to the gold standard after a wild inflationary run during the Great War.
