Unwilling to accept a diminished pound, a symbol of its own humbled standing in the world, Britain had pegged its currency artificially high, but the world wasn’t buying. Gold continued to flow into the United States. Norman leaned on his American friend to help prop up the British pound by lowering interest rates on U.S. Treasury bonds, thus making foreign investment here less attractive.

在会议召开前不久，英国在经历了大战期间的疯狂通货膨胀后，又回到了金本位制。由于不愿意接受象征着自己在世界上地位低下的英镑贬值，英国人为地将其货币挂钩，但世界并不买账。黄金继续流向美国。诺曼依靠他的美国朋友，通过降低美国国债的利率来帮助支撑英镑，从而使这里的外国投资失去吸引力。

Strong knew the risks of obliging. The stock market was running hot as it was. Typically, lower interest rates stimulate borrowing for production and consumption and make stocks relatively more attractive than bonds. As Strong confided to the French representative, a rate cut would give the market “un petit coup de whiskey.” But hey, what are friends for? A few days after the Long Island meeting, Strong overrode bitter resistance among his fellow Fed presidents and forced the rate down from 4.0 to 3.5 percent.

斯特朗知道承诺的风险。股票市场正热火朝天地运行着。通常情况下，较低的利率会刺激用于生产和消费的借贷，使股票相对比债券更有吸引力。正如斯特朗向法国代表透露的那样，降息将给市场带来 “一个小惊喜”。但是，嘿，朋友是什么？在长岛会议的几天后，斯特朗推翻了他的同僚们对美联储主席的激烈抵制，迫使利率从 4.0% 降至 3.5%。

Morgan partner Russell Leffingwell was among those who had a squirrelly feeling about the meeting. “Monty and Ben sowed the wind,” he said in March 1929, seven months before the crash. “I expect we shall have to reap the whirlwind. . . . I think we are going to have a world credit crisis.” 5In fact, stocks had begun the irrationally exuberant phase of their rally immediately after the rate cut in August 1927. This was not likely a coincidence. The Fed had helped turn a rally into a bubble.

摩根的合伙人拉塞尔·勒芬韦尔(Russell Leffingwell)是对这次会议有松动感觉的人之一。“蒙蒂和本播种了风”，他在 1929 年 3 月，即崩盘前七个月说。“我预计我们将不得不收获旋风…… 我认为我们将有一场世界性的信贷危机。” 5事实上，在 1927 年 8 月降息后，股票立即开始了非理性的繁荣阶段的涨势。这不可能是一个巧合。美联储帮助将涨势变成了泡沫。

This year, of course, also happened to be the year that E. R. A. Seligman had given his blessing to buying on time. In 1928,Century Magazinehad proclaimed “credit” the cat’s pajamas. When ordinary citizens discovered they could put as little as 10 percent down on a stock purchase and borrow the rest “on margin” in the anticipation that the rise in stock prices would pay the interest, they bulled through the financial china shops in unprecedented numbers. The story is told that financier Joe Kennedy grew wary of the market when he was offered a hot stock tip by a shoeshine boy.6With shoeshine boys buying in, Kennedy bailed out just in time.

当然，这一年也正好是 E.R.A. 塞利格曼对按时购买的大肆鼓吹的时候。1928 年，《世纪杂志》曾宣称 “信贷是猫的睡衣”。当普通公民发现他们可以在购买股票时只需支付 10% 的首付，其余的则以 “保证金” 的形式借入，并期待着股票价格的上涨能够支付利息时，他们以前所未有的数量冲进了金融瓷器店。 有这样一个故事：金融家乔·肯尼迪在一个擦鞋童提供的热门股票提示中对市场产生了警惕。6随着擦鞋童的买入，肯尼迪及时地保住了性命。

This new consumer class, bootblacks and barbers and beekeepers, did not need much encouragement. As Charles Dickens had pointed out a century earlier, everyday Americans had a fondness for speculation and “smart dealing.” By 1929, women had joined the ranks of investors. Although history has been oddly silent about their role in goosing the market, some one-third of the new speculators were female.7Brokers had taken to opening offices in New York’s more fashionable shopping districts to attract their business. In August 1929, theLadies’ Home Journalpublished a feature on investing that might have served as a manifesto if its message — Everyone Ought To Be Rich — had not proved so unfashionable just three months later.

这个新的消费阶层，鞋匠、理发师和养蜂人，并不需要太多的鼓励。正如查尔斯·狄更斯（Charles Dickens）在一个世纪前指出的那样，普通美国人对投机和 “聪明的交易” 情有独钟。到 1929 年，妇女已经加入了投资者的行列。虽然历史上对她们在破坏市场方面的作用保持着奇怪的沉默，但大约三分之一的新投机者是女性。7经纪人已经开始在纽约比较时尚的购物区开设办公室，以吸引她们的生意。1929 年 8 月，《女士家庭杂志》(Ladies' Home Journal)发表了一篇关于投资的专题文章，如果其信息 “每个人都应该富有” (Everyone Ought To Be Rich)在三个月后没有被证明是如此不合时宜的话，那么它可能会成为一份宣言。

Of course, not everyone was keen on speculation. In February 1929, Alabama senator Tom Heflin introduced a resolution asking the Federal Reserve to tame the market. “Wall Street has become the most notorious gambling center in the universe,” 8he thundered. But the hip new investor class did not exactly share this yokel’s view that the stock market was a “monstrous evil.” Meanwhile, the Fed — with its power divided between the regional presidents and the Washington governing board — dithered. The death of Benjamin Strong the year earlier had left a power vacuum that his successor, George Harrison, was never quite able to fill.

当然，不是所有人都热衷于投机。1929 年 2 月，阿拉巴马州参议员汤姆·海夫林提出一项决议，要求美联储驯服市场。“华尔街已经成为宇宙中最臭名昭著的赌博中心”，8他咆哮道。但时髦的新投资者阶层并不完全赞同这个乡巴佬的观点，即股市是一个 “可怕的邪恶”。与此同时，随着美联储在地区主席和华盛顿管理委员会之间权力的划分，他们都犹豫不决。本杰明·斯特朗在一年前去世，留下了一个权力真空，他的继任者乔治·哈里森始终无法填补。

As early as 1925, Coolidge’s activist commerce secretary Herbert Hoover had been warning against the dangers of speculation, but his concern had been premature. The market was not yet overheated. As Coolidge would say of “Boy Wonder” Hoover, “That man has offered me unsolicited advice for six years, all of it bad.” 9

早在 1925 年，柯立芝的积极分子商务部长赫伯特·胡佛就已经对投机的危险发出警告，但他的担忧为时过早。市场还没有过热。正如柯立芝在谈到 “神奇小子” 胡佛时所说 ：“这个人六年来一直向我提供不请自来的建议，而且都是坏建议。” 9

Hoover’s remarkable success had made him a know-it-all. Orphaned as a boy in Iowa and shipped out to his California relatives, Hoover had majored in geology and engineering at Stanford and within a few years of his graduation had virtually reinvented gold mining. His mastery of this art had become as hot a commodity as the gold he knew how to find. At the age of thirty, he was reportedly the highest-paid man of his generation. During and after World War I, Hoover single-handedly, or so it seemed, managed the massive food relief efforts throughout Europe. Author Sherwood Anderson would describe his face as that of a man who “had never known failure.” 10This was about to change.

胡佛的非凡成功使他成为一个无所不知的人。胡佛小时候是爱荷华州的孤儿，被送到加州的亲戚家中，他在斯坦福大学主修地质学和工程学，在毕业后的几年里，他几乎重新发明了金矿。他对这门艺术的掌握已经成为一种热门商品，就像他知道如何找到黄金一样。据报道，在 30 岁时，他是他那一代人中收入最高的人。在第一次世界大战期间和之后，胡佛单枪匹马，或者说似乎是单枪匹马，管理整个欧洲的大规模粮食救济工作。作家舍伍德·安德森(Sherwood Anderson)将他的脸描述为一个 “从不知道失败” 的人。10 这即将改变。

The “standard history” of the Depression, as Shlaes notes, is that “Hoover made matters worse through his obdurate refusal to take control, his risible commitment to what he called rugged individualism. Roosevelt, however, made things better by taking charge. His New Deal inspired and tided the country over.” 11Only in the last few years has the grip of this history on our national consciousness begun to ease, and with good reason: the narrative is more false than true in every detail. Beyond that, it ignores the critical role of the Federal Reserve. As the events of 1987 proved, a market crash does not necessarily lead to depression, even recession. That it did in 1929 and thereafter owes more than a little to the misadventures of the still-learning Federal Reserve.

大萧条的 “标准历史”，正如史里斯（Shlaes）指出的那样，“胡佛通过顽固地拒绝控制，对他所谓的粗犷的个人主义的可笑承诺，使事情变得更糟。然而，罗斯福通过负责任使事情变得更好。他的新政激励并帮助国家渡过难关。” 11只有在过去几年里，这段历史对我们国家意识的控制才开始放松，而且有充分的理由：这种叙述在每个细节上都是假的多于真的。此外，它忽略了美联储的关键作用。正如 1987 年的事件所证明的那样，市场崩溃不一定导致萧条，甚至衰退。在 1929 年及其后，它的发生要归功于仍在学习中的美联储的错误行为，而不是一点点。

Sworn in as president eight months before the crash, Hoover contributed his own fair share to the unraveling, but not by being passive. Passivity was not his style. “Words are not of any great importance in times of economic disturbance,” he announced. “It is action that counts.” 12Unfortunately, just about every action Hoover took proved to be the wrong one. He raised taxes, browbeat businesses into sustaining wages and employment, bullied the stock market, and signed into law the flamingly disastrous Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, which triggered a fury of retaliatory measures around the world and sharply cut American exports as well as imports.

在崩盘前八个月，胡佛被任命为总统，他对崩盘做出了自己应有的贡献，但不是因为被动。被动并不是他的风格。他宣布 ：“在经济动荡时期，言语并不重要。行动才算数。” 12不幸的是，胡佛采取的每一项行动都被证明是错误的。他提高了税率，向企业施压以维持工资和就业，欺负股票市场，并签署了 1930 年的《斯穆特·霍利关税法》（Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act），该法案引发了世界各地的报复性措施，大幅削减美国的出口和进口。

By and large, economists are as hard on the Federal Reserve as they are on Hoover.13They argue that the Fed was tightening the money supply when it should have been loosening it. The hard-money economists who make up the so-called Austrian school — Van Mises, Hayek, and their allies — dispute this interpretation. The Austrians argue that Hoover and the Fed tried their best to inflate, but that their efforts were “foiled by the good sense, and by the increasing distrust of the banking system, of the American people.” 14What seems beyond dispute is that, for whatever reason, the actual supply of money in the United States dropped by 4 percent between the end of 1928 and the end of 1930.15

总的来说，经济学家对美联储的态度和对胡佛的态度一样强硬。13他们认为，在应该放松货币供应的时候，美联储却收紧了。构成所谓奥地利学派的硬通货经济学家 —— 范·米塞斯（Van Mises）, 哈耶克（Hayek）和他们的盟友 —— 对这种解释提出异议。奥地利派认为，胡佛和美联储竭尽全力进行通货膨胀，但他们的努力 “被美国人民的良好意识和对银行系统的日益不信任所挫败。” 14似乎无可争议的是，不管出于什么原因，美国的实际货币供应量在 1928 年底和 1930 年底之间下降了 4%。 15

In the place of a Morgan striding down Wall Street, solving problems as he strode, America got a Mexican standoff. The New York Fed, the regional banks, and their Washington overseers were all looking at each other and saying, “Now what?” The paralysis was obvious before the crash in the Fed’s inconsistent response to an overheated market and even more obvious afterward.16Under Hoover and the Fed, the government had assumed for the first time the responsibility for the nation’s prosperity. Profit, however, has a cool logic of its own that politicians have never quite understood.

在摩根大步走过华尔街、边走边解决问题的地方，美国得到了一个墨西哥式的对峙。纽约联储、地区银行和它们的华盛顿监督者都在互相对视，说 ：“现在怎么办？” 在崩盘之前，美联储对过热市场的反应不一致，这种瘫痪是显而易见的，而在崩盘之后则更加明显。16在胡佛和美联储的领导下，政府首次承担了国家繁荣的责任。然而，利润有其自身的冷静逻辑，政治家们从未完全理解。

The patrician Roosevelt did not even care to learn. In his March 1933 inaugural address, Roosevelt may have eased the fears of the ordinary citizens, but he intensified the fears of those he most needed to assuage, the investor class. “The rulers of the exchange of mankind’s goods,” he insisted, “have failed through their own stubbornness and their own incompetence.” 17From that day forward, no businessperson could anticipate FDR’s market logicdu jourany better than he could his gold price.

贵族式的罗斯福甚至不屑于学习。在 1933 年 3 月的就职演说中，罗斯福可能缓解了普通公民的恐惧，但他加剧了他最需要安抚的人 —— 投资者阶层的恐惧。他坚持认为，“人类商品交换的统治者由于自己的顽固和无能而失败了。” 17从那一天起，没有一个商人预测罗斯福当天的市场逻辑，预测的准确性甚至不如他们预测当天的黄金价格。

Although Roosevelt had several trusted Jewish advisors, Morgenthau among them, he seemed to have been dangling a little fresh Semitic meat in front of the inaugural crowd when he railed about “the unscrupulous money changers” who had brought America to its knees. According to Roosevelt, these “self-seekers” could only propose “the lending of more money” as solution to theirs and the nation’s problems. To drive the point home about the evils of such wanton usury, he continued with an analogy that America’s biblically literate population surely understood, “The money changers have fled their high seats in the temple of our civilization. We may now restore that temple to the ancient truths.” 18

尽管罗斯福有几个值得信赖的犹太顾问，摩根索就是其中之一，但他在就职典礼上抨击使美国陷入困境的 “肆无忌惮的货币兑换商” 时，似乎是把一块新鲜的闪族肉挂在了人群面前。根据罗斯福的说法，这些 “自我追求者” 只能提出 “借出更多的钱” 来解决他们自己和国家的问题。为了将这种肆意高利贷的罪恶推向深入，他继续打了一个比方，美国懂圣经的人肯定明白 ：“货币兑换商已经逃离了他们在我们文明的圣殿中的高位。我们现在可以把这个寺庙恢复到古代的真理。” 18

Whether intentionally or not, Roosevelt was rephrasing the themes that Karl Marx had laid out in his treatise “On the Jewish Question.” Marx, it should be recalled, saw salvation for Jews and for society at large only after society had “succeeded in abolishing the empirical essence of Judaism — huckstering and its preconditions.” 19Roosevelt was sophisticated enough to know that WASPs had as much financial clout as Jews. If not as explicitly as Marx, however, Roosevelt implied that there was something inherently Jewish about the source of that clout, “the mad chase of evanescent profits,” and something inherently Christian about the “ancient truths.” These Roosevelt described as “social values more noble than mere monetary profit.” 20

无论有意还是无意，罗斯福都在重新表述卡尔·马克思在其论文《论犹太人问题》中提出的主题。应该记得，马克思认为只有在社会 “成功地废除了犹太教的经验性本质 —— 胡作非为及其前提条件” 之后，犹太人和整个社会才能得到拯救。 19罗斯福足够成熟，知道‘白鞋’与犹太人一样有经济影响力。然而，如果没有像马克思那样明确，罗斯福暗示，关于这种影响力的来源，有一些固有的犹太人的东西，“对短暂利润的疯狂追逐”，以及一些固有的基督教的 “古老真理”。这些被罗斯福描述为 “比单纯的货币利润更高尚的社会价值”。20

After describing a variety of actions to get people back to work, Roosevelt turned his inaugural sights once again on “the evils of the old order.” That this order had made America so prosperous that its dispossessed Okies could drive their own cars to California was lost on Roosevelt and his allies. “There must be a strict supervision of all banking and credits and investments,” he railed, fully ignoring the role of government in creating the mess he had inherited, “there must be an end to speculation with other people’s money, and there must be provision for an adequate but sound currency.” 21

在描述了让人们重新工作的各种行动之后，罗斯福再次将他的就职目光转向 “旧秩序的罪恶”。这种秩序使美国如此繁荣，以至于其一无所有的奥基斯人可以开着自己的汽车去加利福尼亚，但罗斯福和他的盟友却不知道这一点。“必须对所有的银行业务、信贷和投资进行严格的监督”，他抨击道，完全无视政府在造成他所继承的混乱局面中的作用，“必须停止用别人的钱进行投机，必须规定一种充足而健全的货币。” 21=

Roosevelt proved to have unusual ideas as to what exactly constituted a “sound currency,” especially when it came to gold. Two days after the inauguration, he used the legal cover of the wartime Trading with the Enemy Act to declare war on those who were “hoarding” gold.22Three days later, he signed into law the Emergency Banking Act. This bill, which evoked unfond memories of John Law’s tyrannical endgame in eighteenth-century France, gave FDR the authority to demand the surrender of all gold by American citizens in exchange for paper money. A month later, he set May 1, 1933, as the deadline for the surrender. As the conspiracy-minded noted, this just happened to be International Workers’ Day in the socialist world. Those who failed to surrender their gold could face as many as ten years in prison.

事实证明，罗斯福对什么是 “健全的货币” 有着不同寻常的想法，特别是在涉及到黄金的时候。就职两天后，他利用战时《对敌贸易法》的法律掩护，向那些 “囤积” 黄金的人宣战。22三天后，他将《紧急银行法》签署为法律。这项法案唤起了人们对约翰·劳在十八世纪法国的暴政结局的美好回忆，它赋予了罗斯福权力，要求美国公民交出所有黄金以换取纸币。一个月后，他将 1933 年 5 月 1 日定为交出黄金的最后期限。正如那些有阴谋论的人所指出的，这一天正好是社会主义世界的国际工人节。那些未能交出黄金的人可能面临多达 10 年的监禁。

The motive for the seizure of gold was simple enough. Roosevelt wanted to inflate the currency to appease the indebted, especially the farmers. If citizens had the right to redeem currency in gold, as they did under the gold standard, they would turn in their cheapened paper dollars for gold and withdraw the gold from circulation: Gresham’s Law. So the Roosevelt administration criminalized the very possession of gold. In July 1933, Roosevelt denounced the gold standard as one of the “old fetishes” that needed to be replaced. In August 1933, FDR issued an executive order demanding that all U.S. gold producers sell their output to the secretary of treasury at a price that he (with his predilection for lucky numbers) and the secretary would determine.

扣押黄金的动机很简单。罗斯福想让货币膨胀以安抚债务人，特别是农民。如果公民有权用黄金赎回货币，就像他们在金本位制下所做的那样，他们就会用廉价的纸币换取黄金，并从流通中收回黄金。格雷沙姆法则。因此，罗斯福政府将拥有黄金的行为定为犯罪。1933 年 7 月，罗斯福谴责金本位制是需要被取代的 “旧癖好” 之一。1933 年 8 月，罗斯福发布了一项行政命令，要求所有美国黄金生产商以他（对幸运数字的偏爱）和财政部长确定的价格向财政部长出售他们的产出。

“It may be that an unprecedented demand and need for undelayed action may call for temporary departure from that normal balance of public procedure,” 23Roosevelt had promised in his inaugural. He was as good as his word. The civic strip mining of America’s gold was executed without benefit of a single Congressional hearing. Needless to say, this process did not inspire a lot of confidence within the business community.

“可能是一种前所未有的需求和对不延迟行动的需要可能要求暂时偏离公共程序的正常平衡”，23罗斯福在其就职典礼上承诺。他果然言出必行。对美国黄金的公民性剥离开采没有经过一次国会听证会就被执行了。不用说，这个过程并没有给商业界带来很多信心。

Roosevelt was just as adventurous on the banking front. Immediately upon taking office he ordered all banks that were closed to remain closed, even though he had no authority under the Constitution to do this. The Emergency Banking Act, which he had Congress pass immediately thereafter, gave him the power not only to close banks but also to print money wartime-style as he saw fit.

罗斯福在银行业方面也同样具有冒险精神。上任后，他立即命令所有被关闭的银行继续关闭，尽管根据宪法他没有权力这样做。此后，他让国会立即通过了《紧急银行法》，不仅赋予他关闭银行的权力，还赋予他在战时印制货币的权力。

From day one, Roosevelt had done his best to dethrone the “privileged princes of these new economic dynasties,” 24FDR-code for influential bankers. He joyfully imputed a feudal hauteur to their resistance. “These economic royalists complain that we seek to overthrow the institutions of America,” he argued at the 1936 Democratic National Convention. “What they really complain of is that we seek to take away their power.” 25

从第一天开始，罗斯福就竭尽全力要推翻 “那些新经济王朝的特权王子”，24这是罗斯福对有影响力的银行家的编码。他欣喜地将一种封建的高级感归于他们的抵抗。他在 1936 年的民主党全国大会上说 ：“这些经济保皇党人抱怨我们试图推翻美国的制度。他们真正抱怨的是，我们试图夺走他们的权力。” 25

Ironically, however, it was bankers like the Morgans who were diversified enough to weather the Depression and protect their depositors.26It was not economic royalism that led to the great majority of bank failures, but myopic legislation designed to protect local monopolies. Some 90 percent of failures occurred in states whose “unit” banking laws forbade banks from branching out beyond their base. Canada, which had no such laws, had no such problems. Those one-office banks that hung on clamored for federal deposit insurance to protect them against the self-defeating regulation that was making survival difficult.

然而，从历史上看，正是像摩根家族这样的银行家有足够的多样性来度过大萧条并保护他们的储户。26导致绝大多数银行倒闭的不是经济保权主义，而是旨在保护地方垄断的近视立法。大约 90% 的银行倒闭发生在 “单位” 银行法禁止银行在其基地之外设立分支机构的州。加拿大没有这样的法律，也没有这样的问题。那些坚持下来的单一办公室的银行吵着要联邦存款保险，以保护它们不受使生存变得困难的自我毁灭的监管。

In June 1933, Roosevelt signed into law the Glass-Steagall Act. In the apt words of author Michael Lewis, the act “cleaved mankind in two.” 27Banks now had to choose between investment and deposit banking. They could not do both. A classic in political scapegoating, the act rewarded those banks that had done the worst and punished the banks that had done the best. It provided deposit insurance for the struggling banks and forced the successful ones to divest their investment banking operations. As Morgan biographer Ron Chernow observes, “The Glass-Steagall Act took dead aim at the House of Morgan.” 28

1933 年 6 月，罗斯福签署了《格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案》，使之成为法律。用作家迈克尔·刘易斯(Michael Lewis)的话说，该法案 “将人类一分为二”。27银行现在不得不在投资银行和存款银行之间做出选择。他们不能同时进行。作为政治替罪羊的经典之作，该法案奖励了那些表现最差的银行，惩罚了表现最好的银行。它为陷入困境的银行提供存款保险，迫使成功的银行剥离其投资银行业务。正如摩根传记作者罗恩·切尔诺(Ron Chernow)所言，“《格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案》完全瞄准了摩根家族。” 28

The intellectual force behind much of this new legislation was Louis Brandeis. As a public advocate twenty years earlier, he had taken on the Morgan & Co. in its plan to expand the New Haven Railroad. Anticipating FDR, he argued that the company symbolized “a monopolistic and predatory control over the financial and industrial resources of the country” 29and prevailed. Brandeis had counseled Woodrow Wilson in his 1912 run for the presidency and was rewarded with a seat on the Supreme Court, the first Jew so appointed.

这项新立法背后的知识力量是路易斯·布兰代斯。作为一名公共倡导者，二十年前，他曾在摩根公司扩建纽黑文铁路的计划中与该公司交锋。他预见到罗斯福会认为该公司象征着 “对国家金融和工业资源的垄断性和掠夺性控制” 29并取得胜利。布兰代斯曾在伍德罗·威尔逊 1912 年竞选总统时为他提供咨询，并获得了最高法院的一个席位，成为第一个被任命为最高法院法官的犹太人。

Not overly squeamish about the separation of powers, Brandeis continued to advise presidents, Roosevelt included, using his daughter as a liaison to the president. The Morgans blamed Brandeis for Glass-Steagall. “I have little doubt that he inspired it, or even drafted it. The Jews do not forget. They are relentless,” lamented Russell Leffingwell to his fellow Morgan partner Thomas Lamont in still another chapter of Wall Street’s ongoing culture wars. “The reason why I make so much of this is that I think you underestimate the forces we are antagonizing.” 30

布兰代斯对权力分立并不过分畏惧，他继续为包括罗斯福在内的总统提供建议，利用他的女儿作为与总统的联络人。摩根夫妇将格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案归咎于布兰代斯。“我几乎不怀疑他启发了它，或者甚至起草了它。犹太人不会忘记。他们是无情的”，在华尔街正在进行的文化战争的另一个篇章中，罗素·勒芬韦尔对他的摩根合伙人托马斯-拉蒙特感叹道。“我之所以这么说，是因为我认为你低估了我们正在对抗的力量。” 30

In 1934, a year after Glass-Steagall, the Morgans lobbied just as hard against the impending Securities Exchange Act, a sweeping piece of legislation that placed the sale of stocks and bonds under federal control. The Morgans argued that the proposed regulations would turn Wall Street into a “deserted village,” 31but they did not deter Congress or the White House. To aggravate the Morgans all the more, Roosevelt named their old nemesis, Joe Kennedy, to be the first chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

1934 年，在格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案（Glass-Steagall）出台一年后，摩根家族同样努力游说反对即将出台的证券交易法，这是一项将股票和债券的销售置于联邦控制之下的全面立法。摩根家族认为，拟议的法规将把华尔街变成一个 “荒废的村庄”，31但他们并没有能够阻止国会或白宫。为了让摩根家族更加恼火，罗斯福任命他们的老对手乔·肯尼迪为证券交易委员会的第一任主席。

In 1935, forced to choose between deposit banking and investment banking, the house of Morgan shocked Wall Street by abandoning the side of the business that had made them rich and famous. Leffingwell explained his decision in a letter to Roosevelt, asking him to repeal Glass-Steagall: “Nobody can afford to be in the business unless he has a good bread and butter business to live on. A house exclusively in the underwriting business is under too much pressure to pay overhead and living issues to pick and choose the issues it will underwrite.” 32

1935 年，摩根家族被迫在存款银行和投资银行之间做出选择，他们放弃了让他们发家致富的业务，这让华尔街震惊。勒芬韦尔在给罗斯福的信中解释了他的决定，要求他废除格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案 ：“除非有良好的面包和黄油业务来维持生计，否则没有人能够负担得起这一行。一家专门从事承销业务的公司在支付管理费用和生活问题上的压力太大，无法挑选承销的问题。” 32

A blue chip off the old block, thirty-four-year-old grandson Henry Morgan, along with partner Harold Stanley and a few others, split from the mother ship and in 1935 launched the investment banking house of Morgan Stanley. Within a year, the new firm had achieved nearly 25 percent market share in public offerings. Over the next seventy-five years, no investment bankers would do consistently better than Morgan Stanley. Not to worry: J. P. Morgan & Co. would be heard from again as well.

作为老牌的蓝筹股，34 岁的孙子亨利·摩根与合伙人哈罗德·斯坦利和其他几个人一起，从母体中分离出来，在 1935 年成立了摩根斯坦利投资银行。一年之内，新公司在公开募股中取得了近 25% 的市场份额。在接下来的 75 年里，没有任何投资银行家会比摩根士丹利做得更好。不用担心：J.P.Morgan & Co. 也会再次出现在人们面前。

For all of the sound and fury of FDR’s reign, and for all the soothing charm of his style, the New Deal did not deliver. And no one knew that better than an eventually disappointed Morgenthau. “We are spending more money than we have ever spent before and it does not work,” he told a Congressional hearing in 1939. “I want to see this country prosperous. I want to see people get jobs. We have never made good on our promises. I say after eight years of this administration we have just as much unemployment as when we started and an enormous debt to boot.” 33In 1939, seventeen — as in a 17 percent unemployment rate — was no one’s idea of a lucky number.

对于罗斯福统治时期的所有声音和愤怒，以及他的风格的所有舒缓魅力，新政并没有兑现。没有人比最终失望的摩根索更清楚这一点。他在 1939 年的一次国会听证会上说 ：“我们花的钱比以往任何时候都多，但这并不奏效。我想看到这个国家的繁荣。我想看到人们得到工作。我们从来没有兑现过我们的承诺。我说，在本届政府执政八年之后，我们的失业率和我们开始执政时一样多，而且还有巨额债务。” 33在 1939 年，17 —— 如 17% 的失业率 —— 是没有人认为幸运的数字。

twenty-threeHoly Land 圣地

IN POST–CIVIL WAR AMERICA, THE ONLY DECADE MORE ANOMALOUS than the 1930s was the 1940s. For much of that decade, history skidded sideways, particularly the history of credit and debit. Ford was selling tanks and planes — more than four hundred B-24s in a single month — not Model As and Model Ts. There was only one buyer and no installment plans. Consumers were investing not in stocks and bonds but in War Bonds. Homes were not being built, let alone sold.

在二战后的美国，唯一比 1930 年代更混乱的年代是 1940 年代。在那十年的大部分时间里，历史都在侧滑，特别是信贷和借贷的历史。福特公司销售的是坦克和飞机；在一个月内销售了四百多架 B-24 飞机；而不是 As 型和 T 型车。当时只有一个买家，没有分期付款计划。消费者不是投资于股票和债券，而是投资于战争债券。房屋没有被建造，更不用说出售了。

Most anomalous of all was the behavior of individual consumers: they were saving money in unprecedented amounts. The numbers astonish: personal savings rose from $3.8 billion in 1940 to $37.3 billion in 1944, a nearly tenfold increase.1Businesses were setting aside money as well. When the extreme fiscal and monetary policies of the wartime government righted themselves after the war, the cumulative savings of both individuals and business stimulated both investment and consumption. The Depression was not coming back.

最反常的是个人消费者的行为：他们正在以前所未有的数量存钱。这些数字令人吃惊：个人储蓄从 1940 年的 38 亿美元上升到 1944 年的 373 亿美元，增长了近 10 倍。1企业也在留出资金。当战时政府的极端财政和货币政策在战后得到纠正时，个人和企业的累积储蓄刺激了投资和消费。大萧条已经一去不复返了。

The signs of regeneration were nowhere more obvious than in Southern California. In 1950, just south of Los Angeles and east of Long Beach, developers got to work on ten square miles of scrubland and lima bean fields. There they built an instant city and called it, for no apparent reason, Lakewood. In the first ten months of Lakewood’s existence, the developers sold 7,400 single-family homes. As Lakewood city administrator D. J. Waldie notes in his wonderful memoir,Holy Land, “Buyers needed only a steady job, and the promise they would keep up the payments.” 2The city of Lakewood was incorporated in 1954. By 1960, it would house 67,000 people, virtually every one of them in his or her own home.

再生的迹象在南加州是最明显的。1950 年，就在洛杉矶的南部和长滩的东部，开发商开始在 10 平方英里的灌木丛和利马豆田上工作。他们在那里建立了一个即时的城市，并毫无理由地将其称为湖木市。在湖木市存在的头十个月里，开发商卖出了 7,400 套单户住宅。正如湖木市行政长官瓦德（D.J.Waldie）在他精彩的回忆录《圣地》（Holy Land）中指出的那样，“买主只需要一份稳定的工作，以及他们将保持付款的承诺。” 2湖木市于 1954 年成立。到 1960 年，它将容纳 67,000 人，几乎每一个人都在自己的家里。

The average age of the wives in that early 1950s wave of Lakewood home­buyers was twenty-six, the husbands thirty-two. Most of the men had served in World War II, Korea, or both. Many were the first members of their extended families to own their own homes. They had title to these houses due in no small part to the efforts of the federal government to put people in their own homes. Lakewood residents were not unique in this regard. Orange County, immediately to the south of Los Angeles County, would see its population swell from 200,000 people in 1950 to 2 million by 1980, and the majority of these people in their own homes as well.

20 世纪 50 年代初的那波湖心岛购房者中，妻子的平均年龄是 26 岁，丈夫是 32 岁。大多数男人都曾在二战、朝鲜战争中服役，或两者皆有。许多人是他们大家庭中第一个拥有自己住房的成员。他们拥有这些房子的所有权，在很大程度上是由于联邦政府努力让人们拥有自己的房子。在这方面，湖木市的居民并不是独一无二的。紧邻洛杉矶县南部的奥兰治县，其人口将从 1950 年的 20 万猛增到 1980 年的 200 万，而这些人中的大多数也都有自己的房子。

In fact, the federal government had been in the home credit business since at least 1862, when President Lincoln signed the Homestead Act, a subtle anti­slavery bill that gave settlers free title to fifty acres of public land with the only condition being they live there and develop it. Although well intentioned, the act was exploited by a fair share of sharp dealers who hoped to cash in on government largesse. The act also put an awful lot of people into properties that they could not sustain. Do we see a pattern developing here? The homeowners most vulnerable were those on the Western plains, beyond dependable rainfall. The Depression-era Dust Bowl would send many of these families packing, and many of their children would find themselves homesteading with government help in places like Lakewood and Orange County.

事实上，至少从 1862 年起，联邦政府就开始从事房屋信贷业务，当时林肯总统签署了《宅地法》，这是一项微妙的反奴隶制法案，给予定居者 50 英亩公共土地的免费所有权，唯一的条件是他们在那里居住和开发。尽管该法案的初衷是好的，但却被相当一部分希望从政府的慷慨中获利的尖锐商人所利用。该法案还将很多人投入到他们无法维持的房产中。我们在这里看到一个模式的发展吗？最脆弱的房主是那些位于西部平原的人，他们没有可靠的降雨。大萧条时期的沙尘暴将使这些家庭中的许多人打包，而他们的许多孩子会发现自己在政府的帮助下在湖心岛和奥兰治县等地自耕自食。

The first president to make a serious effort at finding homes for the nation’s nonfarm citizens was can-do Herbert Hoover. In fact, Hoover started his home-owning campaign while still secretary of commerce. “Nothing is worse than increased tenancy and landlordism,” 3he preached. Living in a Hooverville, even without a landlord, might strike the residents thereof as a tad worse, but such independent living was still a few years away.

第一位认真努力为全国非农业公民寻找住房的总统是能干的赫伯特·胡佛。事实上，胡佛在还是商务部长的时候就开始了他的购房运动。"3他宣扬 ：“没有什么比租赁和房东主义的增加更糟糕的了。” 住在胡佛村，即使没有房东，也可能会让其中的居民觉得有点糟糕，但这样的独立生活还需要几年时间。

In 1922, Hoover launched the “Own Your Own Home” campaign, arguing that the homeowner tends to be happier and more productive than the renter.4For all his genius, Hoover failed to ask a question that has escaped lesser political lights as well: does home owning make people more happy and productive or are happy and productive people more likely to own homes?

1922 年，胡佛发起了 “拥有自己的家” 运动，认为房主往往比租房者更快乐，更有生产力。 4尽管胡佛是个天才，但他没有提出一个同样逃不过的政治问题：拥有住房是否使人们更快乐、更有生产力，或者快乐和有生产力的人更可能拥有住房？

Hoover’s campaign, aided by new rules that allowed nationally chartered banks more latitude with home loans, resulted in a surge of home building. From mid-1927 to mid-1929, the mortgage lending of the national banks grew 45 percent. At the time, most home loans were relatively short-term. The borrower presumed that, if need be, he could refinance as the note came due. After the crash of 1929, however, the marginal borrowers that Hoover had prodded into home buying often lacked the wherewithal to refinance the homes he had prodded them to buy.

胡佛的运动，在允许全国性特许银行在住房贷款方面有更大自由度的新规则的帮助下，导致了住房建设的激增。从 1927 年中期到 1929 年中期，国家银行的抵押贷款增长了 45%。当时，大多数住房贷款是相对短期的。借款人认为，如果有必要，他可以在贷款到期时再融资。然而，在 1929 年的崩溃之后，胡佛推动的边缘借款人往往缺乏资金，无法为他推动他们购买的房屋再融资。

As the market froze, Hoover used his bully pulpit to try to warm it up, but this seemed no more effective than his earlier efforts to cool down an overheated Wall Street. In the process, he proved that presidential bluster was no match for market momentum. After a series of false starts, Hoover signed the Federal Home Loan Bank Act in 1932. Launched with a dozen banks and $125 million in capital, the FHLBank System was designed to provide funds to “building and loan” institutions so that they, in turn, could make mortgages available to consumers.5Sluggish even by federal standards, the program granted a total of three loans in its first two years. By 1933, despite Hoover’s efforts or perhaps because of them, banks were foreclosing on some one thousand homes every day.

随着市场的冻结，胡佛利用他的恶霸讲坛试图使其升温，但这似乎并不比他先前为冷却过热的华尔街而做出的努力更有效。在这个过程中，他证明了总统的虚张声势是无法与市场的势头相比的。经过一系列错误的开始，胡佛在 1932 年签署了《联邦住房贷款银行法》。联邦住房贷款银行系统由十几家银行和 1.25 亿美元的资本启动，旨在向 “建筑和贷款” 机构提供资金，以便它们反过来向消费者提供抵押贷款。5即使按照联邦标准，该计划在头两年共发放三笔贷款。到 1933 年，尽管有胡佛的努力，或许是因为这些努力，银行每天都有大约 1000 个房屋被取消赎回权。

Upon taking office, Roosevelt found it more politic to assail the banks than to assess the role government had played in the housing crisis. More aggressive than Hoover, he and his administration launched the Home Owners’ Loan Corporation (HOLC) in 1933 to make low-interest loans to families in danger of foreclosure, and followed that up with the more permanent Federal Housing Administration (FHA) in 1934.6Unlike the HOLC, the FHA did not make direct loans but instead guaranteed the loans that private commercial banks would make. Amidst the rash of New Deal programs, the FHA is among the few that actually seemed to work as planned.

上任后，罗斯福发现攻击银行比评估政府在住房危机中扮演的角色更具有政治意义。他和他的政府比胡佛更积极，在 1933 年成立了房主贷款公司（HOLC），向有丧失赎回权危险的家庭提供低息贷款，并在 1934 年成立了更持久的联邦住房管理局（FHA）。 6与 HOLC 不同，FHA 并不直接提供贷款，而是为私人商业银行提供贷款担保。在众多的新政项目中，FHA 是少数几个似乎真正按计划运作的项目之一。

In 1938, to assure that lending institutions had ample money to lend, the New Dealers launched the Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA), affectionately known as Fannie Mae. Although it seems hard to believe today, for nearly the first seventy years of its existence Fannie Mae was, in fact, looked upon favorably. Fannie Mae’s mission was to help keep lenders liquid by buying their loans and, for a small fee, assuming the risk of default. This service created what has come to be known as a secondary mortgage market.

1938 年，为了保证贷款机构有充足的资金进行贷款，新经销商推出了联邦国民抵押贷款协会（FNMA），也就是人们所熟知的房利美。虽然今天看来很难相信，但在其存在的前七十年里，房利美实际上是被看好的。房利美的使命是通过购买贷款人的贷款并收取少量费用，承担违约风险，以帮助保持贷款人的流动性。这项服务创造了后来被称为二级抵押贷款市场的东西。

In 1944, Congress enacted the Servicemen’s Readjustment Act, which in turn begat the VA home loan, a program that in one mutation or another has helped put some eighteen million families in homes of their own. As with FHA loans, the government did not lend the money but rather guaranteed loans made by private mortgage lenders against loss of principal, were the veterans to default. No doubt many, if not most, of the first flush of Lakewood residents came wrapped in a government guarantee. In California, home ownership rates increased from 43 percent in 1940 to 58 percent in 1960, a figure just slightly below the national average of 61 percent.

1944 年，国会颁布了《军人再调整法案》，这又催生了退伍军人住房贷款，这个项目以这样或那样的变体帮助了大约 1800 万个家庭拥有自己的住房。与联邦住房管理局贷款一样，政府并没有借钱，而是为私人抵押贷款机构的贷款提供担保，以防止退伍军人违约时的本金损失。毫无疑问，许多，如果不是大多数，湖州的第一批居民都是在政府的担保下购买的。在加州，房屋拥有率从 1940 年的 43% 上升到 1960 年的 58%，这一数字仅略低于全国平均水平的 61%。

The federal urge to put people in homes inevitably put pressure on housing prices. To continue to meet their political commitments, the VA and FHA began to loosen their lending standards. Loosening, of course, led to increased foreclosures. In 1960, FHA-insured loans were failing at five times the rate they were in 1950, and VA loans were failing at twice the rate.7The economy was not a factor: failures in conventional mortgages remained flat throughout the decade. Traditional lenders had stuck to their underwriting standards.

联邦对人们住房的敦促不可避免地对住房价格产生了压力。为了继续履行其政治承诺，VA 和联邦住房管理局开始放松其贷款标准。当然，放宽标准导致了取消赎回权的增加。1960 年，联邦住房管理局担保的贷款失败率是 1950 年的五倍，VA 贷款失败率是 1950 年的两倍。7经济不是一个因素：传统抵押贷款的失败率在这十年中保持平稳。传统的贷款人坚持了他们的承保标准。

The civil rights movement put more pressure still on lenders. Beginning in the 1960s, they would be asked to factor in the would-be borrowers’ cultural variables, not just their creditworthiness. Washington presumed that lenders, if not watched closely, would ignore their own best interests and discriminate willy-nilly against certain minorities. Private lenders, as well as the FHA and VA, were routinely accused of “red-lining,” that is, consciously denying loans to those who lived in predominantly black neighborhoods.

民权运动给贷款人带来了更多压力。从 20 世纪 60 年代开始，他们将被要求考虑潜在借款人的文化变量，而不仅仅是他们的信用度。华盛顿认为，如果不密切关注贷款人，他们会忽视自己的最佳利益，随意歧视某些少数民族。私人贷款人，以及联邦住房管理局和 VA，经常被指责为 “红线”，即有意识地拒绝向那些居住在黑人为主的社区的人提供贷款。

The statistics, however, tell a more interesting story. Between 1940 and 1960, for instance, the period when red-lining was allegedly epidemic, home­ownership increased substantially across the board — by 24.2 percentage points among whites and by 18.6 among blacks. As is obvious, white ownership rates did increase faster during this period, but as a Vanderbilt University study notes, “Controlling for factors other than race eliminated nearly all of the increase in the gap between 1940 and 1960.” 8

然而，统计数据告诉我们一个更有趣的故事。例如，在 1940 年至 1960 年期间，也就是据称红线流行的时期，房屋所有权全面大幅增加 —— 白人增加了 24.2 个百分点，黑人增加了 18.6。显而易见，在这一时期，白人的拥有率确实增长较快，但正如范德比尔特大学的一项研究指出的那样，“控制种族以外的因素，几乎消除了 1940 年至 1960 年之间的所有增长差距。” 8

The primary reason for the increased gap was obvious to anyone who wanted to see: the vast migration of blacks from the South, where home-ownership rates were high, to the central cities of the North, where home-ownership rates were low among all races. Between 1960 and 1980, home-ownership rates increased among blacks more quickly than among whites and almost as quickly as charges of red-lining. The perception that banks routinely discriminated against blacks, even in the face of numbers to the contrary, would shape lending practices in the years to come with less-than-optimal results.

差距扩大的主要原因对任何想看的人来说都是显而易见的：大量黑人从住房拥有率高的南方迁移到所有种族中住房拥有率低的北方中心城市。在 1960 年至 1980 年期间，黑人的住房拥有率比白人增加得更快，而且几乎与红线的指控一样快。认为银行经常歧视黑人的看法，即使面对相反的数字，也会在未来的岁月里形成贷款实践，并产生不太理想的结果。

To narrow the home-ownership gap, the Lyndon Johnson administration took its War on Poverty into the housing market. In 1968 new legislation enabled poor families to receive FHA-insured loans with down payments as low as $250.9With the lure of FHA-backed loans, and occasionally with the help of well-greased FHA inspectors, smart-dealing real estate agents were then able to finesse low-income minorities into homes they could not afford to keep up.

为了缩小房屋所有权的差距，林登·约翰逊政府将其扶贫战争带入了住房市场。1968 年，新的立法使贫困家庭能够获得 FHA 担保的贷款，首付低至 250 美元。9在联邦住房管理局担保贷款的诱惑下，偶尔在联邦住房管理局检查员的帮助下，精明的房地产经纪人就能把低收入的少数民族骗到他们无力维持的房子。

Many of the new homeowners were not nearly ready to own a home. Single mothers, for instance, received some 20 percent of these mortgages in already vulnerable cities like Philadelphia and Detroit. Since roughly 1960, the federal government had been on an unwitting campaign to drive fathers from the home. That was the year that the Aid to Dependent Children Program became the Aidto Familieswith Dependent Children, or, more realistically, Aid toMomswith Dependent Children. A working dad at home did not fit the state definition of family. In 1964 the Feds sweetened the pot for forsaken moms with food stamps and in 1965 with Medicaid.

许多新房主还没有做好拥有房屋的准备。例如，在费城和底特律等已经很脆弱的城市，单亲母亲获得了这些抵押贷款中的 20% 左右。大约从 1960 年起，联邦政府就开始了一场不知不觉的运动，将父亲赶出家门。那一年，“援助受抚养儿童计划” 变成了 “援助有受抚养儿童的家庭”，或者更现实地说，“援助有受抚养儿童的母亲”。一个在家工作的父亲并不符合国家对家庭的定义。1964 年，联邦政府为被抛弃的母亲提供了食品券，并在 1965 年提供了医疗补助。

Foreclosures followed in record numbers — Philadelphia had more in three years of this program than it had in the previous thirty-three with FHA loans. When foreclosures reached critical mass, neighborhoods turned into ghettos. When aspiring arsonists learned just how much fun it was to watch abandoned buildings burn, ghettos turned into kindling.

取消抵押品赎回权的数量创下新高；费城在实施这一计划的三年里，取消抵押品赎回权的数量超过了之前使用 FHA 贷款的三十年。当取消抵押品赎回权达到临界质量时，社区变成了贫民区。当有抱负的纵火犯了解到看着被遗弃的建筑物燃烧是多么有趣时，贫民区变成了火种。

“The program could not work,” Harvard historian Louis Hyman recently commented, “because it tried to solve a problem of wealth creation through debt creation.” 10This much should have been obvious at the time, but when a road to a particular hell is paved with good intentions, there is no turning back the hell-bound.

“这个计划不可能成功”，哈佛大学历史学家路易斯·海曼最近评论说，“因为它试图通过创造债务来解决创造财富的问题。” 10这一点在当时应该是很明显的，但是如果一条通往特定地狱的道路是用良好的意图铺成的，就无法让地狱的人回头。

Single motherhood was not unique to the poor and/or black. As it often did, California was paving a new road, if not to hell, at least to purgatory. In 1953, whenHarper’s Magazineasked the young homemakers of Lakewood what they missed most in moving there, they usually replied, “My mother.” 11So many of these young families were so removed from their roots that they did not have a close friend or relative in the same time zone. When familial tension built, there was often no one there to mediate it.

单身母亲并不是穷人和（或）黑人独有的。正如它经常做的那样，加利福尼亚正在铺设一条新的道路，如果不是通往地狱，至少是通往炼狱。1953 年，当《哈珀杂志》（Harper's Magazine）问湖木市的年轻家庭主妇们搬到那里后最想念的是什么时，她们通常会回答 ：“我的母亲。” 11所以这些年轻家庭中有许多都与他们的根相距甚远，他们没有一个在同一时区的亲友。当家庭关系紧张时，往往没有人可以调停。

Divorce was spreading like Continental dollars. In 1969, rather than stabilize the currency, the state abandoned the band-of-gold standard and introduced no-fault divorce. Bad marriages promptly drove out the good. In 1970, the first full year of the no-fault law, the state registered a record 112,942 divorces — a 38 percent increase from just the year before.12In 1960, there had been only 105,352marriagesin California. Population growth — 27 percent for the decade — accounts for some of the discrepancy, but the marriage/divorce ratio, no matter what the qualifiers, signaled a massive disruption in family life.

离婚像大陆币一样在蔓延。1969 年，国家没有稳定货币，而是放弃了金带标准，实行无过错离婚。糟糕的婚姻很快就赶走了好的婚姻。1970 年，即无过错法实施的第一年，该州登记了 112,942 起离婚案，比前一年增加了 38%。121960 年，加州只有 105352 对婚姻。人口增长 —— 十年间 27% —— 说明了一些差异，但结婚/离婚的比例，不管用什么限定词，都标志着家庭生活的大规模破坏。

By 1980, California had registered a new record: 138,361 divorces. In other words, more than 276,000 Californians got divorced in 1980 alone. That was more than twice as many as in 1966, and in 1966, the California divorce rate was already 50 percent higher than the national norm. The nation, however, was eager to catch up. By 1985, just about every state in the union had adopted no-fault divorce in one form or another, with predictable results. By 1980, the nation’s divorce rate was higher than California’s was in 1969. Embarrassed by its own numbers, California stopped tracking divorces after 1980. By the year 2000, only 57 percent of the homes in the still functional Lakewood had a married couple dwelling within, and by California standards, that was high.

到 1980 年，加州登记了一个新的记录：138,361 起离婚。换句话说，仅在 1980 年，就有超过 276,000 名加利福尼亚人离婚了。这是 1966 年的两倍多，而在 1966 年，加州的离婚率已经比全国标准高出 50%。然而，全国都在急于追赶。到 1985 年，美国几乎所有的州都以这样或那样的形式采用了无过错离婚，结果可想而知。到 1980 年，全国的离婚率比加州 1969 年的离婚率还高。由于对自己的数字感到羞愧，加利福尼亚在 1980 年后停止了对离婚的追踪。到 2000 年，在功能尚可的湖心岛，只有 57% 的房屋内有一对已婚夫妇居住，按照加州的标准，这已经很高了。

The results of these trends were not immediately obvious. The effect of divorce and single motherhood on home owning was something the chattering classes chose not to chatter about. Like an unpaid debt, these were worries that would be passed down to the next generation.

这些趋势的结果并没有立即显现。离婚和单身母亲对房屋所有权的影响是喋喋不休的人们选择不谈论的东西。就像未偿还的债务一样，这些忧虑将被传给下一代。

twenty-fourThe Market’s Fools 市场的傻瓜

ON OCTOBER 6, 1979, PAUL VOLCKER, THE NEWLY APPOINTED CHAIRMRMAN of the Federal Reserve — and at six foot seven the only one who could dunk a basketball — made a short speech that rocked the economic world. Volcker announced that after several years of economic malaise and high inflation, the money supply would no longer fluctuate with the business cycle: the Fed would fix the money supply and allow interest rates to float.1This move, which increased the allowable range in the federal fund rate from 11.5 percent to 15.5 percent, had some totally unexpected consequences.

1979 年 10 月 6 日，新上任的美联储主席保罗·沃尔克（PAUL VOLCKER）—— 六英尺七英寸高，是唯一能扣篮的人 —— 发表了一个简短的演讲，震撼了整个经济界。沃尔克宣布，经过几年的经济萎靡和高通货膨胀，货币供应量将不再随商业周期波动：美联储将固定货币供应量并允许利率浮动。1此举将联邦基金利率的允许范围从 11.5% 增加到 15.5%，产生了一些完全意想不到的后果。

On Main Street, where many savings-and-loan associations were actually located, the news hit hard. Protected by the federal government more vigilantly than bald eagles or Chinook salmon, S&Ls, often calledthrifts, stumbled into the mid-1970s with some 53 percent of the nation’s home mortgage market.2The reason for their success was simple enough: the Federal Reserve, in an effort to pump more money still into the swelling mortgage market, allowed them to pay higher interest than commercial banks. Congress also provided deposit insurance for the thrifts and carved out various tax loopholes. Home ownership was, after all, an American birthright. On the downside, for no reason anyone could remember, thrifts were not allowed to offer checking accounts or invest in anything but home mortgages. The government giveth. The government taketh away.

在许多储蓄和贷款协会实际所在的主街上，这个消息打击很大。在联邦政府的保护下，储蓄和贷款协会比白头鹰或奇努克鲑鱼还要警惕，它们通常被称为《储蓄所》，在 1970 年代中期跌跌撞撞地进入全国住房抵押贷款市场，占据了约 53% 的市场份额。 2他们成功的原因很简单：美联储为了向膨胀的抵押贷款市场注入更多资金，允许他们支付比商业银行更高的利息。国会还为储蓄所提供存款保险，并划出各种税收漏洞。毕竟，房屋所有权是美国人与生俱来的权利。在缺点方面，没有人记得什么原因，储蓄所不允许提供支票账户或投资于除住房抵押贷款以外的任何东西。政府拿走了。

As a consequence, until the mid-1970s at least, running an S&L had been no more challenging than chairing the local Rotary, which many thrift presidents actually did. Within the industry, these gents were said to belong to the 3-6-3 club: borrow money at 3 percent, lend at 6 percent, tee off by 3 p.m.3Double-digit interest rates threw this whole understanding out of whack. When the 3-6-3 clubbers found themselves in a 12-10-whenever world, they stopped making home loans. It made no sense to lend at 10 percent if they had to borrow at 12. In the three years after the Volcker speech nearly 25 percent of the nation’s four thousand thrifts collapsed.

因此，至少在 20 世纪 70 年代中期之前，经营一家 S&L 公司并不比担任当地扶轮社的主席更有挑战性，许多储蓄所的总裁实际上也是如此。在行业内，据说这些人属于 “3-6-3” 俱乐部：以 3% 的利率借钱，以 6% 的利率贷款，下午 3 点前开球。3两位数的利率使整个理解变得不正常了。当 “3-6-3” 俱乐部的人发现自己处在一个 “12-10-随便多高” 的世界里时，他们停止了房屋贷款。如果他们不得不以 12% 的利率贷款，那么以 10% 的利率贷款就没有意义了。在沃尔克讲话后的三年里，全国四千家储蓄所中有近 25% 的储蓄所倒闭了。

On Wall Street, however, bond traders had not heard news this good since V-J Day. By allowing the interest rates to swing within a broad range, the Fed assured that bond prices would swing as well — inversely in lockstep to rates of interest. Suddenly, investors looked at bonds with fresh eyes, seeing them not just as repositories of wealth, but as generators of the same.4In a veritable eyeblink, Volcker had turned the bond market from a sleepy backwater into the Bellagio Las Vegas. Better still, by getting the money supply under control and reining in inflation, the Fed helped turn credit into the world’s greatest growth industry. Between 1977 and 1985, the combined indebtedness of American governments, corporations, and consumers increased by an incredible factor of twenty.5Most of that money was filtered through Wall Street.

然而，在华尔街，自 V-J 日以来，债券交易员还没有听到过这么好的消息。通过允许利率在一个广泛的范围内摆动，美联储保证债券价格也会随之摆动 —— 与利率成反比。突然间，投资者用新的眼光看待债券，不仅把它们看作是财富的储存器，而且看作是财富的创造者。4在一个真正的眨眼之间，沃尔克就把债券市场从一个沉睡的落后地区变成了贝拉吉奥拉斯维加斯。更妙的是，通过控制货币供应量和抑制通货膨胀，美联储帮助将信贷变成了世界上最大的增长产业。5这些钱大部分是通过华尔街过手的。

Not all Wall Street was celebrating, however. The Volcker move brought only gloom to the Medici quarter at Salomon Brothers. That Salomon’s Italians would be relegated to a ghetto within the historically Jewish firm shows just how entertaining a country America can be. The larger story begins in 1910, when the original Salomon brothers — Arthur, Herbert, and Percy — split from their dad, lured away his clerk, and opened a small office on Broadway near Wall Street.6They soon recruited a Baltimore department-store tycoon as partner, largely for his seat on the Stock Exchange.

不过，并非所有华尔街都在庆祝。沃尔克的举动只给所罗门兄弟公司的美第奇区带来阴霾。萨洛蒙的意大利人在这家历史悠久的犹太公司中被贬为贫民窟，这表明美国是一个多么有趣的国家。更大的故事开始于 1910 年，当时最初的萨洛蒙兄弟 —— 阿瑟、赫伯特和培西 —— 与他们的父亲分开，引走了他的文员，并在华尔街附近的百老汇开设了一个小办公室。 6他们很快招募了一位巴尔的摩百货公司的大亨作为合伙人，主要是因为他在证券交易所的席位。

By this time, Jewish bankers of German origin — Abraham Kuhn, Solomon Loeb, Joseph Seligman, the Lehman Brothers, Marcus Goldman and his son-in-law Samuel Sachs — had very nearly reached white shoe status on Wall Street. Their heirs thought of the humble Salomon brothers and their successors as tradesmen and treated them accordingly. Though resentful of the treatment, Salomon execs took pride in their scrappy, black-shoe backgrounds. The image the firm projected, writes Salomon bond-salesman-turned-author Michael Lewis was “of clannish Jews, social nonentities, shrewd but honest, sinking its nose more deeply into the bond markets than any other firm cared to.” 7

此时，德裔犹太银行家阿伯拉罕·库恩（Abraham Kuhn）、所罗门·雷欧布（Solomon Loeb）、约瑟夫·塞利格曼（Joseph Seligman）、雷曼兄弟（Lehman Brothers）、马克思·古德曼（Marcus Goldman）和他的女婿萨缪·赛科（Samuel Sachs）—— 在华尔街几乎达到了白鞋地位。他们的继承人认为卑微的萨洛蒙兄弟和他们的继承人是商人，并相应地对待他们。尽管对这种待遇感到不满，但萨洛蒙的执行官们还是为他们潦倒的黑鞋背景感到自豪。萨洛蒙公司的债券销售员、作家迈克尔·刘易斯（Michael Lewis）写道，该公司的形象是 ：“宗族式的犹太人，社会上的无名小卒，精明但诚实，比任何其他公司都更深入地进入债券市场。” 7

In the late 1970s, Robert Dall, one of those Salomon partners nostril-deep in bonds, sniffed out a mother lode of possibility. Although Wall Street had historically brought borrowers and lenders together, its wise men had somehow overlooked the single greatest stash of capital in America: home loans. The stash had grown from $55 billion in 1950 to $700 billion in 1976 without anyone mining its riches.8By the time of Volcker’s speech in 1979, the home mortgage industry had passed the trillion-dollar mark and surpassed the New York Stock Exchange as the largest capital market in the world.9

20 世纪 70 年代末，萨洛蒙公司(Salomon)的合伙人之一罗伯特·达尔(Robert Dall)鼻孔深陷债券，嗅到了一个可能性的母矿。尽管华尔街在历史上曾将借款人和贷款人聚集在一起，但其智囊们不知为何忽略了美国唯一最大的资本储藏库 ：“住房贷款”。这个储藏库从 1950 年的 550 亿美元增长到 1976 年的 7000 亿美元，没有人开采其财富。8到 1979 年沃尔克发表演讲时，住房抵押贷款行业已超过万亿美元大关，超过了纽约证券交易所，成为世界上最大的资本市场。 9

Finding gold was one thing. Extracting it was another. The Government National Mortgage Association — Ginnie Mae — had discovered the truth of this some years earlier. Spun out of Fannie Mae’s side in 1968, Ginnie Mae bundled the home mortgages of the least affluent homeowners and sought to sell them as bonds, the only mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the federal government.10

发现黄金是一件事。提取它是另一回事。政府国民抵押贷款协会(Government National Mortgage Association — Ginnie Mae，金尼美)早在几年前就发现了其中的真相。1968 年，从房利美那边分离出来的金尼美将最不富裕的房主的住房抵押贷款捆绑起来，并试图将其作为债券出售，这是唯一由联邦政府担保的抵押贷款支持证券。10

In 1970, Salomon partner (and later treasury secretary) William Simon, had a dustup with Ginnie Mae. This fully federal entity would not correct what Simon saw as the security’s fatal flaw: the ability of the homeowner to prepay his mortgage. A purchaser of a long-term bond wanted the assurance that the bond would pay a given return throughout its specified life. If, however, homeowners could pay off their mortgages when interest rates dipped and refinance at a lower rate, the bondholder could be left with cash in a low-interest environment. Institutional buyers, in particular, had little interest in bonds of unknown maturity.

1970 年，所罗门公司的合伙人（后来的财政部长）威廉·西蒙（William Simon）与金美尼发生了争执。这个完全的联邦实体不会纠正西蒙认为的证券的致命缺陷：房主预付抵押贷款的能力。长期债券的购买者希望得到保证，债券在其规定的有效期内将支付一定的回报。然而，如果房主可以在利率下降时偿还抵押贷款，并以较低的利率进行再融资，那么在低利率环境下，债券持有人就会留下现金。特别是机构买家，对未知期限的债券兴趣不大。

While Simon ignored the Ginnie Maes, Dall, who worked under Simon, started dabbling. He quickly saw the untapped potential in home loans, and in 1977 he and a colleague persuaded Bank of America to package its home loans in the form of a bond, the first private issue of mortgage securities.

当西蒙无视金美尼的时候，在西蒙手下工作的达尔（Dall）开始涉足。他很快就看到了住房贷款中尚未开发的潜力，1977 年，他和一位同事说服美国银行将其住房贷款以债券的形式打包，这是第一次私人发行的抵押贷款证券。

They then persuaded investors that these bonds had a high enough yield and a low enough risk to offset the prepay liability. They attracted enough attention within the firm that Salomon Brothers established a separate mortgage department in 1978, the first on Wall Street.

然后他们说服投资者，这些债券有足够高的收益和足够低的风险来抵消预付责任。他们在公司内部引起了足够的关注，以至于所罗门兄弟公司在 1978 年成立了一个独立的抵押贷款部门，这在华尔街是第一次。

In 1970, the government had launched the semiprivate Federal Home Loan Mortgage Company, or Freddie Mac, to compete with the semiprivate Fannie Mae and create a more competitive secondary mortgage market. Now, with Salomon Brothers in the game, there was a fully private player in the secondary market to complement these government-sponsored enterprises, or GSEs. And unlike the GSEs, Salomon Brothers could deal in what are called nonconforming loans — loans either too large or too risky to conform to GSE standards.

1970 年，政府推出了半私营的联邦住房贷款抵押公司，即房地美，与半私营的房利美竞争，创造一个更具竞争力的二级抵押贷款市场。现在，随着所罗门兄弟公司的加入，二级市场上出现了一个完全私人的参与者，以补充这些政府支持的企业，即 GSEs。而与 GSE 不同的是，所罗门兄弟公司可以处理所谓的不合格贷款 —— 太大或者风险太大，不符合 GSE 标准的贷款。

Dall knew he would need a hard-nosed trader to make the operation work, and he got his first pick, thirty-year-old Lewie Ranieri. The Brooklyn-born Ranieri stepped into the mortgage department straight out of central casting. A college dropout, he had begun just ten years earlier as a seventy-dollar-a-week night shift clerk in Salomon’s mailroom.11He did his job well, got promoted, seized opportunities, and soon enough found himself on Salomon’s trading floor — sloppy, loud, fat, effective, and unabashedly Italian.

达尔知道他需要一个强硬的交易员来使业务运转起来，他得到了他的第一个选择，30 岁的卢埃·拉涅利。出生于布鲁克林的拉涅利直接从中央选拔赛中进入了抵押贷款部门。他是一个大学辍学生，十年前刚开始在萨洛蒙的收发室做一个每周 70 美元的夜班职员。11他工作做得很好，得到了晋升，抓住了机会，并很快发现自己在萨洛蒙的交易大厅，邋遢、吵闹、肥胖、高效、毫不掩饰的意大利人。

When Dall took ill, Ranieri took over the department and started hiring loyalists from the back office — John D’Antona, Peter Marro, Bill Esposito, Ron Dipasquale, Michael Mortara. No fool, Ranieri hired the occasional whiz kid, often Jewish, out of Wharton or wherever, not to appease his bosses, but to do the math. In the streets of Brooklyn, Jews and Italians had often collaborated in the loan business — Italians typically on the collection side of the industry. On Wall Street, at least, their collaboration was legal. Oddly enough, at Salomon it would be left to Ranieri and family to uphold the firm’s street­wise Jewish heritage.

当达尔生病时，拉涅利接管了这个部门，并开始从后台雇佣忠诚的人 —— John D'Antona, Peter Marro, Bill Esposito, Ron Dipasquale, Michael Mortara。拉涅利不是傻瓜，他偶尔会雇用一些天才儿童，通常是犹太人，来自沃顿商学院或其他地方，不是为了讨好他的老板，而是为了做算盘。在布鲁克林的街道上，犹太人和意大利人经常在贷款业务中合作；意大利人通常在行业的收款方面。至少在华尔街，他们的合作是合法的。奇怪的是，在萨洛蒙公司，将由拉涅利和家人来维护该公司的街道­智慧的犹太遗产。

For the first year or two, few begrudged the Italians their fiefdom because no one was getting rich or close to it. Home loans, no matter how pretty the package, were a tough sell. When Volcker allowed interest rates to range upward in October 1979, the selling got much tougher at every level of the mortgage market. New home starts tanked and so did Ranieri’s business. So sluggish was his operation that Salomon management started making noise about shutting it down. Meanwhile, the mortgage departments of would-be competitors — Merrill Lynch, First Boston, Goldman Sachs — died aborning. More stubborn than prescient, Ranieri hung on and ended with the kind of autonomy granted only to the ignored and irrelevant.

在最初的一两年里，很少有人责怪意大利人的封地，因为没有人发财或接近发财。住房贷款，无论其包装多么漂亮，都是一个艰难的销售。当沃尔克在 1979 年 10 月允许利率上调时，抵押贷款市场的各个层面的销售变得更加艰难。新房开工率下降，拉涅利的业务也是如此。他的业务如此低迷，以至于萨洛蒙管理层开始吵着要关闭它。与此同时，可能的竞争对手美林、第一波士顿、高盛等公司的抵押贷款部门也纷纷夭折。与其说拉涅利有先见之明，不如说他顽强地坚持了下来，并最终获得了只有被忽视和不相干的人才能获得的自主权。

On September 30, 1981, the government gaveth once more. To rescue the floundering thrifts, Congress passed a generous and complicated tax break. As exploited, it allowed the thrifts huge tax write-offs, but only if they sold off their old loans. Sunbelt thrifts had little money and lots of demand. Rust Belt thrifts had lots of money and little demand. It made sense for the Rust Belters to supply needed cash to the Sunbelters by buying their mortgages.12Everyone wanted to trade, and the hottest exchange in town waschezLewie.

1981 年 9 月 30 日，政府再一次施舍了。为了拯救陷入困境的储蓄所，国会通过了一项慷慨而复杂的减税措施。由于被利用，它允许储蓄所进行巨额税务注销，但前提是他们必须卖掉他们的旧贷款。阳光地带的储蓄所没有什么钱，但有很多需求。锈带地区的储蓄所有很多钱，但需求很少。锈带地区的人通过购买阳光地带的抵押贷款向他们提供所需的现金是合理的。12每个人都想交易，城里最热门的交易所是 chez Lewie。

Amazingly, Ranieri and his crew were unaware of the legislation until after it had passed.13For them, it was like Christmas morning, and they had found a pony under the tree — it was that serendipitous. With only half an idea of what he was doing, some congressional staffer had just created the greatest market in the history of Wall Street and, oh yes, planted the seed for the eventual destruction of the American economy. But in 1981, who knew?

令人惊讶的是，拉涅利和他的团队直到立法通过后才知道。13对他们来说，这就像圣诞节早晨，他们在树下发现了一匹小马 —— 就是这么偶然。某个国会工作人员对自己正在做的事情只有一知半解，却创造了华尔街历史上最伟大的市场，哦，是的，为美国经济的最终毁灭埋下了种子。但在 1981 年，谁知道呢？

The 3-6-3 guys were to Ranieri’s crew what H. G. Wells’s soft-boiled Eloi were to the omnivorous Morelocks — lunch, or what Wall Street calls the market’s fools. On more than one occasion, Ranieri had to scold a trader for making too good a deal at the expense of some utterly clueless thrift exec.14Not all the execs were clueless, of course, but even the savvy ones had to play to keep their doors open. If they sensed they were just pushing their problems down an unknown road, they felt they had little choice but to do so.

“3-6-3” 的人对拉涅利的团队来说，就像 H·G·威尔斯的软水煮艾洛伊人对杂食的莫洛克人一样 —— 午餐，或者华尔街称之为市场的傻瓜。不止一次，拉涅利不得不斥责交易员在牺牲一些完全没有头脑的节俭的执行官的情况下做了一笔太好的交易。14当然，并不是所有的执行官都没有头脑，但即使那些精明的人也不得不为保持门面而努力。如果他们感觉到他们只是把自己的问题推到了一条未知的道路上，他们觉得自己除了这样做没有什么选择。

By decade’s end, of course, the whole system would implode at great expense to the taxpayer. Said the head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the entity created to clean up the S&L mess, “[The government] provided them with such perverse incentives that if I were to defend the S&L gang in court, I’d use the defense of entrapment.” 15

当然，到十年后，整个系统会以巨大的代价内爆，让纳税人付出代价。决议信托公司（Resolution Trust Corporation）的负责人说 ：“（政府）为他们提供了如此不正当的激励，如果我在法庭上为 S&L 团伙辩护，我会采用诱捕的辩护方式。” 15

The same year that Congressional manna descended on Salomon Brothers, 1981, the firm morphed from partnership to corporation. This was something of a trend on Wall Street, and it had its critics. Wall Street legend — and Salomon veteran — Henry Kaufman was not alone in regretting the change of culture. “The trust and intimacy that once typified relations between investment banks and their clients,” he observed, “has been supplanted by a transaction-driven ethic that favors profit maximization at every turn.” 16

1981 年，国会的甘露空降到所罗门兄弟公司，同年，该公司从合伙公司转变为公司。这是华尔街的一种趋势，它也有批评者。华尔街的传奇人物和萨洛蒙的老将亨利·考夫曼(Henry Kaufman)不是唯一对文化的改变感到遗憾的人。他说 ：“曾经是投资银行和客户之间关系的典型的信任和亲密关系”，他指出，“已经被一种交易驱动的道德规范所取代，这种道德规范处处偏重于利润最大化。”

Michael Lewis, who worked for Salomon in the mid-’80s, came to a similar conclusion, phrased a bit more succinctly: “Short-term greed,” he reckoned, was driving out “long-term greed.” 17In his best-selling satire of 1980s New York,Bonfire of the Vanities, Tom Wolfe heard the mantra of the traders at the barely fictionalized Salomon Brothers as “Make it now!” 18

迈克尔·刘易斯（Michael Lewis）在 80 年代中期为所罗门公司工作，他得出了类似的结论，措辞更简洁一些 ：“短期贪婪正在驱逐长期贪婪。” 17在他对 1980 年代纽约的最畅销讽刺作品《虚荣的篝火》（Bonfire of the Vanities）中，汤姆·伍菲（Tom Wolfe）听到在几乎没有虚构的所罗门兄弟公司的交易者的口头禅是 “现在就做!” 18

The shift to corporate management had as a side effect the shift of knowledge and power from the vested top to the ambitious middle. This shift was enhanced — or aggravated, depending on one’s perspective — by the advent of personal computing in the early 1980s.19The young guys coming out of grad school — and in the mortgage department at Salomon they were all guys until 1986 — began to invent unholy new ways to subdivide the mortgage pie.

企业管理的转变带来的副作用是知识和权力从既得利益者的顶端转移到雄心勃勃的中间层。这一转变因 1980 年代初个人电脑的出现而得到加强 —— 或加剧，这取决于个人的观点。19从研究生院出来的年轻人 —— 在萨洛蒙的抵押贷款部门，1986 年前他们都是男人 —— 开始发明不正当的新方法来瓜分抵押贷款的蛋糕。

The inventors schemed to lessen the effect of loan prepayment, the possibility of which made mortgages unreliable income generators. In 1983, First Boston beat Salomon to the punch and created perhaps the most important financial innovation of the 1980s — the collateralized mortgage obligation (CMO). To put a CMO together, an investment house would gather multimillions of dollars of ordinary mortgage bonds — Ginnie Maes, Freddie Macs, Fannie Maes — and place them in a trust. The investment bankers would then sell interest-earning shares in the trust in certificate form. These were the CMOs. This part is all straightforward enough.

发明者们想方设法减少贷款预付的影响，这种可能性使抵押贷款成为不可靠的收入来源。1983 年，第一波士顿公司击败了所罗门公司，创造了可能是 20 世纪 80 年代最重要的金融创新 —— 抵押贷款义务（CMO）。为了组建 CMO，一家投资公司将收集数百万美元的普通抵押贷款债券，包括金美尼、房利美和房地美，并将它们放入一个信托基金。然后，投资银行家将以证书形式出售信托中的生息股份。这些就是 CMO。这一部分都是很直接的。

Where the CMO got tricky and interesting was when the pool was sub­divided into what are called tranches (rhymes with launches). Although there are any number of ways to structure a CMO — or, more generically, a CDO, “collateralized debt obligation” —— a common one was to divide a mortgage pool into three tranches based on risk exposure: senior, mezzanine, and equity. All tranches would receive interest payments from the assembled loans, but the investors in the senior tranche would receive all of the principal paid in by all the mortgage holders in the pool until their principal was repaid. Only then would the principal be repaid to those in the mezzanine tranche and, after them, those in the equity tranche.20The lower tranches offered higher reward for added risk.

CMO 变得棘手和有趣的地方是，当抵押贷款池被分成所谓的 “档次” （与 “发射” 这个词押韵）。虽然有很多方法来构建 CMO，或者更笼统地说，CDO，即 “抵押债务” —— 一个常见的方法是根据风险敞口将抵押贷款池分为三个档次：优先档、夹层档和股权档。所有档次的贷款都将获得利息支付，但优先档的投资者将获得抵押贷款池中所有抵押贷款持有人支付的所有本金，直到他们的本金被偿还。20低档次贷款为增加的风险提供了更高的回报。

Investors in a senior tranche faced minimal risk and consequently received minimal reward, usually just slightly more yield than a U.S. Treasury bond. Importantly, this process also shortened the life of the senior tranche in a fairly predictable way, all but negating the nagging unpredictability of the prepaid mortgage. This restructuring had astonishing effects. The certainty and security of the CMO unleashed the market potential of the home loan in ways that few anticipated.

高级贷款的投资者面临的风险最小，因此得到的回报也最小，通常只是比美国国债的收益率略高。重要的是，这个过程也以一种相当可预测的方式缩短了优先级贷款的寿命，几乎完全否定了预付抵押贷款的唠叨的不可预测性。这种结构调整产生了惊人的效果。CMO 的确定性和安全性释放了住房贷款的市场潜力，其方式是很少有人预料到的。

As an aside, the reader who finds this explanation hard to follow ought not feel abashed. Wall Street veterans like Henry Kaufman were warning early on that these products were “too complex to be understood by those who trade them.” 21Confirms Michael Lewis, “Across Wall Street, CEOs have made this little leap of faith about the manner in which their traders are making money, because they don’t fully understand what their traders are doing.” 22

作为一个旁观者，发现这个解释难以理解的读者不应该感到羞愧。像亨利·考夫曼（Henry Kaufman）这样的华尔街资深人士在早期就警告说，这些产品 “太复杂了，交易的人根本无法理解。” 21迈克尔·刘易斯证实，“在整个华尔街，首席执行官们对他们的交易员赚钱的方式进行了这种小小的飞跃，因为他们并不完全了解他们的交易员在做什么。” 22

Roger Lowenstein of theNew York Timesmade a good effort at illuminating the process by tracking one particular bundle of 2,393 loans with a total face value of $430 million. Lowenstein followed the loans from their origination at an unnamed “nonbank lender” to a New York investment bank, which packaged them, to the analyst’s desk at Moody’s, the rating service where they were evaluated.23

《纽约时报》的罗杰·洛文斯坦(Roger Lowenstein)通过追踪一捆总面值为 4.3 亿美元的 2393 笔贷款，在说明这一过程方面做出了很好的努力。洛温斯坦跟踪了这些贷款，从它们在一个不知名的 “非银行贷款人” 处开始，到一家纽约投资银行将它们打包，再到穆迪公司的分析师办公桌，即对它们进行评估的评级服务。

Moody’s had access to aggregate data on the loans and the borrowers but not to the loan files. Using historical performance criteria, its analysts assessed which percent of the loans were subprime, where the loans originated, what kind of loans were involved, and other relevant data before ratingnot the loans themselves, but the bonds issued by the “special purpose vehicle” that the investment bank had created to house the loans.

穆迪公司可以获得有关贷款和借款人的汇总数据，但不能获得贷款文件。利用历史业绩标准，其分析师评估了哪些百分比的贷款是次级贷款，贷款的来源地，涉及何种贷款，以及其他相关数据，然后才对不是贷款本身，而是由投资银行为存放贷款而创建的 “特殊目的工具” 所发行的债券进行评级。

To get an investment grade rating for at least some of its bonds, the investment bank sliced this bundle into twelve classes. The upper classes, the ones that were to get repaid first, Moody’s rated triple-A, even though this particular bundle of loans was all subprime (and more on that phenomenon later).

为了使其至少部分债券获得投资级评级，该投资银行将这批债券分成了 12 个等级。穆迪对高等级的贷款，也就是那些将首先得到偿还的贷款进行了三 A 评级，尽管这个特定的贷款捆绑在一起的都是次贷（后面会有更多关于这一现象的介绍）。

The asset-backed securities described above derive their value from real assets, namely, the mortgages of actual homeowners. A CMO is one step further removed from reality. Investors do not buy mortgages. They buy bonds that are based on mortgages, these sliced into tranches and evaluated tranche by tranche by the rating agencies.

上述资产支持证券的价值来自真实资产，即实际房主的抵押贷款。CMO 离现实更远了一步。投资者并不购买抵押贷款。他们购买的是以抵押贷款为基础的债券，这些债券被切成若干档，由评级机构逐档评估。

Although the assembly of a CMO is somewhat less complicated than that of an atom bomb, the CMO has potentially greater fallout, having value only to the degree that investors value it. Typically, investors purchased senior tranche CMOs because they promised a higher return than Treasury bonds with only slightly more risk. If, say, 2 percent of the loans in that mortgage pool default, the CMO has not necessarily lost 2 percent of its value. It may have lost 20 percent of its value or more. A sudden uptick in defaults would make the market jittery and the security suddenly toxic. No one may want to purchase a low-yield asset with high-risk exposure.

尽管 CMO 的组装没有原子弹那么复杂，但 CMO 的潜在影响更大，其价值只取决于投资者对它的重视程度。通常情况下，投资者购买优先档的 CMO，因为它们承诺比国债有更高的回报，而风险却略高。如果，比如说，抵押贷款池中 2% 的贷款违约，CMO 不一定失去 2% 的价值。它可能已经损失了 20% 的价值或更多。违约率的突然上升会使市场感到不安，证券突然变得有毒。没有人可能想购买一个具有高风险的低收益资产。

Ironically, investment houses like Salomon put CMOs together with the avowed intention of minimizing investor risk. To further reduce risk, they offered insurance policies against loss to buyers of a senior tranche. Known as credit default swaps (CDS), these policies proved highly popular in the home loan gold rush.24As secure as the home mortgage business had historically been, the issuers of CDSs thought they had found a perfectly legal way to print money. There were no messy fires or car crashes or suicides to adjudicate. The insured paid in and the insurers cashed out. Although complex, insurers had confidence in their own smarts, and of course, no insurer was smarter than AIG.

以前，像所罗门这样的投资机构把 CMO 放在一起，公开表示要把投资者的风险降到最低。为了进一步降低风险，他们向优先档的购买者提供损失保险。24由于住房抵押贷款业务在历史上很安全，CDS 的发行者认为他们找到了一种完全合法的印钞方式。没有混乱的火灾、车祸或自杀事件需要裁决。被保险人付款，保险人兑现。虽然复杂，但保险公司对自己的聪明才智有信心，当然，没有保险公司比 AIG 更聪明。

Complicating matters is that the primary purchasers of CMOs, CDOs, and credit default swaps have been the hedge funds. These largely unregulated investment groups owe their name to their historic strategy of hedging a “long” position by buying comparable stocks short. Although hedge funds have continued to employ long-short strategies, they have helped pioneer countless new ways to slice and dice debt. A loss in a hedge fund investment can ripple through the financial system because most such purchases are highly leveraged.25In other words, a hedge fund partnership often increases its investment by a factor of five or ten by borrowing the additional money from a bank. In short, when a hedge fund tanks, a lot of people get nervous.

复杂的是，CMO、CDO 和信用违约掉期的主要购买者一直是对冲基金。这些在很大程度上不受监管的投资团体的名字归功于他们通过买空同类股票来对冲 “多头” 头寸的历史策略。尽管对冲基金继续采用多空策略，但它们帮助开创了无数切分债务的新方法。对冲基金投资的损失会在金融系统中产生连锁反应，因为大多数此类购买都是高度杠杆化的。25换句话说，一个对冲基金合伙企业往往通过从银行借入额外的资金，将其投资增加五倍或十倍。简而言之，当一个对冲基金崩溃时，很多人都会感到紧张。

Meanwhile back at Salomon, its heady traders made a killing in the CMO revolution, at least for a while. The problem was that the CMO had standardized the packaging of home loans and turned it into just another bond that could be priced and traded on the open market.26Ranieri and his dropout colleagues were losing market share. All that accrued backslapping knowledge of buyers and sellers was depreciating in value. Ascendant now were the Ivy League PhDs who were packaging home loans in a thousand different ways and turning old-school horse-trading into something like a science. To end run regulation and attract new business, investment houses, Salomon included, were hiring these rocket scientists and paying them in a good year what they had paid their fathers in a lifetime.

与此同时，在所罗门公司，其令人振奋的交易员在 CMO 革命中大赚了一笔，至少有一段时间是这样。26拉涅利和他的辍学同事正在失去市场份额。所有这些积累起来的关于买家和卖家的知识正在贬值。现在，常春藤盟校的博士们正在以一千种不同的方式包装住房贷款，并将老式的马匹交易变成类似科学的东西。为了结束监管并吸引新的业务，投资公司，包括所罗门公司，都在雇用这些火箭科学家，并在好年景时向他们支付他们的父亲一生的报酬。

In the rush to modernity, the new corporate Salomon was also purging its streetwise Jewish heritage, the last defenders of which were, of all people, the Ranieri crew. In July 1987, Salomon fired Ranieri, the firm’s best earner in the previous decade. The family followed in quick order — Mortara, D’Antona, Dipasquale, Marro, Gonella. The lone member of the crew left on the mortgage trading desk, Paul Longenotti, showed up at work one day after the purge wearing a button that said, “Fire me, I’m Italian.” 27Only in America.

在急于实现现代化的过程中，新的萨洛蒙公司也在清除其街头的犹太遗产，其中最后的捍卫者就是拉涅利的团队。1987 年 7 月，萨洛蒙解雇了拉涅利，他是该公司前十年的最佳收入者。随后，莫塔拉、德安托纳、迪帕斯夸莱、马罗、戈内拉等人依次离职。抵押贷款交易台剩下的唯一成员保罗·朗格诺蒂(Paul Longenotti)在清洗后的一天出现在工作岗位上，身上戴着一个按钮，上面写着 ：“解雇我，我是意大利人。” 27只有在美国才这样。

twenty-fiveMembership Has Its Privileges 会员资格有其特权

IN 1946 OR 1947, THE DATE IS IN SOME DISPUTE, A FELLOW NAMED JOHN Biggins, about whom little is known, introduced an item that would pump fresh new blood into American finance. Biggins worked for the Flatbush National Bank of Brooklyn. There he got it into his head that if customers were given a bank card, and that card allowed them to charge items at various stores, the bank would build loyalty among the customers and merchants both. Biggins called the card Charg-It, and, without fanfare, introduced the first universal credit card.1True, the universe extended only to stores within a two-block radius of the bank, but it was a start.

在 1946 年或 1947 年（日期有争议），一位名叫约翰·比金斯（JOHN Biggins）的学员，关于他的情况鲜为人知，他提出了一个项目，将为美国金融业注入新的血液。比金斯在布鲁克林的弗拉布什国家银行工作。在那里，他想到，如果给客户一张银行卡，并且该卡允许他们在不同的商店充电，银行将在客户和商人中建立忠诚度。比金斯把这种卡称为 Charg-It，并没有大张旗鼓地推出了第一张通用信用卡。1的确，这个宇宙只延伸到银行方圆两个街区内的商店，但这是一个起点。

Within a few years, banks across the country were experimenting with credit cards. The first bank to explore its potential in a big way was Amadeo Giannini’s Bank of America, which launched the awkwardly named BankAmericard in 1958.2The card’s acceptance throughout California led the bank to embark on a regional strategy. Among its licensees was Seafirst Bank in Seattle. When a free spirit named Dee Hock came to work for Seafirst in 1968, he discovered that Seafirst was actually losing money on the card. The technology was primitive. The accounting was messy. And fraud was rampant among customers, merchants, and criminals alike.

在几年内，全国的银行都在尝试使用信用卡。2该卡在加利福尼亚的接受程度使该银行开始实施区域战略。西雅图的海首（Seafirst）银行是其被许可人之一。1968 年，当一位名叫迪-霍克的自由精神者来到海首银行工作时，他发现海首银行实际上在该卡上是亏损的。当时的技术很原始。会计工作很混乱。欺诈行为在客户、商户和犯罪分子中十分猖獗。

At a BankAmericard convention in Ohio, Hock rallied his fellow licensees, all as frustrated as he was, to form a cooperative. Over the next ten years, he led the charge for technological and accounting upgrades. He also made a branding recommendation that stuck: replacing the ungainly BankAmericard with the sleek and sophisticated Visa, the card that puts you “everywhere you want to be.”

在俄亥俄州的一个 BankAmericard 大会上，霍克召集了他的同伴，所有和他一样沮丧的持牌人，组成一个合作社。在接下来的十年里，他领导了技术和会计升级的工作。他还提出了一个坚持不懈的品牌建议：用时尚而复杂的 Visa 卡取代笨重的 BankAmericard 卡，这种卡让你 “想去哪儿就去哪儿”。

Although Hock understood that profit was what kept a bank’s doors open, profit was not what drove him. A true visionary, he was intrigued by the idea of electronic money. He saw it as a way to liberate the ordinary Joe from the physical restraints that cash imposed: the need to extract it from suspicious bankers, to have it handy at all times, to carry large sums when away from home in case of emergency. Hock and his fellow pioneers, like Citibank’s Walter Wriston, were about to change all that.

尽管霍克明白利润是银行开门的原因，但利润并不是驱动他的动力。作为一个真正的有远见的人，他对电子货币的想法很感兴趣。他认为这是一种将普通人从现金的束缚中解放出来的方式：需要从可疑的银行家那里提取现金，需要随时准备好现金，需要在离家时携带大笔资金以备不时之需。霍克和他的同伴们，如花旗银行的沃尔特-赖斯顿，即将改变这一切。

What Hock could not anticipate was the role that credit cards would come to play in a still inchoate anti-debt revival. In the absence of universal Christian sanctions, Catholic or Protestant, this revival would be wholly secular, but its leaders would be no less zealous than Luther, Calvin, or Savonarola. Before the advent of the universal credit card, twentieth-century America had, of course, seen sporadic attacks on the peddlers of debt, but the credit card gave focus to those attacks. In the financial morality play of postindustrial America, if the user were Everyman, the credit card dispenser would embody greed, the only one of the seven deadly sins that social puritans cannot abide.

霍克无法预料的是，信用卡将在一个仍未成形的反债务复兴中扮演角色。在没有普遍的基督教制裁的情况下，无论是天主教还是新教，这种复兴将是完全世俗的，但其领导人的热情不会低于路德、加尔文或萨沃纳罗拉。在通用信用卡出现之前，二十世纪的美国当然也有过对债务贩子的零星攻击，但信用卡使这些攻击成为焦点。在美国后工业时代的金融道德剧中，如果使用者是常人，那么信用卡发放者将体现出贪婪，这是社会清教徒无法容忍的七宗罪中唯一的一宗。

These secular moralists go about their business with the charm and detachment of New England divines preaching infant damnation. Yet for all their grim preachiness, social puritans have been remarkably successful in spreading their message and enforcing their themes. Virtually every media news story on credit cards adheres to their template: consumer starts innocently; card company lures consumer; consumer dabbles; consumer has crisis; consumer turns to credit cards; consumer gets hooked; card company harasses consumer; consumer goes bankrupt; consumer accepts minimal blame; reporter exonerates consumer; reporter condemns card company. If this paradigm sounds familiar, recall the century-old advice of anti-usurer Dr. George Bush, who compared debt to a serpent’s bite “often so small as to be scarcely perceptible at first, yet the venom soon spreads and diffuses itself till it reaches the vitals.” 3

这些世俗的道德家以新英格兰神学家宣扬婴儿诅咒的魅力和疏离感来进行他们的工作。然而，尽管他们的说教很严肃，社会清教徒在传播他们的信息和执行他们的主题方面却非常成功。几乎所有关于信用卡的媒体新闻报道都遵循他们的模板：消费者开始是无辜的；信用卡公司引诱消费者；消费者涉足；消费者出现危机；消费者转向信用卡；消费者上瘾；信用卡公司骚扰消费者；消费者破产；消费者接受最小的责备；记者为消费者开脱；记者谴责信用卡公司。如果这种模式听起来很熟悉，请回忆一下反推销员乔治·布什博士的百年忠告，他把债务比作毒蛇的咬伤，“起初往往很小，几乎察觉不到，但毒液很快就会蔓延和扩散，直到到达要害。” 3

Such profiles may concede some responsibility to the consumers in their card usage, but almost never do they question the lifestyle choices that left them vulnerable. Social puritans can be remarkably singular in their zeal. Many recognize no other sin, admonish no other behavior, crusade against no other evil than the promiscuous dispensing of credit.

这样的简介可能会让消费者在使用卡片时承担一些责任，但他们几乎从不质疑让他们处于弱势的生活方式选择。社会清教徒在他们的热忱中可能是非常单一的。许多人没有认识到其他的罪，没有告诫其他的行为，没有讨伐其他的邪恶，只有滥发信贷。

Among the high priests in the unorganized and unrecognized social puritan movement is one Robert Manning, the author of the influential 2000 best sellerCredit Card Nationand the custodian of the Web site of that same name. Playing to a crowd that styles itself nonjudgmental on any other subject, on the subject of credit cards he and his audience can be as self-righteous as a boatload of Venetian monks. Words likeinsidious, usurious, punitive,andcredit- gougingpepper the book.

在无组织和不被认可的社会清教徒运动中，有一位名叫罗伯特·曼宁的高僧，他是 2000 年有影响力的畅销书《信用卡国家》的作者和同名网站的监管人。他和他的听众对其他任何话题都不加评判，但在信用卡问题上，他和他的听众可以像一船的威尼斯僧侣一样自以为是。像 “高利贷” 、 “高利贷者” 、 “惩罚性的” 和 “赊账” 这样的词在书中比比皆是。

The stories that Manning tells flip the Tolstoy maxim that “happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.” In the Manning retelling it is the unhappy, bankrupt families that are all oddly alike. Take the case of Catherine, a fiftyish policy grunt in the New York City mayor’s office. Catherine has grown up in a household where personal debt is seen as a moral failing, “a kind of Jewish Calvinist guilt thing.” 4

曼宁讲述的故事翻转了托尔斯泰的格言："幸福的家庭都是一样的；每个不幸福的家庭都以自己的方式不幸福。" 在曼宁的重述中，不幸福的、破产的家庭才是奇特的相似。以凯瑟琳为例，她是纽约市市长办公室的一名 50 岁左右的政务员。凯瑟琳在一个家庭中长大，在那里，个人债务被视为一种道德失败，"一种犹太加尔文主义的内疚。"4

After graduating from college debt-free and working in publishing, Catherine returns to graduate school “as a means for personal advancement that would enable her to avoid debt.” 5She has a stipend, but then the seemingly unexpected happens: the tuition increases and her scholarship is reduced. She turns to her credit cards. At a friend’s suggestion, she wraps her credit card debt into a student loan and reduces her interest from 18 percent to 3 percent. At the time, Catherine “thought she had made the right decision.” 6That the taxpayer was now subsidizing her credit card debt troubles neither her nor Manning.

大学毕业后，凯瑟琳无债一身轻，在出版业工作，她回到了研究生院，“原本，（学历）作为个人进步的一种手段，可以使她避免负债。” 5她有一笔津贴，但随后看似意外的事情发生了：学费上涨，她的奖学金减少。她求助于她的信用卡。在一个朋友的建议下，她把她的信用卡债务包装成学生贷款，并把利息从 18% 降到 3%。当时，凯瑟琳 “认为她做出了正确的决定。” 6现在，纳税人正在补贴她的信用卡债务，这不会让她和曼宁有任何烦恼。

After grad school, Catherine goes to work for a nonprofit, presumably in development. This job demands “champagne taste with a draft-beer pocket­book.” 7She honors that demand with credit cards. When the inflation of the late 1970s sets in (1975–79 annual average: 8.06 percent), she concludes that spending is the only way to beat the system. “Those macroeconomic circumstances profoundly influenced her decision to abandon the cognitive connect between earnings and consumption,” 8writes Manning, as though inflation had reached the disorienting levels of Weimar Germany, where it took a wheelbarrow full of cash to buy a loaf of bread. As addicted to hyperbole as Catherine was to credit, Manning claims that this short-lived “age of inflation” spelled an end to the “Puritan work ethic” in general.

研究生毕业后，凯瑟琳去为一个非营利组织工作，大概是从事开发工作。这份工作要求 “有关于香槟酒的、有生啤酒的口袋­书的品味。” 7她用信用卡兑现了这个要求。当 20 世纪 70 年代末的通货膨胀来临时（1975～79 年的年平均水平：8.06%），她得出结论，消费是打败这个系统的唯一方法。“这些宏观经济情况深刻地影响了她放弃收入和消费之间的认知联系的决定”，8曼宁写道，仿佛通货膨胀已经达到魏玛德国那种令人迷失方向的水平，在那里要买一条面包就需要一整车的现金。就像凯瑟琳沉迷于夸大其词一样，曼宁声称，这个短暂的 “通货膨胀时代” 意味着 “清教徒工作伦理” 的全面结束。

In any case, Catherine loses her job, moves in with her parents, and then marries a Middle Easterner. “After a year,” Manning writes blithely, “irreconcilable cultural differences led to divorce.” 9Now it is back to grad school for another master’s, more student loans, more credit card debt; then a career shift, more graduate school, more loans, more debt, a recession that stymies her job search; then in the early 1990s, a job with a salary that cannot “keep up with inflation” (1992–95 annual average: 2.85 percent), more credit card debt. In 1996, a year when employers were scrambling to find workers, “the nonprofit sector was implementing serious budget cuts.” 10Catherine loses her job, and the credit card companies turn on her.

不管怎样，凯瑟琳失去了工作，搬到了她父母家，然后嫁给了一个中东人。“一年后”，曼宁轻描淡写地写道，“不可调和的文化差异导致了离婚。” 9现在，她又回到了研究生院攻读另一个硕士学位，更多学生贷款，更多信用卡债务。然后是职业转换，更多的研究生院，更多的贷款，更多的债务，经济衰退阻碍了她的求职；然后在二十世纪 90 年代初，找到了一份工资无法 “跟上通货膨胀” 的工作（1992～95 年的平均水平，2. 85％），更多的信用卡债务。1996 年，雇主们争相寻找工人，“非营利部门正在实施严重的预算削减。” 10凯瑟琳失去了工作，信用卡公司不再是她的朋友了。

Finally (reluctantly, of course), Catherine decides on bankruptcy. She reasons, with Manning’s tacit approval, “Why should I feel so bad after all the S&Ls that went broke and the corporations that filed for bankruptcy?” The one catch is those seemingly benign student loans. The bankruptcy court won’t discharge them. Still, she finds a decent job and a rent-controlled apartment. Were it not for that apartment, says Catherine, who has obviously become accustomed to living on other people’s money, “I would be leading the workers’ revolution. . . . There is no way a single woman can survive on my salary and pay a market-rate rent in New York City.” 11

最后（当然是不情愿的），凯瑟琳决定破产。她的理由是，在曼宁的默许下，“在所有破产的 S&L 公司和申请破产的公司之后，我为什么要感到如此糟糕？” 有一个问题是那些看似良性的学生贷款。破产法院不会解除它们。尽管如此，她还是找到了一份体面的工作和一套租金受控的公寓。凯瑟琳说，如果不是那套公寓，她显然已经习惯了靠别人的钱生活，“我将会领导工人革命…… 一个单身女人不可能靠我的工资和支付纽约市的市场租金来生存。” 11

Catherine was one of literally millions in the late 1990s who contributed to an unprecedented phenomenon: a dramatic spike in bankruptcies during a period that even Manning concedes was one of “economic prosperity and low unemployment.” 12He offers no explanation for this rise other than the “lax lending policies of the banking industry that offered easy consumer credit to increasingly higher-risk, lower-income workers.” 13

凯瑟琳是二十世纪 90 年代末数百万人中的一员，她对一个前所未有的现象做出了贡献：在一个连曼宁都承认是 “经济繁荣和低失业率” 的时期，破产数量急剧飙升。 "12除了 “银行业的宽松贷款政策为越来越多的高风险、低收入工人提供了便利的消费信贷，他没有对这种上升作出解释。” 13

The role of divorce, delayed marriages, single motherhood, and a media that elevates prodigals to victims does not seem to factor in. From Manning’s perspective, that single women were “the fastest-growing subgroup” 14among the bankrupt is merely further proof of their exploitation by the banking industry. Nowhere does he acknowledge the hell that banks would pay if they were more selective and that selectivity led to “disparate outcomes” along race and gender lines, as it inevitably would.

离婚、延迟婚姻、单身母亲以及将败家子提升为受害者的媒体的作用似乎没有被考虑在内。从曼宁的角度来看，单身女性是 “增长最快的子群体” 14，在破产者中只是进一步证明她们被银行业剥削。他在任何地方都没有承认，如果银行有更多的选择性，并且选择性导致了按种族和性别划分的 “不同结果”，那么银行就会付出地狱般的代价，而这是不可避免的。

Protected by the media, social puritans do not feel obliged to think through their positions. On the one hand, Manning chastises banks for making credit too accessible. On the other, he laments the fact that “low-income minorities, new immigrants, and the struggling lower middle class” are finding access to banks “increasingly difficult.” 15

在媒体的保护下，社会清教徒并不觉得有义务去思考自己的立场。一方面，曼宁责备银行使信贷太容易获得。另一方面，他对 “低收入的少数民族、新移民和挣扎中的中下层阶级‘发现获得银行服务越来越困难’表示哀叹。” 15

Those denied credit are condemned to a world of payday loans, pawnshops, rent-to-own stores, and loan sharks, a world in which even Manning admits the 19.9 percent APR of a Citibank Visa begins to look attractive. He argues that the cost of credit to these people represents a “new feature of social inequality,” unaware, obviously, that reformers have been making this same argument for the last three millennia. Like most such reformers, he ignores the risk factors that drive up credit costs to the poor. But then again, he pretty much ignores the poor. They net one page in a four-hundred-page book, credit cards being a sexier subject altogether.

那些被拒绝信贷的人注定要在一个发薪日贷款、典当行、租赁店和高利贷的世界里生活，在这个世界里，即使是曼宁也承认花旗银行签证 19.9% 的年利率开始变得有吸引力。他认为，这些人的信贷成本代表了 “社会不平等的新特征”，显然，他没有意识到改革者在过去三千年里一直在提出同样的论点。像大多数这样的改革者一样，他忽视了促使穷人的信贷成本上升的风险因素。但话说回来，他几乎忽略了穷人。他们在一本四百页的书中只占了一页，信用卡完全是一个更性感的话题。

The credit card epidemic, Manning assures the reader, is so virulent that not even the “spiritually guided” are immune.16To prove his point he cites the case of one Reverend Robert Trache.
