By the year 2000, all systems were go for the launch of a massive bubble. All that was missing was an expansionary monetary policy of the sort that kept the Mississippi and South Sea bubbles afloat. Rest assured, the great American housing bubble would not be lacking that policy for long.

到了 2000 年，所有的系统都已准备好启动一个巨大的泡沫。所缺少的只是一种扩张性的货币政策，这种政策使密西西比河和南海的泡沫得以浮动。请放心，伟大的美国房地产泡沫不会长期缺乏这种政策。

twenty-eightBabel 巴比伦

IN JUNE 2000, A MONTH AFTER THE NASDAQ CRASH SIGNALED THE end of the dot-com boom, an obscure Egyptian named Mohamed Atta casually entered the United States and began plotting his evil mischief. As would soon become evident, peace was about to go the way of prosperity.

2000 年 6 月，在纳斯达克大跌预示着互联网繁荣结束的一个月后，一个名叫穆罕默德·阿塔的不起眼的埃及人随意进入美国，开始策划他的邪恶恶作剧。很快就可以看出，和平即将走向繁荣的道路。

Even before the 9/11 attacks, chief bubble monitor Alan Greenspan had persuaded the Fed’s Open Market Committee (FOMC) to lower the federal funds rate. He was responding to the recession that had officially begun in March 2001. After September 11, the Fed ratcheted the rate down to 1.75 in four quick steps and kept pushing it down until it reached 1 percent in mid-2003, the lowest rate since 1954.

甚至在 9/11 袭击之前，首席泡沫监测师艾伦·格林斯潘就已经说服美联储公开市场委员会（FOMC）降低联邦基金利率。他是为了应对 2001 年 3 月正式开始的经济衰退。9 月 11 日之后，美联储以四个快速步骤将利率降至 1.75，并不断将其推低，直到 2003 年中期达到 1%，这是 1954 年以来的最低利率。

Despite a surge in the economy in the second half of 2003, the Fed kept the interest rate at 1 percent for another year. “That is the Greenspan ‘Put,’” observed veteran financial writer Charles Morris. “No matter what goes wrong, the Fed will rescue you by creating enough cheap money to buy you out of your troubles.” 1

尽管 2003 年下半年经济激增，美联储仍将利率维持在 1% 的水平上一年。“这就是格林斯潘的‘把戏’”，资深金融作家查尔斯·莫里斯观察到。“无论出现什么问题，美联储都会通过创造足够多的廉价货币来拯救你，让你摆脱困境。” 1

Out in Calabasas, Angelo Mozilo was not about to complain. “It was the Roaring Twenties all over again,” 2writes Adam Michelson of the atmosphere at Countrywide. This full-service mortgage company, the nation’s largest, was getting larger every day. It could barely hire enough staff to keep up with the consumer demand to buy new homes or refinance old ones. For Mozilo, this meant more than mere profit. He and his key staff saw universal home owner­ship as America’s destiny and Countrywide’s mission. “I have never believed more in what I’m doing, Adam,” one Countrywide exec told Michelson. “What could be more wonderful than helping someone get a home, really?” 3

在卡拉巴萨斯，安吉洛·莫齐洛并不打算抱怨。“这简直就是咆哮的二十年代的翻版”，2亚当·迈克尔森（Adam Michelson）用坎垂外德（Countrywide）的风气写道。这家提供全面服务的抵押贷款公司是美国最大的公司，规模一天比一天大。它几乎无法雇佣足够的员工来满足消费者购买新房或为旧房再融资的需求。对于莫齐洛来说，这意味着不仅仅是利润。他和他的主要员工将全民购房视为美国的命运和全国范围内的使命。“我从未如此相信我所做的事情，亚当”，一位全国性的执行官告诉米歇尔森。“还有什么比帮助别人得到一个家更美妙的呢？” 3

One other cultural trend deserves mention, and that is the public embrace of “sustainability.” The charmed inhabitants of coastal California all but invented the concept, and the public officials of San Mateo County, due south of San Francisco, have labored like Hammurabi to codify it. For a dozen years now, San Mateo has been producing an entertaining document called “Indicators for a Sustainable San Mateo County,” which purports to evaluate thirty-one trends “that form a snapshot of sustainability.” 4

还有一个文化趋势值得一提，那就是公众对 “可持续性” 的拥抱。加州沿海地区迷人的居民几乎发明了这个概念，而旧金山以南的圣马刁县的政府官员则像汉谟拉比一样努力将其编入法典。十几年来，圣马刁一直在制作一份名为《圣马刁县可持续发展指标》的有趣文件，该文件声称要评估 “形成可持续发展快照” 的 31 个趋势。4

On the first page of the 2005 tenth-anniversary document, when the housing bubble was at its most ebullient, the county congratulated itself for “increased use of solar,” “fewer contaminated sites,” “more transit oriented development” and even “improved academic performance.” 5Not until page two did the county bother its citizens with the unfortunate factoid that if theirs was a family of median income, they could afford to buy only 12 percent of the homes in the county. Nor was there any admission that certain sustainability measures — particularly restraints on land use — were pricing the middle class out of the county. San Mateo was not unique. “The affordability of housing is overwhelmingly a function of just one thing,” reports a recent international study of home prices, “the extent to which governments place artificial restrictions on the supply of residential lands.” 6

在 2005 年十周年纪念文件的第一页，当房地产泡沫最热烈的时候，该县祝贺自己 “增加了太阳能的使用”，“减少了受污染的场地”，“更多的公交导向发展”，甚至 “改善了学术表现”。5直到第二页，该县才告诉公民一个不幸的事实：如果他们的家庭是中等收入，他们只能买得起该县 12% 的房子。也没有人承认，某些可持续发展措施，特别是对土地使用的限制，正在使中产阶级离开该县。圣马特奥并非独一无二。最近一项关于房价的国际研究报告指出，“住房的可负担性绝大部分是由一件事决定的，政府对住宅土地供应的人为限制程度。” 6

Mozilo saw these changes in the culture up close. Countrywide head­quarters, after all, were located in Calabasas, an L.A. County enclave so environmentally prissy that in 2006 it made news by banning smokingoutdoors. Nearly half of Countrywide’s loans originated in California. Mozilo, however, failed to recognize the ramifications of the changes underfoot, and the wonkish Greenspan did not even see them. This collective blindness would cost everyone.

莫齐洛近距离看到了这些文化的变化。毕竟，坎垂外德公司的总部位于卡拉巴萨斯（Calabasas），这个洛杉矶县的飞地对环境非常敏感，2006 年，它因禁止在户外吸烟而成为新闻。全国各地近一半的贷款都源自加州。然而，莫齐洛没有认识到脚下变化的影响，而精于思考的格林斯潘甚至没有看到这些变化。这种集体的盲目性将使所有人付出代价。

As the mortgage market heated up, the true believers at Countrywide began to think that Mozilo’s vision of a “loan for every customer” might actually be within reach. To realize this vision, Countrywide had created a subsidiary brand called Full Spectrum Lending. For decades, subprime applicants had been treated like pariahs within the lending industry, but FSL sent out truckloads of mail each month to solicit just such borrowers. Countrywide, says Michelson, took to heart its goal of “‘lowering the barriers to homeownership’ for African Americans, Latinos, and other minority groups who could face potential challenges within the existing lending system.” 7

随着抵押贷款市场的升温，坎垂外德公司的忠实信徒们开始认为，莫齐洛 “为每个客户提供贷款” 的愿景可能真的可以实现。为了实现这一愿景，全国公司创建了一个名为 “全光谱贷款” 的附属品牌。几十年来，次级贷款申请者在贷款行业中一直被视为贱民，但 FSL 每个月都会发出大量的邮件来招揽这样的借款人。米歇尔森说，全国范围内的目标是 “为非裔美国人、拉美人和其他少数族裔群体降低购房障碍”，他们在现有的贷款系统中可能面临潜在的挑战。

Things were equally busy in Wilton, Connecticut, home of AIG’s Financial Products division. In 2001, Hank Greenberg had appointed the son of a Brooklyn cop, Joe Cassano, to run AIGFP. Greenberg made the move not to fulfill any Jewish-Italian cultural destiny, but to keep this cash cow under his control. By all accounts, Cassano, a Brooklyn College political science grad, mirrored his boss’s bullying style but without the compensating talent.8He was indebted to Greenberg, and he knew it. Under Cassano, AIGFP had expanded the kinds of debt it insured. In addition to loans to major corporations, Cassano’s unit was now insuring just about any kind of debt that generated a cash flow — student loans, auto loans, credit-card debt, and especially home mortgages, almost all of them, at least at this stage, to prime borrowers.

在 AIG 金融产品部的所在地康涅狄格州威尔顿，事情同样繁忙。2001 年，汉克·格林伯格任命一名布鲁克林警察的儿子乔·卡萨诺管理 AIGFP。格林伯格此举不是为了完成任何犹太·意大利文化的使命，而是为了将这棵摇钱树留在他的控制之下。从各方面来看，毕业于布鲁克林学院政治学系的卡萨诺反映了他老板的欺凌风格，但没有补偿性的才能。8他欠了格林伯格的人情，他也知道。在卡萨诺的领导下，AIGFP 扩大了它所保险的债务种类。除了向大公司提供贷款外，卡萨诺的部门现在几乎为任何一种能产生现金流的债务提供保险，包括学生贷款、汽车贷款、信用卡债务，特别是住房抵押贷款，至少在这个阶段，几乎所有的抵押贷款都是针对主要借款人的。

Back in New York, things were going swimmingly for Bear Stearns, still the big dog in the mortgage-backed securities market. In 2002,Fortune Magazinenamed Bear the “most admired securities firm” 9on Wall Street. For eighty uninterrupted years, the firm had not had a losing quarter. In 2003, looking for growth opportunities, the firm staked millions of its own money on an inhouse hedge fund. Chosen to direct the fund was Bear Stearns veteran Ralph Cioffi, still another Italian in a Jewish enterprise. Although known to be an indifferent, if not careless, manager, Cioffi made up for it with his smarts and market savvy. The firm rewarded him soon enough with a reported eight-figure compensation package.

在纽约，贝尔斯登的事情进展顺利，它仍然是抵押贷款支持的证券市场的大狗。2002 年，《财富》杂志将贝尔斯登评为华尔街 “最受赞赏的证券公司” 9。八十年来，该公司从未出现过亏损的季度。2003 年，为了寻找增长机会，该公司用自己的数百万元钱押在一个内部对冲基金上。被选中指导该基金的是贝尔斯登公司的老员工拉尔夫·西奥菲（Ralph Cioffi），他仍然是一家犹太企业的另一个意大利人。尽管众所周知，西奥菲是一个冷漠的，甚至是粗心的经理人，但他的聪明才智和市场智慧弥补了这一点。公司很快就给了他足够的回报，据说他获得了八位数的报酬。

The market was ready for a fund like Cioffi’s. With equities stable and the return on Treasury bonds slight due to depressed interest rates, investors were clamoring for action. “Two things happened,” one market analyst observed. “They took [on] more and more leverage, and they reached for riskier asset classes. Give me yield, give me leverage, give me return.” 10

市场已经准备好迎接像 Cioffi 这样的基金。随着股票的稳定，以及由于利率低迷，国债的回报率微弱，投资者吵着要采取行动。“发生了两件事”，一位市场分析家说。“他们采取了越来越多的杠杆，并向更高风险的资产类别伸手。给我收益率，给我杠杆，给我回报。” 10

The big ratings agencies — Moody’s, Standard & Poor’s, Fitch — helped pump air into the bubble. As the bond market expanded, so did their business. Keeping up was not easy, especially since the new securities were so complex that even their creators were hard-pressed to explain them.11Then, too, the people doing the explaining were the same investment banking houses paying their bills. The result was a whole lot of negotiated triple-As.

大型评级机构 —— 穆迪、标准普尔、惠誉 —— 帮助为泡沫注入空气。随着债券市场的扩大，他们的业务也在扩大。坚持下去并不容易，特别是由于新的证券是如此复杂，甚至它们的创造者也很难解释它们。11然后，做解释的人也是为他们买单的投资银行家。结果是一大堆谈判的 AAA 级。

Government regulators, meanwhile, told commercial banks that if the rating agencies assigned triple-A ratings to certain assets, the banks could reduce the amount of capital held against them. This put all the more pressure on rating agencies to upgrade the rating of various asset packages and on banks to structure such packages to maximize leverage and, ideally, profits. Fractional reserve banking was getting progressively more fractional.

同时，政府监管机构告诉商业银行，如果评级机构对某些资产给予 AAA 评级，银行可以减少针对这些资产的资本额。这给评级机构带来了更大的压力，要求它们提高各种资产组合的评级，并要求银行构建这种组合，以最大限度地提高杠杆率和理想的利润。部分准备金银行业务正逐渐变得更加零碎。

In Washington, the Bush administration picked up where Clinton had left off. In 2003, at President Bush’s urging, Congress passed the American Dream Downpayment Act. Said Federal Housing Commissioner John Weicher, “The White House doesn’t think those who can afford the monthly payment but have been unable to save for a down payment should be deprived from owning a home.” 12Conservatives would argue that the inability to save for a home suggests an inability to own one, but “compassionate conservatives” had moved beyond such narrow thinking. The spirit of Herbert Hoover was alive and well in Washington.

在华盛顿，布什政府接替了克林顿的工作。2003 年，在布什总统的敦促下，国会通过了《美国梦首付法案》。联邦住房专员约翰·韦歇尔说 ：“白宫认为，那些有能力支付月供但无法存下首付的人不应该被剥夺拥有住房的权利。” 12保守派会争辩说，无法为房屋储蓄表明没有能力拥有房屋，但 “富有同情心的保守派” 已经超越了这种狭隘思想。赫伯特·胡佛的精神在华盛顿活得很好。

The year before, Bush had signed into law the Single-Family Affordable Housing Tax Credit Act. The program promised more than $2 billion in tax credits to those who would develop affordable single-family housing in economically challenged neighborhoods. Although the White House overpackaged the program as Renewing the Dream, Angelo Mozilo had to like the sound of it. In that same time frame, Countrywide was launching a new ad campaign with the theme Realize Your Dreams. That theme would become the company’s new slogan.13

前一年，布什签署了《单户可负担住房税收抵免法案》。该计划承诺向那些在经济困难地区开发负担得起的单户住房的人提供超过 20 亿美元的税收抵免。尽管白宫将该计划过度包装为 “更新梦想”，但安吉洛·莫齐洛不得不喜欢它的声音。在同一时间段内，全美房地产公司推出了一个新的广告活动，主题是 “实现你的梦想”。这个主题将成为公司的新口号。13

The biblically literate might hear in this home-building mantra an echo of building projects past. “And they said one to another, Go to, let us make brick, and burn them thoroughly. And they had brick for stone, and slime had they for mortar. And they said, Go to, let us build us a city and a tower, whose top may reach unto heaven” (Genesis 11:3–4). In the first years of the twenty-first century, this Babel-like effort would promise affordable housing for all people, regardless of income or character. Their debt obligations, should they choose to honor them, would be packaged, insured, and sold without risk. All would prosper and be like gods. This was not greed so much as hubris but, as its architects would soon understand, hubris can only take one so high, especially since, like the folks at Babel, their language had been confounded, and they did not understand one another’s speech.

了解圣经的人可能会从这句建房口号中听到过去建筑项目的回声。“他们彼此商量说：‘来，让我们来做砖，把砖烧透了。’他们就拿砖当石头，又拿柏油当泥浆。 他们说：‘来，让我们建造一座城和一座塔，塔顶通天。我们要为自己立名，免得我们分散在全地面上。’” （《创世纪》11:3~4）。在二十一世纪的头几年，这种类似巴别塔的努力将承诺为所有人提供负担得起的住房，无论其收入或性格如何。他们的债务义务，如果他们选择履行的话，将被包装、保险，并无风险地出售。所有的人都将繁荣，像神一样。这与其说是贪婪，不如说是狂妄，但是，正如其设计者很快就会明白的那样，狂妄只能使人达到如此高的境界，尤其是像巴别的人们一样，他们的语言被混淆了，他们不理解彼此的讲话。

In August 2003, in the midst of all this mounting euphoria, theNew York Timessounded a warning about the nation’s second-largest financial company, Fannie Mae. The company had ramped up its business of buying mortgages from lenders and selling those mortgages or its own bonds to investors around the world, but it had become highly leveraged in the process, meaning it was carrying much more debt than equity.

2003 年 8 月，在所有这些日益增长的兴奋中，《纽约时报》对美国第二大金融公司房利美发出了警告。该公司已经加强了从贷款人那里购买抵押贷款的业务，并将这些抵押贷款或其自身的债券出售给世界各地的投资者，但在这个过程中，它已经变得高度杠杆化，这意味着它的债务远远多于股权。

What prompted the article were the results of internal Fannie Mae computer modeling on the question of company debt. TheTimeshad acquired this information from a former employee concerned that Fannie Mae “was becoming a risk to taxpayers and the financial system.” 14The documents showed that if interest rates were to rise immediately by 1.5 percentage points, Fannie Mae’s portfolio would lose $7.5 billion in value. “There is no reason for anybody to be worried about the company,” executive vice president Peter Niculescu assuredTimesreaders. “We are very happy, comfortable, and proud of our performance this year in what has turned out to be a very volatile interest rate environment.” 15

引发这篇文章的是房利美公司内部关于公司债务问题的计算机建模的结果。《泰晤士报》从一位担心房利美 “正在成为纳税人和金融系统的风险” 的前雇员那里获得了这些信息。14这些文件显示，如果利率立即上升 1.5 个百分点，房利美的投资组合将损失 75 亿美元的价值。执行副总裁彼得·尼古列斯库（Peter Niculescu）向读者保证 ：“任何人都没有理由对公司感到担忧。我们很高兴，很舒服，并为我们今年在原来非常不稳定的利率环境中的表现感到自豪。” 15

Fannie Mae’s CEO Franklin Raines deflected criticism by focusing on Fannie Mae’s success at social engineering. “We have met or exceeded our affordable housing goals, even as they have increased,” he told the Congressional Finance Committee in late 2003. He also shared the company’s “voluntary goal,” namely, to “lead the market in serving minority families.” 16Through its energetic lobbying and strategic campaign donations, Fannie Mae had won many friends in Congress. At that same hearing, Congresswoman Maxine Waters commended “the outstanding leadership of Frank Raines” and insisted that regulatory reform not impede Fannie Mae’s “affordable housing mission, a mission that has seen innovation flourish from desktop underwriting to 100 percent loans.” 17

房利美首席执行官富兰克林·雷恩斯通过关注房利美在社会工程方面的成功来回避批评。他在 2003 年底对国会金融委员会说 ：“我们已经达到或超过了我们的经济适用房目标，即使它们已经增加。” 他还分享了公司的 “自愿目标”，即 “在为少数民族家庭服务方面引领市场”。 16通过其充满活力的游说和战略性竞选捐款，房利美在国会赢得了许多朋友。在同一听证会上，女议员玛克辛·沃特斯(Maxine Waters)赞扬了 “弗兰克·雷恩斯的杰出领导”，并坚持认为监管改革不会阻碍房利美的 “经济适用房使命，这一使命见证了从桌面核销到 100% 贷款的创新蓬勃发展。” 17

When President Bush expressed concern about the precarious state of Fannie and Freddie in June 2004, seventy-six Democrats in Congress signed a letter warning that “an exclusive focus on safety and soundness is likely to come, in practice, at the expense of affordable housing.” 18Raines had long since transcended safety and soundness. Later in that same year, he took early retirement after the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight caught him cooking the books to the tune of six billion dollars to justify his own ninety million dollars in compensation.

当布什总统在 2004 年 6 月对房利和房地产业的不稳定状态表示担忧时，国会中的 76 名民主党人签署了一封信，警告 “只关注安全和健全的做法，实际上可能会以牺牲可负担住房为代价。” 18雷恩斯早已超越了安全和健全。同年晚些时候，在联邦住房企业监督办公室发现他为了证明自己的九千万美元报酬而做了 60 亿美元的假账后，他提前退休。

In the summer of 2004, Countrywide rolled out an adjustable-rate product called the PayOption loan. This timely creation enabled borrowers to mix and match their mortgage payments as suited their fancy. If things were going well, they could pay the interest and principal as their parents had to do. If money were tight, they could make a minimum payment just as they did on their credit cards.19The negative amortization potential built into this loan actually allowed the principal to grow over time, a novel way of repaying a loan, to be sure.

2004 年夏天，坎垂外德公司推出了一种名为 “PayOption” 贷款的可调利率产品。这一及时的创造使借款人能够根据自己的喜好混合和匹配他们的抵押贷款付款。如果事情进展顺利，他们可以像他们的父母那样支付利息和本金。19这种贷款中的负摊销潜力实际上允许本金随时间增长，可以肯定的是，这是一种新颖的偿还贷款的方式。

Author Adam Michelson, who attended the rollout meeting for PayOption, was shocked out of his Countrywide loyalty. The concept flew in the face of “every bit of interpersonal, ethical, academic, and moral teaching” he had ever learned. At Countrywide, management had dressed up customer service and passed it off as ethics, and Countrywide was more sincere than most. “What if housing valuesdocome down?” Michelson summoned the courage to ask. “Isn’t it possible thathalf the countrycould be upside down on these loans?” 20He was told that the chances of such a scenario were slim.

作者亚当·迈克尔逊（Adam Michelson）参加了 “PayOption” 的推出会议，他被震惊得失去了对这家公司的忠诚。这个概念与他所学到的 “人际关系、伦理、学术和道德方面的每一点教导” 都背道而驰。在坎垂外德内，管理层把客户服务打扮成了道德，并把它当作道德，而坎垂外德比大多数人更真诚。“如果住房价值确实下降了怎么办？” 米歇尔森鼓起勇气问道。"20他被告知，出现这种情况的机会很小。

In 2004, chances must indeed have seemed slim. According to the Case-Shiller Index, arguably the most sophisticated of such indices, home prices had risen nationally every year for the previous thirteen years and sharply for the previous seven. In the previous four years alone, prices had increased 63 percent. Even when prices fell in 1991, the last down year, the dip was shallow and short-lived.21As long as home prices continued to grow, default would not be much of a threat for lenders or borrowers. The borrower could recoup his money by reselling, and if the borrower defaulted, the lender could recoup his loan by selling the home.

在 2004 年，房价下跌的机会确实看起来很渺茫。根据 “Case-Shiller” 指数（可以说是最复杂的指数），在过去的 13 年里，全国的房价每年都在上涨，而且在过去的 7 年里，房价大幅上涨。仅在过去的四年中，房价就上涨了 63%。即使在 1991 年，也就是最后一个下跌的年份，价格下跌也很浅，而且是短暂的下跌。21只要房价继续增长，违约对贷款人和借款人都不会构成太大的威胁。借款人可以通过转售收回资金，而如果借款人违约，贷款人可以通过出售房屋收回贷款。

Besides, PayOption was precisely the kind of “innovative loan” Congress and the media had been championing. At the time, such loans made a certain amount of short-term sense. In the summer of 2004, the federal funds rate remained almost inexplicably low at 1.25 percent. As a consequence, the prime rate — the rate at which banks lend to trusted customers, typically three hundred basis points above the fed rate — stood at a seductive 4.25 percent. In 2004, the home ownership rate reached 69 percent.

此外，“PayOption” 正是国会和媒体一直倡导的那种 “创新贷款”。在当时，这种贷款有一定的短期意义。在 2004 年夏天，联邦基金利率几乎令人费解地保持在 1.25% 的低位。因此，最优惠利率 —— 银行借给值得信赖的客户的利率，通常比联邦利率高三百个基点 —— 保持在诱人的 4.25%。2004 年，住房拥有率达到 69%。

“Stop! We’re at 69 percent home ownership. We should go no further. These are people who should remain renters.” Former HUD secretary Henry Cisneros wished someone had said this at the time, adding that it was “impossible to know in the beginning that the federal push to increase homeownership would end so badly.” 22In 1995, it was Henry Cisneros who had first used his authority as HUD chief to mandate that Fannie and Freddie’s mortgages serve a fixed percentage of low- and moderate-income families — at that time 42 percent.

“停! 我们的住房拥有率已经达到 69%。我们不应该再往前走了。这些人应该继续租房。” 前住房和城市发展部部长亨利·西斯内罗斯(Henry Cisneros)希望当时有人能说这句话，他还说，“一开始不可能知道联邦推动提高住房拥有率会有如此糟糕的结局。” 221995 年，正是亨利·西斯内罗斯首次利用他作为住房和城市发展部部长的权力，规定房利和弗雷迪的抵押贷款必须为固定比例的低收入和中等收入家庭服务 —— 当时是 42％。

Low interest rates, easy credit, and the steady increase in home prices inevitably attracted speculators. If they could buy a home in a hot market for $500,000, spruce it up a bit, and sell it for $600,000 a year later, it is hard to fault them. This model worked well until June 2004, when the Fed finally began to raise the interest rate. There would be sixteen consecutive rate hikes by June 2006. Typically, when interest rates increase, the demand for home loans decrease. Prime borrowers took the cue. From June 2004 to June 2005, their borrowing fell by half. Subprime borrowers paid little heed to the rise in rates, however; in that same time frame, their borrowing doubled. It would double again.

低利率、宽松的信贷，以及房价的稳步上升，不可避免地吸引了投机者。如果他们能以 50 万美元的价格在热门市场买下一栋房子，稍加修饰，一年后以 60 万美元的价格出售，那就很难怪他们了。这种模式一直运作良好，直到 2004 年 6 月，美联储终于开始提高利率。到 2006 年 6 月，将有连续 16 次加息。通常情况下，当利率上升时，对房屋贷款的需求会减少。主要借款人接受了这一提示。从 2004 年 6 月到 2005 年 6 月，他们的借款减少了一半。然而，次级借款人很少注意到利率的上升；在同一时间段内，他们的借款增加了一倍。它将再次翻倍。

To keep the supply flowing through a narrowing pipeline, Countrywide and other lenders had resorted to all manner of innovative and flexible home loans. The most popular loan for the subprime crowd — 78 percent of all subprime loans in 2006 — was commonly known as the 2-28.23A 2-28 adjustable rate mortgage (ARM) would have a low fixed rate for the first two years, often interest only. After two years, the loan would reset, typically at the prevailing interest rate. In a real-world scenario, a person who took out a 2-28 ARM mortgage in June 2004, when the prime rate was at 4.25 percent, would have found herself in a world of hurt in June 2006, when the remaining twenty-eight years reset with the prime at 8.25 percent.

为了保持供应量通过不断缩小的管道，坎垂外德和其他贷款人采取了各种创新和灵活的住房贷款方式。最受次贷人群欢迎的贷款 —— 2006 年所有次贷的 78% —— 通常被称为 “2-28”。23 “2-28” 可调利率抵押贷款（ARM）在头两年会有一个低的固定利率，通常只付利息。两年后，贷款将被重置，通常是按现行利率计算。在现实世界中，一个人在 2004 年 6 月办理了 “2-28” ARM 抵押贷款，当时最优惠利率为 4.25%，到了 2006 年 6 月，当剩余的 28 年重新设置为最优惠利率 8.25% 时，她会发现自己陷入了困境。

A “predatory” loan only seems so in retrospect. At the peak of the bubble, many borrowers expected to accrue enough equity gain in the first two years to pay for the refinancing differential or to bail out altogether. What made this strategy possible was the euphemistically titled “stated income” loan, or, as they were more cynically known, liar loans. As originally intended, these loans allowed the self-employed a way around having to show a W-2. As the pool of new borrowers ran dry, however, lenders began to accept the word of just about anyone. Some lenders no longer asked to see proof of income, ID, or even citizenship. By 2006, most subprime and nearly all Alt-A loans, a class characterized by a lack of documentation, were stated income.

“掠夺性” 贷款只有在回想起来时才显得如此。在泡沫的高峰期，许多借款人期望在头两年积累足够的资产收益，以支付再融资的差价或完全保释。使这种策略成为可能的是被委婉地称为 “声明收入” 的贷款，或者说，它们被更冷酷地称为骗子贷款。按照最初的设想，这些贷款允许自营职业者在必须出示 “W-2” 的情况下有一个办法。然而，随着新的借款人队伍的枯竭，贷款人开始接受几乎任何人的说法。一些贷款人不再要求看到收入证明、身份证，甚至公民身份。到 2006 年，大多数次贷和几乎所有的 “Alt-A” 贷款（一类以缺乏文件为特征的贷款）都是陈述收入。

For years, community groups like ACORN had been pressing for the relaxation of income and identity standards. “No one who gets a mortgage ever has to go beyond [the Philadelphia ACORN] office,” 24reported the 1992New York Timesarticle cited earlier. TheTimesbenignly highlights ACORN-assisted borrowers who did not speak English, had no credit history, or had to “sign ‘X’ for their name.” 25To keep the bubble from bursting, lenders grew increasingly willing to take borrowers at their word. As Reuters reported, “Illegal immigrants were able to buy U.S. homes during the boom years, either by showing evidence that they pay taxes or by simply presenting false documents.” 26Almost half of the mortgage loans taken out by Hispanics were subprime. Many of thelegalimmigrants were unable to read the documents. For that matter, regulatory requirements had so thickened the stack of documents a borrower had to sign that all borrowers had to trust the goodwill of their lenders.

多年来，像 ACORN 这样的社区团体一直在敦促放宽收入和身份标准。“获得抵押贷款的人都不必通过费城 ACORN 办公室”，24报道了前面引用的 1992《纽约时报》文章。《泰晤士报》良性地强调了 ACORN 援助的借款人不会说英语，没有信用记录，或者不得不 “用‘X’代表他们的名字。” 25为了防止泡沫破裂，贷款人越来越愿意相信借款人的话。正如路透社报道的那样，“非法移民在经济繁荣时期能够购买美国的房屋，要么出示他们纳税的证据，要么干脆出示假证件。” 26西班牙裔人获得的抵押贷款中，几乎一半是次优贷款。许多合法移民无法阅读这些文件。就这一点而言，监管要求使借款人必须签署的文件堆积如山，所有借款人不得不相信贷款人的善意。

Despite early signs of impending disaster, Congress kept the pressure on. On June 27, 2005, Barney Frank, the ranking Democrat on House Financial Services Committee, offered a resolution supporting a national home ownership month. On the House floor, he chided those who worried about a housing bubble. “You are not going to see the collapse that you see when people talk about a bubble,” he lectured his colleagues. “So those on our committee in particular are going to continue to push for homeownership.” And push they did.

尽管早期有迹象表明灾难即将来临，国会仍然保持着压力。2005 年 6 月 27 日，众议院金融服务委员会中排名第一的民主党人巴尼·弗兰克(Barney Frank)提出一项决议，支持全国住房所有权月。在众议院会议上，他责备那些担心住房泡沫的人。“你不会看到人们谈论泡沫时看到的崩溃”，他对他的同事说。“因此，我们委员会中的那些人将继续推动房屋所有权的发展。” 他们也确实在推动。

By 2006, Countrywide was offering almost two hundred different loan products. Ironically, the most complex of these loans were being sold to the people least capable of understanding them. When adjustable rate mortgages and PayOption (negative amortization) loans began to play out, Countrywide turned increasingly to home equity loans, often used by borrowers to consolidate credit card debt. These held promise as long as the equity bubble continued to expand, which it did into 2006.

到 2006 年，坎垂外德公司提供了近 200 种不同的贷款产品。具有讽刺意味的是，这些贷款中最复杂的产品被卖给了最没有能力理解它们的人。当可调整利率抵押贷款和 “PayOption” （负摊销）贷款开始发挥作用时，全国范围内越来越多地转向房屋净值贷款，借款人通常用它来合并信用卡债务。只要股票泡沫继续扩大，这些贷款就有希望，而这一情况一直持续到 2006 年。

One easy way for lenders to keep the bubble inflated was to waive the traditional 20 percent down payment. And this they did too. Some borrowers, like Melonie Griffiths-Evans profiled in the opening chapter, took out 80/20 combo loans: that is, one loan for the down payment and another for the remainder of the mortgage. This kind of loan allowed the borrower to avoid the private mortgage insurance charged to those without a 20 percent down payment. By 2006, 46 percent of all home loans in the United States were made with a down payment of less than 5 percent.27And in that same year, the subprime borrower put down on average just 6 percent.

贷款人保持泡沫膨胀的一个简单方法是放弃传统的 20% 的首付比例。他们也是这样做的。一些借款人，如开篇介绍的梅洛妮·格里菲斯·埃文斯，获得了 80/20 组合贷款：即一笔贷款用于支付首付，另一笔用于支付抵押贷款的剩余部分。这种贷款允许借款人避免向没有 20% 首付的人收取私人抵押贷款保险。到 2006 年，美国 46% 的住房贷款的首付比例低于 5%。27而在同一年，次级贷款者的首付平均只有 6%。

In certain areas, home prices were escalating more quickly than others, and nowhere more so than coastal California. In the eight years from 1996 to 2004, the average cost of a California home had outpaced the average California family income by a full 100 percent, and home prices would continue to soar for the next two years. While environmental concerns constricted supply, an influx of subprime home seekers, some of them illegal citizens, expanded demand. The combination put conventional fixed-rate mortgages beyond the reach of even the responsible middle class.

在某些地区，房价上涨的速度比其他地区更快，没有任何地方比加州沿海更快。从 1996 年到 2004 年的八年间，加州房屋的平均成本比加州家庭的平均收入高出了整整 100%，而且在接下来的两年里，房价将继续飙升。虽然环境问题限制了供应，但大量的次贷购房者，其中一些是非法公民，扩大了需求。这种组合使传统的固定利率抵押贷款甚至超出了负责任的中产阶级的能力。

Wall Street was beginning to notice. Meredith Whitney, a research analyst at Oppenheimer, was sending out warnings as early as October 2005. “Since 1996,” she observed, “sub-prime lending has grown 489% [$90 to $530 billion] largely through the extension of credit to first-time borrowers. We believe that at least 5% of the mortgage market is at risk due to the very low equity positions in homes.” 28Although Whitney cited Greenspan’s own cautions on the subject, Greenspan had been curiously incautious in the recent past.

华尔街已经开始注意到了。奥本海默公司的研究分析师梅雷迪斯·惠特尼(Meredith Whitney)早在 2005 年 10 月就发出了警告。她说 ：“自 1996 年以来，次级贷款已经增长了 489%（900 亿美元到 5300 亿美元），主要是通过向首次借款人发放信贷。我们认为，由于房屋资产状况非常低，至少有 5% 的抵押贷款市场存在风险。” 28尽管惠特尼引用了格林斯潘自己对这个问题的告诫，但格林斯潘在最近的日子里一直很奇怪的不谨慎。

In a now notorious February 2004 speech, Greenspan had an Ayn Rand moment. Overlooking the forced flood of incompetent homeowners into the market, he made the perfectly reasonable theoretical argument that “homeowners might have saved tens of thousands of dollars had they held adjustable-rate mortgages rather than fixed-rate mortgages during the past decade.” He added, “American consumers might benefit if lenders provided greater mortgage product alternatives to the traditional fixed-rate mortgage.” 29Observes Charles Morris, “In any scrapbook of bad advice from economic gurus, that [speech] should be near the top of the list.” 30

在现在臭名昭著的 2004 年 2 月的一次演讲中，格林斯潘有一个安兰德的时刻。他忽略了无能的房主被迫涌入市场的情况，提出了完全合理的理论论点 ：“如果房主在过去十年中持有可调整利率的抵押贷款而不是固定利率的抵押贷款，他们可能会节省数万美元。” 他补充说，“如果贷款人提供更多的抵押贷款产品替代传统的固定利率抵押贷款，美国消费者可能会受益。” 29查尔斯·莫里斯指出 ：“在任何经济大师的坏建议剪贴簿中，这个演讲应该是接近名单的首位。” 30

Subprime and so-called Alt-A borrowers were marching to their own drummer. They kept borrowing and Wall Street kept underwriting their loans — to the tune of $2.8 trillion from June 2004 until June 2007. If there was one man making this possible — writer Matt Taibbi would name him Patient Zero of the subprime epidemic — it was AIG’s Joe Cassano. After the usually vigilant Hank Greenberg had been forced out in early 2005 as a result of an unrelated accounting scandal, Cassano was left largely to his own devices. With a frightening lack of oversight, Cassano had allowed the potpourri of loans that AIG was insuring to mutate from diversified consumer credit into a toxic stew whose major ingredients were funky home loans.31With their debt insured by a powerhouse like AIG, Wall Street kept packaging the loans and Countrywide and others kept sending them loans to package.

次级贷款和所谓的 “Alt-A” 贷款人是按照自己的鼓点前进的。他们不断借款，华尔街不断为他们的贷款提供担保；从 2004 年 6 月到 2007 年 6 月，他们的贷款总额达到了 2.8 万亿美元。如果说有一个人让这一切成为可能，作家马特·泰比（Matt Taibbi）将他称为次贷流行病的零号病人，那就是 AIG 的乔·卡萨诺。2005 年初，一向警觉的汉克·格林伯格（Hank Greenberg）因一桩无关的会计丑闻而被迫离职，卡萨诺在很大程度上被留在了自己的位置上。由于严重缺乏监督，卡萨诺允许 AIG 所承保的各种贷款从多样化的消费信贷变异为有毒的炖品，其主要成分是古怪的住房贷款。31由于他们的债务由 AIG 这样的大公司提供保险，华尔街不断包装这些贷款，坎垂外德和其他公司不断向他们提供贷款来包装。

Although Michelson saw no evidence of outright predatory lending or mortgage fraud at Countrywide, other lenders knowingly put people into loans they knew the borrowers could not hope to repay. Typically, the lender would pocket the origination and servicing fees and sell the loan into the secondary mortgage market. Greed might explain the motive here, but then, too, so might fear — the fear that without new customers the business would collapse.

尽管米歇尔森没有看到坎垂外德存在彻底的掠夺性贷款或抵押贷款欺诈的证据，但其他贷款人在明知借款人无望偿还的情况下，故意将人们投入贷款。通常情况下，贷款人会将发放和服务费收入囊中，并将贷款卖到二级抵押贷款市场。贪婪可能解释了这里的动机，但是，也可能是恐惧 —— 担心没有新客户，业务会崩溃。

As a way of personalizing the problem, Michelson peppers his book with profiles of borrowers who have gone awry. Most concede “partial responsibility” but no more than that. Typical is Susan, whose husband made more than a million a year and indulged her and her two daughters in a nicely affluent Santa Monica lifestyle. Then the marriage fell apart, as they tend to do in California. “With grit and guts,” Michelson relates, “[Susan] set out again as a single woman with children to rebuild her life.” 32

作为一种将问题个人化的方式，米歇尔森在书中加入了一些出了问题的借款人的资料。大多数人承认 “部分责任”，但也仅此而已。典型的例子是苏珊，她的丈夫年收入超过一百万，让她和她的两个女儿享受着圣莫尼卡美好的生活。然后婚姻破裂了，就像他们在加利福尼亚所做的那样。米歇尔森说 ：“凭借勇气和胆量，苏珊作为一个带着孩子的单身女人再次出发，重建她的生活。” "32

Although the average American home price at the time was $165,000, Susan found a “charming cottage” that cost a little bit more, nearly $800,000 more in fact. To be fair, the home was in Santa Monica, whose eco-fussy residents had conspired to make it the least affordable city of its size in the world. Thanks to two loans from Countrywide, one a thirty-year fixed and another a piggyback loan to cover the spread between the cost of a home and the limits of a conventional first loan, Susan was able to buy a $950,000 house with no down payment. Only after she had moved in did Susan discover that she had to repay both loans. Alas, the combined $6,100 a month exceeded the budget of this newly single mom.

尽管当时美国的平均房价是 16.5 万美元，但苏珊找到了一个 “迷人的小屋”，价格要高一点，实际上要多出近 80 万美元。公平地说，这个房子在圣莫尼卡，其生态挑剔的居民合谋使其成为世界上同等规模的城市中最不能负担的城市。多亏了坎垂外德公司的两笔贷款，一笔是 30 年的固定贷款，另一笔是用于支付房屋成本与常规第一笔贷款限额之间的差额的附加贷款，苏珊才能够在没有首付的情况下买下 95 万美元的房子。在她搬进去之后，苏珊才发现她必须偿还这两笔贷款。唉，每月合计 6,100 美元的费用超出了这位新任单身母亲的预算。

Meanwhile, the divorce proceedings had derailed, and her embittered husband stopped making child support payments. For six months Susan used her credit cards to make her house payments before maxing out. Upon calling Countrywide for help, she sensed that there would be no dreams realized in its nightmare bureaucracy. In the meantime, with her fabled grit and guts, she filed for bankruptcy. Once she had purged all her credit card debts ——mirabile dictu! —— the child support payments began flowing again, and she was able to resume paying her monthly mortgage bill. Although Michelson’s is a generally fair-minded book, he shares the social puritan’s eagerness to absolve the consumer. All he pulls from this story is that Countrywide had such confused customer service that Susan was able to miss thirty thousand dollars’ worth of payments without the company either helping her or asking for it back.

与此同时，离婚程序已经脱轨，她那愤懑的丈夫停止支付儿童抚养费。在六个月的时间里，苏珊用她的信用卡来支付她的房款，然后就把钱刷光了。当她打电话给坎垂外德公司寻求帮助时，她感觉到在其噩梦般的官僚体系中不会有梦想实现。与此同时，她以她传说中的勇气和胆量，申请了破产。一旦她清除了所有的信用卡债务 —— 醍醐灌顶（mirabile dictu）! —— 孩子的抚养费又开始流动了，她也能够恢复支付每月的抵押贷款账单。尽管米歇尔森的书总体上是公正的，但他与社会清教徒一样，急于为消费者开脱。他从这个故事中得出的结论是，坎垂外德公司的客户服务如此混乱，以至于苏珊能够错过价值三万美元的付款，而公司既没有帮助她，也没有要求她归还。

In late 2005, Joe Cassano promoted the executive who had served as liaison to Wall Street’s mortgage desks and asked a sharp AIG quant named Gene Park to replace him.33Park had misgivings. Earlier that year he had thought about personally investing in mortgage giant New Century but balked when he discovered how infected the firm was with subprime loans. Soon after, he had heard from a jobless friend whose newfound poverty did not dissuade a lender from laying a huge loan on him for a house he could not afford.

2005 年底，乔·卡萨诺提拔了曾担任华尔街抵押贷款部门联络人的高管，并要求一位名叫吉恩·帕克的敏锐的 AIG 量化人取代他。

33帕克心存顾虑。那年早些时候，他曾想过以个人名义投资抵押贷款巨头新世纪公司，但当他发现该公司在次级贷款方面的感染程度时，他退缩了。不久之后，他听到一位失业的朋友说，他新发现的贫穷并没有阻止贷款人为他买不起的房子提供巨额贷款。

Upon being offered the job, Park did some serious snooping into AIG’s risk. What he discovered scared the ambition out of him. Those most involved in insuring the debt packages at AIG had no idea just how much subprime junk they were insuring. All of them dramatically underestimated the percentage. During his final interview with Cassano, Park told him that if he had to take the job he would quit AIG. Cassano initially blew off his concerns. He told Park that, subprime or not, the only way the bonds could default was if housing prices fell everywhere all at once, and that, of course, was not possible.

在得到这份工作后，帕克对 AIG 的风险进行了一番认真的打探。他的发现把他的野心吓坏了。那些参与 AIG 债务包保险的人不知道他们所保险的次贷垃圾有多少。他们都极大地低估了这个比例。在与卡萨诺的最后一次面谈中，帕克告诉他，如果他不得不接受这份工作，他将退出 AIG。卡萨诺最初对他的担忧置之不理。他告诉帕克，无论是否是次贷，债券违约的唯一途径是住房价格一下子到处下跌，而这当然是不可能的。

Still, the interview had sufficiently unsettled Cassano that he sought out meetings with the major Wall Street firms whose debt packages AIG was insuring. “They all said the same thing,” said one of the AIG execs present. “They’d go back to historical real-estate prices over 60 years and say they had never fallen all at once.” 34The shockingly slapdash nature of Wall Street’s analysis convinced Cassano it was past time to stop insuring subprime bonds.

尽管如此，这次采访还是让卡萨诺感到非常不安，以至于他寻求与华尔街的主要公司会面，因为 AIG 正在为其债务包提供保险。“他们都说了同样的话”，在场的一位 AIG 高管说。“他们会回顾 60 多年来的历史房地产价格，说它们从来没有一下子下跌过。” 34华尔街的分析令人震惊的草率性质使卡萨诺相信，现在已经是停止为次级债券提供保险的时候了。

The damage, alas, had already been done. Throughout 2004 and 2005, Cassano had allowed AIG to assume enough risk to keep the connecting gears of the subprime machinery grinding away even in the face of federal rate hikes. “I’m convinced that our input into the system led to a substantial portion of the increase in housing prices in the U.S.,” one AIG trader told writer Michael Lewis. “We facilitated a trillion dollars in mortgages. Just us.” 35By “us” he meant not AIG, not even AIGFP, but the credit default swaps unit within the four-hundred employee AIGFP.

损害，唉，已经发生了。在整个 2004 年和 2005 年，卡萨诺允许美国国际集团承担足够的风险，使次贷机器的连接齿轮即使在联邦利率上升的情况下也能保持运转。“我相信我们对系统的投入导致了美国房价的大幅上涨”，一位 AIG 的交易员告诉作家迈克尔·刘易斯（Michael Lewis），“我们促成了一万亿美元的抵押贷款。” 35他所说的 “我们” 不是指 AIG，甚至不是 AIGFP，而是 AIGFP 四百名员工中的信贷违约掉期部门。

The lending industry kept the gears of the mortgage machinery fluid throughout 2006 by lowering lending standards. When AIG declined to absorb the risk going forward, the major Wall Street firms — Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns — had little choice in 2006 and 2007 but to absorb the risk themselves, lest the whole apparatus break down. It was not greed that was prompting this spontaneous cooperation across a wide range of financial sectors, but fear.

整个 2006 年，贷款行业通过降低贷款标准，使抵押贷款机器的齿轮不断运转。当美国国际集团拒绝吸收未来的风险时，华尔街的主要公司 —— 美林证券、摩根士丹利、雷曼兄弟、贝尔斯登 —— 在 2006 年和 2007 年没有什么选择，只能自己吸收风险，以免整个机器崩溃。促使广泛的金融部门进行这种自发合作的不是贪婪，而是恐惧。

At Countrywide, the stock price held up through 2006, but those on the inside could hear the bells tolling. “It seems like the harder we try, the worse the numbers get,” one mortgage executive told Michelson. “It’s almost like we’re running out of prospects out there.” 36

在坎垂外德，股价在 2006 年一直保持上涨，但内部人士可以听到钟声。一位抵押贷款高管告诉米歇尔森，“似乎我们越努力，数字就越差。” 36

。

Countrywidewasrunning out of prospects, especially in California. In 2006, anyone who looked closely at the California Association of Realtors’ housing affordability index would have seen a bubble inflated to the bursting point. The figures refer to the percentage of homes in the marketplace that a family of median income could reasonably afford to buy.

Los Angeles/ Long Beach46.31.9
Santa Barbara47.53.2
Modesto70.93.9

Riverside52.38.4

坎垂外德的确跑出了前景，尤其是在加州。2006 年，任何仔细观察加州房地产经纪人协会住房负担指数的人都会看到一个膨胀到爆裂点的泡沫。这些数字指的是市场上收入居中的家庭能够合理地买得起的房屋比例。

城市19952006
三藩市/圣马特奥20.87.8
洛杉矶/长滩46.31.9
圣巴巴拉47.53.2

圣地亚哥40.65.2
河滨区52.38.4
萨利纳斯25.112.7
贝克斯菲尔德75.416.5
雷丁52.314.637

In 1995, a median income family could have afforded to buy nearly 50 percent of the homes in the L.A. metropolitan area. By mid-2006, it was down to one in fifty. Once affordable Central Valley cities like Modesto and Bakersfield had become no more affordable than Washington or New York. The executives at Countrywide, headquartered as they were in Los Angeles County, could see the problem on the drive in to work. They were exhausting their customer pool, and they knew it.

1995 年，一个中等收入的家庭可以买得起洛杉矶都市区近 50% 的房子。到 2006 年中期，这一比例下降到五十分之一。像莫德斯托和贝克斯菲尔德这样曾经负担得起的中央谷地城市，已经变得比华盛顿或纽约更负担得起。总部设在洛杉矶县的坎垂外德公司的高管们在上班的路上就能看到这个问题。他们正在耗尽他们的客户群，而且他们知道这一点。

At Bear Stearns, meanwhile, almost no one had a clue just how weird things were getting in their own mortgage-related business. On January 17, 2007, its stock reached $172.69, its highest point ever. The following month, Bear Stearns released its 2006 annual report, which celebrated “83 years of profitability.” 38The most profitable of those years had been 2006. On revenues of $9.2 billion, the firm had recorded a net income of $2.05 billion, a 40 percent increase in profit from 2005.

与此同时，在贝尔斯登公司，几乎没有人知道他们自己的抵押贷款相关业务的情况变得多么奇怪。2007 年 1 月 17 日，其股票达到 172.69 美元，是其有史以来的最高点。接下来的一个月，贝尔斯登发布了 2006 年的年度报告，庆祝 “83 年的盈利能力”。38这些年中，最赚钱的是 2006 年。在 92 亿美元的收入中，该公司的净收入为 20.5 亿美元，比 2005 年的利润增长了 40%。

That same month, however, Lewie Ranieri, the godfather of the mortgage-backed security and now semiretired, shared a deeply cautionary message with the readers of theWall Street Journal. “I don’t know how to understand the ripple effects throughout the system today,” he said. It troubled him that 40 percent of the subprime borrowers in 2006 were not required to produce pay stubs or any proof of net worth (and here he underestimated the number). “We’re not really sure what the guy’s income is and . . . we’re not sure what the home is worth,” Ranieri added. “So you can understand why some of us become a little nervous.” 39

然而，同月，抵押贷款支持证券的教父、现已半退休的路易·拉涅利（Lewie Ranieri）与《华尔街日报》的读者分享了一个深刻的警告信息。他说 ：“我不知道如何理解今天整个系统的连锁反应。” 令他感到不安的是，2006 年有 40% 的次贷者没有被要求出示工资单或任何净资产证明（这里他低估了这个数字）。“我们并不确定这个人的收入是多少，而且 ...... 我们也不确定房屋的价值是多少”，拉涅利补充说，“所以你可以理解为什么我们中的一些人变得有点紧张。” 39

Bear Stearns execs should have been more nervous than they were. Their calm was due largely to a self-imposed ignorance. Ralph Cioffi’s semiautonomous hedge fund had been routinely failing to get the approval of the fund’s independent directors before trading with Bear Stearns. Although a technicality, Bear Stearns placed a moratorium on trading with its own affiliate. “It’s classic Ralph,” colleague Paul Friedman opined. “Details were just not his best trick.” 40Once they stopped trading with Cioffi’s hedge fund, Bear execs stopped paying regular attention to what Cioffi was doing.

贝尔斯登的执行官们应该比他们更紧张。他们的平静在很大程度上是由于自我封闭的无知。拉尔夫·西奥菲(Ralph Cioffi)的半自治对冲基金在与贝尔斯登进行交易之前，经常没有得到基金独立董事的批准。虽然是技术性问题，但贝尔斯登还是暂停了与自己关联公司的交易。“这是典型的拉尔夫”，同事保罗·弗里德曼（Paul Friedman）认为，“（关注）细节并不是他的绝招。” 40一旦他们停止与 Cioffi 的对冲基金交易，贝尔斯登的执行官们就不再经常关注 Cioffi 在做什么。

Cioffi’s High-Grade Fund had problems. In August 2006, it had started to lose money. Cioffi assured his investors that only 6 percent of the fund was invested specifically in subprime loans, which the smarter investors had begun to distrust. What Cioffi did not tell his investors was that the more generic “asset-backed securities” in his portfolio were also heavily laced with subprime loans.41

Cioffi 的高等级基金有问题。2006 年 8 月，它已经开始亏损。Cioffi 向他的投资者保证，该基金只有 6% 的资金专门投资于次贷，而更聪明的投资者已经开始不相信次贷。西奥菲没有告诉他的投资者的是，他的投资组合中更普通的 “资产支持证券” 也有大量的次级贷款。41

In sum, the hedge fund was composed not of 6 percent but of 60 percent subprime. Unaware of this, when Cioffi split the fund into two entities on August 1, 2006, theFinancial Timesapplauded the move. Given Cioffi’s “stellar reputation,” the publication observed, “If anyone could clean up on rising turmoil in the mortgage market, sparked by an increase in defaults by high-risk borrowers, it would be Bear Stearns and Mr. Cioffi.” At this date, Wall Street still hoped to “clean up on” the mess rather than to “clean up” the mess. That would change in a hurry.

总之，该对冲基金不是由 6% 而是由 60% 的次贷组成。由于没有意识到这一点，当 Cioffi 在 2006 年 8 月 1 日将基金分成两个实体时，《金融时报》称赞了这一举措。鉴于西奥菲的 “良好声誉”，该出版物指出，“如果有人能在高风险借款人违约增加引发的抵押贷款市场动荡中收拾残局，那就是贝尔斯登和西奥菲先生”。在这一天，华尔街仍然希望 “继续清理” 混乱，而不是 “清理” 混乱。这种情况将迅速改变。

Among the very few people to anticipate what the future held was Peter Schiff, president of Euro Pacific Capital and a sound-money supporter of the Austrian School. On December 22, 2006, Schiff went public with his analysis that subprime loans “represent the weakest links in the mortgage/housing chain. Once they break the entire chain falls apart.” 42On any number of subsequent talk shows, Schiff was shouted down, often literally. Few wanted to hear what he had to say.

很少有人能预测到未来的情况，其中包括欧洲太平洋资本的总裁、奥地利学派的健全货币支持者彼得·希夫。2006 年 12 月 22 日，希夫公开发表了他的分析，认为次级贷款 “代表了抵押贷款/住房链中最薄弱的环节。一旦它们断裂，整个链条就会崩溃。” 42在随后的任何一个谈话节目中，希夫都被喊停，常常是字面意思。几乎没有人想听他说什么。

On February 28, 2007, the new Fed chief Ben Bernanke assured Congress that a housing downturn was not a “broad financial concern or a major factor in assessing the state of the economy.” 43Back in Calabasas, Mozilo was not worried either. At least, he did not seem to be. In a CNBC interview in March, he shared his belief that Countrywide would likely prosper from the subprime virus spreading through the industry. “This will be great for Countrywide,” he said, “because at the end of the day, all of the irrational competitors will be gone.” 44Mozilo, however, was not telling the whole story. Beginning in 2005, he had started unloading his own Countrywide stock.

2007 年 2 月 28 日，新任美联储主席伯南克向国会保证，住房下滑不是 “广泛的金融问题，也不是评估经济状况的主要因素。” 43回到卡拉巴萨斯，莫齐洛也不担心。至少，他看起来并不担心。在今年 3 月接受 CNBC 采访时，他分享了自己的信念，即全美银行可能会从次贷病毒蔓延的行业中获得收益。“这对坎垂外德来说将是件好事”，他说，“因为到最后，所有非理性的竞争者都将消失。” 44然而，莫齐洛并没有说出整个故事。从 2005 年开始，他已经开始抛售自己的坎垂外德股票。

Warren Spector, the copresident of Bear Stearns, conveyed much the same impression as Bernanke. At a March 29, 2007, investor day, Spector told his audience, “The big question is will [the subprime mess] have a broad impact on the housing market. I don’t see it. We’re very proud of the way we do risk management. It’s an integral part of our culture. . . . We have a strong culture of no surprises.” 45Spector would soon be reminded of the proverbial Wall Street wisdom that “the real risk is the one you can’t see.” 46

贝尔斯登的联席总裁沃伦·斯佩克特(Warren Spector)传达了与伯南克大致相同的印象。在 2007 年 3 月 29 日的投资者日上，斯佩克特告诉他的听众 ：“最大的问题是[次贷混乱]会不会对住房市场产生广泛影响。我不认为会。我们对我们做风险管理的方式感到非常自豪。它是我们文化的一个组成部分…… 我们有一种强烈的无意外文化。” 45斯佩克特很快就会想起华尔街的一句谚语 ：“真正的风险是你看不见的。” 46

Ralph Cioffi had a surprise in store for Spector. His funds were tanking. “I’m sick to my stomach over our performance in March,” he would tell anyone who wanted to listen. In April, he would get sicker still. An internal Bear report on collateralized debt obligations spelled doom. “If it is correct,” said Cioffi’s partner Matthew Tannin, “then the entire subprime market is toast.” Tannin added, “If Triple-A bonds are systematically downgraded, then there is simply no way for us to make money ever.” 47With a triple-A rating these subprime-heavy CDOs could be sold with a relatively low-interest coupon. Once that rating was taken away, and the CDO was revealed to be shaky, no one would buy such a bond at or near par. The price had to plummet it, and it did.

拉尔夫·西奥菲为斯佩克特准备了一个惊喜。他的资金正在减少。“我对我们 3 月份的表现感到恶心”，他告诉任何想听的人。到了 4 月，他将变得更加恶心。熊市的一份关于抵押债务的内部报告预示着厄运。“如果它是正确的”，西奥菲的合伙人马修·坦宁说，“那么整个次贷市场就完蛋了。” 坦宁补充说 ：“如果 AAA 级债券被系统地降级，那么我们根本没有办法赚钱。” 47凭借 AAA 级的评级，这些重度次贷 CDO 可以以相对低息的票据出售。一旦这种评级被取消，CDO 被发现是不稳定的，没有人会以或接近面值购买这种债券。价格必须暴跌，而且确实如此。

The subprime epidemic was exposing the Potemkin ratings infrastructure for what it was. In September 2007, Wall Street veteran Kyle Bass testified at a Capitol Hill hearing in language that the congressmen could understand. “It would be like cattle ranchers paying the Department of Agriculture to rate the quality and safety of their beef,” he explained. “But it is becoming increasingly clear as each month passes, subprime credit has become the mad cow disease of structured finance. Nobody knows who consumed the infected product and nobody has any real faith in the [rating agencies] that gave it a clean bill of health.” 48

次贷流行病暴露了波坦金（Potemkin）评级基础设施的真实面目。2007 年 9 月，华尔街资深人士凯尔·巴斯在国会山听证会上以国会议员能够理解的语言作了证词。他解释说 ：“这就像养牛人付钱给农业部，让他们对其牛肉的质量和安全进行评级。但随着时间的推移，越来越明显的是，次级信贷已经成为结构性金融的疯牛病。没有人知道谁消费了受感染的产品，也没有人真正相信给它开出健康证明的评级机构。” 48

As analyst Meredith Whitney had shrewdly observed, “A company is only as solvent as the perception of its solvency.” 49The perception problem was about to kill Bear Stearns. By late May 2007, Cioffi’s investors were beginning to wise up to the vulnerability of his hedge funds, and they began to cash out.

正如分析师梅雷迪斯·惠特尼（Meredith Whitney）精明地观察到的那样，“一家公司的偿付能力只有在人们对其偿付能力的看法中才能体现出来。” 49看法问题即将杀死贝尔斯登。到 2007 年 5 月底，Cioffi 的投资者开始意识到他的对冲基金的脆弱性，他们开始套现。

Cioffi had a genuine dilemma on his hands: he could tell his investors just how profound the problem was, or he could finesse the truth, stall for time, and hope for some miracle intervention. Had Cioffi opted for the truth, the investors would have rushed to redeem. The banks would have pulled their loans. Cioffi would have desperately tried to sell off his remaining collateral for liquidity sake, and their value would have collapsed overnight. A panic at Bear Stearns would likely have caused similar panics up and down Wall Street, and markets could have crashed hard all over the world — damned if you do and damned if you don’t. Cioffi chose option B: damned if you don’t. He was about to prove Charles Morris’s general rule that “only the smartest people can make catastrophic mistakes.” 50

Cioffi 面临着一个真正的两难境地：他可以告诉投资者问题有多严重，或者他可以巧妙地掩盖真相，拖延时间，并希望有奇迹的介入。如果西奥菲选择了真相，投资者就会急于赎回。银行会撤走他们的贷款。Cioffi 会拼命卖掉他剩余的抵押品以获得流动性，而这些抵押品的价值会在一夜之间崩塌。贝尔斯登公司的恐慌可能会引起华尔街上下的类似恐慌，市场可能会在全世界范围内严重崩溃；如果你这样做了，就会被诅咒，如果你不这样做，就会被诅咒。西奥菲选择了选项 B：如果你不这样做就会被诅咒。他即将证明查尔斯·莫里斯的一般规则 ：“只有最聪明的人才能犯灾难性的错误。” 50

On June 5, 2007, Warren Spector, Bear Stearns’s copresident, walked into colleague Paul Friedman’s office and served up a classic Wall Street understatement: “I think Ralph’s got a liquidity problem.” 51This was the first Spector really knew of the mess in which Cioffi was mired. “All of the grown-ups who were looking at him were pushed aside,” Friedman remembers. “The guys who were managing him didn’t know what a hedge fund was, certainly didn’t know what a mortgage was, and so it was inevitable he would get to the point where his strategy — which was also a microcosm — of more and more leverage on more and more complicated stuff blew up.” 52

2007 年 6 月 5 日，贝尔斯登的联席总裁沃伦·斯佩克特（Warren Spector）走进同事保罗·弗里德曼（Paul Friedman）的办公室，奉上了一句经典的华尔街轻描淡写的话。“我认为拉尔夫的资金有流动性问题。” 51这是斯佩克特第一次真正知道 Cioffi 所陷入的困境。弗里德曼回忆说 ：“所有关注他的成年人都被推到一边。” 管理他的人不知道什么是对冲基金，当然也不知道什么是抵押贷款，因此，他的战略不可避免地走到了一个地步，他的战略也是一个缩影，越来越多的杠杆作用在越来越复杂的东西上被炸毁。

Later that month, the lenders who provided Cioffi his leverage decided that they wanted their money back. Cioffi froze redemption requests by investors and pleaded with the banks to give him time. His thinking was that these banks were all loaded up on subprime securities themselves. It would only drive their price down if he had to sell his into a locked-down marketplace to honor their margin calls. It was too late for logic. Cioffi’s request for time scared the banks all the more. “It was like a pebble being tossed in the pond,” says Friedman. “This was the beginning” 53—— the beginning, that is, of the end.

当月下旬，为 Cioffi 提供杠杆的贷款人决定要回他们的钱。Cioffi 冻结了投资者的赎回请求，并恳求银行给他时间。他的想法是，这些银行本身都在次贷证券上有很多钱。如果他不得不把自己的证券卖到一个被锁定的市场上，以兑现他们的保证金要求，这只会使他们的价格下降。这时的逻辑已经太晚了。Cioffi 提出的时间要求更让银行害怕。弗里德曼说 ：“这就像在池塘里扔了一个小石子,一切刚刚开始” 53—— 一个开始，也就是结束。

By July 2007, when the national unemployment rate was in the 4 percent range, close to 10 percent of the subprime loans that Countrywide serviced were delinquent by ninety days or more, nearly twice the rate of the year before.54By August 2007, the secondary mortgage market for anything except conventional triple-A rated conforming mortgages dried up completely. No one was trading, which meant that no one was buying the kind of mortgages that Countrywide most needed to sell.

到 2007 年 7 月，当全国失业率在 4% 的范围内时，全国范围内所服务的次级贷款中接近 10% 的贷款拖欠了 90 天或以上，几乎是前一年的两倍。 54到 2007 年 8 月，除了常规的 AAA 级符合要求的抵押贷款，其他的二级抵押贷款市场完全枯竭了。没有人进行交易，这意味着没有人购买全国各地最需要出售的那种抵押贷款。

On August 6, Countrywide reported to the SEC that “these conditions, which increase the cost and reduce the availability of debt, may continue or worsen in the future.” 55If they continued, Countrywide acknowledged, there could be no assurance that the company would be able “to operate at profitable levels.” 56On August 15, Merrill Lynch advised its clients to dump their Countrywide stock. The shares had already fallen 50 percent that year. They would fall more.

8 月 6 日，坎垂外德公司向美国证券交易委员会报告说，“这些增加债务成本和减少债务供应的条件，在未来可能会继续存在或恶化。” 55如果这些情况继续下去，坎垂外德承认，不能保证该公司将能够 “以盈利水平运营。” 568 月 15 日，美林公司建议其客户抛出他们的坎垂外德股票。这一年，该股已经下跌了 50%。他们会跌得更多。

As late as August 2007, Joe Cassano and his colleagues at AIGFP were congratulating themselves for having gotten out of the game and avoided the 2006 and 2007 loans now heading south. “It is hard for us, without being flippant, to even see a scenario within any kind of realm of reason that would see us losing $1 on any of those transactions,” 57Cassano assured AIG investors on a conference call, but Cassano had long since ceased to understand what he was hearing or reading.

直到 2007 年 8 月，乔·卡萨诺和他在 AIGFP 的同事们还在祝贺自己已经退出了游戏，避免了 2006 年和 2007 年的贷款，现在正往好的方向走。“我们甚至很难看到在任何一种合理的范围内，我们会在这些交易中损失 1 美元的情况。” 57卡萨诺在电话会议上向 AIG 投资者保证，但卡萨诺早已不明白他所听到或读到的内容。

“So the LORD scattered them abroad from thence upon the face of all the earth: and they left off to build the city” (Genesis 11:8).

“于是耶和华使他们从那里分散在全地面上；他们就停止建造那城了。” （《创世纪》11:8）

twenty-nineHouse on Fire 着火的房子

THE UNRAVELING HAPPENED AT UNIMAGINABLE SPEED. AFTER MUCH dithering, Bear Stearns tried to bail out Cioffi’s funds, but the bailout ended up sinking Bear Stearns. In March 2008, only one enterprise on Wall Street had the wherewithal to save Bear Stearns, and this it did reluctantly and grudgingly. “Buying a house and buying a house on fire are two different things,” 1said CEO Jamie Dimon. Yet for Dimon there seemed little choice. There was Wall Street’s legacy to think of. People were telling him, “You have to save them, you’re J. P. Morgan.”

解套以难以想象的速度发生了。在犹豫不决之后，贝尔斯登试图救助 Cioffi 的资金，但救助的结果是贝尔斯登沉没了。2008 年 3 月，华尔街只有一家企业有能力拯救贝尔斯登，而且是不情愿地、勉强地做的。1首席执行官杰米·戴蒙（Jamie Dimon）说 ：“买房子和买着火的房子是两回事。” 然而，对迪蒙来说，似乎没有什么选择。要考虑的是华尔街的遗产。人们告诉他，“你必须拯救他们，你是 J.P. 摩根。”

In 1999, President Clinton had signed into law the repeal of the Glass-Steagall act. This meant that a commercial bank like J. P. Morgan, which had had to shuck its investment banking arm sixty-five years earlier, could get back into the investment banking business. As a commercial bank, now officially J. P. Morgan Chase after its friendly 2000 acquisition by Chase Manhattan, it was eligible for something that an investment bank like Bear Stearns was not: namely, a loan from the Federal Reserve. That loan enabled it to do the Bear Stearns deal. In October 2007, Bear Stearns execs had refused to entertain buyout offers because at $115 they thought their stock was undervalued. Six months later, J. P. Morgan Chase bought them out at two dollars a share.2

1999 年，克林顿总统将废除格拉斯·斯蒂格尔法案签署为法律。这意味着像摩根大通这样的商业银行，在 65 年前就不得不放弃投资银行业务，可以重新进入投资银行业务。作为一家商业银行，在 2000 年被大通曼哈顿友好地收购后，现在正式成为摩根大通，它有资格获得像贝尔斯登这样的投资银行所没有的东西：即从美联储获得贷款。这笔贷款使它能够进行贝尔斯登的交易。2007 年 10 月，贝尔斯登的高管们拒绝接受收购提议，因为他们认为 115 美元的股票价值被低估了。六个月后，摩根大通以每股 2 美元的价格收购了他们。2

Countrywide fared no better. In June 2008, the public learned the details of a deal known internally as FOA (Friends of Angelo). FOA waived points, lender fees, and company borrowing rules for politically useful allies, among them former Fannie Mae chairmen Franklin Raines and James Johnson, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee Christopher Dodd, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee Kent Conrad, and a host of other prominent politicians.3That same month, the attorney general of California sued the company for predatory lending practices. Illinois did the same. On July 1, 2008, Bank of America put the faltering giant out of its misery and bought it for $4.25 a share, one-tenth of its share price just eighteen months earlier. As a final insult, the SEC accused Mozilo “of remaining publicly upbeat about his company’s prospects during a period when he knew things weren’t going well for the firm.” 4The nerve!

坎垂外德的情况也好不到哪里去。2008 年 6 月，公众了解到一项被内部称为 FOA（安杰洛之友）的交易细节。FOA 为政治上有用的盟友免除了点数、贷款人费用和公司借款规则，其中包括前房利美主席富兰克林·雷恩斯和詹姆斯·约翰逊、参议院银行委员会主席克里斯托弗·多德、参议院预算委员会主席肯特·康拉德以及其他许多知名政客。 3同月，加州总检察长起诉了该公司的掠夺性贷款行为。伊利诺伊州也这样做了。2008 年 7 月 1 日，美国银行将这个摇摇欲坠的巨人从痛苦中解救出来，并以每股 4.25 美元的价格收购了它，这是十八个月前其股价的十分之一。作为最后的侮辱，美国证券交易委员会指责莫齐洛 “在他知道公司情况不妙的时候，仍然公开对公司的前景表示乐观。” 4胆量！

Connecticut Senator Christopher Dodd had another friend in AIG’s Joe Cassano. Cassano had donated heavily to Dodd’s senate campaigns as well as to his absurd run for president in 2008 and had personally solicited contributions for Dodd from his employees.5Hedging his bets, Cassano contributed to Barack Obama’s primary fund and maxed out in the general election for Obama. By this time, though, Cassano was investing only to save his skin. AIG was on the chopping block.

康涅狄格州参议员克里斯托弗·多德还有一个朋友，那就是美国国际集团的乔·卡萨诺。卡萨诺曾为多德的参议院竞选以及他在 2008 年荒谬的总统竞选提供了大量捐款，并亲自从他的员工那里为多德募捐。5为了赌注，卡萨诺为奥巴马的初选基金捐款，在大选中为奥巴马捐款。不过，到了这个时候，卡萨诺的投资只是为了保住自己的脸面。AIG 正在被砍掉。

As the subprime market collapsed, the major Wall Street firms, led by Goldman Sachs, demanded that AIG honor its insurance policies. AIG did not have nearly the capital to tame a tempest everyone had thought unthinkable. Goldman Sachs, however, did not despair. The firm had another form of insurance: its former chief, Republican Henry “Hank” Paulson, was now secretary of the treasury. Another former Goldman Sachs chief, Democrat Robert Rubin, had held the same position under Bill Clinton. Still another ex-chief, Democrat Jon Corzine, had served in the U.S. Senate and was now governor of New Jersey. Paulson convinced the leadership of both parties to cover AIG’s losses at the swaps table, $182 billion and counting, and pay its creditors one hundred cents on the dollar. If Wall Street breathed a little easier, Andrew Jackson had to be urging the angels to remove his name from Jackson Days.

随着次贷市场的崩溃，以高盛为首的主要华尔街公司要求 AIG 履行其保险单。AIG 没有足够的资本来驯服这场大家认为不可想象的风暴。然而，高盛并没有感到绝望。该公司有另一种形式的保险：它的前主管，共和党人亨利·"汉克"·保尔森，现在是财政部长。另一位前高盛总裁，民主党人罗伯特·鲁宾，在比尔·克林顿时期也担任过同样的职务。还有一位前总裁，民主党人乔恩·科辛（Jon Corzine），曾在美国参议院任职，现在是新泽西州州长。保尔森说服了两党的领导层，以弥补 AIG 在掉期谈判桌上的损失，即 1820 亿美元，并向其债权人支付 100 美分。如果华尔街能轻松一点，安德鲁·杰克逊一定会敦促天使们将他的名字从杰克逊日中删除。

As to Congressman Barney Frank, in April 2009, he was denying that he had ever advocated home ownership for low- and middle-income people. Without breaking a grin, he told PBS’s Tavis Smiley that he had long been an advocate for decent rental housing. “When people are making, frankly, $30,000 or $40,000 a year in much of this country, they’re not going to be able to afford a home. And if you pretend that they can, you get them into trouble. The right kind of rental housing is appropriate.” The housing crisis he attributed to the “conservative view that rental housing was a bad thing.” 6Christopher Dodd, meanwhile, was denouncing those who lent money to “lower-income and unsophisticated borrowers” as “unconscionable.” 7

至于国会议员巴尼·弗兰克，在 2009 年 4 月，他否认自己曾主张为中低收入者拥有住房。他不无苦笑地告诉 PBS 的塔维斯·斯迈利，他长期以来一直倡导体面的出租房。“坦率地说，在这个国家的大部分地区，当人们的年收入是 3 万或 4 万美元时，他们将无法买得起房子。如果你假装他们可以，你会让他们陷入困境。正确的租赁住房是合适的”。他将住房危机归因于 “保守派认为出租房是件坏事”。6同时，克里斯托弗·多德谴责那些向 “‘向低收入和不成熟的借款人’提供贷款的人是‘不合情理的’。” 7

In the search for scapegoats, many zeroed in on Alan Greenspan. In April 2008, an Economists Forum in theFinancial Timesenabled major players from all over the financial world to take a swat at a man who had morphed overnight from maestro topiñata. Paul De Grauwe, a prominent Belgian economist, called the Greenspan article that launched the forum “a smokescreen to hide his own responsibility in making the financial crisis possible.” 8De Grauwe voiced what seemed like a consensus opinion on Greenspan’s two major failings: his prolonged suppression of interest rates, and his “religious optimism in the wondrous workings of the financial markets.” 9

在寻找替罪羊的过程中，许多人把目光投向了艾伦·格林斯潘。2008 年 4 月，《金融时报》的一个经济学家论坛让来自金融界的主要参与者对这个一夜之间从大师变成 “小丑” （piñata）的人进行了抨击。比利时著名经济学家保罗·德·格劳韦(Paul De Grauwe)称，发起论坛的格林斯潘的文章是 “一个烟幕，以掩盖他自己在导致金融危机方面的责任。” 8格劳韦对格林斯潘的两大失败发表了看似一致的看法 ：“他长期压制利率”，以及他 “对金融市场奇妙运作的宗教式乐观”。9

Not a single one of the economists who weighed in on the subprime crisis mentioned the moral/cultural factors that contributed to it. Neither did Greenspan for that matter. There was nary a word about the erosion of religious restraints, the cultural embrace of credit, the breakdown in the family, the media support for profligates, the government imposition of race and gender quotas on lenders, the consequences of land restrictions, the political pressures to put people in homes, the overrepresentation of single women in housing defaults, the sanctioned waiving of documentation, and the easy purchase of Congressional support by financial institutions, especially the government-sponsored enterprises.

没有一个对次贷危机有发言权的经济学家提到导致危机的道德/文化因素。格林斯潘也没有提到这一点。没有一个人提到宗教约束的侵蚀、文化对信贷的拥抱、家庭的破裂、媒体对暴发户的支持、政府对贷款人强加的种族和性别配额、土地限制的后果、将人们安置在家中的政治压力、住房违约中单身女性的比例过高、认可的文件豁免以及金融机构，特别是政府资助的企业轻易购买国会的支持。

The reader had to go at least twenty deep in the posts on the Economists Forum, well below those of the prominent economists, to find the first mention of individual responsibility. “What’s troubling is that the undertone of all this Greenspan bashing: a call for more government,” wrote “Mladek,” an American ex-pat living in Europe. “Instead of being afraid of government’s suffocating embrace, they pine for the warm and fluffy security blanket that will protect them not only from international competition, but from their own stupidity.” 10

读者必须在经济学家论坛上的帖子中至少深入 20 页，远远低于那些著名经济学家的帖子，才能找到第一次提到个人责任的内容。“令人不安的是，所有这些对格林斯潘的抨击的基调是：呼吁更多地向政府求助”，居住在欧洲的美国前侨姆拉迪克写道。“他们不是害怕政府令人窒息的怀抱，而是渴望有一条温暖而蓬松的安全毯，不仅能保护他们免受国际竞争的影响，而且能保护他们免受自己愚蠢的影响。” 10

In the final analysis, Wall Street has proved much more honest in assigning guilt and accepting blame than Washington. In summing up the rise and fall of history’s most calamitous bubble, Bear Stearns’s Friedman gives a share of the blame to the investment banking houses for failing to decipher this novel and extraordinarily complex market moment and a share to “FHA and HUD and all those people saying, ‘You better lend to those poor people.’” 11

归根结底，事实证明华尔街在分配罪责和接受指责方面比华盛顿要诚实得多。贝尔斯登的弗里德曼在总结历史上最灾难性的泡沫的兴衰时，将一部分责任归咎于投资银行机构，因为它们未能破译这个新颖而异常复杂的市场时刻，还有一部分责任归咎于 “FHA 和 HUD 以及所有那些说‘你最好贷款给那些穷人’的人”。 11

“But, in truth,” says Friedman. “It was a team effort. We all f***ed up. Government. Rating agencies. Wall Street. Commercial banks. Regulators. Investors. Everybody.” 12

“但是，事实上”，弗里德曼说，“这是一个团队的努力。我们都搞砸了。政府。评级机构。华尔街。商业银行。监管机构。投资者。所有人。” 12

thirtyRestoration 恢复

ON A COOL MAY AFTERNOON IN 2009, SOME TEN THOUSAND GOOD souls, most of them couples, flood into Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Missouri, to begin their “Total Money Makeover.” Hosting the event is a balding, goateed, forty-eight-year-old named Dave Ramsey. Dressed in jeans and a flannel shirt, no more or less formal than his audience, Ramsey struts back and forth across the stage, telling jokes, sharing stories, imparting wisdom in his honeyed Tennessee drawl. He will hold this audience spellbound for the next five hours.

在 2009 年一个凉爽的五月下午，大约有一万个善良的灵魂，其中大多数是夫妇，涌入密苏里州堪萨斯城的肯珀竞技场，开始他们的 “全面金钱改造”。主持这次活动的是一个秃头、长满山羊胡子、四十八岁的戴夫·拉姆齐。拉姆齐穿着牛仔裤和法兰绒衬衫，不比他的听众更正式，他在舞台上来回走动，讲笑话，分享故事，用他蜜糖般的田纳西口音传授智慧。在接下来的五个小时里，他将使这些观众神魂颠倒。

Ramsey knows where his audience is coming from. He’s “been there, done that, got the T-shirt.” By the age of twenty-six, Ramsey, an aspiring real estate tycoon, had a four-million-dollar portfolio, as well as a loving wife, two babies, and a Jaguar in the driveway. And then, through bad business decisions and worse lifestyle choices, he blew it all. He was sued, foreclosed on, bankrupted. “Scareddoesn’t begin to cover it,” he notes. “Crushedcomes close.” 1This all led to a period of deep soul searching and investigation into the way money worked.

拉姆齐知道他的观众来自哪里。他 “去过那里，做过那个，得到了 T 恤”。在 26 岁时，拉姆齐是一个有抱负的房地产大亨，他有一个四百万美元的投资组合，还有一个可爱的妻子，两个婴儿，以及车道上的一辆捷豹车。然后，由于错误的商业决定和更糟糕的生活方式选择，他搞砸了这一切。他被起诉，被取消抵押品赎回权，破产了。他说 ：“害怕并不能说明问题”，他补充 ：“崩溃 就在眼前。” 1这一切导致了一段深刻的灵魂探索和对金钱运作方式的调查。

“My great-grandparents thought debt was sin,” Ramsey tells his Kansas City audience, and after his own experiences in “financial hell,” he had begun to think they were right. In examining his life, Ramsey had “discovered God’s and Grandma’s simple way of handling money.” Their message was as simple as promised: “Live on less than you make.” 2The strategy was just as simple: avoid debt at all costs.

“我的曾祖父母认为债务是罪恶的”，拉姆齐告诉他的堪萨斯城听众，在他自己的 “财务地狱” 经历之后，他开始认为他们是对的。在审视自己的生活时，拉姆齐 “发现了上帝和祖母处理金钱的简单方法”。他们的信息就像承诺的那样简单：以 “低于自己收入的方式生活。” 2策略也同样简单：不惜一切代价避免债务。

Ramsey began to share what he was learning. He spoke at church and with his friends, and they encouraged him to seek a bigger stage. In 1992, he launched a local radio show, which found an audience hungry for the basics. He started writing and found readers enough to put him on theNew York Timesbest-seller list. By 2009, his show was being syndicated on four hundred stations nationwide. Along the way, he had not been afraid to reach into the Bible for wisdom; and in Kansas City he cites, by name and number, Proverbs 22:7: “The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.” If anything, the unraveling of the previous year proved anew the timelessness of biblical teaching on debt.

拉姆齐开始分享他的学习成果。他在教堂和朋友那里演讲，他们鼓励他寻求更大的舞台。1992 年，他推出了一个当地的广播节目，发现有很多听众渴望了解基本知识。他开始写作，并找到了足够的读者，使他登上了《纽约时报》的畅销书排行榜。到 2009 年，他的节目被全国四百个电台联合播出。一路走来，他并不害怕从《圣经》中寻找智慧；在堪萨斯城，他举出了《箴言》（22：7）的名字和数字。“富人统治穷人，借款人是放款人的奴仆”。如果有的话，前一年的解体重新证明了《圣经》中关于债务的教导是永恒的。

Dave Ramsey is not the only media-wise financial evangelist. Equally visible is Suze Orman, who, though Jewish, lesbian, and liberal, preaches a commonsense message not unlike Ramsey’s. Where they differ —— a critical difference — is on the question of debt. Orman makes her peace with it. Ramsey refuses to. Orman encourages her fans to find out their FICO score as soon as they can. “Congratulations if your score falls into the 720–850 range,” she tells them. “You are in the highest FICO range and that typically means you will be offered the best terms on loans and other financial products.” 3

戴夫·拉姆齐（Dave Ramsey）并不是唯一的媒体金融传道者。同样引人注目的是苏西·奥曼（Suze Orman），虽然她是犹太人、女同性恋者和自由主义者，但她宣扬的常识性信息与拉姆齐的信息并不一样。他们的不同之处 —— 一个关键的不同之处 —— 是在债务问题上。奥曼让她与债务和平相处。拉姆齐则拒绝这样做。奥曼鼓励她的粉丝尽快查出他们的 FICO 分数。“如果你的分数在 720～850 范围内，恭喜你”，她告诉他们。“你处于最高的 FICO 范围，这通常意味着你将获得贷款和其他金融产品的最佳条款。” 3

Ramsey loathes FICO and all it stands for. He calls FICO results “your ‘I love debt’ score.” In Kansas City, he lays the blame for the subprime mess at least in part on FICO and its consequences. From his perspective, there is no such thing as “good debt.” He sees it merely as “a symptom of overspending and undersaving.” Something as routine as a car payment, he calls “one of the dumbest things people do.” And even a home mortgage, he tells the audience, should be avoided if possible and, if not, limited to a fixed fifteen-year term.

拉姆齐厌恶 FICO 和它所代表的一切。他把 FICO 的结果称为 “你的‘我爱债务’分数”。在堪萨斯城，他将次贷混乱的责任至少部分归咎于 FICO 及其后果。在他看来，不存在 “好债务” 这种东西。他认为这只是 “过度消费和储蓄不足的一种症状”。像汽车付款这样的常规事情，他称之为 “人们做的最愚蠢的事情之一”。他告诉听众，即使是住房抵押贷款，也应尽可能避免，如果不能，也应限制在 15 年的固定期限。

Ramsey has no more affection for the dispensers of credit than do the social puritans. “Debt is the most aggressively marketed product in our culture today,” 4he contends. He calls payday loans operations “legalized loan sharking.” 5And he does not hesitate to label credit outreach to children as flat-out “immoral.” Ramsey, however, gags on the social puritan gospel of victimization. “The challenge is you,” he tells his audience. “You are the problem with your money.” 6Like all traditionalists, Ramsey believes in sin. There are no victims in his world, only sinners; no pity, only the promise of redemption. The only regulation he asks for is self-regulation.

拉姆齐对信贷发放者的感情并不比社会清教徒多。他认为，“债务是我们今天文化中最积极的营销产品” 4。他称发薪日贷款业务为 “合法的高利贷”。5而且他毫不犹豫地将对儿童的信贷推广称为完全 “不道德”。然而，拉姆齐对社会清教徒的受害福音插科打诨。他告诉他的听众 ：“挑战就是你”，他说，“你才是你的钱的问题。” 6和所有传统主义者一样，拉姆齐相信罪恶。在他的世界里没有受害者，只有罪人；没有怜悯，只有救赎的承诺。他要求的唯一监管是自我监管。

In May 2009, there was a new urgency to Ramsey’s message. Both he and his audience had seen what happens when a population grows addicted to debt, when a government encourages that addiction, and when the markets conspire to feed it. Ramsey does not want to see this scary a scenario again. He envisions instead a nation free of debt and dreams of a national Total Money Makeover that would proceed one citizen at a time.

2009 年 5 月，拉姆齐的信息有了新的紧迫性。他和他的听众都看到了当人们对债务越来越上瘾，当政府鼓励这种上瘾，当市场合谋养活它时，会发生什么。拉姆齐不希望再看到这种可怕的情况。他设想的是一个没有债务的国家，并梦想着一个全国性的全面金钱改造，每次都会有一个公民来进行。

“Saving and investing would cause wealth to be built at an unprecedented level,” he believes, “which would create more stability and spending. Giving would increase, and many social problems would be privatized; thus, the government could get out of the welfare business. Then taxes would come down, and we would have even more wealth.” 7

“储蓄和投资将使财富建立在一个前所未有的水平”，他认为，“这将创造更多的稳定和支出。捐赠将增加，许多社会问题将被私有化；因此，政府可以从福利事业中退出。然后税收会下降，我们会有更多的财富。” 7

This is pretty much the way Moses saw the world — and Augustine and Aristotle and Aquinas and Andrew Jackson. Ramsey, however, is no monk. He enjoys his wealth and respects the system that has allowed him to achieve it. What that system needs, he believes, is not more regulation but a restoration of individual responsibility. Unlike so many of his academic betters, he understands the connection between the character of the individual and the success of the economy. The final word on the subject he gives to that esteemed social philosopher Austin Powers: “Capitalism, yeah baby!”

这几乎是摩西看待世界的方式 —— 有奥古斯丁、亚里士多德、阿奎那和安德鲁·杰克逊。然而，拉姆齐不是和尚。他享受着自己的财富，并尊重让他获得财富的制度。他认为，这个系统需要的不是更多的监管，而是恢复个人责任。与他的许多学术权威不同，他理解个人性格与经济成功之间的联系。关于这个问题的最后一句话，他交给了那位受人尊敬的社会哲学家奥斯汀·鲍尔斯。“资本主义，耶，宝贝！”

About the Author

JACK CASHILL HAS PRODUCED A SCORE OF DOCUMENTARIES, MOST RECENTLYThine Eyes: A Witness to the March for Lifewith Jennifer O’Neill. His writing has appeared inFortune, The Wall Street Journal, Washington Post, andWeekly Standard, and he also writes regularly for theAmerican ThinkerandWorldNetDaily. His recent books includeHoodwinked, Sucker Punch, andWhat’s the Matter with California?Jack has a PhD in American studies from Purdue University.
